job_title: Engineer/Scientist R&D II in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Honeywell's "revolving door" philosophy makes it a leader in providing the 3-5 years of experience required to obtain your dream job.  You will have the opportunity to work with some bright, talented, and personable people.
cons:
You will also find that many employees from the pre-Honeywell era are simply counting the days until their retirement.  You can obtain the experience you need for gainful employment outside of Honeywell if you can stand listening to senior employees say thing like "this used to be a fun place to work".  

Surveys conducted by the company will indicate your compensation is competitive, but I found that my own pay was ~20-30% below that of my contemporaries from school.  My first (prorated) merit increase in my new job was more generous than any merit increase I received from a full years' work for Honeywell.

Even while RIF's occurred at lower levels within the company, new roles were being created in upper management with goals which sounded arbitrary, or redundant with those of existing positions.  This gave me the impression that the cautious fiscal conservatism preached in quarterly updates was little more than a way to funnel pay out of low-level employees' pockets to support cronyism in upper management.

review_title: Employees are a cost to be cut
job_title: Product Manufacturing Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Salary is competitive, room for advancement, and great co-workers.
cons:
You are a number, and this isn't a typical scorned employee opinion, this is fact.  In the 5 years I've been with the company:
- Top pay for high level mechanics has been cut by 10k/year
- Medical costs have risen 20%
- Company contribution to HSA account was reduced, then removed altogether
- We are now "fined" up to 1.5k (to be added to medical cost) for not participating in employee health screenings and for smoking
- Pentions are now capped at current salary (will no longer increase as salary increases)
- Two (2ea) raises in 5 years totaling 2.5% (1st was 1%, 2nd was 1.5%).  Raises are suspended this year as well
- Furloughed for a week (7 days without pay one month before Christmas).  Upon return, layoff begins

There are more examples but who has the time.  It seems no opportunity to screw employees is passed.  It happens incrementally, slowly, meticulously removing another "perk" as soon as the memory if the last fades.

The stock is doing well, so it must be working for them.

job_title: Research Scientist/Engineer II in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
At the time of this review, I am very new, and I also work on a small team doing more software related stuff, so take this with a grain of salt.

Coworkers here are very friendly, making the work atmosphere great. Everyone is very communicative, and conversation is good so far. The internal web portals are very well organized, and getting settled in has been a breeze.

Honeywell so far has come across as a company that really wants to make an investment in their employees, allowing them to grow in their profession.
cons:
If you are going into software looking for a fancy skyscraper office looking out over a city, this isn't exactly it. You will probably get your standard cubicle, although the equipment provided is pretty nice. 

Honeywell is a bit more of an older company, and they are heavy in government contract work. While it seems that many of their new policies are pretty progressive, their seems to be a fair amount of cookie cutter government paperwork / red tape / corporate kind of activity that goes on (such as redundant or unnecessarily extensive training videos, or lots of digging to get access to materials / information to move forward with projects).

review_title: Don't work here unless you  are a "yes" (wo)man that is okay with the status quo
pros:
- Work with smart people

- Brand name on your resume

- Compensation at market rate when you start
cons:
- Systemic lack of accountability, ownership, and career growth across the different businesses unless you are at VP, GM, or above

- Furloughs, pay cuts, re-orgs, and title changes are infamously part of Honeywell's "MOS" year after year

- Approx 30% voluntary attrition within 2 years and 15-20% within 1 year across multiple functions (especially product management, sales, marketing, customer experience...engineers and production tend to be RIF/RIM instead of leaving voluntarily)

- Outside of a high-level onboarding at HQ, you and your team will likely not receive training, education, or tools as your budget keeps getting cut

- Annual raises above 3% for even the most stellar employee, totally unheard of. Average raise without a job promotion is 1-2%. The 8 core behaviors are subjective performance metrics and the vehicle that Honeywell uses to downgrade your annual bonus because each department does not get a decent budget for bonus or merit.

- Run down offices. Free coffee not provided.

- Many more, which layoff.com does a good job recording while also providing endless entertainment

pros: Great salary well above the starting average for a chemical engineer.  Benefits Package that is pretty standard.  Some locations have great people and management.
cons:
This position was advertised as a 1 year rotational program cycling through 2 or possibly 3 plants over a year to gain engineering experience in a variety of processes before being placed into a permanent role.  The actual job was to train and work as a process operator at 1-2 sites that were undergoing union labor contract negotiations.  This would enable the company to push a tougher contract on the operators without any chance of a work-stoppage.  In this case it was planned to lockout the workers if a contract was not reached, which puts them in financial difficulty and removes the likelihood that a new contract is not agreed to.

I have spent the better half of 2015 working as an operator in come capacity with night and day shift weeks ranging from 48h minimum to 88h week maximum.  The majority of this time was paid as a salaried worker (See no overtime or extra compensation of any kind.  No comp days.)  I am totally burnt out and frustrated that I signed on for something that was very different from what was promised when I had other options for employment upon the time of my college graduation.

There is plenty more to write, but I don't want to turn this review into a longwinded rant.  I have essentially lost a year of my life without anything really happening due to almost zero free time.

review_title: Good for long term employment with job security and a good scope to make career in Aerospace
pros: First of all, the job security, which is a burning issue now a days due to the market up and downs. Here, one can plan for long term employment and can find a great career scope in Aerospace. Company provides a great platform to show your abilities and even to go beyond your abilities. It always motivates to do good. One can learn a lot in Aerospace. It also sponsor the selected employees for Private Pilot License, which is a great opportunity for anyone to fly a real airplane. Also, It gives a good salary package to the freshers. One more thing, as there are a lot of project running in parallel, so one can find a lot of scope inside one roof.
cons: Location of Honeywell is not good. It have three campus in India (for Aerospace), Bangalore, Hyderabad, and Madurai. All the campuses are in South India. So, if any North Indian employee got Madurai location, it will be difficult to survive there. Second one is its relocation policy, according to policy, one can't be relocated before three years. But, On-site opportunities are there. So in my view, it should not be a matter of worry.

pros:
- Stable company.
- Ability to work remotely (depending on your position).
- Great learning resources.
- A great "brand name" company to put on your resume.
cons:
***Please keep in mind that I was "hired" through an acquisition.

- Ridiculous bureaucracy.
- It felt like an "old boys club". I did not know what a glass ceiling felt like until I worked for Honeywell. 
- My salary was much less than those who were hired directly through Honeywell; even with equal job responsibilities. Numerous promises to rectify this were never fulfilled. 
- Management made promises to clients without any concern about the impact on their employees.
- Management did not care about their employees' work life balance. 
- Management migrated jobs to lower cost regions and left their employees to shoulder the burden (misunderstandings due to cultural differences, angry clients, general lack of education on key processes, etc..).
- Management seemed to only care about their margins.
- There were a lot of disgruntled workers at my location due to  various cutbacks. Some who had been with the company for decades. It was tough to remain positive through the daily complaints.

review_title: It stays afloat by cutting employee benefits
pros: It is a safe company to work for. They push safety but I'm sure its more for the bottom line.
cons:
It can careless about the health of it's employees, we basically have minimal insurance with a $3000 dollar delectable that has expensive premiums and it claims it is self insured.
It is not giving raises this year on the lame excuse "they are not sure what is going to happen if we go over the fiscal cliff", my take is they are just adding to their profits, It has cut our benefits down to the point it cannot cut anymore. 
Did I mention our company made billions of dollars last year so our CEOs, with a plural there will get their bonuses. 
We also have received email notices not to talk to any law enforcement about company business and are to refer them to our legal department.
This is a review from a 25+ year employee so I have to much invested to find another job. I would not work for them because it is just a shell of what it was 25 years ago Cote has gutted it.

review_title: Highly centralized/bureaucratic and no commitment to employees
pros: The people I work with locally are intelligent and great to work with.  Work life balance is good.
cons:
The company is highly centralized - i.e. all meaningful power is concentrated at the VP level or higher.  e.g. The ability to hire people is not at the Manager, Senior Manager, or even the Director level - all hiring must be approved at the VP level or higher.  Any travel must be approved by a VP.  Individuals are NOT empowered to do their jobs at all, and, instead, are bogged down by company-dictated processes that do not add value.

Benefits are not competitive.  Cost cutting has steadily eroded benefits and pay very significantly over the past few years.  Annual raises are very low, even for top employees.  All of this is done in the name of "uncertainty of the future", but it is obvious to everyone that it is really done to cut costs and boost stock price.  Company stock price is higher than ever but it is not shared with the employees.  The company no longer approves training for personal improvement.  Promotions are extremely rare, and typically require a manager to create a "new" job posting for which an employee deserving promotion has to apply.

This company does not have a good future.

review_title: Used to be a fantastic place to work, but it's rapidly going down hill
pros: Fantastic opportunities for career development and progression. Exciting opportunities for overseas assignments for those who are willing and able to relocate.  Strong performance is recognized and rewarded. Lots of exceptionally smart and talented people working for the organisation. Twice yearly performance reviews, with meaningful input from management. Some very inspiring leaders at tier 2 and 3 in the organisation.
cons: Honeywell is no longer a fun place to work.  CEO focus on results and shareholder value at the expense of any empathy towards employees.  Widespread benefits erosion (cost saving) impacting employees at all levels.  Reductions in workforce leading to loss of tribal knowledge and de-skilling in large areas of the organisation. Remaining employees expected to absorb the work and continue delivering more, but with less resources, knowledge and experience.  Performance culture is driving 'me first' behaviours instead of collaborative team working in some parts of the organisation, making them unpleasant environments in which to work.  Home working was abolished some time ago (blanket global policy), so there is little flexibility regarding work life balance.

pros: Great people to work with, some actually care about what they do. Managers at least pretend to care about people to save face to those they don't completely screw over behind their back. Has a reputation of being a great company (out dated).
cons: Any day can be your last for no better reason than the headcount was too high in the department. Tons of money was dumped into hiring/training then abandoning new hires on the street. A lie was sent out that those selected for the RIF would be poor performers with corrective actions. This was not the case, people were selected simply because their tasks could be covered by someone else willing to do free overtime or simply low seniority. This is unfair and sick. The company would not have gone under by keeping most of these people. People with families. This band aid solution (RIFs) will have negative long term effects on the people kept, and damage the Honeywell name beyond repair. Do yourself, your family and your career a favor and avoid this company. Not trust worthy!

pros: I thought the interview process and onboarding was great. Everyone in the company is so eager to help, and they have all been welcoming. I am on my second week, and from the IT department to the payroll support and of course the great manager I have this has been a great experience so far. The company expects high performance and people who are focused on profitability, but that is why they are successful.
cons: I came from a much smaller company and it was a bit overwhelming to be in a large company where they have detailed processes and telephone hotlines for everything. I do have to say though once I got into the groove every department has been very supportive and highly professional. The support is there and it works if you just use the tools they give you.

review_title: Good development experience/resume builder, not for the long haul
pros:
Honeywell (specifically FM&T in Kansas City, MO) has been a great development opportunity.  Due to high turnover, they generally give early career engineers more responsibilities than industry average.  After a few years as a solid performer you should have some pretty good experience for the resume.

Corporate Honeywell brings both positives and negatives to the table, with an end result of a neutral.  Functionally, it's a great company with a strong stock.  However, the employee policies are generally pretty terrible and the benefits are average.
cons: There is basically no long term option.  At best, as a top 20% performer, you can grow your career like the average employee outside.  If you are in the middle 70%, you can basically forget getting raises higher than inflation.  As a government contractor, they are constantly compressing salaries to be competitive for renewing the contract.  The bottom 10% get reviewed yearly and put on a plan with which 50% are let go.  I've been told the general breakdown is consistent across Honeywell (and other companies like GE), but our raises are significantly lower.

review_title: Stay Away unless your just desperate for a job in this economy
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Company worked hard to get you nice ergonomic desks - you pick out your chair, mouse, they set up everything ergonomically correct.  They had a nice (but small) gym & even offered training.  Picnic tables outside were nice when the weather was warm.  Close to lake - escaped to walk around the lake when I couldn't take it anymore.  Did offer 3 sigma training.
cons: Contract I worked required 42 hrs/week for 40 hrs pay.  Even if you didn't have work to do, you were required to put in your "green" time.  No pay for travel time but you could accumulate green time if you travelled.  Ridiculous work that made no sense - busy work that didn't add value.  Cube farm had street names so you could find your way around.  No real break room.  Weird safety briefings required daily - if you didn't hold the handrails on the stairs you could get fired!  Many good sub-contractors laid off and treated badly.

review_title: No longer a good company to work for
pros: Pay is good, but good luck getting a decent raise.
cons:
The company is top heavy at the corporate level.  At individual sites, they run with the minimum number of employees possible.  Everybody wears multiple hats.  Everything gets done in a mediocre way.  Nothing gets done well because you are always in a rush to get to the next fire.

Local management are yes men to the US corporate team.  All sites are not held to the same standards.  US locations can get away with more push back than Canadian sites, even when it comes to safety.

All management (local and corporate) like to read out the rules, but fail to follow these same rules themselves.

Management is not honest or ethical when it comes to reviews.  You can refute what is said, but they say that once they have entered their reviews into the system they cannot be changed.  They will not even put in addendums even when their is physical proof.

HOS is a huge burden to small locations.  There is minimal benefit to the site, but the costs are huge.  It is all about "metrics" that time is spent on compiling, but are not used to better the location.

CEO is too overpaid and not worth the cost.

review_title: Not a place to go for a career anymore
pros: Decent pay.  The executives think highly of themselves. Stock holders are King. Non US workforce is run with more employee goodwill. Good 401K match. Good place to get experience (and then leave)
cons: Very spotty career paths with US workforce being constantly reduced. Severe lack of positive re-enforcement. Poor Job stability. Support workforce teams are highly disjointed which basically eliminates mentoring and team synergy. Constantly turn 10-20% of workforce per a systematic process built into their 9 block performance system. Poor and un-timely executive downward communication on what matters to employees. Vacation time off based solely on Managers prerogative. Benefits are constantly being watered down. Focused on getting out of manufacturing and moving all operations possible off-shore to low cost regions. Many international meetings and a work from home policy that does not work for this type of modern culture.

review_title: Work in Aerospace domain is OUTDATED
pros:
No spoon feeding, that gives employees more things to learn.
Nothing as such to highlight
cons:
This is my brutal honest opinion of Honeywell, who work in Aerospace domain
Aerospace domain in Honeywell is much OUTDATED as compared to market.
1. For namesake its a product based company, most of the CORE development is done in US. The leftover work comes to INDIA.
2.  Especially the people who work in Verification & Validation jobs, they are highly pressurized by the management (Nasty Micro Management Tracking which flows down from higher management). In return the engineers in ground level aren't recognized. Basically it lacks good leaders.
3. Least opportunities, given to work on emerging technologies for the current employees.
4. No employee satisfaction & facilities are provided.
5. Lot of organizational changes happens, in the sake of positions(Designations) for higher management people.
6. People who work in Madurai (Honeywell-Aerospace), the management screws the employees "Work-Life-Balance". Here they are forced to work on every Saturday & Sunday in office premises.
7. The Local Managers are cruel for other region employees, there is lot of biasing for localities.
8. The hiring process for freshers from local colleges around Madurai is very poor standard.
9. The employees who move from BLR or HYD offices to Madurai office for the purpose of higher positions, after 1-2 years of stay they comeback.
10. Madurai (Extreme Southern part of India), it makes difficult to connect other parts of India. (No proper communication)
11. They Should better shutdown the office in Madurai.

review_title: Good place to have a career
job_title: Specialist Project II in Deer Valley, AZ
pros:
I personally am satisfied with Honeywell.  I specifically work with Process Solutions for Technology R&D, so I can only speak on my experience with that organization of Honeywell.  

There are quite a few benefits that come with being permanently employed with the company - the basics: medical, dental, vision, 401K.  Of course you can buy their products at a discounted rate.  There are wellness benefits that keep getting added and implemented.  EAP is a thing here as well.  

Information is readily available if you know where to look. Being fairly new with the company (almost 2 years) I can say that things got easier when I figured out where to find the little things that come with "tribal knowledge".
cons:
We have to use Express Scripts as part of our medical insurance and they are horrid to work with.  

In my experience, there are too many applications used for different purposes across different businesses.  It would be nice to have less of that and more streamlined and integrated information between businesses as well as functions.

pros: Meaningful/interesting work, sophisticated tools, cutting edge HR analytics, competitive pay, career growth/mobility, strong performance culture, terrific industry, incredibly talented colleagues (both within the HR function and among business partners)
cons: In some locations, antiquated decor.

pros: Work on very cool stuff, Most co-workers are great people, about half of workforce has been there for 20+ years,
cons: Management does not listen to employees, Management has no idea what employees do or their job functions, Rarely get raises above 2% if any, HOS is a complete joke, About half the workforce is close to retirement but the refuse to hire new people and when they do they do not train them, employees are told to do their job correct but don't have tools to do their job correctly, Management refuses to buy the tools they need, tools we do have are 20-60 years old, Overworked, over-stressed, underpaid. More than half of every day is wasted arguing about HOS and getting product delivered to each area. Employees are pushed to turn against each other rather than working as team members to get job done. Management forces Engineers to leave engineering to get professional growth. No career growth for techs. Insurance is terrible and benefits are bad as a whole.

review_title: Good job if a steady paycheck is all you're after
pros:
Great if you're after a 40-hr work week go home-type gig. 
Lots of interesting projects and stuff to learn about.
Coworkers are generally ok, but some are complete douchebags and have an arrogant attitude who will put you down for asking stupid questions while others are totally helpful and super nice to work with.
Salary is OK, but it's not competitive. Benefits are average as well.
cons:
Some employees are really arrogant about their knowledge and it seems like they will put you down just because you asked any question.
The title seems to drive everyone's behavior. So many new hires who are Engineer I and II are looked down upon like if they're complete idiots like myself even if they're more highly educated than they are.
Management has a constant apply downward pressure technique to force you to work overtime. Then you get told at your review, you're doing great, and get rewarded with a crappy raise that's below inflation, which if you're doing the math is a salary decrease.... 
There's too much "growth" talk going on and the need to follow the "8 behaviors".
Promotions rarely happens. You'll either have to promote yourself by leaving or moving within the company. So hard work and technical expertise/innovative solutions are not seen/rewarded.

pros: Very good environment and friendly
cons: nothing bad to say about the company

review_title: Big, strong culture in a company that expects a lot from it's rank-and-file employees
job_title: Supply Chain Manager in Houston, TX
pros: The industry and the company doesn't feel to be as up-and-down due to the good diversification among the portfolio of products (Honeywell as a whole); however, how Honeywell does in the bad economy is yet to be seen.  Honeywell is a great company to work for to bolster your resume and gain experience (as you'll be working hard).
cons: Honeywell is a culture stuck in the "we've always done this and it's the best way" company.  I haven't seen much openness to change or improvement of the current ways.  Management doesn't seem to value employees as people as much as commodities.  Work-life balance outside of emergencies is non-existent.  Salaries are low compared to industry (for my role) as compensation is done "on the cheap".  Jobs have recently been sent overseas and budgetary spending is not done wisely.  VERY metrics based organization.  Goals seem to be constantly moving, as even meeting or exceeding goals is often met with "we need more" and very rarely a "good job".   Even people hired in the past 2 years have been on a revolving door as people come and leave the organization often.

pros:
* Flexible work-hours and work from home policy (5 days a month) is a definite plus.
* My manager does not sit at the top of my head for deliverables.
* Expectations are not unreasonable and difficulties are well understood by the management.
* Salary planning is pretty good since there are no variable bonuses etc and we can to an extent configure own salary to maximize tax benefits.
cons:
* Performance evaluation is really bad and to good extent non-professional. Loyalty for your manager pays well and nothing else.
* Job assignment practices are also very bad. Only charge-hours matter to most of the managers and nothing else as such.
* Nobody cares whether you are satisfied with your work or are making any self improvements or not.
* Senior management is often busy in their own world and hardly care to learn what on junior level employees feeling or what problems they might have. Middle level management is a real fad.
* Salary as such is poor as compared to other companies except may be management level or selected groups.
* Politics in rewards and recognition.

pros: Nice facility, opportunity to work with people locally and internationally.
cons: The company claims that it is a progressive one offering good benefits, competitive pay, training opportunities and career growth.  Over the 6 years I worked there, the company said it couldn't afford to pay our earned merit increases for 3 of those years while the CEO received his, and compensation fell well below industry standards.  Benefits only became more expensive each year, although they did contribute funds to your HSA to help.  My management would not pay for the training opportunities that were available to me because they believed their current practices were satisfactory - innovation and risk taking were discouraged and you would get a slap on the hand if you made recommendations to senior management.  Finally, unless you worked in Finance, management and HR were not interested in career planning or development.  I watched dozens of talented college graduates leave the company over my 6 years there to work for a different company that was actually invested in their employees and developing talent for long-term growth.

review_title: High Employee Attrition. Beware - Aero CBM India Team
pros: Good salary. Benefits are just right.
cons:
Honeywell Technology Solutions (HTS) has become a school; a Bad One. CBM Aero, Bangalore team is the worst. 
There is a rising concern against companies' "Hygiene" factors" and "Motivator" factors. For examples, policies and administration, supervision, interpersonal relationship, status and security issues with the Project Leaders, cases of frequent employee harassment, verbal assaults and high employee attrition rate. The conflict resolution is by forceful techniques, where the other party views and concerns are ignored and rudely put down. Besides, there are
redundancies leading to the loss of sense of accomplishment, recognition, work satisfaction, growth and advancement. Well-experienced resources joining Honeywell find it difficult to adjust in this environment and many have left in less than a year. More often than not, rude emails by PLs are circulated. PLs
promote their own fabricated negative work culture. For examples, forcing the team to be physically present in everyday status meetings from 9.00 am, monetary fine if they fail to attend meetings, not allowing to attend such meetings from home if the resource did not stay beyond 9.00 pm the previous day, threatening resource to apply for leave if their card access time in a week is less than 45 hours, random peak expectations on people despite of no trainings. There are circumstances in which the PLs literally threatened resources in appraisal meetings.

Overall, HTS is no more holding its virtues. It is lost.

review_title: Not for long term US employment for HON-Aerospace
pros:
Excellent pay, 
Ability to work from home.  
Bonuses if you're able to get Band 4 or above.
Software engineers are a focus for the future.
cons:
Expensive health insurance with $3000 deductible.
Relentless focus on removing US employees in Aerospace and placing overseas.
Layoffs and furloughs with no annual raises are happening more frequently.
Low investment in new Aerospace products, appear to be cost cutting company to death or sale to another company.  UTC was smart to stay away.
Upper management appears to never focused beyond 1 year out.  They tell Wall Street one thing and employees another.  
They've been saying they're in a slow growth environment for 8 years now.
If you're right out of college,  I wouldn't recommend Honeywell as you'll find better management. work environment, health insurance and more elsewhere without the high risk of losing your job.   
They want to be a software company,  so Aerospace hardware is in conflict with that.

review_title: Big company politics - don't change from practices of 30 years ago.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Redmond, WA
pros: Some can get in a niche and it will be a reasonably secure job.
cons:
Not cutting edge. Using techniques and methods that were proven ineffective 25 years ago by the rest of the world. Those trying to change things for the better are not rewarded, only fought at every step of the way, including by upper management.

Often not given the tools needed to do the job. For example, so many websites are blocked now, that I've been unable to access websites I tried to use to find good info to do my technical job. Also been blocked from doctor's websites. Far too much "scare tactics" that you are being monitored.

Too much hero worship. Instead of setting up a positive environment to do things right in the first place, the standard procedure seems to reward the "heros" who come in and save the day so that it is ALWAYS a firefighting mode type of lifestyle.

review_title: Corporate company, but doesn't feel corporate
job_title: User Experience Designer in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Stability working for an established company (as opposed to startups)
Startup mentality within the teams I work on
Great pay, very competitive with other companies in the city
Working on worthwhile and fulfilling projects
Chances to take ownership/responsibility for projects beyond your role responsibilities, which helps expand the scope of your skillset
The importance of good design and human-centered design approaches is recognized from top-level executives
Supportive managers that are there to help you reach your career goals
Managers recognize that work-life balance is important
Unlimited vacation policy
cons:
The health insurance is just ok - this is where Honeywell is not competitive, it's better than no insurance though
Sometimes feels very corporate - you can't get away from this, but sometimes decisions take a while to be made as they go up the chain of command
Company politics - Honeywell is a company that is built from acquisitions, and some of those acquisitions have vitriol against Honeywell, which makes for some interesting (but also frustrating) office politics

pros:
- Salary is high for the area (rural), especially considering the cost of living.
- Direct boss is good at defending our time and shared similar views regarding the job we were *actually* hired to do.
- Honeywell is a big brand name that impresses outsiders.
- The safety-first culture is real and permeates well throughout. People may gripe about the rules, but a safe workplace is the best industrial workplace.
-Opportunities are always available to apply to, but relocation is practically universally required.
cons:
- Health benefits are a complete joke and encourage employees to seek coverage elsewhere.
- Honeywell's corporate "lean" system is a hodgepodge of, at best, well-intentioned requirements that leave no room for making the system work on a plant-to-plant basis. All these corporate musts fall on the shoulders of engineers that should be focusing on process-related projects, not time-consuming charts and graphs and pretty pictures.
- Middle management has the unenviable job of catering to higher and higher management levels while attempting to delegate increasing amounts of action items to their people.
- Corporate greed seems to drive every decision. There is no camaraderie when you can feel every penny pinched.
- Priorities change constantly.

job_title: Director of Finance in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: Salary - But that is because you are expected to work 6 days a week, all hours of the day.
cons:
Where to begin.... 
* Work Life Balance - Expect to sacrifice time with your family.  You'll be working 6 days a week.  Meetings at all hours of the day.   Your parent passed away? They will expect you to respond to emails.  Having a child?  Does the hospital have WiFi to jump on business meetings.  They will demand you come into the office on weekends.
* Unlimited vacation - You'll be lucky to take 1 week a year.   And it's a major inconvenience to the Company if you need to take a random day off.  
* You'll have multiple meetings on the very same topic each day, issues don't get resolved.
* No one believes in the numbers, everyone questions everyone's work, a lot of non-value added work. 
* Systems - You  would expect systems to tie out and they do not.  You'll never be able to get the right sales numbers or costing unless you make manual adjustments.
* Took 3 weeks to have full system access in order for me to complete my job.

There are multiple finance employees in my area looking to get out.

pros: All the benefits of a large company
cons: Some disadvantages of a large company

pros: Inter personal understanding among the team and management looks good most of the time.
cons: Growth path sometimes appears unclear.

pros: Good culture and operating system
cons: Too much process oriented which discourages problem solving

review_title: Poor leadership, no opportunities to grow or advance, only focused on cost cutting
pros: Salaries are very competitive, although Leadership will do and say anything to avoid giving raises.  Leadership is very flexible with Personal Time off, although be prepared to work 24/7 the rest of the time.
cons: Poor leadership vision - you can't "cost cut" your way into profitability.  "One size fits all" approach means you'll do it the Honeywell way, even if it's less efficient and effective for your business.  Employees are not valued - if they can find someone to do your job in a low cost region, then they'll do it, even if it means that 5 other people will have to pick up the slack due to poor work quality.  No training opportunities, no advancement opportunities.

pros: Very few.  I actually have pretty great work life balance for a SW engineer compared to some of my friends at other companies.  No weekends, little OT.
cons:
Poor benefits.  Not bonus/profit sharing for engineers.  Healthcare costs have increased every year and now only offer 1 option (High deductible plan). Low wages for SW positions for the area (Seattle).  Will never compete for top talent unless pay competitive wages for the area.

Had layoffs where all US build and test teams were laid off to move to India prior to setting up the teams in India.  After which test management wants the developers to implement testing and builds in the interim in addition to development projects.

US hiring freeze has left a decimated US engineering team between layoffs and people choosing to leave for other companies.  Those who are least likely to find new work (older and less skilled) seem to be becoming the majority that are left.  Most the young talent that was acquired has left.

pros: salary, 401k and vacation policy is good but you have to work for a terribly managed company that spends most of its time trying to outsource all of the work the US companies that they acquire used to do.
cons: You'll eventually hate life and either quit or get laid off...or get moved to a different site 45 minutes away (they like to close down offices and move them frequently) and then they will let you go as a cost down move.  This place is a meat grinder.  They will furlough you (often) while beating you down on project schedule.  Give you no resources to work with (everyone assigned eventually quits or gets let go so they throw another warm body on it from some remote site) and they try and shred any dignity that you have left.  If you hang on through that, they will then start layoffs.  Morale is so bad at most sites  and most people are just hanging on biding their time until a better gig opens up somewhere else.  This is a truly terrible company to work for.  They treat their employees like garbage.

review_title: Slow-moving beast with a short-term view
pros: To be honest, a few years back I could fill up this section easily, but now, not possible unfortunately.
cons:
* Everything that happens is with the outlook to the current financial quarter, meaning it's close to impossible to drive new projects and innovation, and get the required funding. Everything is geared towards inflating the stock value as much as possible in preparation for the company split. So no cost is taken, no employees replaced, no travel, no meetings, no training,...
* over the last year an extremely short-sighted view on everything
* When senior leadership is continuously measured on the quarters, it is impossible to take sane investments and look 2-3 years ahead within large projects
* Extremely hierarchical
* verify difficult for decisions to be made
* constant travel bans impacting teams and projects, and their progress
* impossible to get work done and flowing in a good way
* constantly changing organization, back and forth, no real visionary drive
* employee turn-over rate increasing

pros: The product work is absolutely the best in the industry. Working with great customers, working on the front edge of avionics, and new software development.
cons: As my employment advanced with Honeywell, their attention towards new product development changed from advancement to more of a stand still and only modifying their exciting product. I felt like they were only holding onto what they had created in the past, milking the cow, instead of advancing their technology. I left the company because they became more concernd with the bottom line and not the employees. The Heath insurance was terriable, and most importantly the management. They are clearly hiring more over seas, mainly India, because they can save more money. when I left the company, I had more co-workers that lived overseas than local. They created a work culture that was depressing and not enjoyable or motivating.

pros: Absolutely not a pro to this company
cons: everything about this company id a con

pros: Good people to work with.
cons: 100% percent travel for my current job.

job_title: Senior Strategic Sourcing Specialist in Dubai
pros: Exposure, Growth, Multi-segment, Leadership, Multicultural, Expertise
cons: Quite vast, Visibility, Challenging, Coordination,complacent

pros:
- Great opportunities for training and extended learning (if you can find the time to take advantage of this)
- Great opportunities to move around the company (people are always coming and going, or just wait a few months and there will be another big reorg)
- Company full of smart and hard-working people
- Good employee benefits
cons:
- After many rounds of layoffs and reorganizations, there are fewer people left to do the same amount or more work.  Everyone is working full-speed, overtime, all the time, all year round.  It is physically, mentally, and emotionally draining.
- Very little to no work-life balance
- Just when you are getting settled in, everything changes again

job_title: Electrical Project Engineer in Mason, OH
pros:
The quality of life and work life balance seems to be largely influenced by department. Controls engineers spend a large amount of their time (50%+) on the road which, for some, is excessive. 

The electrical engineers spend a fair share of time on site too, usually between April and September, but are home about 70% of the time. The typical travel schedule is about 2 weeks on site then 2 weeks in the office, though the project schedule may dictate a more aggressive schedule at times. 

The staff is great and very knowledgeable; it's a fun place to work. With the quick growth the opportunity for advancement is very apparent, though if the work ethic is lacking people will be passed over.

The company also pays for hours worked over 45 each week. This bonus pay is mostly reserved for on site time, but can be a substantial increase in your salary. It is a fantastic benefit and definitely difficult to match elsewhere in the industry.
cons: The travel is not for everyone, but the electrical department is cognizant if that and the supervisors do a good job at balancing it. Other departments may have more or less travel, do some research if this is a concern.

job_title: Director of Engineering in Charlotte, NC
pros: None that I can endorse
cons: You are a nothing but a number

review_title: This review is for the Honeywell Process Solutions division only -- people are good, compensation is poor
job_title: Project Engineer I in Houston, TX
pros: The people and team camaraderie is excellent. I've met many great people here -- employees and managers. The work flexibility and extremely casual and laid back environment is probably the most recognized perk here. Employees are allowed to work remotely, there's no strict work schedule, and attire is casual.
cons:
The strategy at HPS is extremely focused on cost reduction. As a result, much of the work and manufacturing is now outsourced and employee compensation is extremely below market average (especially in Houston, TX). The 401(k) matching has been reduced and the healthcare coverage is not impressive. The result is plenty of employee turnover and some instability within the organization. One can expect to have a different superior annually.

Due to the outsourcing especially for the large and global projects, it is highly recommended to avoid working on these projects since the experience one would hope to gain will instead be gained by someone overseas. Local projects are recommended instead.

pros: Pros for working in this company are depleting every year. Sad to say that this is not the Honeywell I used to love to work for.
cons:
Systematically takes benefits away from employees in an effort to improve profit margins. This is especially true when organic sale prognosis is flat. Took 401K 100% away and refuses to bring it back stating terrible market conditions.  Honeywell is self-insured and as such hides from State Laws. One example of this is refusal to help children of employees that have been diagnosed for Autism Spectrum Disorder.  There are many other examples. Honeywell is quick to promote their volunteering efforts, for children affected by Autism, but it fails to mention that it will not help employees who have children diagnosed with this disorder.

CEO is basically a clown recognized by Wall Street for cutting cost on employees backs so that his Wall Street buddies are happy. This guy is so out of date that he is still using 9 box model, for employee evaluation, which was invented by his mentor Jack Walsh (another proven clown). There is much more, I could write a book about ridiculous bureaucracy present in this company. Take my advice and look for somebody else to work for, after all your job will soon be exported to India, China and other emerging markets because that’s where Honeywell customers are, Yeah right.

pros: As an engineer at Honeywell Aerospace you will have the opportunity to work with some very talented people.  In most cases at the engineer level, the direct managers are former engineers who understand the issues and challenges at hand and are willing to go to bat for you.  Schedules are flexible.  401k match used to be better but still pretty good compared to the industry.
cons: Where to begin...this company being mismanaged from the top down and it is extremely management top heavy.  Raises are almost non-existent on top of the below average pay.  Schedules are made to meet customer demands as opposed to the reality of engineering/design schedules.  Furloughs and layoffs are becoming regular practice.  A lot of design and engineering work is being shipped overseas while the domestic workforce continues to be shrunk.  Used to be a much more pleasant work environment, in fact the only thing keeping this review from being a 1 star rating are the people you get to interact with on a daily basis.  Healthcare benefits?  Why even bother.

pros: As an engineer at Honeywell Aerospace you will have the opportunity to work with some very talented people.  In most cases at the engineer level, the direct managers are former engineers who understand the issues and challenges at hand and are willing to go to bat for you.  Schedules are flexible.  401k match used to be better but still pretty good compared to the industry.
cons: Where to begin...this company being mismanaged from the top down and it is extremely management top heavy.  Raises are almost non-existent on top of the below average pay. A lot of design and engineering work is being shipped overseas while the domestic workforce continues to be shrunk.  Used to be a much more pleasant work environment, in fact the only thing keeping this review from being a 1 star rating are the people you get to interact with on a daily basis.  Healthcare benefits?  Why even bother.

review_title: They will use you then fire you.
pros: You will gain experience. You will work so much over time you will double your salary. It is better than being on unemployment.
cons: You will be worked like a dog. No one will appreciate that you are working like a dog. You will have to guilt them in to a raise of your base pay. Which you will need to do when you find out that the new hires you are training are making more than you. Though they offer paternity leave don’t expect to use it they will fire you before your baby is due. And when I say before I mean three days before.

review_title: Good company, GPGI Focused so constant portfolio adjustments.
pros: Excellent company during my 17 plus years there. Worked for very good leaders and managers, and Mr Cote was a true visionary leader. Lots of opportunities to grow - for example - I had about 8 roles, the last 5 in leadership. Very good 401K Match and we even had a pension (ended a few years back). Good vacation policy.
cons: The health insurance plan is really bad.  It is truly a “high cost - very high deductible” plan that only works for catastrophic illnesses or conditions, so please consider that into the evaluation of an offer. And you can no longer work from home even if your team is globally dispersed.

job_title: Product Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The work is challenging, the company is financially stable, this is a global company, and the company is among the leaders in the markets it serves.  There are lots of opportunities to make a contribution.  Management is making a concerted effort to improve work processes, to increase the focus on customers and on doing the right jobs in the right way.  The company supports telecommuting and other accommodations for people who cannot (or prefer not to) work 8-5 five days a week.
cons: A lot of activities have been outsourced to India, such as software development.  This limits job opportunities since some career paths are not available to people from North America or Europe.  The company is large with a lot of overhead, and will never be a nimble, Silicon Valley startup.  The global presence means that it is easy to work odd hours, such as early mornings or evenings.  Certain jobs require a lot of travel.  There are occasional rumors that Honeywell will sell all or part of ACS, which would likely result in major dislocations.

review_title: Good Until Bought by Allied Signal
job_title: Staff Systems Engineer in Glendale, AZ
pros: Intellectually stimulating work. Leading-edge technology in the Aerospace field. Dynamic environment, especially in the government and defense sector. Diverse and very talented engineering workforce.
cons:
Very much "old boy" network as far as advancement and promotions. Horrible management style of "rank and yank" inherited from CEO Dave Cote, a devotee and apprentice of GE's Jack Welch. Employees are ranked together with peers once a year during review cycle. Bottom 10% are marked for elimination - no exceptions. Stupid and incredibly moral destroying management style. Employees are forced to compete against each other just to keep their jobs, instead of focusing on innovation and new technology.

Every year, benefits are cut down from the previous year. Management Incentive Plan sounds good on paper, but in practice management finds ways to restrict the payouts by tying to unreachable goals the average employee has no control over.  

Company seems to be more interested in moving jobs to cheaper off-shore locations rather than investing in their mainland U.S. employees. Stock price seems to be the focus of the company - period.

pros: The paychecks haven't bounced yet.
cons:
Management continues to chase short-term dollars in a myopic exercise to increase shareholder value. In the process, they continually overwork and push employees to deliver with no reward. As a thank you for a year of hard work, long days, urgent calls in the middle of the night, and  weekend travel to other sites; senior leadership is instituting a manual furlough (unpaid time off work) the first week in January. They are also not modifying delivery expectations and somehow, programs and projects will magically continue to progress despite no effort. 

This review is long on the short, but the work life balance, policies, and way people are treated is appalling, and many have been here so long they don't know any better. There's no way Honeywell can transition into a top-flight software company with their current mentality. There's no vision; and if there is one out there, it's certainly not shared. 

They've brought in some incredible talent with the lure of building some massively innovative products; but each of those products requires a death march of a project to get them done and a LOT of people are fed up. Expect the smart and capable ones to start jumping ship in early January when other companies ramp up their hiring. 

DON'T LISTEN TO THE BS RECRUITERS GIVE YOU, THIS PLACE IS A PRISON WORK CAMP!

pros: The people you work with will make this job much more bearable.  Good starting salary but maybe don't let that fool you; I'll explain in the cons section.  Pretty good work life balance.  Not too many others I can think of.
cons: Management plays favorites.  Constantly going through riffs and layoffs.  Even when we have a great year there will be layoffs.  It's just management trying to meet their bottom line.  Cost of living raises are a joke (if you even get one).  If you get promoted the pay bump will make you wonder why you even tried to get a promotion in the first place.  Benefits get worse every year.  This year it was our health insurance that got worse as well as more expensive.  Turnover rate is insane.  Within two years you will see at least half the people you work with leave for a better opportunity.  The only people still there are the ones with 30+ years who are grandfathered in to the pension plan.  They dont do pensions anymore.  They dont match 401K for the first year, and they do that probably because so many people leave after a year or two.  I could go on and on but just try to find a better opportunity first.

pros: You can work a lot of overtime.
cons: No work life balance at all.

job_title: Global Associate Product Manager in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: Given the size of the company, there are a lot of opportunities to grow.  Honeywell places a lot of emphasis in Product Marketing as the driver for growth.  It is a great place to work as a Product Manager where you can use the systems in place and tools available to set, drive, and implement growth strategies in wide variety of markets.
cons: The company, specifically the Sensing and Controls division, is fairly risk averse.  Given the size of the company and the tendency to be risk averse, you can find the implantation of the projects to be slower than a smaller, more nimble company.  My advise is to backup all initiatives and ideas you might have with data and a cost/benefit analysis to gain the support of management and get your projects funded.

review_title: No longer the company I used to love
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL
pros: I think you'll see the same major "pro" from all employee reviews - working at UOP gives you access to an amazing amount of brilliant and talented scientists and engineers.  I am always amazed at how much I continue to learn from my colleagues.  Current senior management appears to be moving the company in a positive direction (time will tell).  Communication with senior management has certainly improved in the past few years - it is nice to understand the goals of the company from management's perspective.  The work/life balance is good at UOP - no complaints there.
cons: From my own personal perspective.  Salary is average and has stagnated in recent years.  Currently there appears to be little opportunity to advance my career - and I have been trying hard to do this.  Benefits are slowly being eroded away.  It is unfortunately no longer the company that I used to enjoy working for.

job_title: Global Product Manager in London, England
pros:
- Working with in a cross functional team to drive results and develop truly global products that enhance our industry & safety.
- Being number 1 with in our industry, this is done by the hard work by all teams with in the LOB.
- Although an American company, Honeywell has a global presence and working with different regions/cultures and skill sets is great for personal & business growth.
- Funding of the right NPI projects to better enhance the portfolio. We have world class Marketing/Engineering to deliver truly game changing products.
cons:
- Process are to heavy at times (esp NPI's), just because we are a multi billion dollar company doesn't mean our processes have to be overly complex. Live by KISS.
- Sometimes people are to focused on just there own LOB, remember to talk across the business as you will often find many synergies between SBG's

review_title: HONEYHELL INTELLIGRATED IS THE CORRECT NAME
pros: They provide decent 401k match but you have to stay the whole year to get it at the end of the year. That’s pretty much the only pros
cons:
They recently rolled out a new overtime policy. It was 45 hours before they start paying premium time for the engineer and now it’s 48 hours. No more holiday pay. So if you happen to have to work over holiday or weekend. You basically will be working for free. 
Furlough is also a new thing at Honeywell. They furlough their employees once every quarter to make their number looks good hoping that they won’t disappoint their investors. They do not care about their employees AT ALL. 

Few big names already left the companies for the competitors so I don’t expect this company will last very long. Employees start leaving the company right after the furlough and pay cut. They also want to limit your meal expense to $40 a day. That’s right, they want their top not engineers to spend “$40 a day” on their meals. That’s even less then how much they give to the installers because the installers are getting per diem

pros: I cannot think of one
cons: Horrible place to work; Huge turnover

pros: Opportunities to work in process control projects with interesting industrial clients
cons:
Rotten politics, it's all about perception and not the work completed. You need to make sure you complain first and fast as all scientific evidence will be ignored by management. Basically you spend more time thinking about how to CYA than doing your job.

Strip clubs were considered normal entertainment for staff and clients, even new grads thought this was an acceptable night out.

Training is a joke, they offer many courses but when you are back in your team you are unable to use your new skills as you aren't working on projects that used them. Worse senior engineers will not let you apply the new skills to improve a project e.g. to make it run faster, because they've always done it this way. Which was the way it was taught five years ago.

If someone it mates with the boss they cannot do anything wrong and the boss will happily let them scapegoat someone else who had little involvement with the project.

Lying to clients was common, there were cases where external parties had been paid kickbacks to approve designs 


It's the only company I know that doesn't have integrity as part of there core values and it shows.

pros:
- Wages are competitive
- Interesting work
cons:
- Honeywell views employees as liabilities.  They cut back benefits at every turn.  For example, they just announced that 401K match will be given only at the end of Jan of each year (lump sum).   You lose it if you retire or are laid off.  All this when they are experiencing double digit growth and profit.
- Benefits are horrible.  Extremely high premiums and deductibles.  No dental or vision.
- No vacation except for hourly employees.  They switched to unlimited vacation, but varies wildly with your manager..
- Cannot work from home - even if your spouse is dying from cancer.
- Extremely poor decision making at every level.
- Too many processes that add no value.
- They do not care about customers or quality.
- The only entities that benefit from Honeywell is leadership and investors.
- Salary employees are required to work a minimum of 44 hours per week at a 40 hour pay scale.  No overtime for salaried employees.
- Honeywell is outsourcing as much as possible to low cost regions.
- Honewell is borderline unethical.

pros: Any Pros are far outweighed by the cons
cons:
- Culture
- Leadership
- Facilities
- Performance expectations

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Honeywell FM&T has great work/life balance, and most employees/managers are very nice to work with/for.  Pay levels are excellent.  The new building is quite nice.  The National Security focus is a great motivator to know that products for some aspects of the business are benefiting our soldiers and the defense of our country.
cons:
In the words of one of the managers, "HR rules the world."  The HR department is one of the worst I have ever worked with.  The 9-Block rating system instills distrust (and disgust in most instances) amongst peers (read previous reviews).  Unless you're well connected, promotions can be difficult to get.

With the introduction of the "9-block" and increased Corporate influence, the culture has morphed over the past 10 years from a family-oriented, enjoyable working environment to a more watch-your-back mentality.  It's sad to have witnessed this transformation at the hands of Corporate greed.  It used to be such a great company to work for.

review_title: A once great company now ruined by Honeywell
job_title: Mechanical Engineer II in Mason, OH
pros: My manager and co-workers, Close to a lot of good restaurants, Pay was adequate
cons:
-The whole company is fractured 
Each group is focused on their own individual goals and not a unified goal for the company. Honeywell's only focus is on making products cheap and maximizing a profit, no matter the sacrifice. Thousands of hours are wasted on chasing pennies and outsourcing everything to the lowest bidder while quality diminishes. 

-Leadership is oblivious or just doesn’t care 
Honeywell constantly preaches the value of its employees, but never seems to listen to what the employees have to say. Every step they have taken since purchasing Intelligrated has done nothing but drive employees out the door. The turnover rate within Intelligrated continues to grow and Honeywell has yet to understand people are leaving because of their terrible business practices and lack of ethics. Honeywell frequently blames managers for employees leaving and that most employees who left the company were “non regrettable losses.” 

-Don’t expect rewards for good work 
Intelligrated won “Best Honeywell Company” of the year in 2018. There were a lot of congratulations from leadership, but the only benefit employees saw from this was a pizza party. Raises in 2019 were pretty minimal even though we were told Intelligrated received more money to spread around for doing so well.

job_title: Senior Mobile Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
- Great Salary (but the benefits suck)
- You can never get fired even if you don't show up to work.
- Perfect for retirement coasting.
cons:
- No product focus. Driven by MBA management team that strictly looks at sales/numbers.
- Spray and pray approach when it comes to building products. All the recently released products have been a total failure.
- During offer stage, HR doesn't tell you that 401k matching is on a vesting plan.
- Blame game is the management style.
- High deductible health plan and the premium costs a lot of money.
- Employees are punished by not giving them raises where as the CEO makes millions in bonuses. The failure at our level is caused by org structure and lack of product vision but engineers still get blamed.
- Agile is slowly rolling out but only to SW COE. While the Product Management moves forward with waterfall management.
- Distributed global locations = potential for international travel, weekly meetings past business hours.
- Engineering leadership is located in Bangalore and the management style archaic.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Golden Valley, MN
pros: When working on important programs, there is lots of money for tooling and prototypes.
cons:
No money for raises.  Frequent years with no merit increases for the whole company.  Limited advancement opportunities for non-software technical talent.  Most future US hiring now targeting Atlanta.  Most technical hiring is now in Mexico or China.  Product management frequently makes major changes mid-program, but demands schedules not change resulting in long days and working weekends.

Everyone expects new "unlimited" vacation policy will be used to severely limit vacation taken.  Every year the benefits are significantly reduced.  In 2017 we lost the company contribution to dental, earned vacation, and flexibility to work from home, even occasionally.  In previous years we had already been limited to expensive high deductible health plans, lost our company contribution for vision, lost our company contribution to our HSA, and lost the ability to borrow from our 401(k).

Morale is so low that employees openly discuss state of their job search.
