review_title: Not a good place to work
pros:
- Flexible (depending on team and boss).
- No pressure to do any overtime.
- Coworkers are helpful
- Low stress for most part
cons:
- No chance for career advancement. Getting promoted is almost impossible no matter what your ratings are.
- End of the year ratings are meaningless. Extremely difficult to move up without leaving your team and very political. It's not what you know but who you know.
- Very low morale across all sectors due to constant benefit cuts and furloughs over the past year.
- Most employees are looking for jobs outside the company making working there frustrating because nobody seems to care anymore. I don't blame them as I totally understand.  
- Management constantly lying when it comes to career progression. Make you lose respect and working there very difficult.
- Very bad medical insurance.
- Constant benefit cuts and regular RIFs and furloughs.
- Not much new development in the US and no chance to learn new skills as a result.

pros: Decent Salary and Work Tools
cons: Toxic Environment and Dishonest Leadership

job_title: Software Engineer I in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good benefits, and tuition reimbursement. I am lucky to have a manager that is willing to give me flex time for school. So I guess like many places it depends on your department. The tuition reimbursement is top notch, there is no cap. The pay is close to what the industry pays, but they will try to low ball the hell out of you when you come on. So watch out. The people I work with are competent and intelligent. The medical benefits are ok. Nothing to write home about, but you have choices and is better than most. enjoy
cons: slow moving and sometimes boring. Very hard to get any information from a unit or any engineering document. I need a secretary to just handle researching parts and stuff I am working on. I am sick of working with people from india. They have a totally different mindset and they are very clicy. Can't understand half of the stuff they are talking about and they get frustrated with you for not understanding. It will not stop anytime soon, they are building a center over in china now so I am dreading the day that opens up. Some of the contractors are slackjobs and very rude.

review_title: Be prepared for a daily headache.
pros: Honeywell is a great name to have on your resume. They also do a lot of rotations between positions so if you are there for any length of time you will most likely get to know a lot about the business.
cons: Honeywell claims to be big on training but I disagree. There are classes available to all employees but that is if you have time to take them and none of them are job specific. Honeywell just throws an employee into a position with no training and litle guidance or access to resources. For this reason a lot of people are stressed on a daily basis. Once a person actually masters the skills necessary to perform the job, with little help from anyone else, they are up for a new rotation to start the process again. The corporate culture is another downside. This place is all about office politics. It is all about making your boss happy. That means providing the information that they beleive they want, not necessarily providing the best information. The way to move up here is not by hard work or being skilled, more about your relationship with your boss.

job_title: Principal Scientist in Kansas City, MO
pros: Flexible work weeks and schedules.  9/80. Clean, safe environment.  Lots of great innovative talent and people. New and changing technology.   Great place to ...START!  And a  great stepping stone. Use them as they use you.
cons: Below market target on  salary offerings.  Healthcare and assessment process is totalitarian. Benefits have been scaled back, while we are told to our face that shareholders are more important.  Company surveys are a joke.  The obvious bad results (i.e.: benefit) gets skimmed over by top management, while they focus on the minuscule as change goals.  Lots of managers from GE, still old philosophy of ridding of top and bottom 10% by an antiquated 9-block system, which results a high turnover rate.

pros:
I absolutely love working at Honeywell. Not only is my team collaborative and supportive but the entire company is as a whole. They really know how to keep a great work life balance and treat their employees really well!
Everyone has been so welcoming and it's truly a fun, laid back work environment where everyone seems genuinely happy to be coming to work everyday. The atmosphere is extremely open and collaborative with open workspaces. 
Our company has a strong sense of community that is felt in every office globally. Honeywell is the best place I've ever worked! I say this because I'm challenged each day, motivated to do my best and feel supported by my management team. It's a joy coming to work each day!

My boss Rajib is a great guy who support me all the time with challenges to go beyond our expectation. Rajib is a strong leadership man when action is needed. He influences others to perform better. He provides clear direction and has little problem gaining compliance from others. He provides consistent, valuable performance feedback, and he dedicates considerable effort to developing the skills of his employees. Rajib includes employees in most planning, and he takes responsibility for his employees' activities.
cons: There is no cons with Honeywell

pros:
People: Everyone I work with on a day to day basis is great. Coworkers, direct supervisor and even the next level up in management are easy to work with and approachable.

Diversity of Work: Able to work in many different capacities from design to production support to test. Keeps the day to day varied and fresh.
cons:
Work/Life Balance: Be prepared to work weekends. Since upper management decided to layoff everyone that wasn't absolutely critical remaining employees are being forced to pick up the slack. Now they are coming back with more layoffs and this is only going to get worse.

Benefits: 401K matching is there but not great; 75% up to 8%. The insurance plans are a joke. 

Morale: Unsurprisingly overworked people that have to deal with multiple layoffs every year don't always bring the best attitudes into the office.

pros: Good working environment but high pressure
cons: Very low payscale and single digit increments yearly.

review_title: Once a great place to work at.
pros: Excellent technical marketing training provided throughout the year. Great leadership from Honeywell Corporate VP and CMO Rhonda Germany that can be felt throughout the business.
cons: Constant re-orgs and new business leaders under pressure to make an impact on the business, creating a lot of reporting out requests that prevent strategic marketing from providing value added help to the business and sales team. Big corporate culture with endless politics at play. No standard learning plan for functional roles. New hires are expected to learn Honeywell culture, products, and applications independently, which can be challenging for those operating out of a satellite office or home office.

review_title: Big company = big opportunities for carrier, sometimes big troubles to do a work.
pros: Big company = many opportunities.  There is many groups and they can be very very different. So if there is something you don't like in your group, you may choose to to elsewhere in the company.
cons:
- Top management is sometimes directly requesting random changes to the top priority project (for instance enforcement of use dualband WiFi for all products regardless of situation on market).
- Many high level managers just collect reports, sends them up and sends command from top to down. No value added. 
- Willingness to fire whole team (even team with best-team award) just because engineers in India will do it cheaper.
- Slow and inconsistent decisions - different parts of company do have different opinion, so when it gets down to developers, it is often a mess. This may be better after spinning off the Turbochargers and Homes businesses.

pros: good technical base to learn
cons: office politics and over aged people

review_title: UOP: Leader in Technology Development, 2014 marks its 100 Anniversary. A century of Innovation in Oil and Gas Industry.
job_title: Process Design Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Top Talented Chemical Engineers to work with, may be the Best in the Industry and Not just at the professional level but also at the personal level.

if you are a truly talented chemical engineer and love the challenge and is willing to put the effort to impact our society, then this is the place to work.

do you want to leave a "mark" in this world for future generations: then UOP is a place to be and develop all your potential.
cons: as UOP is owned by Honeywell, its Today's leaders are not encouraging/attracting  talented professionals, as the benefits are NOT competitive, the salary is below median and the facilities of the company are old and not appealing at all.

review_title: Do not work here if you are all about efficiency, effective communication and processes.
pros: Great people, decent pay, great name.
cons: The internal communication channels are the worst I have ever seen.  This company has horrible processes in place and nothing gets done about it.  Customers are left very frustrated and begin contacting the seller as the Customer Service team gets back to the customer in an untimely manner.  Maybe a little sooner if multiple emails are sent.  About our products....we are continuously running out of product and shipping to customer is delayed by months.  I have never seen anything like this.  There is no efficient way to manage inventory and as you try to take ownership of it and discuss, there is absolutely no communication back because they have no idea what is going on as well.  I can go on and on.

review_title: Excellent work/ life balance.  Little to no supervision or micro management.
job_title: Senior Field Service Technician in Duluth, GA
pros: Company paid for just about everything. I had a company car with a gas card,  plus a travel/ expense card,  and a purchasing card to get all my tools.
cons: I was laid off after 9 months due to " restructuring". This is the second time I've worked for the company and the only way to really make head way is to quit and come back, at least at the tech level. Yet everyday I see new notices of someone else being promoted to an executive level. Also I'd you're laid off,  the compensation/ severance isn't worth it unless you've managed to stay with the company for over 20 years.

pros: Pay compensation is very good
cons: Everything else. Way too top-heavy with management

pros:
*Resume booster.
*Must be awesome to work at the home headquarters where one might actually get treated like a team member.
cons:
*Honeywell has gotten to big, in that, they will get what they want 100% of the time. If your on the  salary side, Honeywell pretty much eats their own.
*$6800.00 premium on a family healthcare plan with a $7000.00 deductible for the employee and $8000.00 deductible for family members. Warned it will rise again in 2018.
*They care more about investors/bonuses than the employees that produce the products.
*Fortune 100 company than runs on North Korea benefits.
*Morale, I don't know where to start but I know where it ends, the parking lot before entering the plant site.
*Don't expect anything around the holidays, that way your hope of a $36 Billion dollar empire being generous wont dissolve in a puddle of "Entitled" mindedness.
*The disdain looks coming from the C.E.O. standing on his pedestal high above us peasant sand pounders.

review_title: HTS Bangalore - All is not well
pros:
Friendly colleges and average technology adoption 
Used to be employee friendly until 2014.
cons:
If you throw a stone in HTS campus  it'll  hit a manager or program manager for sure. Company is filled with inefficient managers and  most of the talented employees already left the company due to politics.
Leaders talk a lot about innovation culture and when it comes to new technology or training they wash of their hand.
Leader's in HTS are only good at power point presentation .They are more worried about HOS,Kaizen and process a than project .

No transparency in hiring process.   Recruitment team is outsourced and they give importance only to external consulting firms.Refers are only for name sake here.

Cafetaria food is horrible and no action taken to improve it. Operation team members bully the cafeteria vendor and  get free food/meals/juice. 

Don't get trapped by brand name.
worked here for 6.5 years.

pros: The company still has good name recognition in the industry. There are still some remaining UOP employees that have the knowledge and skill set to keep the company successful and are generally good to work with.
cons: Honeywell is the biggest con. Since taking over a world class company with loyal employees the have constantly decreased employee benefits and moral. They came in with the attitude that even though UOP had built this great reputation, knowledge base and footprint in the industry UOP had done it all wrong. Honeywell set out changing everything from top to bottom that made this a great company. Now UOP is a company that has been cannibalized by it's owner strictly concerned about short term profits and goals with little or no concern for the long term viability of UOP. The people made UOP what it was and no system can be put in place to replace the knowledge or loyalty that Honeywell is loosing in this company daily.

review_title: Friendly Employer Struggling for Market Growth & Sustenance in 21st Century
pros: Traditionally a strong systems integrator from technology solutions perspective is a excellent workplace for research oriented engineering graduates (especially in the fields of aviation, specialty materials, industrial automation).   With an agile leadership at top, it has been a remarkable journey for this company since 2003, be it winning investor confidence, sustaining employee morale while adapting to the changes dictated by era of cloud & competition.
cons: It is bit of a challenge in this globalization era, to retain its DNA throughout its multi-site cross cultural workforce.   Attracting right talent have been a formidable challenge for Honeywell, wherein lowering the guard is not a solution.   Off late, India operations have been rescinded to a back office engineering services enabler(cost arbitrage)  than seen as sharing the responsibility of the new age growth in these regions.

review_title: Friendly Employer Struggling for Market Growth & Sustenance in 21st Century
pros: Traditionally a strong systems integrator from technology solutions perspective is a excellent workplace for research oriented engineering graduates (especially in the fields of aviation, specialty materials, industrial automation).   With an agile leadership at top, it has been a remarkable journey for this company since 2003, be it winning investor confidence, sustaining employee morale while adapting to the changes dictated by era of cloud & competition.
cons: It is bit of a challenge in this globalization era, to retain its DNA throughout its multi-site cross cultural workforce.   Attracting right talent have been a formidable challenge for Honeywell, wherein lowering the guard is not a solution.   Off late, India operations have been rescinded to a back office engineering services enabler(cost arbitrage)  than seen as sharing the responsibility of the new age growth in these regions.

pros: The 401K match is up to 8% of the employees salary.  The legacy employees before this division was acquired are exceptional people.
cons: The benefits are not up to industry standards.  Only one insurance carrier to select from previously three.  The medical deductible is very high.  The dental insurance is poor.  Most of the management has left this particular division for other career opportunities out side the company.  The new management does not understand the business.   I see similar management issues at other sites.  The company expects the employee to take the brunt of revenue and profits shortfalls in order to keep shareholder  price up.  Not enough funding to maintain present business status in order to keep market share.  There is a lot of contract hiring and bringing in outside support from lower cost areas.  The end result is a higher cost product because of lack of technical knowledge and additional training.  Recent furlough and layoffs.

review_title: Another year and more benefits cut.
job_title: Senior Engineer in East Gaffney, SC
pros: Household name that looks good on resumes.  If you are able to stay under the radar and put up with average pay and reduced benefits, you could camp out here for many years.
cons:
Large slow moving company.  If you live in China or India you will be very happy here.  Otherwise, look for no raises, reduced benefits and managers that move around every few years changing the policies of the former managers.  They just cut more benefits for US workers for the 2017 year.  My favorite quote in business applies here:  "A company should be concerned when their most passionate workers go silent". The silence is deafening now.

Most older employees are just trying to retire and meet minimum standards to stay until that happens.

review_title: Stay away from anything that says CONNECTED!
pros: Market leader in certain areas, good financial shape, pay
cons:
There are two parts to Honeywell; legacy businesses and the new HCP business! The legacy businesses are very organized and healthy but the working culture is what your grandpa was used to! Forget any sort of telecommuting, flexibility, fun, management feedback, etc. but you will make good money! 

Now the problem starts with the CONNECTED or HCP part! that is a total mess! they don't have any plan for this business and just keep hiring people! they don't even have desks for people they hire and there's a revolving door with people staying just a few months on the jobs. I would definately not recommend those jobs! 

The benefits are subpar with health insurance for a family costing over $700/ month!! They will offer you a big number as base pay but there are no real benefits so you have to take at least $10K off of the base salary to compare it with other companies! 

They outsource everything they can! That includes even IT, HR and Marketing! So don't expect a lot of ownership culture here since they're all contract workers! 

The building is old and smells like mold, seriously the most depressing company I ever worked for!

pros: Honeywell is a good employer - provides opportunities for all of the training you can handle -  referring to CBT type courses.  This ranges for Agile, PMP, Six-sigma, MS Office, etc..  The people are good to work with and there is opportunity to gain experience in diverse control projects, fire alarm, and security.  They have a good 401k plan and incentives
cons: Honeywell is process driven to an excess - gets bogged down with a lot of corporate baggage, i.e. check box type reporting.  Internal product support is cumbersome, slow, and difficult.  Sales teams are not held accountable for omissions which places the burden on the Project Management Team to deliver under budget.  There is too much overhead to compete with smaller companies in the highly competitive controls market unless it is a very large project.

review_title: At the edge of the cliff
pros: The people that you work with on a daily basis are smart, for the most part friendly, and extremely hard working.  But that's pretty much the only positive left, and people are leaving in staggering numbers.
cons: Pressure to make each quarter is extreme and financials are engineered to do so.  Lack of any revenue growth has led the company to improve its profits by squeezing the employee base among other edge-of-ethics actions.  Abusive work culture driven from the very top with people leaving in droves.  Management banned remote work globally in late 2016, punishing the entire workforce because a tiny sliver of the organization was abusing work-from-home privileges.  Horrible medical benefits - a family can expect to pay more than $10k per year in premiums and medical costs.  Punitive medical screening policy essentially forces employees to undergo annual medical testing or pay a $1,500 penalty per adult on the policy.  It's just sad to see what this once-great company has become.

review_title: Run do not walk far away from hr
pros: Similar to another hr review my paycheck arrived on time.
cons: Most arrogant, archaic, inhumane hr dept ever.  Function has the highest turnover of any function there.  Horrible hr brand in the marketplace ( wish i knew this prior).  I would say only 2 hr leaders there that have respect.  Please if you’re considering working here, do your research!  Oh yes, endless fire drills, very tactical, no strategy, and while they say in the interview process they want external perspective, that is simply not true.  If it’s not the Honeywell way...... there is zero acceptance to listen and perhaps admit they maybe doing something wrong.  Last, zero work life balance with no work from home flexibility.  In fact not unusual if you were working from home and didn’t come back to the office...... adios!  If you’re interested in working 24/7 for said firedrills, this is your environment!

review_title: Great People but very poor workplace structure and organization. Low Payscale compared to most
job_title: Maintenance On Millwright Crew in Geismar, LA
pros: Most of the people who are here and actually want to stay have been here years, so from supervisors on down it's one big family (most of the time).
cons:
Payscale is lower than most of the other plants and its pretty much all Union on the maintnance crew side.

Like most places they have their cliques of family  members and people who "know" someone who shouldn't be there based on work ethics.

The other main problem is the Organization and structure of the upper management and overall company. They prefer to budget tightly but don't plan things well enough so they end up spending more than they need to in the end. 

Another issue is that you will most likely get switched from nights to days and crew to crew often and since they won't hire people very often, the crews there get a lot of OT.

job_title: Research Scientist in Golden Valley, MN
pros:
Honeywell was the place everyone wanted to work when I graduated from school and now that I work for Honeywell, I can see why!  Pros include

1.  Working on cool new technologies which will make people safer and more comfortable!
2.  Allowed to use my creativity to help the company accomplish its mission!
3.  Brilliant, creative, and friendly co-workers who work together for success.
4.  Fast-paced work environment where I'm allowed to focus on what matters most and not so much on the bureaucracy.
5.  Reasonable and common-sense manager who cares more about getting the job done and done ethically rather than how or where it gets done.
6.  Managers who know that it's hard to accomplish a lot when I have too many projects at the same time and who work hard to help me to not get bogged down.

I could go on...
cons: 1. Big company bureaucracy requires some work to figure out when first starting, though it doesn't affect my daily job much.

review_title: Great place to work, but no family/work life balance
pros: Directions to perform your job function are displayed on a computer at your station. The company supplies high quality tools, and breaks are taken every few hours.  Amenities and benefits, once you become a permanent employee, are excellent. Overtime is frequently available
cons: Mandatory weekends, overtime.  For parents, this wreaks havoc on your schedule.  For those with a life, it practically puts an end to it.  Training is spotty at best, nonexistent at worst.  Coaching from leadership is a fantasy.   Expectations aren't communicated, performance isn't recognized.   For the first six to ten months, should you happen to start as a contract employee,  you'll feel the wrath of the permanent employees, who will go out of their way to ridicule, shame, or put down any workers who aren't permanent employees yet.

review_title: Great first time entry level job
job_title: CDP Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Good pay, Travel, lot of savings
cons: Poor management, No control of time, fluctuating oil and gas market

review_title: Acompany that does not care about employees or your family
pros: the people i worked with was the best part!!!! and the only part!!!!!
cons: Management could care less about you or your family...good people on the floor,terrible managers and everyone on the floor knows dave cote hates the union and wants it out..He would like to pay employees 9-10 dollars an hour and rape them on thier insurance, metropalias plant confims this statement.. the division itself sell over 300 million in sales and the pay is only 16 dollars and they shove down your throat about how you should be thankful for your job..Don't have a death in the immediate family either,cheap company could'nt even send a card or flowers...the employees thier know more than mangement proven fact,if not for the employees the division would crumble...management is trained to hate the union point blank....i will only miss the people  on the floor.....

job_title: Quality Assurance Specialist in Bensalem, PA
pros: This site was part of an acquisition Honeywell made of the former corporation, EMS, Aviation.  The people at the site were wonderful to work with and the Honeywell Aerospace upper management, located in Arizona,  forced site management to implement better processes making the plant safer and more productive.
cons: At the time of the acquisition in 2011 no one at site level knew there was a plan at top level to eliminate the Moorestown as a Honeywell Aerospace facility. The Moorestown site had its most productive fiscal year in 2013 and, before the end of January of 2014 was over, we were told the site would close with production being sent to Mexico and the FAA repair station work removed to Georgia, USA. The master plan appears to be an conglomerate, then elimination, as many U.S. sites as possible to please the top stock holders. Many of my former colleagues were offered positions at other sites, but most refused because there is no guarantees that, once moved, that site will not close soon.

review_title: Move on if you are able
job_title: Mechanic II Electrical in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Hardworking and talented co-workers. Work was varied and sometimes challenging. Most times replacement tools or upgraded equipment was not hard to request and receive.
cons: You are expected to put in constant overtime - hourly or salary - even if there isn't enough work to justify it. Stack ranking style reviews. Micromanagement through the use of HOS rules right down to what you can throw in your trash can. A pay scale that used to be transparent - now it is a big secret. Lack of merit raises or promotion on said secret pay scale. Benefits that have been constantly culled. Only high deductible insurance plans available with health screening requirements to get a "discount".  Workers treated like kindergartners with respect to safety i.e no pointed scissors allowed. I could go on...but just read the other reviews and you will see enough correlation.

pros:
Stable employment  due to high turnover rate and the lack of staffing.

good employee match on 401k.
cons:
No career advancement unless you are in elite upper management. Raises below the inflation rate. If you talk to your manager about getting a raise they will take you to go out and get another offer and they will "consider" matching it.

If you don't have a minimum of a college degree Honeywell has a policy that you cannot  be promoted to a manager. If you r company is acquire by Honeywell as a principal or staff they will demote you to senior and you will never get promoted even if you work there 30+ years and invent the cure for cancer.

The employee cost of healthcare is higher than average.

Vacation policy is unlimited however depending on who your manager is they will limit it to whatever they think it should be.

Management policy is the 10-80-10 rule. 10% of your employees are above average, 80% are average, and 10%  are below average. A manager is required to put someone in the upper AND lower 10% catagary. The people in the lower 10% are require to complete a "Performance Improvement Plan" or PIP for short. They are required to  satisfactorily complete the plan or their employment will be terminated. PIPs are arbitrary and decided upon by your manager.

The list can go on.....

pros: Fantastic growth oppertunities when you report to the right boss. Great leaders do exist and you learn a lot. Software Development teams and practices are highly mature and balance between work and personal life leans more towards personal life. I have worked in a few places before, and I have found none that are more respectful to their employees or even care such as Honeywell. During the Global Financial Crisis, a sense of community came about and employees of the Software Center in North Ryde came together and agreed to work 4 paid days instead of 5 to prevent any redundancies. This is something that makes it completely worth it especially for those seeking job security and career growth.
cons: There seems to be a lot of politics played at higher level management. Indian politics is something to keep a very close eye on as very senior positions are filled by Indian background employees who will advance the Indian agenda without ill intentions to others but in survival mode

pros: Being a big company there are a lot of opportunities to move around. As of now they still provide a 401(k) match, but it's going to get cut soon.
cons:
Aerospace division is significantly hurting. Business is extremely slow and the management is taking away from employees to meet their annual numbers.
The company has cut the 2016 salary down by 10% already by the way of furloughs. There was no merit increase in 2016 and no increase expected in 2017 either. There was a lay off in Q2 of 2016 and there are rumors of additional lay off in Q1 2017. Recently, the CEO decided there Telecommuting is no longer allowed and would required approval from the President of the company. This in 2016 is ridiculous. The reason given
was that face to face interactions drive collaboration and faster decisions. At the same time the company encourages us to send work to India. I've nothing against it but these two things don't go together. 
For the last 9-12 months it almost feels like the company is instituting policies to drive us away so that they don't have to pay severance when they lay us off.

review_title: Tough to call home, highly political
job_title: Project Manager in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: Decent salary, good people where the rubber hits the road, good source for experience, liberal time off
cons: No investment in innovation, weakening benefits, no investment in people, WEAK marketing, HIGH turnover, LOW morale, motivate with a stick, tons of political land mines.  Most customers work with you because they have to, not because they want to and management is full of sycophants.  NO leaders, all decisions are made by consensus or to appease the latest motivational program du jour.  Very short sighted, constant crisis management often created internally

review_title: A company built by American Talent that shuns American Talent.
pros: The compensation starts out pretty good, but if you end up working for a scumbag manager - this company has TONS of them - you won't ever see a raise and you'll be lucky if you ever see a four digit bonus.  Enjoy the nice paycheck while it lasts, because, if you are located in the US, you have a bullseye on your head anyway.
cons: Sooner or later your job is going to India.  Ignore the current "what do I do to keep my job?" advice that's circulating right now.  It doesn't matter how many successful projects you work on and it doesn't matter how many hours you put in.  This company WILL send your job to India and they don't care what you do for their benefit.  Dave Cote has been quoted as stating there is to be no hiring in mature markets.  You don't need to be a brain surgeon to figure out reducing headcount in mature markets is high on his list, too.

job_title: Associate Engineer II in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: You will get your paycheck on time, They are a known company, They take job site and employee safety seriously.  If you can find the right spot and keep your ear to the ground then you should have a long term job as the company is not closing its doors tomorrow.
cons: Large companies view employees as numbers, no less no more.  Do not expect loyalty even if your boss has your back who has theirs.  I have watched managers that thought everything was fine show up at work to have there badge taken and be shown the door with no notice or warnings.  I have watched the company repeatedly create positions to go after a government contract just to terminate it the day after the contract is awarded.  Transparency levels require you to read between the lines of what they are not saying as well as what they are during monthly meetings or you will be totally blind sided.

review_title: Mechanical Engineer at Honeywell Aerospace - Glendale
job_title: Mechanical Engineer II in Glendale, AZ
pros: Great people, interesting products, and a wide range of opportunities to learn new skills and processes. The experience gained at Honeywell at Glendale made an an otherwise unsavory political environment an overall worthwhile experience.
cons: Sudden and unpredictable layoffs stemming from top level management that result in an understaffed business. Short sighted, flawed , and lazy policies that are damaging to product quality and the engineering culture. The company does not do an effective job of living up to the values and ideals that it often preaches. Overtime is used as a proxy to measure productivity. Moving up in the company often requires a complete change in job function. Lower level management has a negligible level of power and control over the organization and decisions made at the top rungs make work challenging and often overwhelming.

review_title: Field Service Engineers around West Coast are very unprofessionals
job_title: Field Service Engineer in West Covina, CA
pros: They need field service techs all the time so they hire them pretty quickly. So expect some really high turn-overs also because of the culture or the nature of this work. Although they pay overtime after 45 hours every week, you will have no time for any relaxations with your family or friends on the weekends. You will always be working like a slave. So when you accept this type of job, expect to travel 110% of your time.
cons: Not a good place to work at this time because they just got bought out by Honeywell corporation last August 2016. So lots of restructuring which means lots of laying offs left and right. Cutting costs everywhere. Very clickish type of culture. So if you are not being liked by everyone in your dept although you work hard and always reliable, you will always feel like an outsider. You need to kiss their behind to be liked. Lots of back stabbers at the field service type of jobs. So, always need to watch out with your behind. Benefits are not that great because of restructuring. So many cut backs on old benefits.

review_title: A great place to build your future!
pros: I have now been with HON for nearly 6 years and I thought I must write about what I love most about Honeywell. Its a company for the true professional who is eager to learn, take risks, have a progressive mindset and a passion for excellence in everything you do. We are changing to become the software industrial and provide connected offerings. There is a lot of learning through knowledge and experience sharing at all levels of the organization which helps to gain a broader view of the company. This helps in picking difficult assignments that would stretch you and help you advance your career. Everyday is exciting at Honeywell.
cons: Still struggles to move quickly on some areas in terms of decision making maybe due to the size and the way the organization has grown over the years. This is changing and the new behaviors are expected to bring in a sense of urgency and ability to go quickly from ideation to execution.

review_title: Very poor management and disasterous work/life balance
pros:
Good opportunities for diverse work and changes of position. Due to constant changes and transformations and high number of people leaving there is number of open positions and it's possible to change teams and work in different areas and so broaden your knowledge. 
Good salary.
cons:
Work/life balance is catastrophic.  Due to banned home office, work across timezones and heavily understaffed teams the work stress and demands are enormous and exhausting.  Lack of planning for tasks and activities lead to inefficiency and frustration from unsatisfying work results.  

Constant changes in organization and teams lead to instability and lack of moral  (I had 5 different team leads in 1 year).  Promoted leaders often does not have leadership skills so teams are falling apart and people are leaving.  

Management does not care about keeping good people with skills and experience. More important is location and costs, so there is high number of cheap unqualified people without potentials.

job_title: PPC Analyst in Kansas City, MO
pros: Honeywell is by far and away the most stable environment I've ever worked in.  There is plenty of opportunity and exposure to move around.  Hours are incredibly flexible presenting excellent work/life balance.  Base pay is above average, but the benefits package lacks creativity and depth.
cons:
The company is managed with an iron fist, though there is ample opportunity, you cannot transfer unless you have been in your current position for 18 months, which is incredibly excessive.  If you have enough cache with your manager, you can get an exemption, but that has EEOC violation written all over it, so the exemptions are likely to go away soon.

Ideas for improvement don't go anywhere unless you're a manager.  Manager's only care about their own pet projects, even when they are worthless.  The company spends far too much time examining low impact avenues like onboarding, and doesn't improve actual productivity much.

pros: 401K, Honeywell swag (freebies), fair pay, and this company does more than most to take care of employees.
cons: There are as many bad apples as good on the factory floor.  Some of the co-workers bully and get catty.  It creates a hostile work environment.  HR matters are entirely self service and done online.  It is tedious to get questions answered or errors corrected.  Leadership seems to be spread too thin to provide adequate direction and assistance.  I've worked here 3 weeks and have seen the "HR generalist"  only once, and she was 15 minutes late.  She spoke three sentences to me, at most, and never seems to be at work.  If you aren't already a HR professional, you have to learn how to be one quickly.

review_title: Not recommended for young engineers, women and minorities
pros: You can achieve a good work-life balance in general. If you have a compelling interest outside of work like raising your kids or a favorite hobby, that's significantly more important than your career, it could be a great place to work.
cons: There is no planned growth in the company in the foreseeable future. In the past few years attrition has been necessary to meet financial goals. Consequently, opportunities for career expansion are currently very limited. Honeywell is a rather bureaucratic, top heavy organization. The culture is not very supportive toward younger engineers, and is especially skeptical of women and minorities. Networks tend to form around, cater to and promote dominant people groups. On several occasions the identical professional opinion, delivered in the same words, was received very differently when presented by myself (a minority woman) as compared to a white male counterpart. I was not given the same opportunites as my male counterparts even when these responsibilities were a part of the job description I interviewed for. Performance reviews can be a joke. Your department manager can highly commend you for something and your manager can recommend improvement in the same area in your review separately without batting an eyelid. Creative licence in performance reviews with no factual basis has surprisingly few consequences.

pros: The stock price has gone up.  Seems to be a good place to work if you are in Sales or Marketing and have access to a spouse's health insurance benefits.
cons:
There is a decided effort to shift engineering jobs to "emerging regions", which is management speak for "low cost".  As engineers have quit, their positions get shifted to China or India.  It doesn't matter that the foreign engineers are less than half as capable!  

This, along with cutting out Vision Insurance last year, Dental Insurance this year, and no raises in 2 of the last 4 years  make this a miserable place to work.  In the last 5 years they've eliminated the pension for new employees, reduced the 401k match for everyone, and ruined the benefits to the point where it's almost cheaper to get un-subsidized insurance through the exchange.

Lastly, the culture is very much "do as I say, not as I do".  I've had someone from management question me over the ethics of taking a USB Flash drive as a gift from a vendor, and then have the same person accept multiple smart watches from another vendor.

pros: Good place to learn. Decent pay and benefits although they are declining.
cons:
The personal touch at Honeywell Aerospace is gone and employees are a number rather than an asset. In 2016 we have taken pay cuts and unpaid furlough week off every quarter. As people leave they do not back fill and we have had 2 layoffs in the 1st 3 quarters of the year while the stocks do great and leadership gets their bonuses. The company continually cuts project and site funding needed to improve quality on rejected hardware or meet customer investigation commitments.

Those of us left are expected to do more with less and cover the job responsibilities of those that have left or been laid off. Years ago, this was a great place to work, but not anymore. We are losing many talented people as they choose to seek employment elsewhere due to all of the changes and cuts.

review_title: Lot of negativity flowing in this company for last six months
pros:
1. Many projects from aviation to intrusion system to CAS to device to Home automation.
2. Compensation is competitive and for high performers there is no limit.
3. Good peers and sometime there is some learning
cons:
1. Lot of legacy style of software programming
2. Not much to learn as a career growth
3. Management is biased to certain employees.
4. No work from home policy even in difficult situations
5. HR policies are years-old
6. Mangers are not by choice but by chance, due to lack of qualified managers.
7. Huge reshuffle happened in the last one year from top management to senior engineer.
8. Completely a maintenance of the coding

review_title: Interesting work but the most incompetent leadership ever!
job_title: Software Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
* Stable work.
* Good pay for engineers.
* Company has good potential only if management would get out of the way.
* If you know the right people, career advancement opportunities can be had.
cons:
* No telecommuting.
* Work 42 hours; get paid for 40 -- not a true salaried job either.
* Tier 3 management lacks focus and vision.  More effort put into buzzwords and process than product.
* Vacation doesn't roll over.
* Senior management can be found policing employees to make sure they use handrails, ensuring staff meets safety goals with silly "near miss" program, and with radar guns in the parking lot.
* Technology incompetent managers.
* HTSI COS has documented the path to excellence is through "changing employee behavior", very top down and oppressive.
* Hardware-centric leadership forces 1980s process and manufacturing principles on software developers.

pros:
1. Job security. Ok, till you work for less at least...
2. constant salary. You will get what is mentioned in your offer.
3. Kind of flexible timings. But you need to bill at least 8 hours per day.
4. Work from home allowed depending on project.
cons:
1. Struck with old technologies. 
2. HTSL is like a service wing of parent company. So here you will find all services company policies not a single product company kind of feeling.
3. Managers sees you as just a resource who ever you are; engineer, architect, manager even... A billable resource just as in services company
4. Yes boss culture internally as well as with US people.
5. Way too much non value added work in the name of HOS. You end up making excels and ppts  more than writing or designing.
6. Way toooo hierarchial
7. If the US bosses find that some TCS or somebody is doing for less dollars than you, you might not get any further work. That's the treatment.

review_title: Interesting Work but Worst. Leadership. EVER.
job_title: Aerospace Product Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Salary is acceptable. Projects I've worked on have been multi-disciplinary, technically challenging, and overall interesting to work on.
cons: The leadership is tanking this company. I never knew this level of low morale was even possible. Most attribute it to the insatiable greed of the outgoing CEO. He is trying to ensure his retirement comfort through the furloughs, layoffs, reduction in benefits, salary freezes, etc., that have been going on for years now. The company is doing well, but he is milking every dollar for the bottom line he can with these unsustainable hardships on the employees. I can't imagine there has ever been a company that has cared less about their employees.  Also, management cares more about the number of overtime hours you put in, rather than any output of value or quality of work. This contributes to a terrible work culture and general lack of work-life balance.

pros:
Honeywell got lot of market and really very good company in terms of brand but when it comes to Pune, it is really worst and experience is un believable.
 - Collage campus like buildings
 - Co-workers and their support
 - Campus gym ( 150 rupee only per month)
 - Good parking (ohh, really ? )
 - Cafetaria 
 - Best for people who wants to settle and don't want any growth in their career
cons:
- Management and their attitude
 - Time maintaining : While company tells that it follows flexibility in time, management changes perhaps they have their own rules on timing. Ex: One of the manager(my manger) defined his own rule says that: reporting people should come before manager comes to office and should leave office after manager leaves office
 - Least priority on work people do: Managers told that, "we are paid to do the work", how rash he is ?
 - Worst perks and not at all good place
 - Not a best place for people who want to see their career development

review_title: Great Performance-based Company with plenty of opportunity
job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
-lots of opportunity to get diverse experience and move up in the company quickly
-Currently transforming into a software industrial company which is an exciting transition to be apart of.
-Lots of support in your first 30 days.
-Supporting products that really make a difference.  You can be proud everyday you walk into work.
-Management is competent and supportive. I feel valued and heard on a daily basis.
cons:
-Many facilities are outdated and in desperate need of renovations (they are investing in fixing this).
-Work-life balance is not a strong focus point within the company culture. It really falls on the employee to establish this "line in the sand". Although I have not had a problem with work/life balance in my role, it is something I hear many people discuss as the biggest weakness to Honeywell's culture.

pros: Diversity, Interesting projects, reasonable training
cons: Bad environment to work for

pros:
Honeywell provides it's employees with a great benefits package, including health, dental, and a vision plan. They also match 50% of 401(k) contributions, which changes to 100% after 5 years. Honeywell provides regularly scheduled reviews, which help you know where you are standing within your department, and how you can improve. 

While I mention it as a downside as well, due to Honeywell's size, there are many, many opportunities for advancements and career path changes. You have the opportunity to do pretty much any job role you want, if you work hard enough.
cons: Honeywell is a massive company, and it can be frustrating to accomplish seemingly simple tasks due to the trail of red tape and procedures that need to be followed. There can also disparity between treatment for different band level employees.

pros: Honeywell is a huge corporation with over 120,000 employees worldwide, so things tend to vary by division and location. They are a process oriented organization, and provide a significant amount of training, pretty good benefits, and exposure to world class technology in many cases. I believe that executive management is competent, and leading the company in the right direction.
cons: Because of its size, you sometimes feel like a cog in a giant wheel, where the quarterly earnings are all important. They will cut quickly to make projected numbers, without much regard for the long term. Much of HON is a manufacturing driven organization, and has a hard time truly understanding some of their service based businesses. There can also be competition in the marketplace between various HON divisions. Although they claim to take an objective approach, if you are in a company acquired by HON, leave quickly, as they will gut it and put their own people in place (even as they say they won't).

job_title: Project Manager in Des Plaines, IL
pros: While my time at Honeywell was limited, you can tell that employee development and career advancement was an important part of Honeywell-- from the SMART review system to the employee training/skills development programs--you could tell that it was an integral part of the company. They also offer and in some ways promote changing positions within the company through their internal job search system.
cons: Unfortunately for me, the opportunities to continue to work at a great company was cut short due to their unwillingness to allow for remote work/telecommuting--even though many of the projects that I would manage would be at remote locations (e.g. - not in the home office) and spent most of my time communicating with people on the phone of via Lync around the world.  In my humble opinion, this type of position could very well be conducted from almost anywhere, especially with current technological advancements.

review_title: Team Lead, Cutting Room, or Sewer
pros: The only pro for having this job is that you have a job.  It's an ok position if you love endless mandatory overtime and low pay with stressful times.  Yes, you can get hired on and get lost in the crowd, but you have very little chance to excel.
cons: Mandatory overtime, (50-60 hrs a week),  very low pay for the responsibilities they make you responsible for.  hourly rates are like 8.00 an hour aprox. many many people do not speak English so you are faced with the stress associated with such a divers culture you want to scream at times.  They will listen to you try to better the place but it will go undone and all the new things they implement seems to last less than 6 months.

pros:
- Good Technical exposes
- Development is good
cons: - Firing anytime without intimation

pros: Flexible work schedule is a major plus. In my group, we are allowed to work different hours, so long as our yield is met, and advance notice is given. My direct management is generally available and willing to help when direction is needed.
cons:
I don't think that executive management is really looking out for the employee. Pay cuts were given to employees, but not to the executive management. Throughout the various townhall meetings, you get the distinct impression that you are being told one thing, but that the actions will soon be something else. 
The processes in place for almost every activity can be a real headache to get through. It can be discouraging to see simple tasks take weeks or even months, due to a "process"

pros: Great Industries they are in, Good to Fair Products, Great Opportunities if given the chance,  Desperately need great talent so if you are talented, you will shine.  If you are mediocre, very compliant, stay fit, do nothing innovative,  and tell Upper Management what they want to hear you will succeed here.
cons: Below Average Industry Benefits,  Masters at Cutting not Growing, Stock is vastly overpriced, Double Standards abound, Cut so much staff-most hardworking employees are overtaxed with little support,  Less Staff than 5 years ago,  Few Subject Matter Experts left,  No Accountability for Engineering and Upper Management,  Far too much turnover especially with the most talented and proven staff.   SPS is the worst performing Group and that's where Darius came from which should tell anyone especially stockholders.

job_title: Product Security Engineer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I really liked the people I worked with and some of the work was interesting.
cons: HR and IT is horrible. I put my resignation in February 8 and HR did not put it into the system until March 4. They paid me extra because of that. Now they want the money back. OK no problem. But when they sent me notifications via paper mail, they looked like a scam so I ignored it. I finally, after the 3rd notice, called them and asked for more details. They sent the reply via email to the wrong email address. I called them again after not hearing from them. They said they sent it via email and sent it again.  After getting it, I sent an email asking to set up payments but they already sent it over to a collection agency. IT is not much better. I had a computer problem (windows config problem) and they had to re-image the computer, but they did not backup my files, they backed up the Windows directory. Luckily I did not lose too much. I had to acquire a external hard drive to backup my files, just in case. These are only a few examples of the problems.

pros:
Secure job. They won't fire anybody no matter how bad they are.

Good vacation and holiday policy.

Management is very good at allowing time off when needed. (see the first thing)
cons:
Processes, processes, Processes. Processes are more important than production and keeping the cost down. You spend more time keeping up with processes than engineering and manufacturing hardware.

There are 4 stages of a company. One, creation. Two, growth. Three sustain. Four, decline. Honeywell is definitely in the 4th stage. The problem is the management structure is so large that by the time you get high enough up the chain where 2 groups have a common manager that it is such a small problem to that manager that nothing ever gets fixed. The groups are separated and work in a vacuum removed from actually being responsible for cost so much that they don’t care if a process cost more money. It’s whatever it takes to make their job easier.

There is very little chance for advancement. Promotions are very few and far between if at all. Many people have worked for over 20 years without a promotion.

Frustration from work environment and lack of growth have sucked the life out of the people. They are like zombies trying to put in their time until they can retire.

review_title: Running place to ground. Fake leaders. Layoffs. Demotions.
pros: Big brand. Large portfolio. Diversified Technologies. Innovation and process. Fortune 100. #illusion. #shareholdervalue. #stockprice. #goodfromoutside
cons: #ReductionInForce #RIF You cannot make up the stuff that goes in Honeywell. HON only cares about operating income and #shareholder value. #Layoffs are a norm. This place is a #circus. You are constantly seen as a number. If you are a #block5, be worried. You are seen as #average. They keep telling everyone an 'A' player from outside is typically a #block5. You will be on #RIF. Everyone is constantly #worried. We keep getting told that HON has to do the #rightthing. #shareholdervalue. #donotrecommend. #50hourworkweek. #7amConferenceCalls.

review_title: Absolutely awful since day 1 with Intelligrated.
pros: Absolutely none. Paychecks are always on time?
cons:
-Piss poor leadership; bad leaders in positions they should not be in. 
- Zero growth despite excellent reviews and/or feedback. Leaders seem to want yes men in higher up positions for further org control  
- raise cuts, paycuts /furloughs
- slave labor hours to support poor engineering quality/lack of a stable product.
      - weekends weekends weekends. You need to work       every single weekend. Even when off site but mostly on site. Prepare to miss out on your personal life as long as you work here. 
-Blame falls on the wrong individuals for a product that just isn’t there / engineering isn’t there. 
- Software engineering is extremely political rendering it impossible to maintain a schedule or customer satisfaction 
- no visibility on where the product is and where it’s going. Company almost seems as though they want their employees to be on an absolute need to know basis. Probably because everyone knows that folks don’t stay much longer than a year.

review_title: Honeywell Aerospace is good. Each facility is not the same though
pros: Honeywell is a great company to work for. There are plenty of opportunities to grow in a company this size. The technology that the Aerospace side of the house has is fun and exciting.
cons: Learn as much as you can about each facility. They are NOT the same. The Redmond facility is all about who you know and how close you are. If you have "grown-up" there you will do just fine. If you are an outsider coming in, you may find the "Good-Ole-Boy" club hard to deal with and a hindrance when issue resolution is in order. The management is focused on dollars more so than the employees. There needs to be a balance and the employees are not afraid to tell you their feelings of neglect.

review_title: Just a Minion with a Number - HBS/HPS
pros: As long as you're not an Admin Assistant I would say that salaries are competitive. Also if you are a senior manager then you are treated with respect.
cons: There is no work-life balance for most. Leadership is self-serving. Union employees fair better. If you have the courage to stand up for yourself you are labled a trouble maker. HR is more about protecting the company then doing what is best for employee. If you have medical needs, Honeywell does not work with you. Anything you say will be used against you. Performance bonus is a joke and is based on your popularity with your manager.

pros:
The technical environment at Honeywell is great at placing employees to their strengths and allowing them to learn and excel. There was very little in the way of dead weight, everyone was good at something, and I learned a ton from working with the engineers there.

Pay was great. 401k is good. Vacation is typical. And the health care plan is a joke.
cons:
On the other end, management is rather out of touch. Company policy was that there were no promotions, you simply had to apply for another job if you wanted to move up. Talent retention is abysmal with regards to younger employees for a variety of reasons that they refuse to acknowledge. Ebeneezer Scrooge runs this company. And they still use the old Jack Welch employee ranking system which pits employees against each other. 

Mandatory overtime even if work is slow.

I recommend working here for a few years, but don't expect to make a career here.

review_title: Acclimation to toxicity is not healthy
pros:
-Decent starting salary 
-Interesting work
-Unique opportunities to develop technical skills
-Good co-workers, few good managers 
-Walled cubicles (down to preference)
-OT pay
-Commuting to work is accessible, traffic around area is not bad at all
cons:
Where to begin....

-Toxic, high stress work environment
-Abysmal, and i mean ABYSMAL workplace morale 
-Literally no work/life balance. No clubs, societies, recreational leagues. No relationships outside of work.
-Lack of accountability, culture is heavily influenced by shifting blame to someone else 
-Favoritism and nepotism are clear to see
-Very top heavy; these positions are occupied by some seriously incompetent individuals
-Extremely poor project planning 
-Not a single program success in the last little while. Profit margins are still coming from products designed years ago by people who have long left for greener pastures. Lack of success comes from terrible decisions made at the highest level
-Heavily lacking a young workforce due to their inability to retain young, fresh talent
-Many half-baked and failed endeavors to improve workplace morale
-Attrition has been high the last few years, especially under current leadership. 
-No cafeteria serving food
-Poor benefits (benefits were reduced recently)
-Layoffs are an annual occurrence
-Furloughs happen every few years 
-Site leadership legitimately do not care about you, and value the worth of the dollar more than any contributions their employees make - i.e no loyalty

review_title: Not A Good Place to Work
pros:
The company pays their employees very well
If you like structure, Honeywell has their HOS (Honeywell Operating System) culture that they shove down your throat at every opportunity.  It is so rigid that you have to carry a pamphlet with your daily/weekly duties with you everywhere you go and mark off what/when you performed the task so management can review it when they ask for it to make sure you're doing your job.
cons:
Benefits stink.  High deductible insurance policy with HSA, 401K after 1 year of employment, very little time off for new employees.
Company lacks the value of time management skills for their employees.
Honeywell loves meetings. If something is going wrong, there's a meeting for that.  If that's going wrong, need to have another meeting for that.  They get so caught up in meetings that there is no time to actually work on what you're supposed to be doing to make sure things get accomplished/fixed.
Management acts aggressively towards their employees and expects them to work 12 hour days and gives employees a difficult time if they don't come in "early" or stay "late".

job_title: Product Manufacturing Engineer in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
There is a lot of freedom to work on what you
Pay is pretty decent
cons:
The tier system used is archaic at this point and leads to a lot of pointless meetings.  
Work life balance was awful, if you proved you were useful you would be forced to work 50+ a week while the useless employees could skate by at 40.
Do not expect a title change, you have to apply to higher positions and compete with internal and external candidates and if you do not get the position you get locked out for up to 6 months.
Due to the large rate of people quitting the team was always understaffed  since the company will only post positions at the new year
You have to watch an insane amount of training videos and due to the metrics of leadership these can take priority over line down issues

review_title: A regressive career  option for Senior IT Technical Roles.
pros: If attending meetings and not doing any actual work is your objective then this is the best organization.
cons:
Pathetic and nasty management, HR Folks and  work culture. 

Too much dependence on vendors for technical work.

Most of the significant architectural decisions taken while evaluation 
software platforms are taken by Business leaders influenced by vendors. 

Incompetent in-house technical architects and technical leadership.
Most of the technical people  have been promoted due to their loyalty (number of years in organization) rather than capabilities or have  joined here as last resort.

HR does everything else other than the what their job  requires.including encouraging colleagues and managers to spy on their own employees and inform them about personal private life of colleagues.

God forbid you decide to resign from this organization, since you are fed up and see no future for yourself in the organization, you will be harassed to no end  for getting your relieving letter and even  try to find ways to claw back some  part of your final settlement.

pros: Engineering, Reputation and Stability. If you like working at a strong and reputed engineering corporation, Honeywell is good place to be. Honeywell is a very structured environment, and very diversified, which means if you are lucky you could end up contributing to different projects.
cons:
Too many managers. Compensation is average at best. Bureaucratic Management, who's only claim to fame is that they have stuck around long enough to get promoted. The work environment is very very officious and boring. No-one jokes around, there are meeting very early in the morning. Projects usually run past deadlines due to mismanagement. 
No strong organizational commitment to innovation, but then that's the case with a lot of companies working in the same field as Honeywell.

job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Brookfield, WI
pros: Great product. Loyal Customers. Pay is good. Full Compliment of benefits. Company car, laptop, blackberry, expense account. Tremendous breathe of technology and expertise to draw from.
cons: Management totally incompetent. No knowledge of marketplace, competitors and what really will help get product sold. Outrageous quotas in some instances as much as 5000% growth expected from one year to the next. Very bureaucratic structure of company made it difficult to get the simplest things accomplished. Tremendous turnover. Terrible Customer Service caused unbelievable anger and hostility by Customers towards Company. Management would make promises to Customer's face and break them. No tact or diplomacy from upper Management. President stated at meeting "The Reps. are over paid $80K is to much for just getting up in the morning, washing your face, visiting a Customer and giving out your card". Management felt we should not attempt to "PARTNER" with Customers. But treat them purely as Customers who are only worth our time if they are buying. Product launches are half thought out and ill conceived.

pros: Great work environment; Managers won't breath down your back every day; Lots of knowledge to be gained both from text and co-workers.
cons: Low salaries compared to the market. I have only been here a few years but have already seen a handful of people leave for a different company (sometimes competitors) solely because they offered them a lot more.

review_title: Worst company culture - Honeywell Sensing and Productivity Solutions
pros: Large company with a wealth of resources
cons:
Working for or with Honeywell is a detriment to your health.  Honeywell makes its money on acquisitions - they buy up profitable companies, consolidate and outsource jobs, steal their technologies, move to the next company and repeat...They report a profitable bottom line from the acquisitions, but internally they are cutting benefits, scrutinizing every minute expense, shutting down facilities and laying off employees.  

Honeywell absolutely does not care about its employees.  They do not promote anyone to a manager without a Bachelors degree and director level promotions require a Masters degree.  It's an unwritten rule, but they write their job descriptions to rule out people they don't want.  As a result, employees with tenure from acquired companies are often overlooked and discarded.  Employees are expected to work long hours, with unrealistic expectations/metrics, and are stressed to the max because of the workloads and demands.  These expectations are not limited to their employees, but also to vendors that work for them and want their business. If you're looking for work-life balance, this is NOT the company for you.

review_title: Have room to spread my wings for sure.
pros:
I'm part of the HCE division here at Honeywell and definitely feel like as long as what I'm working on aligns directly with the overall strategy for the business, I have all the room and support from leadership in the world to go make it happen.

They are definitely allowing me to be a # Futureshaper and I'm not just saying that...no BS. Honeywell is a great company. Externally you might not be able to see the revenue but trust me its a good place to be and I'm enjoying it so far.
cons: Something else I'm working on is better aligning the day to day operations of my particular business. There are issues with the same function for example being done differently in different parts of the world or leadership not having the visibility they need.  There are things like this that need to be corrected which will make life easier for everyone once resolved and I'm working on helping address these issues. It's not that it's so bad but once the kinks get worked out everything will flow much better.

review_title: Have room to spread my wings for sure.
pros:
I'm part of the HCE division here at Honeywell and definitely feel like as long as what I'm working on aligns directly with the overall strategy for the business, I have all the room and support from leadership in the world to go make it happen.

They are definitely allowing me to be a # Futureshaper and I'm not just saying that...no BS. Honeywell is a great company. Externally you might not be able to see the revenue but trust me its a good place to be and I'm enjoying it so far.
cons: Something else I'm working on is better aligning the day to day operations of my particular business. There are issues with the same function for example being done differently in different parts of the world or leadership not having the visibility they need.  There are things like this that need to be corrected which will make life easier for everyone once resolved and I'm working on helping address these issues. It's not that it's so bad but once the kinks get worked out everything will flow much better.

pros: Honeywell is a stable company, thee is a lot of career and knowledge growth opportunities. Opportunity to work on leading edge Aerospace R&D programs. Rich multicultural environment.
cons: Too much red tape everywhere - some of that is caused by the regulations (FAA/EASA) but the most worrisome is the over processing - there is a process and policy and rules and paperwork for anything and sometimes people just rather give up that to waste time on bureaucracy (eg. it takes 12 signatures and 6 months of time to get approved purchase of an item worth >$2500 for your project). Matrix based organization - in the end people hide behind this and refrain from making decisions or taking actions. You have to use so called "influential power" to get anything done - but some people are just resistant against this and do not help you no matter how important it is, what is at stake.

review_title: If I was provided with more training I would have enjoyed the job.
pros: Honeywell has pretty good benefits. You will not work weekends, it's Monday through Friday. You will receive an aggressive employee discount within the branch.
cons: I've never worked for a company that provides very minimal amount of training. Vendors would rarely come in to train, if they came in it was to meet a "visit quota" and leave very shortly after dropping off flyers. If you're new to the security industry this job will be a huge challenge for you. Also, you will take numerous calls a day. There's very minimal branch traffic as ADI provides drop shipping and overnight shipping. It's also team commission, so if you're use to holding your own destiny, you now rely on your team to sell and seek out new business.  There's absolutely no way that they could structure commissions on an individual level however due to the size of their customers accounts.

pros:
-Interesting work
-Decent travel mix
-Texh forward company with good technical infrastructure (SFDC, Tabluea, customer tools, etc.)
-Some Telecommute flexibility, though you have to fight for it.
- great advancement opportunity if you are a female: upper management mandates female grooming and promotion
- great if you live in a low cost of living country
cons:
- Not much opportunity for advancement in this direct path, but there are many potential branches like sales.
- Comparatively low salary, especially given the on call and after hours expectations.
-Phone system is a nightmare that tracks every second of your day.
- Airline operators are demanding 
- much less promotion opportunity if you are a male.
- prone to layoffs, especially as employees age.
- general feel that the company is 'cheap', where anything that can be is outsourced and upper management hordes the profits

pros: Supposed to provide a secure work environment - not that I have really seen it
cons:
Very large & slow moving bureaucratic elephant. Moves one degree at a time. Everything boils down to metrics and traffic lights on Excel Spreadsheets. One can create magic with numbers and distort facts if you are smart enough. 

Management ineptitude is layered under jargon's of HOS, MOS or HSE - all the same. Onsite is absolutely out of bounds for folks in Support Functions or Non - Sales roles. Every year Q4 comes with the predictable freeze in hiring and travel, though this is conveniently worked around for senior management. Visiting India is a junket tour for them under the guise of "important business meetings". 

HR is virtually non - existent and works in cahoots with the local management. No independent or employee centric decision making. Rules and processes are bended and twisted to suit convenience.

Work ethos on the floor resembles the culture of a typical BPO/Call centre with multiple support centres being established.

review_title: Excellent company with incredible resources, expertise, and unique position in the petrochemical industry
job_title: Senior R&D Engineer/Scientist in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Great learning environment, cutting edge resources, great people to work with tremendous knowledge base. UOP really has a lot of opportunities and a nurturing environment, but you have to want it. There are a lot of incentive-based opportunities available that will get you noticed. Although owned by Honeywell, UOP has its own company culture, very tight-knit group of scientists and engineers. Having Honeywell as the parent company has its advantages however (stock options). Overall a great work experience.
cons: Honeywell has somewhat diluted the company culture, many obscure meetings and company philosophies, pay is a little on the lower side, you do have to work long hours to get recognized, and everyone is overworked. People tend to stay in their roles so advancement is somewhat limited.

review_title: Resistance is futile.  You will be assimilated.  If you company is targeted for acquisition....RUN!
pros: 401K program is good.  Vacation time is good
cons:
Process, process, process.  That good 401K plan still is not back up to full match since it was cut during the recession.  I am always so busy that I do not fully enjoy my vacation time worrying about the things I need to be doing at work.  So much for the pros.

Our CEO goes on media outlets talking about how the US needs more engineers, but the mandate is no new hires in the US.  Hypocrite.  Our site is asked to grow by rather large amounts each year.  We are doing it, but no additional help.  The production workers have been working unsustainable amounts of overtime for far too long.  Everyone you bump into (including myself) looks like the company has broken them.

review_title: Things have changed over the last 10 years but it is still a good place to work
pros:
Many terrific people who work very hard at their jobs. 
A good place to be challenged on several levels.
You are given the opportunity to grow as your experience level grows.
cons:
Some business groups within the org. are too concerned about having a body that lives local to HQ and has an MBA versus actually hiring the right person for the position. Now those groups are at a point where product management and engineering have no experience/knowledge of our business and build products they want versus what the market requires. 
Too many processes, example - to roll out NPI generally takes 2 years (and that is using the Agile engineering process).
Benefits continue to slip. Over the past 10 years we have gone from a company that took care of its employees to a culture of cut costs and increase margins so we can boost the stock price so our CEO and Co-Chairmen can make 200x the average employee salary. There is a balance point that needs to achieved.

review_title: Run away and don't look back!!!
pros: Some good people. Great engineers and maintenance people. I learned a lot about process analysis and problem solving.
cons: Benefits are horrible now, cost cutting always comes at the employees expense. Upper management has ridiculous expectations. Management in my facility had the most turn over I've ever seen at any job. No work/life balance. I hated being micro-managed from some upper management that was 2000 miles away and understood the process only on paper and none of them have a clue as to what's really going on. I met some of the dumbest people with degrees that I wouldn't trust to make me a big mac correctly. Lazy employees get rewarded, hard working employees are expected to pick up their slack with no reward. Worst "raises" I've ever seen.

review_title: A company that slowly crushes the workers’ spirit.
pros: The people but they’re all quitting or walking out. Also, the flex time.
cons: This company does not care about a person. They pile work on you meant for multiple people, offer no help nor guidance, expect you to get it all completed in a day, and they simply do not care. They only care about money and nothing more. It is open environment which means you have ZERO privacy, no desk space, and as each coworker breaks down in tears you cannot console them without bring a tremendous amount of attention. So to give them some kind of privacy, you’re forced to ignore them. 80% of workers are contractors which means ZERO benefits and because you will be a contractor that means you are not allowed to participate in ANY UOP Honeywell company activities. No matter how appealing this place looks visually, it truly is not. It WILL break your spirit and they don’t care, all they will do is drive you to quit by setting you up for failure which they can then fire you; or, they flat out fire you. Like they did with a former colleague a week before his retirement (he’d been there for almost 20 years.) If you have any self value, don’t work here.

review_title: A company that slowly crushes the workers’ spirit.
pros: The people but they’re all quitting or walking out. Also, the flex time.
