Benefits are getting cut every year.   Management incentive cut 50% for band 4's under Director.  Constant nickel and dimming employees on benefits is getting old. 

Design and development processes are cumbersome.

pros: none i could find in Madurai honeywell
cons:
The list is big 
Hikes in Madurai honeywell are very very less compared to other locations and management will give dumb and illogical reasons for that.
1. No work life balance. Not sure why they have deadlines every week. Mostly are faked by management in Madurai.
2. If you are non Tamil don't even think of joining honeywell Madurai . If you are lucky may get some good work but still is not worth taking that kind of torture.
More over people will be asking when are you leaving if non Tamil. Managers also will be in that thinking and will not give proper hike or promotion 
3. Managers in Madurai expect employees to work and stay in office late and want employees to work on weekends. I myself have never seen any Saturday or Sunday of my 1st year there.
4. In Honeywell Madurai you are mouse trapped . Can't learn something new or change the job either.it is difficult to attempt for interviews also because of the location.
5.office politics are at their peak in Madurai honeywell and you will not get any growth or opportunities unless you are local.

job_title: Senior Project Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Lots of high tech and interesting projects to work on.  Great place to learn and expand skill sets.
cons: This is a large corporation so the stock price is all they really care about.  Benefits steadily decrease over time.  They will not hesitate to have a Reduction In Force to make quarterly numbers even if this would leave projects woefully understaffed.  Employees are definitely just numbers to them.

job_title: Senior Project Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Lots of high tech and interesting projects to work on.  Great place to learn and expand skill sets.
cons: This is a large corporation so the stock price is all they really care about.  Benefits steadily decrease over time.  They will not hesitate to have a Reduction In Force to make quarterly numbers even if this would leave projects woefully understaffed.  Employees are definitely just numbers to them.

pros: The technology and product portfolio are very interesting and forward looking.
cons: For as large and profitable a company as it is, they spare expenses for people.  It is a very cost conscious penny pinching company that will 'trim the fat' at every opportunity.  There are typically travel bans every year and furloughs even though the company is making profits. Company events are basically coworkers scrounging up what they can to put on a office party or get together on their own dime.  I have never known of any large scale company events.  Medical benefits are a high deductible fiasco that causes employees to forgo medical treatment because they can't afford to go.

job_title: Aerospace Rotational Development Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: You will get to figure out what you want to do as a career by rotating through 3 different functional engineering roles, meet people your age in the program who have succeeded and moved up through the company to managerial roles, and live in a great city of young professionals excelling in life. It's a good salary (I've heard higher elsewhere in full time, non-rotational roles), but it comes with a great bonus that other companies do not offer, as well as an incredible relocation package. Typically known as the "fast-track" employees who move up quickly. Company events, food truck Friday, Dave & Busters events, Employee appreciation lunches.
cons: Unsure of where you will end up at the end of your rotation. There is typically an age gap between you and the group in your department (15-20 year gap). Health Insurance just was raised 5-8%, they lowered their contribution, got rid of vision care, and charges $1000 if you test positive for nicotine.

pros: Excellent work culture in Bracknell, UK office. Very good work to life balance. The top management is very professional and has a great vision to excel in the business and meet client demands. The department I work in generates very high profit per engineer basis mainly because it has very experienced and talented engineers in it. Work from is allowed in many cases if work is getting done within time and in budget. Several opportunities to move within departments and even within global locations of the business if one wants to grow within. Good reward scheme if one does work above and beyond normal duties.
cons: Very large organisation with already ripen kind of business so limited upside potential. Very poor pension scheme for new employees. Not many benefits to employees. Company takes very strict cost control measures if the business environment becomes little shaky. Pay wise okay could be better for deserving candidates.

review_title: Excellent Growth Potential and Purposeful Culture
job_title: User Experience Leader in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Excellent strategic plan alignment to project prioritization and role responsibilities, global travel opportunities, continuous improvement culture, well managed for growth, world-class Human Resources (HR) leadership and end-to-end thinking
cons: Benefits are not competitive, but this can be mitigated by focusing on interesting work, delivering results and excelling in Honeywell behaviors to achieve a desired standard of living.

review_title: HAIL is really hell. Worst company in my life.
pros:
1. You can leave early on 6pm
2. You will get around 30 leaves in an year
cons:
1. Master slave like treatment by Managers and Team Leads. Team lead and Managers are old with no knowledge and with so much useless attitude. 
 
2. Very few meaningless projects which will never be helpful for ur career growth. 
 
3. Salary structure is worst and they are cutting both Employee and Employer PF which is hugh because of high basic salary component. Maybe ur previous company salary will differ more than in HAIL which u will understand only after getting salary slips
 
4. Worst food quality with very high rate in canteen. Though GST rates are revised, still they are applying  18% GST on food, and u don't have any other nearby option.
 
5. No travelling facililty. Rather they are saying we will manage that or  we are working on that. 

6. No body is there to solve your concerns or problems. 

7. Overall it is not at all like an IT company. They are considering employees like workers in Factory.

pros: Was good before major hire and move from them closing Wichita and Washington.  Better company to work for when it was smaller.  Also better under other person running building.
cons: They allow fellow leads to suggest other people to be leads. Not allowing others how been there longer to move up.  Seems if you're a millenial that knows nothing and been with the company 4 weeks your a candid.  Seniority means nothing to them including knowledge.  Hiring people out of desperation due to work flow.  New person running building will try to run R/O like production.  Also do away with flex time. Will become to micro management.

pros: Competitive base salary + 401K match (HON stock)
cons: Political environment is insufferable. Zero training for new hires is apparent and is hurting the company big time. We create tons of internal issues and roadblocks because no one knows what they are doing, to the point I spend ~85% time fixing self created issues. Culture is worst I’ve ever experienced, unsure if it could be worse. Daily email traffic with internal coworkers is surprisingly combative, we virtually fight with each other. “Relationships” with suppliers are toxic and don’t exist. Executive  leadership is clearly unqualified and overpaid. If your young, talented and looking to be recognized, RUN. Management is on the moon when it comes to recognizing talent and a job well done. You will not move up unless you conform to the stupid political environment. I don’t recommend anyone to work here.

pros:
A very good Leader in India
Open work environment
Process Oriented
Till 2009 had very employee oriented policies and schemes
Very attractive place to get low end. man power intensive SW Validation jobs.
cons:
Leadership at the domain level in Aerospace was very poor, most of them are technologically incompetent and do not understand professional management of people.
Has become a old age home for a lot of  ex-defence, PSU, DRDO staff, most of whom do not have a professional outlook required in MNCs
Most programs are run like rituals without a clear focus on the end objectives.
Talent engagement is poor

pros:
If you are interested to learn you can learn by looking at the code base of non-indian developers.
If you want to enjoy you can maintain 8-5 work time ,no one can stop you.
no work pressure at all,as company needs more people than required in a team for billing model to get more revenue,so they don't care if you have work or not.
cons:
you will just get decent salary and decent hike.never ever expect extra ordinary money.
you have to beg to get work from non-indian honeywell centers,most of the time you will not do anything but you have to project to higher management that you are doing something great.
There are technical designation like tech lead,technology specialist.most of these people only do google search ,they have zero or negative knowledge.If you ask anything they might mislead you.

job_title: Manufacturing Engineering Technician in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Pay may be slightly above average. Some opportunities for movement within company.
cons: This company has the most unrealistic expectations that I have ever witnessed in my career.  It became worse everyday.  They cut about 15% of staff in 2009 and continued to not replace other retiring workers.  They outsourced labor to Puerto Rico, India, and Mexicali but the outsourcing was handled so poorly that workers at the site had to perform the tasks themselves, which added more burden.  The workload became unbearable for those left to pick up the pieces.  There is also a culture of verbal abusiveness, yelling etc.  The louder you can yell at your staff, the more likely you are to be promoted.

review_title: management did not care if you got a day off,always pushing for more,very unappreciated feeling
pros: decent  medical,dental vision,until they take it away whenever they get the chance.....
cons: 7 day work schedule ,no holidays might as well live there,so bring a cot and pillow they don't care about family they care about the parts out the door..the company hates the union and the employees don't even get anywhere near top pay, they'll bust that union so they can get 12 dollar an hour machinist...which will get them nowhere...but i did like the people i worked with and will miss them....the employees are the backbone of that company..

review_title: Drama, bad treatment of sub-contractors, major bureaucracy
job_title: Software/Business Requirements Analyst in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Long term government contracts, nice ergonomic chairs & keyboards/mouse provided to employees
cons: HTSI is actively seeking sole-source contracts & trying to get rid of all subcontractors that helped them get where they are.  As a Honeywell employee, I was appalled by how horrible managers treated sub-contractors on our same team.  People would be laid off then brought back as HTSI employees with less benefits.  Facility in Colorado Springs has no real break room or cafeteria - just a small counter to get so-so food.  Internet access is blocked even to things like Google Calendar.  Daily safety briefs are a joke.  Certain contracts require workers to work 2 hrs "green time" (unpaid) per week (even if extra work is not required).

review_title: Just OK Company to Work For
job_title: Field Technical Advisor in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Decent starting salary seeing as I was fresh out of college but slightly lower than average for Chemical Engineers. I attributed this to the fact that I'd be making a lot more while on the road and traveling and having all expenses paid for.
cons: Don't care where they send you on the road or for how long. Months (or years) spent in China could kill a person. No access to internet, poor hygiene/water available gave me health issues that continue 2+ years later, can't come home until job is over. They don't try to make sure you're there with someone your age so you even have someone to spend time with outside of work. Boss didn't care about my mental health. You're a number not a human.

pros: The company encourages promotion through taking on new roles, whether that's switching from engineering to a business role or finance to a sourcing role, once you're hired in Honeywell, you can construct your career as you like.  Promotions and new opportunities are generally secured through networking.
cons: I definitely experienced some sexism, given the demographic of the company is largely baby-boomer white males.  There is a large generational gap as well, which can be positive for ambitious young employees looking to climb into middle management, but is difficult when often times your manager is struggling to understand what drives your generation.  Benefits such as money towards grad school and 401K match only reseeded while I was employed at Honeywell.  Work/life balance is not a top priority, especially as you move up the ladder.

review_title: Once a great place to be an engineer
pros: Stable, well-performing publicly owned company.  CEO has done a good job maximizing the value to shareholders.   Good benefits but costs now being passed on to employees.
cons: Aerospace division suffers from glut of politically correct middle-managers with little talent and no vision, a functional matrix organization where no one is in charge but everyone can block progress, job deflation caused by export of real engineering work to 'high-growth' regions of the world, and hyper-focus on process improvement and project (micro) management over pragmatic engineering excellence to get results.

review_title: Good people - stock market driven short term focus
pros: Excellent engineering community. Very knowledgeable, dedicated bunch of people to work with. After working for 10+ years I am still enjoying learning from my colleagues.
cons: It is amazing to see in the aerospace  business where the products provide profits for 25+ years, management focuses on quarterly stock market appeasement policy.Isn't it interesting that misses in forecast result in employees losing their jobs but the management that makes these promises and forecast do not get penalized but get rewarded.

pros: Good local coworkers, commiserate together
cons: Mobile is a terrible city to live.  Corporate management live their lives for shareholders and stock market. Sold their souls to money. Put less qualified people in upper management that have no idea what the business or the culture is about. Work the employees to the bone with decreased pay and limited overtime but yet when corporate is asked for more positions it is declined. Looking to unionize.

pros:
Easiness to express yourself and to address your concerns, free to apply on internal jobs on your own, as long as you have at least 1,6 months within the company, otherwise only with manager approval.
Matrix Management is most of the times abroad (USA), possibility to relocate in another country, flexible working hours. A lot of good training sessions, especially the Negotiation Training ones, are the best.
cons: Local management is really bad and no inspiring people to work with, a very diverse environments where is important "who knows who", preferential treatment, if you meet the right persons you may have a really good chance to overcome yourself and become better, if not, there is a small one chance.

job_title: Senior Product Marketing Manager in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Honeywell has many divisions and the Pittsburgh office delivers voice enabled solutions for for the enterprise.  The culture in the Pittsburgh office is very inclusive with a strong technology history and focus on delivering the best customer service.  Leadership recognizes and encourages mentoring and practices career development, which is a refreshing change from the typical corporate culture.  There is a good balance between work and personal time.  

The overall Honeywell culture has a good feeling with a positive outlook, which translates into a strong bond between employees from all divisions.

The health benefits are good for families and individuals with options for coverage.  The 401k is good with a strong matching program.
cons: There is always room for improvement and the corporate culture is about fixing things that are not working.

review_title: This is the Company to Grow Your Career
pros:
Honeywell is the place to really see what world class HR looks like.  

In my years with Honeywell, I have taken on increasingly challenging roles and found them very rewarding from a personal and career perspective. Enabled by my willingness to relocate, I have enjoyed tremendous career opportunities. Business leaders across the organization truly value the HR function and how we work as an enabler.

I enjoy the leaders I work for and with and appreciate the value that Honeywell's technologies add to the world. We are careful with how we manage costs and consistently perform well as a company financially. I also value Honeywell's commitment to ethics and integrity in everything we do.
cons: As with many large organizations, bureaucracy can slow things down and stifle growth and innovation. Honeywell is actively working to improve this but should continue to do more.

review_title: Honeywell is a great place to work.  Much is expected, but much is also given.
pros: It can be difficult to get your foot in the door at Honeywell but it is worth the persistence.  So many people here have longevity of 20, 30, 40 years which is, virtually, unheard of these days.  One of the first things I noticed on my first day was that most people were smiling and some were whistling as they walked down the hall.  This is a fantastic, stable company with smart, great people. Honeywell tries to always promote from within and encourages learning, growing, and moving, laterally or upward, to improve your knowledge and gain new strengths.  The benefits are decent, although not what they once were.  Leadership is superior and they are always pushing themselves and all employees to continually improve.  Great leadership + great employees = a great company.
cons: Hours can sometimes be long, but hard work is recognized.

review_title: Employee's review of Honeywell International USA
job_title: Human Resources Manager in New York, NY
pros: HR professionals are very highly compensated at Honeywell.  Honeywell has diversified businesses which positions the company well when there is a downturn in any of their lines of business.  The CEO is a very strong leader and has done a great job to turn Honeywell around which substantially has raised the stock price.
cons: Benefits coverage is very expensive.  The plan covers preventive services only prior to meeting the very high deductible.  Also, typically, when someone gets a promotion, it means they keep their current responsibilities and take on another role.  Therefore, the workload becomes impossible and means the employee needs to work/be available almost 24/7.  They burn out many of their employees with this philosophy.

review_title: Loved working for the Company, but........
pros: Great people for the most part....I enjoyed working here and would go back.  Being an Executive Admin is what I have done for so many years.  My manager was the best, but then he retired, leaving me in the hands of the lions.  They let Admins go and make the staff try to do their jobs as well as Admin work.
cons: HR person used a confidential meeting I had with her to use against me to RIF me.  She even stated that "they" hadn't even looked at the Admins for RIF's, until I went to talk to her of some of my concerns.  Lesson learned on my part for sure.  I wasn't even on a PIP, had always gone great reviews.

review_title: Old fashion and boring company with highly demotivated employees.
pros:
Share price evolution in the last 4 years (increased from 60$ per share to 130$ per share)
Salaries are correct for the level of the people in place, but does not allow to attract real talents.
cons:
Serious lack of innovation especially in the automation (security) side of the business. Product are actually outdated before being launch due to slow product development process, poor understanding of customer needs and competitor moves
HOS (Honeywell Operating System) is considered as best in class by the senior leadership team. Reality is very different. Process are so complicated that employees barely understand them. IT infrastructure is a disaster (it is actually difficult to imagine that such a company has so little knowledge about its business).
Unstable leadership teams (2 years tenure in average for operational leaders) with on going restructuring.
 HR function is mainly doing restructuring, employees are staying in their role for years with no career progression, very old employees.
Poor customer satisfaction as a result of all the above.
No vision, no culture, no pride to work for Honeywell

review_title: Lack of integrity at every level
job_title: Lab Technician in South Bend, IN
pros: Interesting work, plethora of learning opportunities, valuable experience.
cons: Appointed management is not competent, knowledgeable, or integral in any aspect. Through the several changes in management I have been present for, this is the norm. Lab is run like an assembly line, with little effort or desire to produce reliable data for customers. General operating procedure is to make things work, figure things out, and push out results- regardless of if it is the correct way to do things. Always lacking in basic tools and equipment to conduct the most basic of daily tasks. Adjustments to testing procedures are rampant, business practices are borderline fraudulent.

review_title: No such thing as unlimited vacation
pros: Flexibility to work from home some times
cons:
Unlimited vacation - yes this is a con. Instead of “unlimited vacation” it’s your manager telling you “no you can’t use vacation to take time off for Hanukkah you can use sick time or work from home because you didn’t enter it into time work bench back in June”.  

Constant turn around in leadership who doesn’t know what they are doing. Biased manager who talks in circles around you and never provides direct answers. Our HR person is in managers pocket so can’t really go to him for anything. Feels like there’s nowhere to turn for any hr matters.

review_title: Time to Train Your Foreign Replacement
pros: Good Benefits and interesting work.  You can make time for golf in the afternoon.  Working people are nice and honest but if they hace an office with walls they can not be trusted.
cons: Honeywell will work you until all your energy is gone,  pump you for information and outsource your job.  They will have you train your foreign replacement before they lay you off.  The company has tremendous knowledge that is constrained by overhead rules.   These rules like sending you a reporting on indirect spending and telling you to review the report to waste more time is classic.  If you find a problem with it and report it, it costs you more.

review_title: Great learning opportunity but be aware of negatives.
job_title: Development Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
-Very rigorous technical projects.
-Exposure to all facets of oil and petrochemicals.
-Opportunities to utilize all knowledge from college.
-True chemical engineering environment.
cons:
-Most groups are overworked and pushed to the limit by management.
-Project time lines set employees up for failure by management.
-Low morale of employees due to work load and project expectations.
-Honeywell takeover has increased expectations and stress with lowering of benefits.
-UOP is dominated by a large older group of experts that are difficult to work with sometimes.

review_title: Life of R&D Senior Lab Technician at Honeywell
job_title: Lead Lab Technician in Morristown, NJ
pros: Work was good, I had a good product line to work with, and I made a difference to the customers
cons: Healthcare was terrible, Management hopped around between businesses and did not understand the businesses they were in, so they managed by spreadsheet. They never came into my lab and did not know what value anyone in the labs brought to the company. Managers did not understand the customer needs, or what our product line could do for them, and they kept wasting time with impractical projects because of it. They prevented R&D lab managers who knew the customer's processes from going to customer, and would kill good projects without ever understanding the project's value to the customer and the market. The product line made money in spite of them, not because of them. As one of my coworkers said: Too stupid to live, too big to die.

review_title: Life of R&D Senior Lab Technician at Honeywell
job_title: Lead Lab Technician in Morristown, NJ
pros: Work was good, I had a good product line to work with, and I made a difference to the customers
cons: Healthcare was terrible, Management hopped around between businesses and did not understand the businesses they were in, so they managed by spreadsheet. They never came into my lab and did not know what value anyone in the labs brought to the company. Managers did not understand the customer needs, or what our product line could do for them, and they kept wasting time with impractical projects because of it. They prevented R&D lab managers who knew the customer's processes from going to customer, and would kill good projects without ever understanding the project's value to the customer and the market. The product line made money in spite of them, not because of them. As one of my coworkers said: Too stupid to live, too big to die.

pros: Honeywell is a global Brand Name and has a diversified portfolios across many domains. So would look good on your resume.
cons:
I was in the Aerospace vertical. It sounded exciting during interview but that's about it. 
There is no domain/technical training and on the job Training means studying project documents and talking to your team mates to learn something.
No work life balance. Your job is to satisfy US parent team and your managers here ask you to bend down for everything that is being demanded without an iota of consideration for timelines or understand the complexities of the task.
You are treated like a floating resource. You will be development project one month. After that, you may be asked to work on V&V. There is no consideration for your skills.
I was hired as a developer but the only work I did was modify requirement documents with almost no involvement on the Code. 
No other benefits to the employee other than salary.

pros:
- If you are able to survive as fitest one there then you can get good salary.
- There are some good leaders also who will recognize your work
cons:
- Highly inclination towards beautiful girls, they will shower all the oppurtunity available on beauties and even these beauty icons wont work then they will be nominated for awards and all.
- Some of the middle level Managers (Dept head) are too rude and they think they are the founder of Honeywell as per their behaviour I can say this.
- Too much of time waste due to tedious process like Kaizens and HOS.

review_title: Technology driven company but they should listen to their people more.
pros: Honeywell is a technology driven company so the best thing about working for them is that you get to work with cutting edge stuff.
cons:
The Canadian arm of Honeywell is not mandated with the same focus as the American parent company, hence the direction and managment style is far different.  There is a lack of regard for the employee and their well being.  You get the impression that all that is important is the generation of revenue above personal job satisfaction.

The management staff are the definition of hypocracy.  They say what they think they have to say to make you think they have your best interests at heart but they do not.  I believe it is not a reflection of the company itself but more a reflection of the people.

review_title: Worst place I have ever worked
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: The Kansas City plant provides fairly secure employment and a reasonable work life balance
cons: The culture is a "good ole boys" network where who you know is more important than what you do.  People are more focused on who to blame rather than working together as a team.  They don't want to be put in the "elbow" (lowest 10%) and fired, so they deflect blame to protect themselves.  The Engineering group feels that they own the place.  The HR team is clueless and  measured on getting 10% of the employees fired each year.  Health insurance is horrible.  A family is out of pocket $8000 before everything is paid 100%.  Raises were non existent for 2 years and very low when you get one.

pros: Great opportunity to work on complex matters.  Great work-life balance.  Good benefits, but incredibly expensive compared to other employers.  If you just wanna punch in and out, a great place to fly low.
cons: Limited job growth and advancement opportunities. Mgmt focuses on and advances people who are good at busy work instead of core competencies. Constant harassment to participate in the Honeywell Political Action Committee with senior leadership evaluated on their enrollment success for their groups. Outcast and sidelined if you don't participate in the PAC.  Extreme degredation of benefits to "improve shareholder value." Very little innovation or thinking outside the box.

review_title: Beware if you are acquired by Honeywell
pros: Huge company, lots of opportunities if you are willing to relocate and become a minion to the executive staff - i.e. do not have your own thoughts, absorb the exec staff's and do their bidding.
cons: Too much bureaucracy, too many directors and VPs and not enough workers to get the job done. During integration, didn't bother to take the best practices of the acquired company, imposed the "Honeywell way" on top - released 50% of the program managers and sales people and assumed their existing staff could take up the load - big mistake.  Orders dropped 40% in the first year.  Reduced our compensation or froze it, and reduced bonus plan by 65%.

pros:
1.Good work place infrastructure
2. Average pay scale 
3. Average learning opportunities
cons:
1. No work life balance. Many people go home and work. Many work on weekends also. 
2. Associate managers and team lead ips don't work much. They tend to blame analyst and pressurize him and get work done rather than encouraging. Work place environment is very discouraging.
3. Most of associate managers and team lead--ips are rude. 
4. Lot of work place politics. Most of people who joined early got promoted and they are running the group based on favouritism. They run things based on whims and fancies rather than established policies.
5. Not a good place to join as a fresher. Senior team members are reluctant to train freshers and they blame the new joinee if work not done properly. Senior team members simply want to enjoy life and don't want to take responsibility to train new joinees
6. Wide disparities in pay.

pros:
- Exciting product
- Exposure to suppliers, customers, and cross-functional coworkers around the world.
cons:
- The culture of continuous improvement is admirable until you find yourself inundated trying to execute on poorly planned top-down initiatives.  
- Honeywell doesn't do very well at professional development even compared to similar aerospace companies.  
- Honeywell Aerospace has had several layoffs and furloughs over the last year and a half.  In recent years raises have not been given.  Benefits were good about 10 years ago, but have steadily declined.  Be sure to factor all of this in if you are considering an offer from Honeywell.

pros: Was promised loads when they took over the company I worked for and to begin with seemed promising.  First 2 years doing integration work was great
cons:
Claims to want to be a technology company but TUPE'd all their IT staff to a company that their IT director has a personal friendship with (golf buddies).

Was told to stop using the company slogan of "The Power Of Connected".  Can only assume it was because they are the most disconnected company ever!

If a colleague leaves don't think they will be replaced, the workload will simply be given to another member of staff, expect 2,3,4 times the amount of work after a few  years.

And huge amounts of waste on H&S policies.  Hold the handrail,  knock on the door before entering, wear gloves that don't do anything, the list goes on!  No company outside of Honeywell buys their safety equipment as it's too expensive!

Minimum possible benefits
Plenty of IT career opportunities if I moved to Bangalore

pros:
The company has a open culture, people are free to dive into any issues. The company takes care of work life balance, provides ample opportunities of fun while working
I could hardly remember any month when there was no event being organized by the company. Its ideal for people who want a balanced lifestyle.The free food facility at the cafeteria was a huge attraction to me. The HR at Honeywell is very good, they try their best to keep employees happy and resolve most of the issues with proper intervention. It looks more of a fun and learning place where people join in have some fun while working and then another day starts.
Innovation workshops are awesome feature here.
cons: Some of the employees are very mediocre ,, may be due to huge demand of heads. The promotion policies could be more flexible but  are not because of old age of company.

review_title: Honeywell, a step back in time.
pros:
-The pay is on par with industry standards for the job title
-12.5% night shift differential
-Expects their employees to become fishermen rather than relying on others
cons:
-Benefits for a company this size are pathetic
-No perks 
-Being ran by people who struggle sending emails and are terrified of technology in the workplace 
-Honeywell would rather spend money on acquisitions than improving and sustaining their current entities
-Outdated technology and the unwillingness to catch up with the competition
-Near zero HR presence
-Engineers are given too much control of the business side of running things

job_title: Project Manager, IT in Richmond, VA
pros: In my almost 20 years here (started at Allied Signal), the single most impressive attribute is the good people I work with.  Honeywell only hires the best and those that prove otherwise don't last very long.  Dave Cote is one of the best CEOs in the world and it shows in everything including our stock price and consequently, my 401k balance.
cons: No company is perfect but it is hard to come up with anything bad.  If pressed I'd say I'm concerned where our health insurance benefit is headed, it has gone downhill rapidly over the past few years.

review_title: Lots of experiments coming from manufacturing to IT are loosing the main focus of technical advancement and betterment
pros: Comparable salary with the market. Lot to learn on process and management skills. Well structured organisation and very good communication channel/protocol.
cons: Very tight schedules. Lot of management rather than technical. Lots of experiments to reduce cost and improve quality of the products but it has taken over the root of innovative products i.e., more budgeting and focusing on the technical side. Growing competencies with high end / latest technologies. Inappropriate competition between managers for cost saving which has gone to a level where they want saving irrespective of complexity/quality. the cost must reduce by some good strategies, automation, simulation, etc rather they are trying to fetch it by putting pressure on team to work extra hours and not billing it to the customer. So much to write but due to time constrain I'll end it here... as I'm still in Honeywell..

pros:
- Pay - Fair.
- 401k Company Match up to 8% - Good.
- Health Insurance & Dental - Ok.
- Time-off: Easy to take time off - Great.
- Overtime: Can get plenty, but on volunteer basis mostly - Great.
cons:
- Big change over in supervisors and management in the past 5 years. Reviews are not consistent. Raises are not fair due to this big changeover.
- Not much opportunity for advancements, but growing. Will be in the next 3 years.
- No incentives for training others.
- Raises are based off of your behavior, and not so much experience, knowledge, or productivity. More knowledge and cross-training does not improve raises. Raises are base lined for the majority of processors.

job_title: Human Resources Analyst in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: The organization has a global scope, so you can learn whatever you want related to HR. Also, being in HR you can understand how the business decisions are taking based on people.
cons: The company needs to enhance the management culture since Leadership team often forgets that the organization is mainly built by people and they are only focused on get results regardless the human factor. Although, the company is global, all the main decision and plans are taken and considered only in the US region, sometime it looks like the other regions are not important for making decision.

review_title: Great place if you want to get paid to twiddle your thumbs for years on end.
pros:
If you’re looking for somewhere to get paid while doing nothing until you’re retired, look no further, this is the place for you. 
Nice coffee machine.
The lady in the deli is best thing about this place and her food is pretty good. Security guards are pretty nice people too.
cons:
Managed Services Security Center is a crap show. 
Not a true cyber security department.
Security practices are so terrible and nonexistent, it feels unethical at times.
Managers have no proper managerial training.
There’s no urgency to actually handle customer issues, since the company is paid up front. 
A lot of favoritism, but not much work to go around. 
There’s no career advancement here, work is really limited so there’s a lot of thumb twiddling.
There are permanent work from home opportunities under the table, but you must be a favorite for this opportunity.

review_title: Cool project, but be extremely careful
pros: Team and project is great for engineering work, it's a good, highly capable team.  First level management is friendly and easy to work with.
cons: For SW engineering, their pay is not competitive with the rest of the northern Colorado area, they tried to make this up with "bonuses" and verbal promises.  Since then I moved on due to a more competitive paying job, but after I gave my notice, security and HR has completely switched from a positive relationship to 100% negative.  Without going into details, they have released a really rough collection agency on me, this has been very painful and I believe they are completely wrong in what they are asking for.  The HR people are borderline scary the second you give notice, be extremely careful what you sign...be extremely skeptical of what they verbally promise...in my opinion, they are NOT like your standard employer.  Overall, I would completely avoid this place, it's just not worth the risk.

review_title: Stable company but workforce turnover rate is too high.
job_title: Systems Engineer III in Toronto, ON
pros:
- large company
- stable work
- colleagues are knowledgeable
- ok pay
If you want a stable job and don't mind doing the same thing over and over again, then it's ok...
cons:
- poor benefits - employees need to pay a portion yet still don't cover much
- too many contractors in the workforce leading to too much turn over of coworkers
- only hire contractors and then contractors can apply for full-time positions later, but at that point you loose bargaining power, because you are already working for them.
- little to none employee development.  Managers tend to put you in exact same tasks in different projects to save time and training.

review_title: Don't fell for Honeywell brand name
pros:
Work from home. 
Good if you are on business teams ACS, AERO, PMT. 
Good for freshers. Salary offered is very high even if you don't deserve that much salary
cons:
Politics. Manager can kill your career while he projects your work as his work. 
Salaries: Fresher joining from 2015 are getting more salary than people with 3+ years of experience because of stupid Hr policies. 
Workspace : Used to be okay, now worst. If your mouse or lync headset stopped working, they won't provide a replacement because company does not have enough funds to take care of its employees. 
People managers who don't know basics of your work will be assigned because of their cordial relationship with domain leader. 
Last but not the least HOS: Neither the management nor the employees know why it is there but exists In Honeywell because it was decided to be implemented

review_title: Stable company but workforce turnover rate is too high.
job_title: Systems Engineer III in Toronto, ON
pros:
- large company
- stable work
- colleagues are knowledgeable
- ok pay
If you want a stable job and don't mind doing the same thing over and over again, then it's ok...
cons:
- poor benefits - employees need to pay a portion yet still don't cover much
- too many contractors in the workforce leading to too much turn over of coworkers
- only hire contractors and then contractors can apply for full-time positions later, but at that point you loose bargaining power, because you are already working for them.
- little to none employee development.  Managers tend to put you in exact same tasks in different projects to save time and training.

review_title: Don't fell for Honeywell brand name
pros:
Work from home. 
Good if you are on business teams ACS, AERO, PMT. 
Good for freshers. Salary offered is very high even if you don't deserve that much salary
cons:
Politics. Manager can kill your career while he projects your work as his work. 
Salaries: Fresher joining from 2015 are getting more salary than people with 3+ years of experience because of stupid Hr policies. 
Workspace : Used to be okay, now worst. If your mouse or lync headset stopped working, they won't provide a replacement because company does not have enough funds to take care of its employees. 
People managers who don't know basics of your work will be assigned because of their cordial relationship with domain leader. 
Last but not the least HOS: Neither the management nor the employees know why it is there but exists In Honeywell because it was decided to be implemented

job_title: Systems Engineer III in Phoenix, AZ
pros: There are flexible working hours, meaning you can work your 8 in any normal time frame. But this doesn't include 6am 9/10pm conference calls with worldwide team members.
cons:
50+ hours a week expected (more before/after furlough weeks), week long furloughs, quarterly layoffs, out of touch management. Eliminated the ability to work from home to encourage collaboration (90% of my immediate project team work at different locations). Switching to a new unlimited* vacation policy.  

*Based upon management discretion, program milestones, workload etc. There has never been a period in my experience that a vacation would be approved with these requirements (programs are ALWAYS behind).

review_title: Fulfilling technical work with managers that know how to navigate a large corporation
job_title: Senior Advanced Research and Development Scientist and Engineer in Plymouth, MN
pros:
I can only speak for my department,  Advanced Tech, as I don't have experience with other groups. I'm very impressed with what I've seen so far. Very intelligent, yet down to earth people that are dedicated to doing quality work. Managers and Program Managers here know how to navigate the red tape that is typically associated with major corporations. The company is willing to invest in research efforts to develop state of the art technology. 

The work is very technical and fulfilling. 

I have worked at several other companies, where most engineers were buried in red tape, restricted by overly lean budgets, and managers didn't understand the strengths and weaknesses of engineers with different expertise. This is not the case at Honeywell.
cons: Have to be very senior to be eligible for stock and bonuses. The automated side of on-boarding could've been smoother.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Stable job, work from home, easy to change teams, pension, company match 401K, company is making smart acquisitions, you can retire here as long as your are competent.  The majority of your colleagues are competent, but there are always a few where you wonder how they got hired.  Find a good manager and try to stay with them as long as possible.  You can choose to work on a maintenance mode project (boring, may not have opportunities to move up, but 40 hour work weeks).  Or...you can work on something really exciting with a lot of opportunities to move up, but 50 hour work weeks.  It's actually nice to have that choice given some other companies only have one or the other.
cons: Pay is lower than industry average, exciting work is usually understaffed (new development), boring work is well staffed (maintenance mode).

review_title: They still live in Stone Age
pros:
- good people to work with
- benefits are decent, not the best in the industry
- lot of lunch and learns helping everyone to grow
- acquired by Honeywell making it a larger company
cons:
They are just not flexible with work hours nor do they let you work from home. They want you to be in the office 8-5 or 9-6 adding the work week to 45+ hours. The upper management is constantly watching clock in and clock out times of their employees making you feel you are just out of school. They have been hiring like crazy mostly fresh out of college which helps them adapt to this culture sooner I think. 

Grow up and have some trust in your employees. It's the quality of work that counts not the quantity. And get out of your stringent 9hr work rule, it's 21st century and nobody does that..

pros: Been at Honeywell/AlliedSignal/Garret/AiResearch for almost 40 years.  I've been privileged to work with some of the brightest, most talented people I've ever met.  The work is very challenging, which tends to bring out the best in us.  The culture is collaborative, and the projects are team oriented, and all are encouraged to bring the best they have to the job.  Compensation is performance based.  There is opportunity for growth and advancement, created by the development of new products, as well as attrition due to age demographics.  New management at the top is extremely growth oriented and supports bold initiative and new ideas.
cons: Ongoing benefits erosion, arguably, or not, consistent with the rest of the industry.

pros:
Honeywell is perfectly positioned to enter the  Industrial IoT space and transition from creating physical products to analytics, digital products and AI.  Problems awaiting analytic solutions are interesting and varied and a path to digital products should encounter few obstacles due to Honeywell breadth of expertise and variety of clients.
Pros  also include recently implemented unlimited vacation time (as long as your manager will approve)
cons:
Sadly the present CEO and his staff do not understand the difference between data driven digital products and standard software development. One bad decision after another in terms of organizational structure, endless reorgs and uninformed staffing pretty much guarantee that Honeywell will follow GE and IBM in their failure to transform from building physical things to digital. 
Benefits are much weaker than other similar size companies, from expensive healthcare to forced presence in the office. And this year "innovation" of the 401K match is truly horrible: Honeywell holds on to all employees matches till the January of the following year, this keeping to themselves all market gains of those funds.  That is a robbery, loud and clear.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: Resources of a conglomeration (read deep pockets) behind your division if the shareholders like your growth potential.  Unlimited (within reason) vacation for salaried employees, flexible start times, good pay, and you at least get benefits
cons: awful vacation policy for hourly employees, typical 2 weeks to start then an extra week after 5 years blah, blah.  Would be okay but in the face of salary employees getting the unlimited vacation, its a real slap in the face to the tradespeople.

pros: Flexible for your personal situation. Made accommodations when my spouse couldn't enter U.S. due to immigration delay
cons:
Very short term focused and metric minded to point of absurdity. Example being project delayed by 3 months so existing asset retirement expense cost would hit the books in following quarter even though cost to change schedule and contractor change payments were > $150k. Procurement also needs to meet previous 90 and now 180 day payment terms, even though it leads to dropping suppliers who won't t meet payment terms and forgoing 10-15% discount for 30 days terms.
Also a lot of my fellow employees don't seem to be proud to work at Honeywell as there are a lot of indifferent or partially negative comments on working here (sarcastically "I'm living the dream working at Honeywell")
Previously I was running my own company for nearly 20 yrs, so don't know if this is typical of large corporations in general, or specific to Honeywell.

pros: The pros depend on your manager.  If you area Manager or above, you can do whatever you want and get away with it.
cons: Don't expect to be rewarded for a job well done. If you work outside of a Mother Honeywell location, they don't pay much attention to your contributions. Even if you have a legitimate issue with someone in your chain of command, HR doesn't care. HR protects management, not employees. Leadership is missing. People are promoted based on who they know. Honeywell values cutting costs so they can pay dividends to major shareholders. Employee responses to internal feedback have dropped 3 years in a row--but nothing has been done to counteract this trend. Expect to work within 3 global time zones.

pros:
Great opportunity to learn
Great co-workers, many dedicated employees
Good pay, benefits used to be excellent but started chaning the past few years
cons:
Short term financial focus is driving bad behaviors in leadership - saw situtations where layoffs were required dues to financials and right after the end of the quarter sites were scrambling to fill hourly positions.  Site Leaders have thankless jobs!!!
Short term focus negatively impacting what started out as a positive step forward, i.e. Honeywell Operating System.  Its all about end of month / end of quarter.
Exodus of alot of good talent
Work environment became toxic over past couple years

pros: At this time Honeywell Process Solutions is focused only its shareholders interests. It's customers and employees are treated like hindrances. If you like seeing a company making tons of money while systematically taking away employees benefits then Honeywell is your dream job.
cons:
Benefits- 
Wages are below industry standards
Healthcare is very expensive and covering less every year
$1000 yearly penalties for not participating in Company Health Assessment program.
Vacation policies are being changed to promote fear of taking time off.
401k match was 1 to 1 but not anymore, additionally new policy requires you stay with the company for a full calendar year to keep company matches. 
H1B visas have replaced the programs for domestic talent development. 
Flexable work schedules are being phased out. 
Many jobs are being outsourced to low cost centers.

review_title: Decent company but doesn’t treat employees well
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: Great people, good products, financially stable, nice offices in Morris Plains and Atlanta
cons: No work/life balance. No work from home, no flexible schedule, no summer Fridays. 401k match is paid out the following year. Benefits are not good and extremely expensive. Lack of women in leadership. Constant layoffs and furloughs. Experienced “band 4” employees being let go and replaced with recent graduates in “development” programs. When an employee leaves or is let go, co-workers must take on the work with no bonus or promotion. Bravo awards taken away in 2019 to save money, so hard working employees not recognized. New Hub strategy means if you can commute to Hub location you lose your job. Horrible company for working mothers.

job_title: Senior ASIC/FPGA Engineer in Glendale, AZ
pros: Great place to coast, with the occasional misuse by management. No need to grow here, there is no expectation for you to do so.
cons: Your hard work will not be recognized if you don't fit the template:heterosexual white male who voted for George W. Bush and whose wife is a stay-at-home mom. If you're an Asian with a Ph.D. you will be treated like a mad scientist--you can yell and mistreat African Americans and Latins so long as white male heterosexuals who voted for Bush think you're a genius, which as long as you keep that stereotypical Asian disposition going will be forever. Just keep pronouncing English with an "r," if you know what I mean. If you're not either of the aforementioned, good luck buddy.

review_title: Great job on the local level but corporate decisions questionable.
pros: Great work/life balance.  Good people to work with & for.
cons: Decisions made on the corporate level favor the Honeywell shareholder much more than the salaried employee and are by no means consistent.  Salaries have just been temporarily reduced by 10%.  Lay offs of supervisors that were just set up in the supervisory position less than a year ago.  Notification of these decisions are typically by emails about difficult economic headwinds and the reductions absolutely necessary.  Honeywell stock price continues on the rise, however.

pros: Since joining Honeywell, I have had exposure to a vast spectrum of technology, development and opportunity. I have driven my own development to become a key member of our site Leadership team and also an influential regional team member. I have managed this by accepting the challenging and often relentless pace of operations and aligning myself to the corporate direction. Honeywell has rewarded me through promotion, renumeration, development opportunities and travel
cons: There are few benefits left. Honeywell new recruits will often only be offered the minimum statutory pension contributions from teh company and little else to go with it. The pace of work and expectations can become bewildering

job_title: Field Service Supervisor in Pendergrass, GA
pros: I have worked for Honeywell for a little over 6 months and I have to admit that this is the best employer I have ever worked for. They offer a competitive wage, training, as much as you want to learn, advancement opportunity, and treat their employees very well. So if you are the type of person looking to learn, advance, develop a career and are willing to come to work, be the best you can be, always  looking to improve upon whatever you do, then I would highly suggest you put in an application and see if what I am saying is reality.  I enjoy my job, the people, and the ability to make my own destiny.
cons: If there is any, I have not found any yet.

review_title: If you like a toxic soup, dive on in
pros: Location of the Atlanta office
cons:
-	Attempting to be a software start-up in a large bloated bureaucratic environment needs to be more than saying you use agile methodologies. If you want to be agile, and the leader of IoT, it might help if you listen to your employees who actually know how to do this.
-	Be prepared to be publicly humiliated by leadership. This stems from the CEO down. 
-	Be prepared to work 80 hour weeks and weekends with no recognition of the effort to go above and beyond.
-	HR Leadership is a joke. They do the bidding of business leadership and sweep employee issues and toxic leadership behaviors under the carpet.
-	Promoting diversity is different to actually acting on it. It’s still a good old boys club when its all said and done. Inclusion is just a hollow word here.

review_title: Don't hang your hat here too long, meeting the next quarter may get you out the door
pros: The engineers /technicians are great to work with and are concerned about safety/putting out a quality product.
cons: No time set aside to be creative or grow skills, always under the gun to bring schedules in and cost down.  Not a great place to be a low level manager as you'll spend many hours at work and get little credit for it.  Low level managers work 7-5, go home, have dinner, then log back in remotely for evening meetings from 9-11 (work/life balance?).

pros: Honeywell FM&T is a good company to work for, they have a strong directive in what they are doing to help defend the country, and they take looking after their employees seriously.  (ie; Honeywell avoided employee furloughs during the 2013 Government shutdown)
cons: Although Honeywell FM&T has its pros, the company morals do not trickle down to the management of IT.  IT management is intimidating at best and if a member of the IT management does not like something, it is communicated to all of IT management and the person, or persons, are quickly turned against.  The GOBN (Good Ole Boy Network) is definitely in place!  It is an environment that strongly practices, "Do as I say, not as I do" ...

pros:
You will learn at Honeywell
Strong Processes
Hard working environment
Liberal work from home policy in some areas
cons:
Mandatory 10% salary cuts enacted in April 2016, all while posting record profits to Wall St
Shareholder value is the one and only focus
Employees are viewed as an expense only.  Little training is available
Cote flatly said he doesnt care if people like working there, they can leave and be replaced
No organic growth, all growth through acquisition and cost cutting.  Bonuses and salaries have been cut, the only thing left are jobs.
60-80 hour a week is standard if you want to progress.  You live for the company.

review_title: Not the same company as just a few years ago...
pros:
-Competitive salaries.
-Very low expectations of employees.
cons:
- Continuous reorganizations have reduced morale to record lows.  New management in nearly every business group have been brought in from other business groups, and have no understanding (or desire to learn) the history of the businesses they are now running.
- "Flattening" of the organization has dramatically reduced the number of promotion opportunities for those in (or interested in) management.
- Company is in the process of consolidating most remote locations into just a few major North American centers (Morris Plains, NJ, and Atlanta, GA among a very few others).  Almost no growth opportunities exist in the multitude of non-central locations.

pros: In general, the people are great.  My hours are flexible which is important to me.
cons: Lots of them.  Morale is very low and getting lower for those in the lower ranks.  I've been at Honeywell just over a year and am facing my fourth unpaid furlough. Didn't get the raise I was promised at 6 months because wages have been frozen.  No overtime, even though work loads are heavy.  They keep cutting benefits and the health benefits suck.  Constant layoffs.  Employees no longer have the option to work remotely.  The culture is negative and very vertical.  I'm looking for another job!

review_title: I have never felt less valued at a job.
pros: Hard to think positively through the continuous rain of blows to my wallet.
cons:
Last January I had 25 days of vacation to use when I chose. This year I have zero.  If my supervisor feels like rewarding me -and provided the company gives him a budget to pay me - I may be able to get days off. If I need time off for job interviews (and I plan to!), I have none available.

 Probably I'll get some vacation this year. But since vacation pay is now discretionary spending - the first thing to be cut when money is short, as it ALWAYS is in this company - I expect to be "rewarded" less every year, instead of guaranteed more as in our old earned vacation plan.

It's really REALLY hard to see this change as anything other than (yet another) huge benefit cut. Essentially the hourly earnings HW owes to me just dropped 10%.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: New & rewarding work on tech development projects that produce systems & software products that enhance automation, usability and safety of avionics systems deployed for commercial & business aircraft.
cons: Support of metrics collection on progress towards milestones and repetitive quoting of  project costs steals engineering time that should be applied to quality systems development, integration & testing as well as work on patents.

review_title: Great company with great opportunities and encourage  innovation
job_title: Senior IT Manager in Shanghai, Shanghai
pros:
I have been working at Honeywell for more than 9 years and have multiple different roles in IT function to support the SBUs and business functions from the end to end planning to the project delivery and the operations.  Senior leadership and management team established the role model and the management operating system, so we can continue to learn from them, from different functions with innovation mindsets and practice thru the program/project delivery. 
In addition, Honeywell is enabling the digital transformation, so we can see lots of opportunities for us to utilize the data liquidity based on the modeling, performance, production process to make us/our customer successful thru the digital transformation.
cons: Collaborating with the global team with different time zones, we have to do some meetings at night, but generally that is ok, we can switch to our day time according to the audience and priorities.

job_title: Lead Process Engineer in Morristown, NJ
pros:
The job they say you will get sounds great.  But most of it are lies.  Horrifically bad bosses.  Constant turnover at all levels.  Horrible travel policy that makes it worse than when you are on vacation paying yourself.  Better like center seats.

And then comes health benefits.  For a family, it's $6500 a year for $3000 deductible.  So $9500 out of your pocket before any real benefit.  I found just buying drugs at Walmart with no insurance was better in many cases.

Any positive reviews, especially for healtcare, are likely company plants. NO ONE is happy except those long timers on the OLD Honeywell pension.  Current pension is essentially a severance package.  One time payment of well less than your yearly salary, and that's it.
cons:
Pretty much everything.  Beware promotions.  You'll get a small salary increase, and then expectations on you will jump massively.

2014 was one of their best years financially EVER, so they awarded employees with NO raises, and cut bonuses in half essentially.

pros: I had a lot of success as an intern at Honeywell. My advice is to network and be seen. No one will hold your hand to accomplishing anything, but it is within your power to reach out and grab the opportunities that are there.
cons: The older engineers are stuck in their ways and resistant to change. Don't trust anyone in HR. They go looking for gossip and act on it before speaking to you. You must hold your own council. They are not there to help you.

review_title: Darius up to bat with Cote watching from the board room
pros: exciting place to work, very fast pace, lots of change, good people in the trenches.
cons: Corporate management only has 30-day patience for results. This trickles down into organization culture. The constant pressure to deliver 90 results for Wall Street results in continuous upper management churn & burn mentality.

pros:
I work as an engineer at Honeywell Aerospace. This business has a significant portfolio of mechanical and electronic products that are in nearly every single airplane flying. Many employees are fascinated by aviation, have hobbies related to aviation and are generally very bright, hard working individuals. This industry requires significant optimization and so there is a great deal of satisfaction in solving tough engineering problems. Overall, here is a list of pros:

- if you are on the right project (I.e. new development or research), the work is fascinating.
- good opportunities for career growth and movement if you have signifiant talent (technical, management or project areas for engineering)
- benefits are on par with other aerospace jobs. No pension for new hires and marginal health benefits but decent wages, 401k matching and some might like the negotiated vacation plan (you and your manager get to decide how many weeks of vacation you have each year)
- Phoenix is a great city to live in if you are outdoorsy. Quality of life is pretty good in AZ with employment at Honeywell.
- Honeywell has been stable and shareholders love Honeywell (ok, but I’ll get to the cons below ...)
cons:
Honeywell, as a corporation, is extremely focused on free cash flow and operating margin, which is much higher than other aerospace companies (so far ....) .  This has led to some culture issues that I’ll describe here:

- supply chain has been squeezed to the point of complete disfunction. Rebellion of suppliers, huge issues of quality/delivery that are managed through heroic efforts by employees. Engineering is the current scapegoat (for a variety of complex reasons). Large portions of engineering is just focused on processes and manufacturing work-arounds, dogwork with very little innovation (many are reassessing their life priorities here)
- focus on reducing engineering spend: very little research, plant closure rampant, shifting work to low cost regions at an increasing pace. All companies are doing this, but Honeywell is really starving engineering at a rate that is not comparable to other companies.
- limited new product development: growth story from corporate disconnected from product ... Corp focused on software-industrial and connected which is generally inappropriate for aerospace since we don’t sell to end consumer. Business unit leadership scared to provide candid feedback so we dilute scarce resources on low value mandates and have few real products in pipeline.
- superficial employee engagement campaigns but gradual reduction in benefits, stagnant wages and expectations for mandatory overtime. It’s feeling very much like “1984” with the propaganda vs reality.
- High attrition from retirement and disillusioned new grads when faced with the above.

I would generally tell prospective new employees to carefully examine the work opportunity & product growth plans and ask yourself “what do I want to do with my career?”  There are some good opportunities, but the environment is soul-sucking.

review_title: Lots of challenge and variety but limited advancement opportunities
job_title: Senior Credit Analyst in Plymouth, MI
pros: Working for Honeywell Turbo Technologies provides the opportunity to learn a wide variety of concepts and to develop many different skills.  The people I work with are generally very professional and respectful in their attitude, and focused on achieving common performance goals.  There are also opportunities to move from one business to another within Honeywell.
cons: One downside is limited advancement opportunities.  Another downside is the lack of a bonus program for non-management employees.  Another downside is only 2 weeks vacation for non-management employees.  Another downside is the increasing trend toward moving jobs from the U.S. to developing markets such as Mexico, which seems to be more of a short-term cost saving advantage than a successful long-term strategy.

pros: Good work ethics, emphasis on training and cetification of employees' skills, organized career development and progessional growth process, decent salaries and overall good business stablity, global and with an interesting relocation plans among their multiple plants in the world.
cons: Slow and bureocratic, changes take forever even benefits are obvious and low hanging fruit like, approvals need to come from corporate, goals and objectives contradictory among different departments, obsessed with 6 sigma even though the company has enormous opportunities to become leaner and more profitable by just using common business sense.

review_title: Little training, lackluster benefits, and a company culture that's too focused on corporate baloney create a fatal mix.
job_title: Systems Engineer I in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Average pay, flexible hours (core hours of 10am-3pm M-F, otherwise just make 40 hours a week and you're good), good work/life balance.
cons: Unpaid overtime (get paid hourly up to 40 and no other pay, even if mandatory overtime assigned), horrible health insurance (my insurance as a student was better - and I paid less for it), too much process and too little engineering, little to no training, takes way too long to move up the hierarchy, raises are minuscule, workplace is super depressing, no social events for employees (except when an employee leaves, oddly enough).

pros: Good people. Working inside in the summer in Phoenix. Vacation time better than average.
cons: My career began with AiResearch (Garrett) in the late 70's and I ended up retiring as a Honeywell employee. Over the 30 plus years, we saw change mostly negative, in benefits and working conditions. Fact is, it's pretty much the same all over in major corporations. A lack of unions, foreign outsourcing, and too much emphasis on short term results/shareholders does not make for an environment conducive to happy employees, regardless of what the pundits on the business channels say. This fact should say it all to anyone who thinks about it: In 2013 as average Honeywell employees were getting raises (if they were lucky) between 2 and 3 percent, the CEO was paid nearly $39 million.

review_title: Massive conglomerate, eating up companies, spitting out employees
job_title: Senior Electrical Engineer in Lynnwood, WA
pros: Unlimited vacation. 7% 401k match, flexible work options (working from home), on-site gym (but I've been told that our site is unique in having a gym), free snacks and drinks.
cons: Poor employee recognition, no bonuses, employees have to pay for their own team parties, upward mobility is extremely rare, annual health check-up required, penalty for high BMI,

review_title: Good Company with Questionable Human Resource Strategy
pros: Good all around company with a great opportunities to grow your career in different directions. Mr. Cote is a great CEO and his fellow senior leaders are always looking to the future and trying to do what is best for the shareholders. The company has sustained growth in good times and in bad over the past 5 years.
cons: Large companies like every other large company has issues with size and balance. The company is moving more and more towards emerging markets. So given the growth strategy, you have to always learn new skills to keep yourself employed and on top. If not, your job will be moved to a low cost region and you will be out of work.

pros: The compensation is comparable to other aerospace manufacturing companies, although layoffs and pay cuts have been recently implemented.  The company has great potential, but poor decisions by senior management have long lasting repercussions which are difficult to overcome.  Company veterans tell me it has always been this way, so get used to it.
cons: The product quality is often sacrificed for cost savings and production quotas.  Honeywell tends to outsource just about everything, and assembles and tests the final product.  The outsourcing has resulted in a loss of quality control of the essential hardware which really is the product.  The emphasis on Six Sigma Plus and the Honeywell Operating System doesn't really matter much when the end result is a non-conforming product shipped to meet a deadline.

pros: Very flexible with respect to timings. A few years in the company can give you significant say in a product's life. You can learn a lot of things in depth. Nice company to spend around 5 years.
cons: No benefits whatsoever except for health insurance (for which there is a 10% co pay). This is not a company you want to be in if you have a technical aspirations. Honeywell's technology requirements are very limited because of the domain in which it operates. It can be very difficult staying relevant after several years in Honeywell.

pros: Stable company with growth potential.  Still has some of the remnants of a company that cares.
cons: Honeywell has taken a company that used to be great and stressed it to the breaking point.  What used to make UOP a great company to work for - benefits, knowledgeable employees, technical expertise are slowly being traded away for short term profit.  Honeywell consistently pays under the market rate.

pros:
-Good first job for ChE's that plan on working in the petrochemical industry as UOP's name is everywhere.
-Joining the Field Engineer pipeline would be a good idea.  You would gain very valuable experience that would be useful if you'd like to be a plant manager someday 
-Honeywell name recognition will look good on your resume when you look for a new job
cons:
-R&D as a Development Engineer does not allow for the best work/life balance.  
-For being in the petrochemical industry, pay is relatively low for a ChE, especially in the Chicagoland area
-If you don't plan on doing road assignments, you are wasting your time at UOP as a ChE.
-If you plan on transitioning back to the company after being a field engineer, there doesn't seem to be many places for advancement.  There is a large gap for middle experienced engineers (4-8 yrs exp)

pros: Upper management positions are very lucrative. Acquisitions keep the company growing. Shareholders have seen good returns. Not much else matters.
cons: Honeywell was acquired by Allied Signal in 1999, mostly for the avionics business. The Honeywell name was taken because Allied Signal's wasn't as good. Yet the corporate philosophy remains the same.  Cronyism is rampant. Putting corporate micro-managing in control, the HOS (Honeywell Operating System) only serves to reward management. The lowest tiers of workers are paying for the companies acquisitions through lower wages with less, or more costly benefits. Management is very anti-union. The unions leaders are useless, self-serving puppets. Most workers are rewarded by making others look bad. Fear is used instead of reward to get the work done. Quality is down. Rework and scrap have increased exponentially. The engineers are incompetent. The numbers are either distorted or ignored to make the HOS management system look good. Nothing but management matters.

review_title: I can hardley wait to retire!
job_title: Machine Ooerator in Golden Valley, MN
pros: When I started at Honeywell it was a great place to work, they were very family oriented and cared about you as a person. After Allied Signal bought us things are progressively getting worse. I am in a union shop, so when we get a raise in wages our out of pocket medical premium goes up so we really do not see a raise in wages at all. We used to have excellent medical coverage but that keeps getting more expensive with less coverage. Sometimes i swear that they stay awake at night just trying to find ways to piss us off!
cons: Allied Signal becoming the parent company and the plant manager at Golden Valley.

review_title: one of the best place to learn

People have great domain knowledge and technical capabilities.  There is absolutely no discrimination on the basis of seniority/designation - If you are good, you will go high, you will get chance to do good available work and get good hikes.
Good place to work for long time and probably the best place to start your career.

Projects go on for a long time too and the company policy makes it compulsory for you to work in a project for sometime before you can switch to another.  Compensation is not one of the best in the industry too.

pros: The only pros is in a year you can get work-life balance for 2-3 months.

Managers and Project leads fakes honeywell international by showing saving and cost reductions and make there employees to work day-night almost 16hrs a day. The Only way to survive here is play politics. Try to blame others if you are not able to do something. And if you are bachelor then they will also ask you to stay at night and work.
