pros: Process-oriented company... Very clear definition of what needed to be done for each position. Reasonable level of support to get the job done right. (Not nickel-and-diming each aspect of a project)
cons: Rigid adherence to process and structures even when the surrounding environment had changed... Not able to adapt; Sometimes infuriating/silly behaviors based on near-religious adherence to procedure that was outdated.

pros: I like what I work on and most of the people I work with.
cons: I've been here for 10 years and have seen the benefits deteriorate almost to nothing. This is a lesson to the youngsters to demand things that they may not be aware of. This is what I had when I started: 1) paid OT (true, after 44hrs and straight time), 2) 401k match at 8%, 3) pension plan, 4) Christmas parties with FREE gifts for all the kids, 5) company picnics, 6), company paid VSP (vision plan), 7) company paid for 1/2 of dental insurance and decent insurance. Now: no paid OT for exempt employees (most engineers), 401k match down to 6% (back from 3%), no pension plan for new employees, forget Christmas parties and picnics. You get to pay for your own vision AND dental plan, have HIGH deductible insurance plan that Honeywell "blames" Obamacare for.

pros: Money was good and most of the employees working on the floor were friendly.  They train you in different areas which helps in decreasing monotony.
cons: Management like an old boys club and only think of themselves e.g. (I have to get my bonus this month at all costs). If you prove a manager or supervisor wrong they will be out to get you (very childish).  If you're not in the clique you can forget about promotion.

review_title: Meh! Lots of hours, little fun, stable employment
pros: I feel my position is stable.  In addition, there are many other opportunities in a company this size.  Those opportunities can be in a different field or different business unit and even a different industry.
cons: The company is very focused on a lean operation - to the extent that it becomes hard to get anything done.  Everyone is overworked.  People you rely on are slow to respond -or just flat out tell you they can't support you.  But that doesn't stop the pressure to produce.  Company culture is all about getting the job done.  There is no sense of team.  You are a small cog in a big machine.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL
pros: UOP is one of the top licensor of refining technology in the world. They have an extensive customer base and are well respected in the industry. At UOP you get to work along some of the leading experts in the industry and work with some of the greatest minds in oil and gas. Travel is also a good experience that I have had with UOP.
cons: Salaries are not the highest in the industry. You can make more as a process engineer at a refinery. During a down turn in the oil and gas market is not a good time to work at this company.

review_title: Depends on where you work within the org

cons: That meant ignoring a screaming, lunatic of a boss (there were far too many but I rarely saw mine), her assistant who broke down in tears 1-3 times each week, the numerous extra-marital affairs with VPs and promotion by cleavage.  HR's job was to fire anyone who was a whistle blower or in any way disagreed with management. Senior managers were great (the ones I knew all left), mediocre and a bit crazy, the latter two "styles" fared the best.

review_title: Used to be decent - no longer
job_title: Control Systems Engineer in Cincinnati, OH
pros: There were some people who made working there bearable.
cons: Excessive travel leading to no work life balance, denied raises (after being told I'm doing an amazing job though), denied multiple awards I submitted for fellow employees with no explanation why, force employees to get biometric screenings from a company who keeps having data breaches, significantly cut all benefits, hoarding employees 401k matching until the end of the year to appear more profitable than they are, claim they have unlimited vacation policy but deny employees vacation.  I could go on, but point being that any good reasons to work there have disappeared.  Avoid Honeywell/Intelligrated like the plague.

pros: Work/life balance as a young engineer has been great. Many talented, motivated coworkers with years of experience to draw from.

Minimal R&D funding; prone to cuts if fiscal targets are in jeopardy. The company is hyperfocused on quarterly and yearly financial targets and neglects the mid- to long-term. Aerospace division lives and dies by contracts - major impact from recent downturn in demand for the products offered by Honeywell Aero.

review_title: Lots of open opportunities all over the world... But look out for outsourcing.
pros: I was lucky enough to have one of the best supervisors around but other managers (both above my supervisor and within our plant) that were around were not nearly as good. It's a good company to grow in depending on the work that you do. Since they are global there can be opportunities to travel and work in a variety of locations. The vacation package is good and the availability of overtime really helped.
cons: Money. You don't get paid enough to do your job so I had to rely on overtime to help make ends meet. The company can be cheap, not only with the pay but also with jobs as our plant was closed and outsourced to Mexico. The benefits are horrible and I decided to opt out of the medical plan because it costs too much.

pros: world-class products, great brands, good marketing support, liberal sample budgets, ability to manage your own territory, SIP looks good on paper if the AOP is accurate
cons: no sales leadership, direction or focus / too much emphasis on processes that do not support sales and make, difficult for distributors to deal with (too many ineffective processes), fractured inventory strategy, very poor customer service (left hand has no clue there is a right hand), processes win out over sales and make it difficult to grow your territory, no accountability for sales representatives which leads to disengagement and a low level of effort by some

pros: Had been good company to work in the 80s & 90s when they were an employee-based company, that is one that invests in, develops, and retains its hard-working personnel through rewards and benefits.
cons: Beginning with the economic downturn in 2008, UOP and Honeywell, its parent company, have gone the way of all big conglomerates in corporate America.  Today's corp mantra is to demand more and give less, and less, and less.  Short term quarterly financial performance far outweighs the need to invest in future technologies and solution development through R&D.

job_title: Computer Rack Builder in Houston, TX
pros: This company pays fairly well. Also, all work is done in a clean, comfortable environment. Everything is planned ahead of time, so you will work on the same project for weeks or months at a time.
cons: This job is for people who aren't very social. The feeling around the warehouse is almost always nervous. They worry more about everything being in its proper place than they do about production. They have you feeling like you're walking on eggshells at all times. They make you lock your phone in a locker all day.

review_title: Great respect for Honeywell as an organization but it should have control over "discrimination" practices

Some of the sites could be very conservative with blatant discrimination against "outsiders".

review_title: Long career which in the end sputtered out

Annual increases are pathetic to nonexistent, no life/work balance.  Very demanding work environment, with long hours, not uncommon to work 60+ hours. 

Culture varies between different business segments and locations.  Division headquarter locations are much better environments.  

Employees that move on to new roles are difficult to replace, often for months and months, and often cannot be replaced, causing a great deal of employee dissatisfaction.

review_title: Good company to learn and grow in diverse segments of business.
pros: Diverse business functions and focus on generating innovations. Opportunities for lateral movement within the organization. Effective systems and processes in place like SAP and HOS (Honeywell Operating System). Good culture and values.
cons: Most of the employee friendly benefits have been reduced to cut down on costs like team out bounds. Professional training and certifications are very limited and most employees are expected to learn at job. Promotions and vertical growth are very limited. HR function is not independent and hence does not have a good strategy towards achieving employee satisfaction. Appraisal system is not effective as it has lot of subjectivity and lack of transparency.

job_title: Design Engineer III in Tempe, AZ
pros: The people are the best asset to this company. They are friendly and knowledgeable. The work is very interesting and challenging. I really like my boss and find he is very supportive of my work.
cons: Honeywell is adding so many tools and processes and requirements to the responsibilities of a design engineer that it is impossible to truly focus on creating quality designs. The network and CAD system are the worst I have ever seen and as a former design engineer contractor I have seen at least 10 other well performing systems. The upper management is so focused on profit that it has lost it's ability to see why its implementation of new processes and tools are costing money.

pros:
The managers can be bend on the corporate rules to reward good and talented workers.
They support school education for the sciences.
cons:
They're attempt to implement best practices, drives away talented people.
If you penalize people for bad habits, and not reward those that have good habits, then that is being selfish.
They do not hire the students that have been educated locally or nationally if the science fields.  It is easier to hire a temporary foreign national for the job.

job_title: Senior R&Amp; D Engineer/Scientist in Des Plaines, IL
pros: The company has been around for many years.  Very well known in the industry.  Many smart people working there.  Many long term employees.
cons: The company is very profitable currently but has made employees take several furloughs and now has taken 10 percent of our pay.  But there is still money to take over 100 employees to a baseball game to boost moral?  Well what about the rest of the company?  The spending that is still going on make absolutely no sense at all.  It makes the new president look foolish.

review_title: Room for growth-however unstable in Golden Valley
pros: Big company with room for growth.  Competitive wages.  401k matching.  Flexible schedules.  This is minor, but unlimited soda and coffee in the cafeteria is a nice little perk.
cons: Unstable in Golden Valley with jobs moving out of country.  With hiring freezes, no raises in 2016, riffs, and layoffs, it is difficult right now.  This is not how it has always been.  There have been a lot of changes in upper management that have caused this.  Top talent that have been with the company are leaving or being let go.

pros: Honeywell offers fair pay, good work experience, decent benefits, typical vacations, and holidays off.  You can learn much there.  It's a good place to get work experience.
cons: I worked in Supply Chain Management at HON's Tempe, AZ site.  High stress. No matter how much you do, it's never enough. We abused suppliers, squeezed every dime from them.   Management makes unreasonable demands is if they're not met, the employee career is threatened.  This is a metrics driven company.  Employees are under constant fear of layoff (typically around the Holidays every year).  It's a terrible, stressful environment.  You've been warned.

pros: Honeywell is one of the most work friendly organisations that I have worked in. THe team, whether its your seniors or your department leaders are absolutely approachable. Once you finish your induction as a fresher, you are taken through the entire training process under your assigned manager. Each fresher is also assigned to a buddy mentor who guides your with each and every step. The first few days of joining will involve much lighter work and you will be given sufficient time to gradually fit into the entire process. All in all,  its been absolutely smooth journey and it feels like honeywell is a great place to start your career!
cons: As of now, i have found absolutely no cons of working with honeywell. If you are someone who is flexible with the working hours then its perfect.

review_title: Strong Company but under values employees
pros: Great benefits, good pay, modern technology at office
cons: Overworked (many 70 plus hour weeks), random trips to the customer sites to fix issues causing you to pack up and go at any time. Poor work/life balance, on call schedule for a full week at a time, your shift doesn't always end on time. Lunch breaks are not always guaranteed, no privacy at your desk with the modern "open concept"

pros:
Ability to work on a project by yourself, so no waiting on a slow coworker (or being flooded by a faster one).

Small, tight knit community

Laid back managers
cons:
Low pay for area (12.50 on 3rd shift) with no pay raises.

Looong background check (1 month for me).

Little to no direction on most things (Everyone at plant confused or in dark about policies and procedures)

Poor training (thrown onto floor very first day with an employee that had trouble communicating instructions and seemed more concerned with telling me who was a poor worker/troublemaker)

Honeywell as a coporation seems shady ($1000 penalty for a knee/back surgery if I don't make multiple calls to your "experts" to try and talk me into a cheaper option?  Ha...no)

pros: Good work/life balance, good compensation, most people are very willing to help and guide you, some good benefits, although not as good as pre-recession.
cons: US based employees are treated like liabilities as the desire by upper management is to move all of these jobs to "low cost" regions like Mexico and India.  Massive bloated corporate structure consisting of too many people working on vague initiatives to "improve process" instead of doing real work, thereby hindering the people attempting to do real work.

pros: working since 1-1/2 year, yet to find pros...!!! not sure if I can find any... yeah, one thing is for sure... flexible timings and less work pressure.
cons: Biggest drawback of the organization is it has no policies fixed yet and they do not know how to frame policies even. very very poor in management. most of the senior employees had very good time previously in honeywell in terms of work, salary and other benefits and sticked to the organization like a frog enjoying in a well... no awareness of the outside world. Only few projects have authority over the product, rest as like service industry... read mails from customer and work/deliver accordingly. Btw, poor compensation paid to employees.

review_title: Poor place for women to work.
pros: Excellent ccess to an extensive knowledgebase of technical articles and other printed resources including IEEE libraries, books 24x7, etc.
cons:
Very unfriendly toward women. Your ability to move to a new position is based only on your current one within Honeywell, so if you had other more senior positions elsewhere and took a less challenging one due to family needs, you are stuck permanently.  
Serious pay inequities. Even with more experience and a higher degree than all of my subordinates, I am paid less than 8 out of 10 of them. Addressing this with HR is fruitless for as long as they believe you will not leave.  
Management and executive bonuses are funded every year, even when those at the bottom get no raises and are forced to take pay cuts through furloughs.  Lowest level management bonuses are 10%, and jump up to 35% quickly after that.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: Compensation is barely a pro. It’s certainly not a con, but it’s not that great. They encourage rotation.
cons:
So top-heavy. I’ve got request after request for reports for these folks at the top, and it’s all so frivolous and a waste of everyone’s time and sanity. I spend 95% of my time reporting up some useless data that probably isn’t even reliable, and I doubt these execs spend more than a few minutes considering any of it. Oh and these crazy requests come in last minute but are always needed ASAP.

Sooo many good people are quitting, because it seems the culture has radically shifted with the new management turnover the last few years.

pros: Retirement benefits are best-in-class.  Interesting positions and large size of company allows for much variation in job opportunties.
cons: Compensation and health benefits are below average in general.  But compensation is very low compared to other defense contractors.  Leadership uses some very questionable practices relating to compensation.  Years ago, they stopped posting ranges on positions so there's no governance to ensure that there is equity in pay across the company.  Employees can be performing the same job with as much as 40K difference in salary between employees in those same positions.  And there's little recourse for an employee as HR supports management in these practices.

review_title: Development Engineer program "training" overshadowed by R&D assignment work
pros: Good experience for young engineers in troubleshooting and data analysis. Forces you to learn quickly and take on several projects at one time. Offers good field engineer refinery experience and Travel at the beginning of your career.
cons: Career Development Program is too long and not focused enough on training and field work in refineries. Work assignments during the first two years are almost entirely office based work. The R&D work assignment culture is stressful and does not give a good work/life balance. Specialist actively try to belittle and embarrass young engineers during presentations. Very negative work atmosphere in R&D.

pros: Great People and Resources throughout the company.  The environment is very competitive and it is a results driven organization.  Good for people that are able to generate business on their own and are creative in maximizing their time and effort.
cons: Benefits and pay are close to the lower end of the spectrum for a fortune 100 company.  A lot of upper management changes creates constant changes to strategies and objectives.  Implementations of processes and procedures also weigh heavily on employee morale.

pros:
Job security 
Well defined processes
Good work life balance
The salary that you see in your offer letter is what you get every month.
cons:
If you are the one who wants to take up more responsibilities and grow up the ladder, then this is a wrong place to be in. 
Overall CTC is lesser that competition and Y-o-Y increment is minuscule compared to market average. 
Lot of bureaucracy and bossism. They want to behave like a startup but bound you with so many rules and processes. Everyone will advice you and ask to do things but no one will take ownership or take responsibility of any decision. As a result you end up discussing the same thing again and again over meetings.

pros:
If you are a techie, you can focus on your work though, there are a lot of useless distractions
Better life balance if you can organise your work and date commitments properly.
cons:
Very ineffective leadership for the last 10 years in the Aerospace business in Bangalore.

Most inefficient people are  promoted to Director/ Sr. Director positions, in fact the joke at that time was that we have the same number of technicians as the number of directors.

The organization does not have a clue whether they are a Service organization or a Product organization, the management claims to be different things at the same time in front of different audience.

Top quality talent is neither recognized in time nor retained.

Highly beurocratic and complicated processes set up and established in the name of CMMI and HoS, no useful work gets done in time. 

From leaders to laggards in a quick time has been the theme of Aero business, Rockwell Collins, Garmin and L3 doing far better in every segment.

review_title: Typical corporation of the new millennium.
pros: Starting salaries are usually pretty good.  People are nice and the environment is somewhat laid back.  Generally a pleasant place to work.  Has so-so benefits, 401k matching and stock options.
cons:
- Furloughs.  
- Spin-offs.
- Base level structure is practically non-existent.  
- While the salaries might seem nice, don't expect any other benefits, bonuses,
raises or any other type of monetary/morale boosting perks.  
- Constant RIFs, changes in management, corporate instability and the open floor
plan is unsightly and does not serve the intended purpose (waste of time and money).

pros: Honeywell Aerospace has a good onboarding process with online learning, HR reps checking in, and a clear online checklist of tasks. Overall getting up to speed was intense but pretty slick. The company has a clear vision/agenda which it holds true to. Particularly working at my site I have felt valued, needed and respected; a good place to be.
cons: Engineering required to work 45 hr week minimum. Insurance is costly.  401k company contributions are done at end of year.

review_title: Awful. Don't work here. Check glassdoor pay rates, this company is the low end of the market.
pros: None to be honest. There used to be, ten or more years ago.
cons: Favoritism, good old boys club atmosphere. Constant threats by leadership. Excuses for mandatory overtime without compensation, meaning 15% pay cut so far. No more promotions. Demolitions from higher salary bands to lower. Removal of manger positions due to the high attrition and layoff rates. No rewarding of individuals unless you invent perennial energy sources.

review_title: Great Place To Work. Health Care Could Be Better!
pros: Honeywell is a great place to work. The work life balance makes it hard to even consider thinking about another place to work. Co-workers are really friendly and upper management remains involved. The work culture is very positive and almost everyone who works here loves the work that they do. Getting bored of your job? Honeywell allows employees to switch departments every two years so that work remains exciting and new. These switches also sometimes come with pay raises and promotions.
cons: Honeywell has one of the worse health care plans when it comes to Fortune 100 companies. Not only are deductibles and premiums rising, corporate requires mandatory annual Biometric Screenings for each person covered under Honeywell Healthcare. Those who smoke cigarettes or have a BMI of 35% or higher are fined.

pros: Unlimited Vacation is the only nice benefit!
cons:
Terrible Benefits with high premiums and high deductibles. Strictly enforced no work from home policy. No longer allowed to have summer hours. There are certainly other organizations to work for that offer more work perks and flexibility.

Systems are outdated and unreliable.  Lacks proper functional support. Data/records are not well maintained.

Management team lacks strong  organizational and leadership skills and are unable to grow the business as they continue to promote and retain staff that are unqualified, unmotivated, and do not give 100%.

Tough  environment to work in if you actually care to do things the right way. 

Unnecessarily stressful work environment.

Digging themselves into a financial hole.

review_title: It's an okay place to work if you just want to do your job and go home.
pros: Flexible work schedules/locations is the primary benefit to working here. I am able to maintain a good work/life balance, I can just do my job and enjoy the rest of my life when I'm done with my employment obligations.
cons: No financial recognition is provided for doing a good job. Too many inefficient employees that the company refuses to get rid of.  Constant cost cutting of benefits and no corporate culture.

pros:
Four huge businesses - Automation Control, Transportation, Specialty Chemicals, and Aerospace. 
Good technology, particularly Aerospace products.
cons:
Aerospace is moving workforce and locations out of N. America, very clear direction & directives. 
Creation of numerous functions with multiple VPs in each function generating isolated processes have removed focus from customer to functional area.  This continues to impact our customers, decision making, and morale.  Fewer and fewer employees care any longer due to all the top down decisions, constantly reduced benefits, and higher process expectation without any additional people to support.

pros: Decent pay with a very competitive bonus plan.. It is project based work so you need to be willing to put in the extra hours to meet deadlines, but with that said you'll have more intense work some months as well as slower months.. it balances out. Travel 30-40% of the time, will always fly you back for the weekend with options for a company car if driving more frequently if you live near by. You can work from home or office, everything is remote.
cons: Since everything is remote, your coworkers are just voices over the phone.. Took me over a year to meet my mentors in person which makes building relationships harder. Also for those that like the office atmosphere this isn't for you.

pros: You will hardly work overtime, the people are nice since it is not a stressful environment, half day Fridays during the summer. Like other reviews said, there are many smart folks, but that`s a given with most people having engineering degrees.
cons: They hire young talent fresh out of college and lay them off during down cycles in Oil and Gas.What`s crazy is that they had new college grads lined up to start almost immediately after layoffs.  That is probably how they nickle and dime by avoiding raises. The benefits are not great at all. The work does not require much ingenuity. If you fresh out of college like me, there are more intellectually stimulating engineering out there. They really do not care about being a great employer; they are all about the the bottom line over there.

review_title: Overall positive experience across 13 years of service at Honeywell.
job_title: Principal Project Engineer in Houston, TX
pros: Opportunities to participate in large projects in different parts of the world.  Access to training, and a stringent safety culture.  Excellent 401k company match.
cons:
Health benefits not so good. Remote worker policy cancelled with little warning making people drive severasl hours to an office or relocate to a different city. All so that you can sit in an office with people who were not even in your department. Unnecessary disruption in people's lives. The best talent does not always live near an office.

Management does not always promote the best talent, but will back a favorite regardless of competency or track record of failed assignments. Leadership is encouraged as long as you can lead within the narrow parameters set by non-visionary managers.

review_title: It really depends on the department and direct manager
pros:
Diversity, international environment and young team.
Generally secure.
If you have good and supportive manager, you can enjoy stable environment and learn a lot.  
Manage your own time.
cons:
Furloughs and redundancy is very usual.
Higher management is disconnected from the lower management.
Noneffective HR (do more problems than solutions).
Only positive numbers and projects are being reported up.
Management (and vision) is changing very frequently, which has negative impact on workload, goals, time management and overall knowledge of the processes and company environment.
It is not "right and fast" but "cheap and fast". Even for the price of good quality, human health and environment. 
Slow growth of salary. 
Lower salary and respect for young women (even they do same job in one team).
Home office is forbidden. 
If a colleague leaves, they wouldn't be replaced, the workload will be given to another member of team.

review_title: Honeywell Aerospace a World Class Company?
pros: Hard to say, i will say if you are a new grad and want to learn in slow motion with really limited responsabilities and are willing to spend a while with no professional grow it is a really good place to work, you can get in touch with multiple engineering tools and information available, great for self learners.
cons: No professional grow, careless managment, in our case we were a metric for one of the sites so it doesen't matter if we are not doing anything we just charge the hours so they can say they are global working site, You could spend months without job, of course at evaluation they argue that you didn't had a project to evaluate you.

review_title: Good company to learn & shoulder responsibilities
pros:
o Good learning opportunities
o Good visibility to higher management & partners
o work environment promotes innovation
o Good hands on even for beginners on all product developments
o Flexible timings
o optional work from home policy (if the work is doable from home & if your manager agrees)
cons:
o less benefits (you almost get nothing apart from your salary & tea/coffee) & it keeps reducing
o Non transparent career growth policies & process (the appraisal process is pathetic, everything is up to your manager to decide). I had to quarrel everytimne to get a good hike or promotion
o Huge career ladder
o Non responsive management (they escape using the name of policies, this & that)
o deteriorating work environment & work culture

review_title: Like watching a train wreck in slow motion.
job_title: Service Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros: Still some exceptionally talented people on the front line of business.   Work/ life balance is fair, wages are decent.
cons: Middle and upper management is so consumed in deflection of responsibility for bad decisions or avoiding decisions altogether, no cohesive direction or leadership with vision remains.  A rapidly dwindling customer base struggles to keep an incompetent and technically inept management clique afloat.  Any employee blind enough to remind management of its precarious position is paraded out in some surreal blood lust ritual,

pros: Diversified portfolio of products, 4 major divisions in different industries providing stability for the entire corporation in any economic environment, also allowing to shuffle and focus budget and investment where the opportunity arising. Some very talented, knowledgeable individuals. Unlimited career opportunities if you work yourself up in the organization.
cons: Too many incompetence tolerated for too long in the senior management. Generally a very slow motion organization and situation is getting worse as corporation becomes a GE type of industry giant. You will only progress in the organization if you have strong mentoring relationship - silent hard working won't take you up in the food chain.

review_title: Sometimes technically challenging work, but personally degrading treatment by corporate policies.
pros: Fairly stable job security since 2005, at least in Aerospace engineering.  $7,500 toward education assistance annually.
cons: Honeywell policy shifts over the past ten years have continually eliminated the valuable benefits from working full time at a corporation.  Medical coverage cost me $14,500 last year.  401K matching was reduced to 50%.  Tea/coffee was eliminated because "it cost the company $60K per year".  Can no longer use the mail room to mail personal packages domestically.  Ridiculous scrutiny of purchases--I had to purchase my own $45 head set for teleconferences.

review_title: From excellent to below average for employees
pros: Big company, has many interesting and challenging programs and projects.  There are lots of excellent engineers to work with.  During my 20+ years I truly loved and enjoyed the technical side of the work.
cons: Front line managers were clueless of what's going on technically. Managers wanted you to be thankful to have a job.  Benefits was not bad but, could be much better.  It was being shaved away bit by bit through the years.  Way too many bean counters.  Too many chiefs but not enough contributing worker bees.  Up-side-down pyramid organization.  Long term overtime without pay is expected.  Someone actually worked 80+ hours a week.

pros: If you are in a good team then this is the company you want to be as a fresher. You get to learn all the aspects of product development. You can actually enjoy the development of the product
cons: Manager are the bad part of the company. They play all the tricks to give you many reasons not to give you proper hikes. I remember my manager say due to bell curve your pay is so much. That was un-acceptable . what is bell curve doing in my salary hike. Managers are above HR here and employees are just numbers according to managers.

review_title: International Company Great at Acquisition and Operations
job_title: Director Business Development in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Excellent process oriented company with one of the best track records in business for acquiring and integrating businesses.  International exposure is guaranteed if you want it and considered a promotion track.
cons: Career path does not exist; you need to find your own way.  Lots of deadwood in the organization that has been in the same job for 10+ years.  There is a perception that, like the military, you have to wait your turn in line to get to the next level. Staff to operations transitions are hard in this company which is especially important when you look at where the greatest emphasis is placed in senior roles - running an organization gets the greatest rewards and responsibility.

review_title: You'll Hate your life...but will get an education
pros: Benefits and Salary are the best in the industry.  they also have excellent edicational programs from within.
cons: Constantly afraid they will downsize, management who are only there because they are collecting a huge paycheck and are getting ready for their pensions to kick in, promotion based on time served rather than job skill, education and people skills. Great place to learn- awful place to work.

review_title: You'll Hate your life...but will get an education
pros: Benefits and Salary are the best in the industry.  they also have excellent edicational programs from within.
cons: Constantly afraid they will downsize, management who are only there because they are collecting a huge paycheck and are getting ready for their pensions to kick in, promotion based on time served rather than job skill, education and people skills. Great place to learn- awful place to work.

review_title: Almost all new jobs are being filled overseas.  New offices in China/India have advancement opportunities; not US.
pros: High level of education of  US employees.  Good effort by management to keep everyone aware of current state of the business and employee recognition by SBU.
cons: Lack of advancement, cutback in benefits.  Poor coordination of working units- ie design a product in Brno or China, create the prints in China or India,. marketing in US, build site in Mexico, quality in US.  IT support in India slow to respond or not competent.  Travel restrictions hamper design, purchasing and quality functions.

pros: Employees get to share and implement ideas in the process and safety of the plant. Great atomosphere to work in as well as a great learning experience.
cons: Hard to make a living as the lean business practices are focused mainly on wages than overstock situations. Disfuntional management causes some problems and many times productiion is promoted over quaility as if making more will fix the problem or increase the average of quality.

pros: Salary and benefits are decent enough. Flexibility to work from home. Six Sigma training and certification. Good internal opportunities within the larger Honeywell group.
cons:
The Scanning & Mobility group culture is plagued by certain individuals in senior management. When the top is bad, it trickles down. There was a lot of finger pointing, blame putting and questioning. Yes-sayers survive, but that's bad for any company who wants progress.
Also, way too focused on cost savings. Penny smart, pound foolish.

job_title: Project Accounting Manager in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: Robust systems and commitment to using data efficiently.
cons: People are treated like cattle;  benefits are 2nd rate at best; there is no heart at Honeywell.  While employed there, my husband died in a tragic accident.  The company did nothing to acknowledge the tragedy to me and my family.  (Note my coworkers and staff are not part of this comment).  Adding salt to the wound, four months after the accident, the company eliminated my department and laid me off.

pros: Good company, reasonable benefits, pretty new building and good food!
cons: If you are an Engineer, be prepared to be a slave to the company. Xcess hours and especially travel.  In order of losing your life; it is Mechanical, Electrical and then Controls from least to most life lost.  Other positions are very similar.  You are expected to work 45 hours with 5 of those hours on the house.  After that, any hours are paid single-time, including weekends.  60 hr weeks are the norm.  I have worked up to 80+ hr weeks. They appreciate the time spent, but somewhat thankless and expected. There is a long learning curve as this is a very niche business.  Aside - gossip runs rampant here.

review_title: Senior management is prejudiced & HR doesnt even care
job_title: Material Handler in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Great people 
Diverse but the black employees are treated like they are not knowledgeable
Nice workload
good medical team
reputable company 
pays very well
cons:
The managers are prejudiced. The rural (country-raised) employees are treated like Gods. Treats everyone accordingly to who kissing up the most that day. The black men who doesn't speak like them and isn't as well-spoken as the average corporate american employee they are treated like ignorant cogs in the system. So if youre a black male you cannot be yourself they WANT you be like 'them'.
HR ignores all the social issues and racial undertone issues ive reached out plenty times and they looked at me like i was the problem. HR and Management are both salary are they are in cahoots together.

pros: On-boarding was not perfect but far better than some companies. There is high demand for products which has created numerous opportunities for employment and growth. They the best vacation benefit anywhere. The entire Christmas week is off.
cons:
There seems to be high turnover at all levels within the organization. There have been significant changes in senior management. The business very cyclical and is therefore subject to drastic swings in the aerospace industry.  The Tucson location has outsourced the entire manufacturing business. However, many of the employees were assumed by the new company. IT services are very slow and tedious to deal with.

There is a culture that appreciates needless meetings and overly detailed presentations. The don't seem know how to prioritize issues and major initiatives.

review_title: Act like if you had to stay in this role for 20 years
pros: Great products and technology; good focus on what needs to be done to grow the company from a technology standpoint; good teamwork with plenty of history and knowledge on products and customers, good customer base and opportunities to grow the business;
cons: No deep/true emphasis on people personal development - instead of thinking of people as disposable, need to grow them and find the best role for their skills; completely lost the sense of customer satisfaction and focuses on short term results, disregarding long term partnership. Lack of management continuity to have a sustainable personal relation with key customers... this will cost the company with many large or growing customers

pros: Large company with an international exposure and a well know brand. Multifunctional international teams which makes things exciting, in principle a brand that gives pride, however there are serious downsides to the glossy outside.
cons: An institution rather than an enterprise, crippled by it's size and people that are either in it just for their own gain and fail to ensure the rest "grow" with them, or not capable/willing to take decisions or be accountable for them. This is not necessarily the case in all business units, but definitely in Honeywell Safety Products.

pros: Large company with an international exposure and a well know brand. Multifunctional international teams which makes things exciting, in principle a brand that gives pride, however there are serious downsides to the glossy outside.
cons: An institution rather than an enterprise, crippled by it's size and people that are either in it just for their own gain and fail to ensure the rest "grow" with them, or not capable/willing to take decisions or be accountable for them. This is not necessarily the case in all business units, but definitely in Honeywell Safety Products.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Aguadilla, PR
pros:
This was the greatest job I ever had. The job i had was so high profile with the government that engineering had final say over anything related to production. It was really nice having professional who understood what was most important for the quality production of hardware and importance of the customers needs.

I felt I was thanked and well considered when I pointed out minute micro flaws plaguing a functional surface. Always receiving the work instructions to correct it or an excellent answer to continue processing as normal. I was never told "because I said." 

I helped build products I was 100% confident were built right because I had this this support to fall back on when I needed.
cons: Cost cutting culture concerning manpower and resources, Constant expectations to meet budget and schedule milestones that seem to be unattainable.

review_title: Another Fortune 500 Company Bites the dust
pros: Trying hard to come up with a pro; salary is good and 401k is ok.  Used to be a good company but unfortunately there isn't much more to say.
cons:
Constant worry about layoffs; unpaid furloughs; very costly insurance benefits; no raises or bonuses; backwards thinking management; no dental; no acrued vacation, only 56 hours a year pto no matter how long you are here; no WFH allowed; zero loyalty to employees. HR sucks. No pension. CEO is completely out of touch- climate of fear and depression contributes constantly to extreme low morale in the work environment.
I see recent 4 and 5 star reviews and, well, they are made up. No one that actually works right now for Honeywell would or could give a good review.

review_title: Lots of Opportunity - for the right person
pros:
- At a critical inflection point as they attempt to transform to a software industrial, great opportunity for those with sought after skills.

- Solid benefits (but not great, and getting worse)

- New CEO is coming out strong with new corporate behaviors, vision and background to support it
cons:
- Rigid hiring strategy (almost all new NA positions only posted for Atlanta, GA or Morris Plains, NJ)

- Killed off any remote work, with the exception of field and sales positions.

- Financial targets and associated demand/expectations are causing burnout.

- Seems like a higher degree of attrition than I would expect.

job_title: Senior Engineering Project Manager in Kansas City, MO
pros: Lots of work, challenging projects. Some good people here
cons:
Extremely low pay. Engineers are leaving in droves and Senior management isn't doing anything about it. They've been saying "we're working on it" for over a year now. They have a ridiculous overtime policy, you have to work an extra 5 hours per week for FREE before you even start to earn overtime, then it's just straight pay. Annual raises don't keep up with inflation or medical increases. Even with a promotion you are still slowly loosing money by working here. Last year I only got 2.6 percent. Just got a promotion and it was only 2% increase, but I'm managing nearly 30 projects! 

We are all overworked too. Many good engineers are leaving and we have to keep taking on extra work loads. Meanwhile they can't get new people in because they wont offer enough to attract anyone good.

review_title: Toss up between horrible benefits and horrible management
pros:
Honeywell does pay well
My peers have a good team
Most people are good to work with
Location is convenient, but facilities are subpar
cons:
Management is clueless 
Too many internal meetings
Horrible benefits 
Corporate causes too much red tape
Nothing efficient 
Claim to want to watch expenses, no internal travel, yet Corporate constantly requiring travel there for meetings.
Furlough forced on people just so top management can hit inflated numbers for Wall Street  and get bonuses.
Too much shifting of jobs overseas
Salespeople forced to spend too much time creating PowerPoints for whatever whim management has instead of selling.
Too many acquisitions at once and not enough tech support to integrate systems makes things very difficult
Employees are NOT valued, most are used to cut to make numbers

review_title: Too many old timers.  Hard to implement changes.
pros: Company size, location, shifts, amenities, decent pay, and overtime.
cons: Honeywell has a lot of seniors (50, 60+).  I am not saying this is necessarily a bad thing.  However, when your coworkers and managers have been doing the same for decades and feel too comfortable in their positions it  is extremely hard to propose and implement changes without finding  resistance from them.  This is not a place for young people unless  you are willing to work with DOS, old computers, obsolete test stations, and grumpy coworkers who dislike innovating ideas.

pros: You get to work at your timings.
cons:
-No proper redressal of employee's work related challenges. 
-Managers are only focused at getting (read forcing) more work out of team with looking into pain points. This results in burn out of employees. The employees who don't over work and refuse to work after office hours are fired.
-No time is given for skill development in allied domains. It is not encouraged too.
-No work from home policy whatsoever.
-We were recruited from campus recruitment, the salary was reduced by 18%, from the salary at which we were interviewed and selected, immediately before joining.
-Food in canteen is not subsidized (Rs.90 for a N.V meal which includes rice and one curry) and coffee machines on floor work only for specified time (2 hours) rest of the time tea/coffee is available in canteen for Rs.25 per cup.
-The senior management works in silos often not aware of the ground reality.

pros:
- Competitive pay
- Great professional development opportunities
- Consistent activities and fun ways to get involved - game days, ping pong table, councils, raffles, yoga, masseuse on-site, etc.
- Ability to move up as well as laterally so you can learn different roles and figure out what you want; also, Honeywell is a global company so you could work anywhere in the world
- Recruiting process was simple, albeit intimidating (but maybe that's just me because I am a new graduate, new to interviews with large corporations)
cons:
- Large company so large problems that can seem daunting and metrics, unreachable
- A lot of people do not have the same sense of urgency so things can take a while to get resolved

review_title: Respectful and friendly company to work with
pros: Honeywell has been a great place to start out at right out of college.  The staff is very friendly and helpful with questions I have both logistically as well as engineering related.  I feel Honeywell takes care of its employees and has allowed me the time I have needed for my family responsibilities.  Working for Honeywell has also provided me many experiences to learn and grow in areas that interest me.
cons: A lot of the work we do is training on the job and there is not a lot of formal training for new assignments you are given.  As you get more experience, it becomes more natural, but when you first start out, it is a big learning curve to figure out how programs work and what your responsibilities entail.

review_title: this might just be the definition of insanity...
pros: Established great relationships with industry leaders in the multifamily direct industry.
cons: no chance for internal advancement, unrealistic managers who will take no feedback from the field reps if it is not what they want to hear.  Managers spend money on useless resources and then cut employees once they get a pay advance in order to manage the budget.   Lots of internal politics and unfair means of holding employees accountable.  Hire you as a contractor and tell you they will advance you if you perform but then never do.  Limit how many miles a contractor can drive but then tell you that you aren't working hard enough.

review_title: Engineer in Aerospace - stuck with a glass ceiling overhead
pros: It's a stable job with some interesting work.  Pay is okay, benefits okay.  Investors love the company.
cons:
Company is controlled by "bean counters".  Promotions have been stagnant for years and an aging workforce makes the company top heavy, so young or semi-young employees have little, to no room to move up.  This doesn't appear to be improving any time soon.  Senior management is bent on using low cost regions despite knowledge gaps and letting core knowledge errod.
The rules and processes are out of control.  A rule to hold the hand-rail when using the stairs is too far.

review_title: Big Company - Decent Opportunities - Fast Pace
pros:
Honeywell has deep pockets to weather economic downturns.
Many opportunities if you are willing to move.
Good paid holiday benefit.
Last of the big companies to have a pension (it's a pretty decent one, too)
Many opportunities within different business processes (Quality, Engineering, Supply Chain, Operations, Procurement, IT, etc.)
cons:
Health care benefits are not good - big changes in the past that is hurting all employees
The company does not promote a work life balance at all
It can take forever to get changes through the many systems that we have
No incentives for the common employee-operator through supervisor (no profit sharing, bonus scheme)
Improvement programs are being watered down - green belt program is not as robust and comprehensive as it used to be

pros: There is opportunity to move around the company but it is difficult to spend the time looking given it is an extremely busy environment.
cons: The company has reduced or deferred raises over the past several years, aggressively passed on health care cost to the employees, have lay-offs and furloughs and cut employee recognition expenses.  HR treats the employees like dirt and they work for the managers and not the people.  Losing much of the Aerospace business to Rockwell Collins, GE and Garmin. These actions to increase op margins a few tenths of a percent are paying a huge toll on the employee morale and productivity.

pros: 'unlimited' vacation for exempt level employees
cons: STAY AWAY!! Honeywell doesn't give a crap about its employees, its a grind and they know it and don't care.  Work life balance is a lie they perpetuate to get people in the door.  They have a huge HR organization so they know how to 'talk the talk' but dont believe it - the 'pro' mentioned above is simply their way of avoiding payout of vacation to terminated employee.  This company is so disorganized, disjointed, and dysfunctional that its a wonder they continue to survive.  Actually, the only reason they survive is through acquisition of companies that are more successful.  It's like the aliens in the move Independence Day - they swoop in, suck all the life out of the once successful, thriving organization, and then move on to their next victim.  Sad but very true.  Don't give them the time of day.  Trust me you don't want to work here.

pros: Pay grade was matched from previous, but similar line of work. Peers were excellent to work with and very knowledgeable; a great resource for help when needed. Perks included vehicle, laptop, phone, office space. Management not on site (in this case, it was a good thing... also bad).
cons: Immediate manager was out of touch with my job scope and my happenings in the field as he never spent time in the field (straight out of college, into engineering, and management). Other higher management seemed out of touch as well. Lack of customer service and support from management. Minimal mentoring. Benefits were not the greatest, but I have heard of worse.

review_title: Honeywell SPS is a heartless soul sucking company run by an incompetent man who just wants to be part of the boys club.
pros: I got a mediocre paycheck (when we weren’t on furlough) and, well, I can’t think of anything else.  They had a decent cafeteria but that was outsourced and run by another company.
cons: Management, Waldren specifically, have no interest in the employees. They outsource everything to the lowest bidder which ends up delivering bad products.  Little to no raises. Furloughs even though the company was making money.  Health benefits get cut back more and more every year.  It’s cost over everything. They don’t want American workers. The moral when I left was terrible with people leaving it wanting to leave.

review_title: Management considers job experience to be employee's greatest benefit
pros:
Challenging tasks, opportunity to drive results
Global exposure, colleagues across the globe
cons:
Too many ERP systems and slow reaction to the corporation to fix that. Focus on cost is hampering long term growth.

Considers employees as dispensable and no consideration for people's personal life or challenges. This is a company for singles, married couples with no children, or children who are now grown adults. The new brand campaign "Future-shaper" is just a mask to give an impression that people mean something. Internally, it's a further encouragement to people who can just live and die at work.

Too political environment - need to align with 5 people just to ensure something can even be presented to senior management

Too much focus on data and granularity - management can't take decision without data

review_title: If you desire stability, respect, and never forget the customer is always right, this is the company for you.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Like minded co-workers who understand and act according to the concept that helping the customer is number one.  Stable and fair company with a great benefit package...they still pay pensions.  In our particular department the people are all really close and enjoy coming to work despite the stressfull nature of the job.
cons: Since it is such a large company it takes awhile for decisions to be made and actions to be taken and sometimes the people making these decisions are too far removed from the people these decisions will be impacting most, i.e. the customer facing employee and the customer.

review_title: Get your money on the way in and don't grow roots
pros: Large company with opportunity. Room to move around but not mecessarily upward. Decent benefits but trimming away at them every year.
cons: They do not retain talent well. Management is getting caught up in making Honeywell comparative to other similar companies rather than exceeding them in employee benefits and compensation. 13 year employee with yearly raises no more than 2% average. Get your money coming into the company and dont make Honeywell your carrier. I have been making less net money every year for the past 5 years with pay freezes and increased cost in health benefits.

review_title: Get your money on the way in and don't grow roots
pros: Large company with opportunity. Room to move around but not mecessarily upward. Decent benefits but trimming away at them every year.
cons: They do not retain talent well. Management is getting caught up in making Honeywell comparative to other similar companies rather than exceeding them in employee benefits and compensation. 13 year employee with yearly raises no more than 2% average. Get your money coming into the company and dont make Honeywell your carrier. I have been making less net money every year for the past 5 years with pay freezes and increased cost in health benefits.

pros: If you are upper management, you are in like Flynn. Everything is about you.
cons: Horrible pay and horrendous benefits which shrink continuously. Micro-managing is the name of the game and they can't make things worse, they look somewhere else. For example, my department has a ten-fold increase in rework and scrap. Management hides these results in the numbers so they can give themselves a pat on the back. The waste management creates is a laughable fiasco. Lean, Just in time, HOS, are all systems to create the illusion that management uses to justify their own miserable worthless existence. Their gain is the employee's pain. I retired early to rid myself of the depressing selfish charlatans that run this corporation. This isn't Honeywell, this is Allied Signal. They bought Honeywell and took the name because it WAS a much better name. though not anymore. No amount of money is worth putting up with the torment of working and the management team lead by David (Kotex) Cote.

job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Torrance, CA
pros: It's a paycheck. But let the reader understand, it is a continuosly shrinking one.
cons: Constant threat of layoffs and unpaid furloughs, no cost of living increases nor raises for a couple years running, poor benefits and getting worse, reduced 401K match, expensive insurance ($8000.00 annual deductible for a small family), outsourcing engineering & tech roles to India, micro management, low morale, nearly zero advancement opportunities (the best jobs are being eliminated), and yes there is much more... If there were glory days, they are long gone (unless you're a top dog, then you are laughing all the way to the bank).

pros: Decent pay if you work in defense and relaxed on the defense side. They give you some leeway for showing up on time. There are refrigerators in the break room.
cons: Assume you will go to space where the engineers blame you for everything. They are to lazy to give you a process you can build too. Everyone is spying on each other and the management there takes he said she said literally. The entire company is laying off all the time that's why I am looking to jump careers.

pros: Lean processes and Honeywell Operating System creates a standard work environment where expectations are well know and communication freely flows from one area to another.
cons: Company is very concerned about the bottom line to the detriment of employees. Large variances in salaries for same jobs.  Reliance of contract hires with reluctance to hire or convert employees to permanent. Standardization creates machine-like workforce who no longer are able to think for themselves or solve problems quickly and efficiently.

pros: Good wages, clean environment
cons: Greedy Ceo and upper management. Although wages are not bad the company takes and takes from the middle class people who make the money for them. They want to keep them down instead of rewarding them for all their hard work. Young people / new hires don't get pensions, long term emploees get their pensions froze, while the CEO make over 50 million with the stock options and bonuses. It's wrong.

pros: Interesting products with diverse offerings
cons: Honeywell was a great company, but has decided that they do not need people.  Over the last few years they have continued to outsource all areas and have such a lean organization that there is no fail safe for critical processes.  If you are offered a job, make sure you get a very high starting salary-raises are few and far between.  Great place to gain some experience and move to better company.

review_title: How is credit analyst position reviewed by me
job_title: Credit Analyst in San Luis Potosí, San Luis Potosí
pros: It´s an interesing job that can help you develop a lot of  skills just as customer service and analysing risk situations like how to handle big amounts of money. You learn a lot about the internal handling of acompany, the importance of comunication between the departements involved such as customer service, sales and finance.
cons: There´s a lot of pressure in this work. A lot of time invested and sometimes it can be a little bit ciclical. You need to handle a lot of money and you can be a risk for the company if you don´t know how to do it.

job_title: Principal Security Architect in Atlanta, GA
pros: I just started here recently.  The building in Atlanta is top of the line. Everything you could imagine was provided upon starting. The relocation package was top notch. I felt like I was instantly part of a family. The benefits are insane from unlimited vacation to 8% 401k. Also, unlimited vacation time is pretty cool. They have free lunch and drinks every day.  I could go on and on here, but I have never been so happy to start working somewhere.
cons: So far and it is not really a con but I do not know how I feel yet about it. The ability to move desk everyday. I may or may not like it just not sure yet.

pros: Most of the working level people in Temp are amazing. I've learned a lot from working with these people both technically and professionally.
cons: Higher up leadership does not care about their employees. Promotions are hard, almost impossible to receive, even when your direct manager wants to promote you. 401k contributions do not become vested until after over 3 years of employment. Execs are always quick to take away merit raises, which are always low compared to peer organizations, and to enact furloughs. The company does not value training their employees for technical excellence, all time spent in training must be made up with work on chargeable programs. I would not, under any circumstances recommend anyone to work in this office. Though the people you work with are amazing, the moral at the building is very low. It is very obvious that employees are underappreciated and it effects the day to day work and conversations of the working employees.

review_title: A pretty good place to work
job_title: Engineering Intern in Des Plaines, IL
pros: If you want to surround yourself with smart people and competent management while working for a company with good family values, you might be interested to apply here. The company is big enough that there are plenty of opportunities to move around to different technologies, though you may have to be your own driver. Technical people can grow well here, as there are opportunities for promotions strictly within the technical ladder. If you can do your job and you perform well, people will notice you here. Depending on your group, management can be flexible to very flexible with personal issues requiring telecommuting or going into work late.
cons: Average compensation, above average benefits

review_title: Great place to work, but ultimately depends on under whom you are working
pros:
Great place to work or start career.
Good place to come and settledown in senior management position.
Opportunities to change domain/projects are good
cons:
The process of promotions is entirely dependent on "CRITICALITY OF RESOURCE" in the project. If a particular resource is very critical for the project, they give everything. At the same time another resource who is equally competent, is ignored. Hence they loose good talented resources. Again it depends on the mangers capability to balance. 
The middle level management doesn't do any work, but pretend that they are working.
The top level management doesn't know whats happenning at the ground level.

review_title: Good stability, below par compensation, manageable work, incompetent middle management
pros: HPS has been stable enough throughout the economy  with minimal lay offs and high cost cuttings.
cons: HPS doesn't seem to compensate the employees at the market rates though the company did exceedingly well in sales and share market in the past year, the management is more interested in acquiring other companies. Junior Engineers have minimal guidance and appreciation from the immediate bosses and are forced with unrealistic goals. Individual growth is hardly ever important though it is projected as its of the highest priority. As this is a product based business, the philosophy of  depending on the strength and sale of the product rather than the Engineer who works on it is evident in compensation policies. Not recommended for junior/entry-level engineers

review_title: Don't expect to have a long career with Honeywell
pros: Decent pay, but you are exposed to some nasty things.
cons: Poor retirement, costly medical plan,lots of politics. Upper management out of touch with the hourly  and first line supervision.  Company will devour the best years of your life then toss you out like rubbish.  You will be hard pressed to find a happy Honeywell employee in Hopewell VA.  Don't take my word for it. Just ask someone who works or has worked there in the past 10 years.  I would not want anybody I cared about to get caught up in that rat race.  I had over 25 years there and witnessed it all.

review_title: Great Company with No Respect for Mid Level Managers
pros: Diversified company with good positions in great markets (as driven by CEO Dave Cote). Technology and Lean Tools are used everywhere. Getting traction in very exciting fields.
cons: Honeywell is doing great thanks to the hard work and leadership of thousands of underpaid and underestimated mid level managerial teams and very smart engineers that get no raises despite record profits YOY, while the senior leaders get huge rewards regardless.

job_title: Lead Systems Integration Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great place to work, you will gain a lot of knowledge and training. There is plenty room for advancement in one choices to move up. Also, Honeywell is recognize as as solid company, those who leave are generally looked append by other companies as a person who has potential
cons: Layoff are abundant. Honeywell, on the other hand does not refer to them as layoff, but rather reorgs. Meaning, they will restructure (reduce jobs), then have you apply for your own job. So you'll have say, 100 people applying for 50 jobs. Those who do not land a job, are let go.

pros:
1.Highly reputed brand all over the world.
2.Dave cote one of the best CEO's in world.
3.Job security. 
4.Good Projects.
cons:
1.Average or below average salary. 
2.No clear cut interview process.If your luck is good, you will get hired because of an incompetent employee.
3.Honeywell has now become a school due to it's stupid HOS(Honeywel Operating System)culture.
4.Whole company starts running at 9 am daily to attend their respective morning meetings. 
5.Project leads/managers will take attendance in meeting just like school and will  send you mail if you miss daily meetings often. 
6.Good relationship wifh manager will take you forward.Doesn't matter if you work or not.
7.Worst food in cafeteria.

review_title: HON AERO is in a death spiral
pros: Flexible work arrangements, but coupled with long hours in a frenetic environment. On-site gyms at many locations (not free).  Mostly a meritocracy - if you are good, you'll rise up the ranks.
cons: Terrible culture. I'd estimate 85% of the employees in AERO wish they worked somewhere else.  Zero investment in making it a fun, enjoyable place to work.  Office are very outdated - frozen in time from the early 80s. Very siloed teams.  Political, bureaucratic.  Terrible customer support; our customers HATE us. Regular furloughs, pay freezes, layoffs, outsourcing.

review_title: Not what it used to be
job_title: Customer Service in Golden Valley, MN
pros: There are some good people to work with. You get free soda or coffee as long as you bring your own cup. Recently started to have Customer Care Appreciation days, where they will pay for lunch for a whole week out the year.
cons: They are non flexible if going to school, you cannot advance within company without BA degree or know someone. Too many secrets and not enough communication.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Challenging, innovative, technical, many experts in the industry work(ed) or started their career here. There are many divisions that people can explore their career paths on.
cons: Ever since Honeywell bought the company, benefits had gone down hill. Corporate decisions on some, if not all, company policies make little to no sense. Banned remote work completely (it was one of the few perks left). Makes absolutely no sense to force employees to work at a local Honeywell site where they don't collaborate with any of them. Many employees do not feel appreciated, experience don't seem to be valued or as much as it should. Retention issue is growing though executives and HR still feel it's low and not concerning. Working environment is horrific, old building, problematic HVAC system. Slow progression.

review_title: Not what it used to be
job_title: Customer Service in Golden Valley, MN
pros: There are some good people to work with. You get free soda or coffee as long as you bring your own cup. Recently started to have Customer Care Appreciation days, where they will pay for lunch for a whole week out the year.
cons: They are non flexible if going to school, you cannot advance within company without BA degree or know someone. Too many secrets and not enough communication.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Challenging, innovative, technical, many experts in the industry work(ed) or started their career here. There are many divisions that people can explore their career paths on.
cons: Ever since Honeywell bought the company, benefits had gone down hill. Corporate decisions on some, if not all, company policies make little to no sense. Banned remote work completely (it was one of the few perks left). Makes absolutely no sense to force employees to work at a local Honeywell site where they don't collaborate with any of them. Many employees do not feel appreciated, experience don't seem to be valued or as much as it should. Retention issue is growing though executives and HR still feel it's low and not concerning. Working environment is horrific, old building, problematic HVAC system. Slow progression.

pros: Career opportunities. A robust organization with specialists for every possible niche skill or area of knowledge. High-profile deals and famous customers. Some top notch technology, together with run-of-the-mill low-added-value-products.
cons: Red tape. Process-based organization, which can sometimes be a disadvantage. Different corporate initiatives, some not tied to actually doing business at all. Overly politically correct - prevents messages from getting across internally on a daily basis. American culture - you are supposed to be positive at all costs, saying things you do not mean just to avoid saying "no".

review_title: Great company to start a career
pros: You will be tackling difficult challenges in almost every software engineering problem, the company culture will motivate you to show initiative to overcome them. On a daily basis, there is potential to seek out new ideas to do things better. If you are a lucky, management, for the most part, will try to energize you to become better, be dependable to match your actions with your words and to focus on results and not activity which are the things you want if you want to become an achiever and not just a "doer". Most of the time you will work across diverse global teams to meet daily job duties.
cons: Sometimes management can be nitpicking everything and trying to micro-manage every aspect of the software engineering efforts.

review_title: It's an ok place to work but the culture is horrible.
pros: challenging work,  great place to get started in engineering career.  I was give a chance to really increase my knowlege and grow. The six sigma program is also a great career advancer that was provided for free. I have always gotten very positive reviews and managers have treated me fairly. My issues are more with the company at large than my specific group or manager.
cons: contant fear of layoffs due to outsourcing, people are very beaten down because of this. The workplace culture is very negative and it makes teamwork nearly impossible. Teambuilding is a joke and they treat employees like everyone is trying to steal from them.

pros: Benefits are good and aerospace engineering work can be interesting.  Still seen are as solid company, so employment there looks good on a resume.
cons: Honeywell's business strategy  is consistent in two areas: constantly outsourcing American jobs to anywhere where labor is cheap while laying off employees in the US -- then using the profits from this to buy other companies to cannibalize.  The dwindling experienced American staff are expected to clean up the substandard work that was outsourced while their salaries stagnate to generate more cash flow to buy other companies.   New engineering development is limited as management likes to milk its technology as long as possible and then sells off business units no longer able to sell their outdated products.

review_title: Still struggling five years after a re-org.
pros: Engineering Middle  management cares about people and is trying to get the job done.
cons: Reorganization into functional silos five years ago was disastrous and further injury was done by a somewhat late move into global markets.  Expertise in the US now tries to get work done by pulling the puppet strings of emerging market workforce.  Huge amount of bureaucracy created to try and "fix" / prevent project failures stemming from communication gaps between US and emerging markets.

review_title: Great place to learn from lots of smart people.
job_title: Design Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Business is booming, lots to do but not overwhelming.  
Lots of smart people to learn from.  
Ample opportunity to move around (if you desire).  
Great place to learn the refining petrochemical business...stay for your whole career if you'd like.
cons:
Work culture is stuck in the 90's, not appealing to millennials.  
No on site work out facility.
Getting crowded, many people doubled up in offices
Older buildings - nothing pretty to look at.
Vacation schedule is bad...2 weeks for the first 5 years is tough, takes long time to earn 3+ weeks.

review_title: running behind thoughtless processes,greatly missing the talent
pros: good company to work but not anymore because of mindless and pathetic project leads who misuses the talent greatly and obsolete ur skills like a mere dumb fellow..not a innovation company anymore
cons: you have to cope with a process called "HOS" which will be highly challenging to balance your personal life and improving ur competencies... really crushes you and bog down you with bossy culture..

review_title: Not a place to work; treats employees with disdain
pros: Good work life balance.  Good systems and process in place.
cons: no perks, health insurance cost rise every year, they dropped dental for next year. furloughs,merit freezes, and reduction in force despite company growth and gangbuster stock price. eliminated telecommuting.  its a company that squeezes ever bit of earnings on the backs of their employees.

review_title: KPI Driven - You are just a number (and a letter)
pros:
Good Pay
Great colleagues
Interesting and challenging work
cons:
Obsession over KPIs
Customers can be quite abusive (not at the employee, rather they vent their frustration and anger about the company at you as you are the one talking to them!)
No focus whatsoever on the customer - I now work for a vendor reaping the rewards of this behavior.
Staff are just a number on a spreadsheet, virtually zero care for work/life balance - Will send you overseas or interstate for long periods without any consideration of your situation.
HR Rule the roost. Have way more power over staff than anywhere I've ever worked.
Massive cronyism in HBS and ACS.

review_title: A Good Company In Need Of A Benefits Overhaul
pros: As a long-term employee, I’m still proud to work at Honeywell and genuinely believe that we have some of the best people in the industry. The opportunities the company has afforded me have been vast and my career growth continues. The fast pace can be challenging but the skill development you get in return is great if you are someone who doesn’t mind change and can be flexible. The recent increase in paid maternity leave in the U.S. was excellent to see, I hope the company keeps up the good work in taking steps to make this a more women friendly work environment. Our track record in having women in senior positions is not stellar and our diversity at senior levels in general, not just gender related, needs more focus. The recent change is meaningful and deserves to be called out positively.
cons:
From middle management and up the demands are great, this can hugely impact work/life balance.
As such, the restrictive work from home policy that was introduced a year ago just isn’t realistic. This is a truly global company and we need to work at odd hours to effectively do our jobs. This means taking calls remotely, being available after hours etc. It’s  not appropriate to demand that employees must turn up at an office everyday while still expecting this kind of flexibility in return. The policy is also making it harder for those in management and leadership positions to recruit and retain talent.

pros: Salary is higher than most, but you are expected to pull the load of five people
cons:
You are treated like a number.  the way they save cost  is to Furlough staff.  They never ask for ideas to reduce cost or a furlough will happen.  They have furloughed employees five times in the last decade.
There is no CONTINUITY, eveyone is allowed to change jobs evry 18 months, to positions they have no education in or background in.  There are Seniro Directors in C&PS who hired in as a buyer and know NOTHING about cutomer service.  There are contracts Direcotrs that have never seen a law book before.  There are VP's in areas that they never worked in before much less can understnd the jobs being performed.

job_title: Field Technical Advisor in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Good smart people
Fantastic technology base
Leader in technical expertise
Knowlegde expansion is second to none
Best first job for a chemical engineer
Excellent work experience
World travel
cons:
Poor salaries, especially compared with contemporaries
Low morale
Poor communication
Poor leadership - constantly changing organization and management
lack of promotion within
Midsize company trying to act like a gian corporation
Hiring of too many contractors

review_title: Lot's of Opportunities. Some are Great, Some are true "Widow Makers."
job_title: Engineering Manager in South Bend, IN
