review_title: This company is good if you're a guy.
pros: Honeywell is a very old company that has been around a long time.  They have opportunties for advancement. Good benetis.
cons: It's great if you're a man. But females don't seem to advance.  There are not a lot of women in senior or managerial positions.  It's like the "old boys club".  Company is American, so a lot of their "ideals" don't match the Canadian work ethics here.  Human Resources is very disorganized.  Salaries could be brought up to the "norm" levels, it seems they pay lower than other companies in the types of positions.  Dave Cote is making MILLIONS, and is overpaid in my opinion.

review_title: Great pace to work near the beach
pros: Location in the tropics.  Competitive salary compared to local salaries nearby. Great facilities.  The people are very nice.  Opportunity to gain project experience.  They are very flexible with time management.  No need to come in early as long as you complete your required hours.  High ceilings and an open environment.  Ethical attitude.
cons: Limited growth.  Almost impossible to transfer to a site in the US, even though it is the same job/responsibilities.  Constant focus on cost cutting and efficiency.  Lots of work (although that is also a good thing).  High turnover in department.

pros: Lots of opportunities and room for career development if you can stomach the politics.  Decent benefits but they are continuing to reduce them under the guise of cost savings.
cons: Inconsistent direction and constant leadership changes have caused the business unit I was with to falter badly.  They have reduced headcount to the absolute minimum and can barely execute to keep the lights on let alone drive change and innovation

job_title: Principal Systems Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good place to gain experience in basic engineering practices and processes.  There's opportunity for growth within certain segments.
cons: The bottom line numbers trump everything; practices to show growth/revenue targets were met go to the point of being detrimental to the long term viability of the business.  Aside from deleterious accounting/business decisions, three furloughs and two layoffs in 2016 within the Aerospace unit did little to raise the declining morale.

review_title: Frustration; Lazy Union; No investment in employees
pros: Opportunity to learn new skills, opportunity to meet and learn from good leaders
cons: Laying people off, forcing people to retire, forcing people to work mandatory overtime for 6 days a week. Very little leadership development, corporate micromanaging, very negative and frustrating place to work. no investment in employees, it's a revolving door of young motivated people trying to make a name for themselves at the bottom of the pay scale. They cancel annual raises, cut training programs like Green belt doc Sigma, old dirty building that has water leaking through the roof when it rains. Benefits are discouraging.

review_title: One of the worst corporate experience.
pros: Nothing to share here as a honest techie ,cant find a place in this area for Honeywell.
cons: The worst work environment I have experienced in my 20 plus years of corporate life. All mangers are looking for boot licking juniors and if anyone raise a concern or complexity instead of looking into the reality they will start playing politics and force you to leave the company. Especially the industrial safety products team in Hyderabad and  its Indian leadership (Hyderabad and Bangalore) are grown with others favor and they want same stuff from their juniors as well. A worst example of slavery and highest level of regionalism and office politics. A sinking ship in reality.

review_title: Great company culture, great people and challenging interesting work in a company that values design
job_title: Senior User Experience Designer in North Ryde
pros:
Honeywell really values design and innovation from the top down.
It's a great, friendly, no politics atmosphere where ideas are shared freely and ideas come to life that make a difference to our users.
Everyone is really talented and motivated to do amazing work.
Everything is driven off experience outcomes for our customers.
Lots of team activities
Opportunities to travel and perform OVOC.
Table tennis table.
cons: Its not close to good places to shop or eat.  The coffee around there is not great.

review_title: I enjoyed my days at Honeywell
pros: Over all very attractive place to work.  Everyone very kind in the office, family like.  We understood our product and did a great job with engineering,  We made the revenue, our small group of 35 employees.  We felt valued like we were making a difference.
cons: Higher management out of touch with our overall contribution to the company.  Took the easy way of sending our jobs and technology overseas.  This is a time when the US needs to hold on to the jobs that are producing, products are being designed and bringing revenue to the bottom line.

review_title: Downhill slide in U.S and other developed Countries
pros: Great place to learn, get involved, have fun with many different people, types of products, factory locations around the world.
cons: Over past few yearsOutsourcing of U.S. jobs has been rampant.  Highly qualified excellent performing people let go and jobs moved to low cost countries at low cost salaries and output levels.  No future professional career paths for U.S. employees.

job_title: Software Engineer III in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Work with some great people.  Very diverse and respectful place to work.  We make interesting and cutting edge products.  Fantastic work enviroment.  Productivity increases from the Hon Operating System and other intiatives have been great especially the last two years.

100% paid for generic drug prescriptions with out the deductable.

 Top  mangement, CEO and Division presidents seem very capable and nice people. BUT...
cons:
Very little to no raises in 2012. 
NO RAISES for everyone in 2013.
Company stock is doing fantastic.  Just annouced a 10% dividend increase. 
So why no raises?
Health Insurance is super expensive.  Just announce 5% increase for health and dental.
We pay more than 400% more for a high deductable health plan ($3000 family deductable) than I paid for the exact same plan at my last employer.  And my last employer was a significantly smaller company than Honeywell.  
Employees suspect since Honeywell is self insured for health care that the company actually makes money on us.  Maybe this is not true, but the company does not share that information, so how do we really know.
Top executives including CEO got HUGE bonuses, stock options, long term growth awards, private jets etc.  and we got no raises, no bonuses.
Other benefits are average at best.
NO health club benefits
Very little starting vacation even for very senior people. 
NO Bonus for most salary people unless you have people reporting to you.,
NO Holiday Bonus, lunches, free turkey etc.
If you fly for work and go all the way to say China, it is in coach.

review_title: Good company to work for if you are looking for long term stay
job_title: Associate Operations Lead in San Diego, CA
pros:
**Stability of employment, great vacation benefits as seniority grows
**There is always opportunity for overtime due to lean workforce, 
**Excellent opportunity to learn lean / six sigma methodologies with the Honeywell Operating system
cons:
Poor follow up with HR related issues
Too lean of a management core allow for many issues to be left unattended / unresolved
Poor level of accountability specially on the manufacturing floor
Talent base is largely gone...  unwillingness to attract talent to stay competitive

job_title: Senior HSE Engineer in Tucson, AZ
pros: Good view of the mountains.
cons: If you work here you will be understaffed and they work you hard. we have been understaffed on and off the four years I have been there. They do not invest in the infrastructure and are about to realize a tidal wave of issues. Seems they can't out of their own way to fill a job. Been 6 months since my manager left, holding a carrot in front of me well I'm not going to be fooled any more Time to move on.

job_title: Systems Engineer III in Clearwater, FL
pros: Competitive Salary, Location, Benefits, Performance Bonuses, Flexible Work Hours, Apply Embedded GPS/INS (EGI) to various Military Aircraft which included R&D, Requirements Development, Static & Dynamic Testing and Troubleshooting issues in the field. Many Engineers spend entire career with company.
cons: Most Engineers in department have many years experience which makes it difficult to relate & communicate. Layoffs are too common and furloughs are required depending on status of Aerospace finances.

pros: Salary is reasonably good, given the cost of living in my area. There are (or at least were) a lot of very skilled and knowledgeable people and opportunities to work on interesting and challenging projects.
cons: Employee benefits have been reduced in recent years - cut 401K Matching in half, eliminated work from home option, and went to 'unlimited vacation' approach. This - on top of 3 weeks of furlough in 12 months, RIFs and no raises in 2016 - evidences that upper management does not greatly value its workforce. Main focus now is to meet AOP in the short term at all costs.

review_title: Join here if you don't want to learn anything new and settle in a company for rest of your life
pros: Great Work Life Balance, Good Salary and Perks
cons:
Everything goes slow here. If you request a software or hardware for your work, it may take few months to get it. People are lazy here. I joined here as a UX designer and even after 2 months I didn't get the essential tools for my work.  So I had to quit. 

Lot of politics from Management. Nobody cares about doing good work. You do some scam and survive.

review_title: Diversified multinational that provides challenging & interesting work, shareholder focus drives behaviors.
pros: Numerous growth opportunities.  Excellent training ground.  World class employees. Ability to move between industries and stay with one company.  Dynamic business environment with regular change to shed the dead wood.
cons: Employees sometimes sacrificed to please shareholder demands.  Globalization rules the day in recent years.  Short term success focus often at the expense of long term success.  Sink or swim culture where some good people end up drowning if too ambitious.

review_title: Good people, stingy management, good place to work if you are not interested in growth
pros: Very knowledgable and technically strong work force. Competent and smart front line managers. The salary is reasonable. Good work life balance.
cons: Senior management has become real cheap. Very few opportunity for growth - promotions are once every10-12 years if you are lucky. HR has a mission - find ways to make life miserable for its employees. No long term growth focus from product perspective. Management believes on milikng the existing product line and squeezing every ounce possible from its employees.

review_title: An overall fulfilling year of experience
pros: Salary is competitive, Work environment encourages creativity and good results, regular award schemes for those who do well, very focused, tie-ups with universities for study along with regular work to earn a degree, quite transparent, encourage extra-curricular activities during annual fests, conscious about helping society through conducting various social programs. Very professional in their approach, all administrative processes are very smooth.
cons: Tendency in the beginning to allocate new graduates based on current requirements and openings without properly accounting for their interests and specific backgrounds. Had to struggle to change HR's mind, but the HRs were willing to help.

job_title: Systems Engineer III in Dallas, TX
pros: Prestigious company, great technology, comfortable environment, interesting projects. Work life balance is good. Good benefits that are getting worse as time goes on.
cons: Meeting overload is a constant problem. Too much time wasted in meetings that could be accomplished with group email or a simple group online chat session.

pros:
Honeywell has job security. Honeywell has not been through layoffs any point if time I have seen. So you get a good night sleep. :-)
It has various divisions to work with.
cons: You'll almost all the time required to do overtime. In certain groups there is no focus on technology advancement. Instead of it like to spend money on Toyota principles and thinks that it will automatically enhance the technical environment.

job_title: Electrical Engineer in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great mission impacting national security.  Great job security with a lot of opportunity for growth and/or advancement, especially for those early in career.
cons: Benefits have been changing rapidly over the last three to four years.  401k matching is reduced, healthcare has moved to High Deductible Healthcare Plan without a reduction in premiums.  Pensions are no more for new hires.

pros: Great people make the job rewarding.  Opportunities to be promoted from within.
cons: Company made 38.6 Billion in 2015, no one got raises.  Excessive overtime.  Company does more to keep shareholders happy than they do employees.  Distribution Centers (Warehouses) increase profit by shipping orders early to customers, even taking shipments out through the following month to increase revenue in the current month.  This increases demand on man-hours to make up the lost revenue the following month and then compounds overtime to show false profits.

review_title: Honeywell has their hands in UOP's honeypot...
job_title: Chemical Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Back in the day, over a decade ago now, UOP used to be a fantastic company to work for.
cons:
However, since the Honeywell takeover in 2005, Honeywell has slowly squeezed the lifeblood out of UOP. If you are considering working for UOP, please note that their workload swings every few years from extreme highs of 190% capacity down to extreme lows of 30% capacity.

Please don't waste your valuable time applying to UOP, a company who once cared greatly for its employees and treated them like family... now managed by Honeywell, a company who cares only for itself.

pros: They do have match 401K contributions.  They have 'unlimited vacation' policy (US).
cons:
They do not look out for employees.  RIF's (Reduction in Force) are occurring frequently.  New 401k Matching contribution changed.  Now instead of getting the match with every paycheck you ONLY get it on Jan 31 of the following year. You need to be employed at HON on Dec 15 to be eligible.  Thus, if you get RIF'd or quit on Dec. 1 (or anytime before that) you will NOT get the matching contribution.
Regarding the unlimited vacation policy.  Again, if you get RIF'd or leave on your own there is no 'unused vacation' paid.  All vacation much be approved by manager.
Honeywell shows little respect for their employees.  
Sadly, this company used to be an awesome place to work.  For the last 7 years it has been a steady decline....

pros: Honeywell offers a chance for employees, tier level management, and executive management to recognize other internal employees based on the companies 8 Behaviors.  The pay-for-performance work culture and rewards system allows us to feel the success of doing a great job that affects the overall whole of the business.
cons: Sometimes the level of detail within one's own job is not known by others within the company, therefore when you go beyond in your job expectations your effort is not recognized by your internal customer.

job_title: Electrical Engineer in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: At Honeywell they have a fantastic initiation process to become familiar with all the internal processes and all external processes that we need to involve ourselves in. And I think most importantly, we have an excellent work environment. We are encouraged to spend time getting to know each other, be curious about areas beyond our own and go beyond the spectrum of our direct responsibilities.
cons: Since my current position requires a lot of international travel, it is unfortunate that we have to pay for our own visas. Although it will be reimbursed, since the embassy appointments are dependant on the payment date it is not ideal if it is your first job or simply do not have the money at hand.

review_title: If you enjoy feeling disrespected, then you will love working here.
job_title: Work Flow Specialist in Renton, WA
pros: The pay is pretty decent for the work performed.
cons: Too many to list.  The company does not value their employees one bit, and they show it.  Management is completely disorganized and segmented, and the bad managers seem to get promoted while they fire the good ones. No room for advancement unless you want to be a brainless "yes man".  Everything the company does or says is a lie.  This is one of the worst companies to work for.

review_title: Diversified and global organization with great benefits
pros: Diversified organization enables many job-growth opportunities for advancement. Honeywell offers leadership and personal development courses to all employees. I find the opportunities to be product specfic or product wide knowledge always challenging to my career-path.   Innovation attempts are paramount to success.
cons:
Diversified organizations or global companies are to slow to respond to emerging technologies in their space.
New techologies are slow in the pipe line to emerge to the marketplace. Honeywell does however place great importance on new product development. The challenge to keep new porducts portfollio constantly updated and new products to the marketplace .  Consumers or B2B  want innovation in a timely fashion

pros: Good salary structure thats above the industry avaerage, good interaction with folks from senior management across locations.
cons: The Senior Management is too afraid of losing their jos to stand up for their employees, there are way to many levels in the organization, the HR plays a very small role and doesnt have much say in charting the career path, growth is stunted and there are not too many challenging roles on offer.  Co-workers - the old timers, anyway. They've been doing the same thing, the same HTSI has a long history of placing people in positions different than initially described, promised, or within the employees' actual desires or skill set.

job_title: Project Engineer III in Houston, TX
pros: The company offers a great benefits package and presents a technological challenge to all employees that are motivated self starters that need little leadership instruction.  The opportunities for advancement are fair if you are newly joining the company but with an expereinced background.  Employee and company sponsored events are often available and fellow employees are relativity helpful and easy to work with.  The mentorship program is in process and aimed toward non traditional employees as well as new hires and those that are returning to the workforce.  Overall the company has its good and bad points but that is always bound to change under the right leadership.
cons: Slim Knowledge base.  Career building draw backs

pros: Large company, variety of career opportunities.  Depending on the business unit, there can be a range of relocation options available.  Also, Honeywell generally values training and development.  The culture is fairly relaxed and dress code is business casual in most areas.  People are friendly and usually helpful.
cons: Sometimes slow moving, not  the most dynamic industries.  There is a wide range of cultures between the divisions.  Some have morale issues, especially areas with large numbers of jobs being cut or moved overseas.  The compensation/benefits are in line with what's available at similarly sized companies.  Acquisitions can sometimes be a big headache.

review_title: Opportunities for driven, talented people who have thick skin.
pros: Good opportunities to gain complementary experiences in related roles, all without changing companies.  Reasonable job security for those who get demonstrative results.  Fairly objective system for performance assessment and merit pay increases, to the extent that it is possible with different managers.  There has been a fair amount of change in the past 5 years regarding how the entire company is managed, creating a more unified culture and achieving greater synergies from the prior cobbling of companies making the conglomorate.  In the Aero SBG in particular, however, the cultural change has not been as significant, possible due to the longevity of many career Honeywell Aero employees.
cons:
The leadership tends  to swing dramatically from one critical initiative to the next, often at the expense of prior progress.  For example, the current economic environment has caused a singular focus on working capital liquidity (even though the company is in excellent standing in this regard) at the expense of long-term footprint strategy - an executive blocked a move to a manufacturing center of excellence in Europe that closely matched the technical capability required for certain product in favor of a move to a Mexican COE because the temporary rise in inventory needed to make the move across the pond was 'unacceptable'.  As a result we will have a mismatch of strategy  and product at this location (and reduced long term savings) to "save" a short-term blip in inventory.
Other downsides include the "other side of the coin" of the job security benefit: the organization has members at all levels that have outlived their ability to perform the job (i.e. the job has increased in technical requirements or the environment has changed, but they have not kept up).  Also, there is little effort placed on recruiting and retaining early-career employees, such as from universities, particularly as the economy has worsened.  Rather than invest in the future employees the leadership is content to wait for a crisis of retiring experts.

pros: You can gain knowledge of many areas and there are certainly options for sideways movement.  Company somewhat encourages movement to gain expertise in multiple areas.  Pay is on par and benefits package is pretty good, though current times have reduced this.  Plenty of time out of work to have a life.
cons: Not much room or fostering of people to move up in position.  Organization pretty stagnant.  Work being performed is not very intellectually rewarding.

review_title: Mind-numbing work, no training, average pay, no opportunities for advancement.
pros: Decent facilities, really easy work, almost impossible to get fired.
cons: The company wastes potential of employees. There is a lack of training and opportunities for growth and no apparent link between achievement and reward. The company is quite disorganised and there is little management support in solving problems. This is very frustrating for employees and customers. There is a culture of staying in the office late for no reason and employees spend most of their time in fairly useless meetings that turn into endless whinge-sessions.

review_title: A company of creating proprietary processes that are useless in industry
pros: It is nice to have a job to put food on the table, but search for another job quickly before your skills are obsolete.
cons: All processes are copied existing standards that are regurgitated in a more verbose style.  Training on the original standards such as DO-178B would be much better than creating internal standards that map to the original.  Internal training is very poor.  Working here is a good springboard to find another job, but find another job quickly before the skills are obsolete.  This organization does not understand that 3rd party certification and training is much better than their internal training.  Also this company suffers from a high degree of nepotism.

review_title: Tough place to maker a career
pros: Decent starting pay, very good people at a level where stuff actually gets done, great technology pipeline, excellent reputation, very profitable, flex hours and ability to work from home when needed, good place to develop experience, strong stock price
cons: Worst medical benefits ever !!!!  Most employees end up on spouse plans.  Very intrusive policies.  Some of the worst managers I have seen in my 25 yr career.  They manage up and manage their careers only.  Not a very personable place to work and very political.  No real pension.  Cutting benefits left and right.  Work life balance can be a challenge.  Lots of butt kissing and favoritism with no accountability.  Very few promotions unless you jump from job to job.  Arrogant business practices make customer interactions very challenging.  Lots of red tape and programs that handcuff ability to deliver results.  A culture that doesn't empower employees and policies that restrict creativity.  Raises are miniscule and don't keep up with inflation so net pay decreases over time unless you want to move from job to job.  Consensus decision process that dilutes results.  If you are outspoken, watch out, it will bite you.  Very poor communication.  Some of the most arrogant self serving leadership anywhere.  If you find a role you truly love, accept that you will stagnate in it.

pros: I work with (or worked with before they left) good people.
cons: I was hired as a remote worker, and accepted the job based on the work from home policy. The company has recently revoked this policy for all workers for no reason. Many of us work globally via Skype, starting our days at 5am and being highly available for this type of need, so taking away WFH makes zero sense. They have also cut benefits and i have never received a merit raise or bonus, even though i am consistently rated highly by management and peers.

pros: Traveled for work.  Team members were awesome. Couple of great bosses out of 22 years of service.  MBA degree paid, worked from home.
cons: Managed to make it through MULTIPLE layoffs/RIFs (Reduction in Force) over my 22 years there. Focus is on making the numbers and Wall Street's reactions as well as which company they can next acquire.  Benefits are so so.  This is such a big company that they can't do more than industry standards.  Lots of jobs moved to Mexico, or if not moved then just filled in Mexico to begin with.  Pay was not that great - even with MBA took many many years to work up salary ladder

pros: Challenging work and nice people
cons: Upper management is as crooked as a politician. They take away benefits at every opportunity and when they're shamed into doing something remotely positive, they find a way to make everyone feel worse. Now our 401k match is credited only if you stay with the company through December. Otherwise no match.

pros:
-Great company to start a career out of college
-Interesting work
-They're starting to hire young eager people
-Competitive entry-level pay
-401k Matching increased
-The people
cons:
-Frustrating High-deductible health plan
-Work-Life balance
-Incentives
-Procedure-based system slows productivity 
-Employee Moral is low because of the above and because of layoffs last year
-Typical Shareholder focused company, not employee focused
-A lot of Senior staff (Clearwater, FL)  have been here their whole lives, they're entitled and will throw anyone under if it means they look good in the end.

pros: Decent salary, easy job as in low-stress.
cons:
It seems management wants only yes-men. Challenging the status quo either will get you in trouble or you will find that it is more trouble than its worth.

No bonuses for good performance and it seems like the ones who make the most noise or are the most bureaucratic hold the highest positions. Easy to hide your incompetence at this place. All the smart people want to leave the company and they all will eventually when the economy gets better.

review_title: Grew up in the company from my 20s to my 50s
pros: Really great products made by some of the most talented people in the world. Diverse workforce, diverse locations, and a diverse portfolio of products and services allowing a rich career experience and oppotunity to build a unique skill mix.
cons: forced ranking. Takes too long to get poor performers with slick personalities out. They almost always do get let go but only after their true performance is revealed.

review_title: Good overall, not likely long term
pros: Big company with lots of resources, good starting pay, flexible schedule.
cons: Benefits are not great, only average at best.  There is little opportunity for advancement, and the merit increase system is a joke.  Unless you get promoted (not likely) you can't even keep up with inflation.  Management has conflicting goals.  Most only care about revenue at the expense of everything else.

review_title: Great Company. Just understand where you're going within the Company before you jump in.
pros: Old-fashioned Americana value-based company. They value people more than most modern corporations; and Honeywell is a juggernaut of a corporation. It's great to be a part of.
cons: Bureaucracy. However, most large companies have this. My particular department was small and remote from the company mainstream - as we were a small acquisition. It was like being living on a small remote Island off the coast of Alaska with a population of 20 people and telling foreigners you live in the USA. It's not a lie, but sure doesn't give an accurate picture to outsiders. Avoid this problem.

review_title: Boring and process driven, but the processes allow predictability and stability
job_title: Engineer III Mechanical in Torrance, CA
pros:
In Aerospace, product development is 110% engineering driven. I haven't heard of a project being pushed through without total consensus from all parties. Schedules are driven at a high level, but each group has the time to do their job with appropriate thoroughness.

Little to no politics, bickering, or personal vendettas, at least at the lower levels.

Stable work. Enforcement of local department processes and spreading work out helps prevent individuals from becoming protective of their knowledge and/or unfirable single points of failure.

They don't "do" mass layoffs like the other defense companies. When they do get rid of people, it's for true incompetence or rulebreaking, and it's targeted. 

Work-life balance is good.
cons:
Work output and deliverables are highly standardized. If you're here for 20 years, you won't have 20 years of experience - you will have 1 year of experience 20 times over. 

No opportunities for advancement unless you apply for a job in another department through the careers website like an outsider.

Micromanagement gets very annoying, but at least you usually only have to make your front line manager happy.

Rigid enforcement of roles means that if you have skills outside your job title, you will be discouraged if not punished outright for doing anything that another group is supposed to be responsible for.

Cafeteria isn't the best, off-campus food options are limited

Benefits are awful. No 401k matching the first year, only 3% the second year, and the health plans are mostly high deductible HSAs.

IT is a godawful outsourced-to-india-can't-understand-a-word-they're-saying waste of time. Takes 3 months to get a new employee a computer, but at least you don't have to go through that very often.

pros:
Honeywell offers higher salaries than most companies on the Romanian market, but don't expect big raises over the years, so keep that in mind when you negotiate your starting salary. 
The benefits are also better - employees can choose between transport cards, vacation vouchers, private pension, extra medical insurance, etc.
cons: Depending on the job you might have to do a lot of overtime. The fiscal year is the same as the calendar year, so the December- January period is a really busy time for finance departments.

pros: Good market correction. I received it twice. Good hikes. Nice people to work. Lot to learn in Avionics System Side. Your voice will be heard by your manger and they will respect. You can share your opinion openly
cons: HOS. Though you are performing beyond your role you have to wait till your seniors gets promotion so that you can get promotion. You have to spent two years to get promotion though you attain around 4 years still you will be engineer.

pros: Good market correction. I received it twice. Good hikes. Nice people to work. Lot to learn in Avionics System Side. Your voice will be heard by your manger and they will respect. You can share your opinion openly
cons: HOS. Though you are performing beyond your role you have to wait till your seniors gets promotion so that you can get promotion. You have to spent two years to get promotion though you attain around 4 years still you will be engineer.

review_title: Corporate does not seem to care about employees
pros: People I work with are great.  Everyone works together to get the job done and meet our goals.  Very good work life balance.
cons: Benefits not the greatest.  Corporate hides a lot.  No communication of why certain decisions are being made.  We are losing a lot of very good young engineers due to corporate decision and lack of explanation.

pros: None that come to mind.
cons:
They don't value their employees.  Poor benefits and they get worse every year. Implement new policies that negatively impact the employee.  Seems like the CEO just wants to cater to the investors at the expense of the employee.

Also with such a large corporate environment everything takes 5x longer than it should to get things done and there are too many layers of management for anyone that is not a Sr Manager or Director to have any impact on change.

review_title: First 2 months at HTS Bangalore Karnataka India
pros:
No limits to learn and implement.
Competitive Work Environment.
People are good with strong technical skills you can learn from and grow.
Fun place to work with good pay/perks.
Support staff (vendor - Sodexo) is very active and responds immediately.
cons:
No work from home - discontinued few months ago - however, it can be availed in emergency conditions with Manager's approval.
Only 1 food court vendor - Sodexo.

review_title: Great technology and huge market but too big and dispersed and poor execution!
pros:
1. Great technology and experience to gain from
2. Flexibility
cons:
1. Too many hours required to put in to get good results 
2.  Teams are spread worldwide. You get flexibility but your workday has no set schedule and end - start your day at 5 am and go on till midnight
3.  A lot of micromanagers around 
4.  Employee with aggression and tendency to yell in meetings move up fast 
5. Too many processes and everything is focused on revenue. More time is spent on project planning and revenue review than actual execution 
6. Decent compensation but poor benefits

pros: Talented Co-workers; fast track advancement for middle managers only.
cons: The company is very rapidly changing under the same leadership that destroyed the stock value of GE. Internally focused management has completely lost site of customer satisfaction and are interested in squeezing profits and stock value only.  Account managers are left to pick up the embarresment of half baked products introduced to the field.

pros: I get a paycheck. I have a service vehicle. Good 401k match.
cons: No room to advance unless you are related.  Lower level supervisors are just a body.  Area "leader" leaves a great deal to be desired.  Company nickels and dimes the employees and milk the same customers.  Have not had a "new" customer in years.  Management rules by fear..... constant fear of being fired.  Unfair policies.  For a fortune 100 company as an employee i expected more, especially with the name Honeywell.

review_title: Awful place to work!!!  Run away, don't walk!
job_title: Field Quality Engineer in Clearwater, FL
pros: None, None, None, None and No Pros at all!  Glassdoor makes you complete at least one star for overall rating.  I wish I could leave it blank.  This place is awful.
cons: All they care about is immediate shareholder value.  They would sell their own children to make the stock move $1.  They don't even care about the future as they figure it will be the next guys problem.  No investment in new designs or talent.  They lay off RIF every few months.  They are replacing many of us with contract workers.  DO NOT ACCEPT AN OFFER FROM THIS COMPANY!

job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Baltimore, MD
pros: Honeywell is one of the World's Great companies. Financially astute, Technologically advanced beyond state of the art, and with diverse leadership that sets the standard in the Fortune 500 World.  Cream of the Crop, Best of the best.  Career Growth is only limited by one's ability and personal preference. Silo's do not stand in the way.  Offering the World's greatest products/solutions to the benefit of the world's greatest Industrial Customers.  Honeywell's Eight Behaviors are a blueprint to success in the Business World
cons: I wish I would have come to Honeywell sooner

pros: Great leadership team under Darius' leadership. Clear long term and short term visions set for the organization's growth. Interesting and challenging yet rewarding work assignments. Opportunity for international work assignments on short term and long term basis. Managers do really care about the team members and about their career goals, aspirations and development. Modern workspaces  with  recerational amenities. Great set of product lines and offering.
cons: I have been working here for over 6 years and have not come across any issues. Prior to this assignment, my work tenure with other corporates was around 1.5 years.  The fact that I have stayed for a long time says a lot about why Honeywell is a great place to work.

review_title: You'd be lucky to work for honeywell
job_title: Customer Service Representative  in Toms River, NJ
pros: I am a mother with a small child, if i need to go they make it work. We joke when can and we are serious and business like when we are supose to and have to. we are a very good dependable group, and management lets us know beside just a pat on the back. health insurance is awsome. you can choose between a few different ones.
cons: dealing with the different companies and remembering they don't always run as smoothly as honeywell. perscription, dental and eyeglass coverage sucks a little.

review_title: Honeywell is better than typical large company
job_title: Senior Firmware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Manageable workloads with variety of tasks and learning opportunities.  Better scheduling than typical high tech environment.  Generally enough resources to support projects, and time to do a good job.  Good pay, excellent benefits, flexible leave and work hours.
cons: Like other larger companies, cumbersome bureaucracy and rigid policies can interfere with completing tasks or obtaining resources.  Heavyweight processes like Six Sigma can be overkill or inappropriate for small projects that don't need such elaborate testing or measurement.  Lack of coordination between departments may delay projects.

review_title: Neutral - good for experienced people to settle down
pros: If you have more domain knowledge you will be respected. Work life balance, flexible hours. Prefer to join in a higher cadre
cons:
1. No onsites will be 5-10% in life unless you are very close to your manager
2. No recognization for work what you did. You have to market it to Managers.
3. Pay is not according to standards
4. Hikes n perks very low.
5. Year reviews some times will be very hectic. You can't digest those comments.

review_title: Incompetence among senior ranks due to "good old boy network"
pros: Loyal folks working in the company's lower levels, they take a lot of pride in their work
cons: With the latest re-organization so many layers have been created at the VP, Director level within the corporate organization it has turned into a white elephant. Difficult to get things done and due to the "good old boy network" a rash of incompetent players have added a new dimension of non-value add.

review_title: A series of highs and lows.
pros: Great benefits, okay wages, lots of great and very talented people (when they can keep them).  The Mississauga location has a huge full-service cafeteria, full gym, showers and even an on-site doctor & nurse. Flexible hours.
cons: Moral is low most of the time. Always a dark cloud of 'layoff possibilities' overhead. A lot of outsourcing to other countries brings down productivity. Not a lot of energy in the environment, it can bring you down.  Sometimes feel more like a number than a valued employee.  Lack of qualified leadership and too many organizational changes.

pros: It is a successful, growing and well respected company with a drive for continuous improvement, which involves all employees. Honeywell is developing and expanding product offerings to position itself growth in current and future markets. They are investing in correcting issues within the supply chain to improve performance to their customers.
cons: The demands on time for keeping abreast of the continual flow of information, both job related and organizational, growing scope of responsibilities and maintenance of database inputs. The survey requests are endless.

job_title: Process Engineer in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Large cooperation with an emphasis on training and access to many resources. Honeywell is a stable company.
cons:
Honeywell is a large cooperation but chemicals are not its core business. The decisions that are made from the cooperate level are not consistent with operating a chemical plant safely and efficiently. This leads to unsafe working conditions and repeat failures. 

Benefits are mediocre at best, low raises, and no bonuses make the job unrewarding financially. High turnover rate does not allow for any sustained progress.

review_title: Fast paced, lean culture, hard-working environment.
pros: Growth, change management focus, you will learn an amazing amount about 6 and lean sigma in a short amount of time.  Constantly striving to be better and driving results.
cons: Fast paced, almost breakneck speed, high expectations of all employees.  Just coming to work and doing a good job isn't enough - you have to shine and be a star performer to move up.  40 hour weeks don't exist - you will work evenings and weekends.

review_title: Good learning experience provided you "get" the right opportunities
pros:
- Good work life balance
- Job stability
- Good place to work for short term and see if you "land" up with right people who are open minded !
cons:
- Bureaucracy in different levels
- Mid-level management does not promote talent and is insecure

pros: Better company to start your career in and develop internally than being acquired
cons: Benefits are terrible; company will send jobs outside of US to low cost regions at every opportunity; people leave and do not get replaced - increase productivity internally and shift jobs to india or romania or mexico all to improve shareholder performance like most large US companies.  Destroyed our businesses positive culture and work enviroment - people leaving voluntarily that have been with org for years - of course they either do not get replaced or backfilled at snails pace.

pros: Better company to start your career in and develop internally than being acquired
cons: Benefits are terrible; company will send jobs outside of US to low cost regions at every opportunity; people leave and do not get replaced - increase productivity internally and shift jobs to india or romania or mexico all to improve shareholder performance like most large US companies.  Destroyed our businesses positive culture and work enviroment - people leaving voluntarily that have been with org for years - of course they either do not get replaced or backfilled at snails pace.

pros: Wonderful people on team.  Demanding and fast paced environment.  Good place to work if you are young and right out of school.
cons: No room for promotion unles you are one of the chosen few.  Lousy merit increases. Always rumors of reductions in force.  Management in Aerospace are always crying slow performance yet attend expensive resorts for meetings, fly internationally when not required, and take pay cuts out on the workers exempting themselves.  Then they turn around to Wall Street and say that they beat their performance forecast.

pros: Great colleagues trying to work to the best of their ability regardless of the circumstances.  Due to the implementation of lean and 6Sigma throughout the company, Honeywell has been able to build a strong reputation for quality products.
cons: Several years of reorganizations, furloughs, layoffs, and managements refusal to fill key positions have negatively impacted the company's once strong culture.  Employees all over the U.S. have been forced to do more with less, have had multiple changes in leadership, and have watched their colleagues be RIF'd all around them.  The mission and vision is no longer clear.

review_title: Dont believe HR Shill reviews, There is nothing posativer at Honeywell.
pros: The only Pro I can think of is Allied Signal will soon completely destroy another company reputation, and need to acquire another new name.
cons: Cut headcount to unsustainable levels drive employees to continuously do more and more (now driving for 35% overtime)  negative culture and moral from top down.  Employees are viewed as disposable, Seasoned subject matter experts are leaving the company but instead of acknowledging this as regrettable turnover, it is shrugged off as oh well just hire someone younger for less money.  HR is staffed by by 20 & 30 year old inexperienced pawns.   That think posting positive reviews are fooling anyone.

pros:
Working for a recognized brand name company
Potential to work on remote long-term assignments
cons:
* Little respect or trust for employees as people. Management often treats people with suspicion.
* No compassion or accommodation for special circumstances.
* Terrible or no benefits (medical or any other)
* High attrition rate 
* Work environment with many unhappy and frustrated employees (negative atmosphere)
* Aggressive and intimidating tactics to pressure people to work more
* Not a fun place to work at (e.g. no social activities)
* Very few competent people are left working at the site in Kanata. New employees always struggle to navigate their way through the system let alone understand it.
* No on-site HR personnel for employees 
* Big corporate culture with bureaucracy and confusing and irrelevant processes.
* Fast-pace environment, but with very little outcome/productivity.
* Employees feedback is often not translated into tangible changes.

review_title: Joining this company was the biggest mistake I have done in my life
pros: My work used to be awesome. Got to work in to deep architectural designs of aerospace.
cons: Egoistic management. They want technical people to work like donkeys for them. Management never knew how technical people do their work. And that made this company the worst to work with. There are many stupid projects in aerospace where they make us work on some tools and when we want to escape from this company nobody will accept us. My heartiest advice to freshers is that, management will tell that you are working on rocket science , but the truth is if you continue there, you can work only there. This is from my own experience. From past three years i am begging for jobs in other companies and nobody even respond.

review_title: Horrible Culture and Out of Touch Leadership
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Mill, SC
pros: Good pay, some great people
cons: Chaotic, lack of strategic direction from leadership, most people work in panic mode daily, lack of collaboration, global operation but corporate mandates you cannot work from home, except when it benefits them, working at a high level is fine but not when direction and priorities shift faster than other company I have worked for causing complete lack of productivity and momentum

pros:
1. Honeywell is a big platform that is worth paying for, where you will be exposed to a variety of technology masters, so as to make yourself grow rapidly.
Honeywell offers many opportunities to travel abroad, both in Europe and developed countries such as the United States.
3. On the whole, I'm very much in favor of working for honey.
cons:
1. If you're fit for business travel, this is perfect for you! Not only increase experience, but also enhance their ability. It is true that some places have a tough environment, but it is true that people can be trained and their efforts will be rewarded.
2. If it's not suitable for business travel, then you don't agree.

pros: Honeywell is a good company to help you grow and learn. It forces you out of your comfort zone. Also, the pay makes it worth it.
cons: There’s a lack of formal training and compassion from leadership. People struggle to fit in and find their place. There’s definitely a learning curve. It’s also an extremely aggressive and stressful work environment. Employees are expected to work at least some weekends without overtime. There’s been a decrease in paid holidays in some departments.

pros: Decent pay, good PTO/Vacation benefits, good company to work for, relatively clean and safe, if you're in you've probably knew someone or you're very lucky(in the location i've worked at anyway)
cons: Job security is questionable, one month we'll be told we are strong for the next 5 years to come business is good; to now recent lay off not even 2 years later..

review_title: World class organization. Frequent leadership structure upheaval.
pros: Able to utilize existing world class new product introduction methodologies and tool sets. Honeywell velocity product introduction builds in additional rigor with the ultimate goal of being faster, better, stronger, organized and metric centric.
cons:
Leadership team and structure transitions every 1-2 years. New initiatives which require culture change are continually being rolled out. The constant upheavals are exhausting. Difficult to deploy great tools like VPD when the structure and leaders are constantly changing. 

Benefit cost increases outpace salary increases.

pros: There are some very smart people working within the ranks of Honeywell, from entry level up to the C suite.  The breadth of products is enormous and opportunities are everywhere.
cons: The leadership team does not support the employees.  Many in the rank and file at Honeywell consider the leadership team's  order of precedence to be (starting with most important): self,  shareholders, customers.

review_title: Worked for 7 years. Ok types company
pros: Good work, job security, experienced ppl, solid process orientation.
cons: No work from home, very less growth chances , manager are trained to stop your career development n just give sugar coate words, cribbing around the count in India office and crying to give benefits to employee, cost cutting in every penny, old employee don't share knowledge so new employee has to suffer by self learning, below ok work life balance.

pros: A lot of very smart people.
cons: Back stabbing, dishonest people who are cut throat.  They work in silo's and care nothing about their people, it's all a facade.  HR is horrible and upper management is demanding to the point that you have no quality of life and the pay is below scale.

pros: Stable big company, lots of talented people to meet and work with.
cons: Managers are not able to react to the market changes quickly enough. Honeywell had grown to dinosaur size.

review_title: Too focused on profit at employees expense.
pros: Work life balance. Flex schedule.
cons: Declining benefits year over year, EVERY year. No 401K match per pay period, now annual lump sum in January, if and if you are employed on Dec 15th. So RIF's will now be commonplace the beginning of December & no benefit of compounding gains throughout the year. Pay is low versus peers for technicians. Engineers are compensated fairly with lots of promotion opportunities. They typically get promoted several times in the first few years of employment and are paid very well. Technicians have no path to move up and only 2 promotion possibilities throughout career.

pros: If you are friends with the supervisors they will lie for you and cover up your mistakes.
cons:
Poor quality no one cares of quality.
Documents are forged a numbers are just made up on a daily basis.
Hard work is penalized quality work is also penalized and you are retaliated on by The Slackers for making them look bad. Bottom line is it doesn't really matter how good or bad you are at your job just be friends with your supervisor no matter how much you hate them and they will make you look good.
Can not take any issues to the HR department nothing will ever be done and they will just gossip to the shop about whatever you tell them.

review_title: Great company to work, great opportunity to learn and improve on career path.
job_title: Senior Inspector Mehanical in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Honeywell provide you with a great opportunity to learn various technologies as well as real life scenarios as you progress along the career path, you are given responsibilities commensurate with your experience and though some are very challenging but you can always fall back to the wealth of resources available at your finger tip wherever you are in the world.
cons: My role involved a lot of travel and acclimatizing to different time zones and weather sometimes but this is part of the job, so you have to brace up for the challenges and excel at the end.

job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Salary slightly higher than market average
Some unique and innovative projects
cons:
Chaos, Chaos, CHAOS - unrealistic project deadlines forcing 12+ days nights and weekends.  need to work a variety of hours because of the different team time zones
Pompous and arrogant leadership that borders on incompetence - leadership has no experience with software development process and it shows.
Honeywell's employee model is to ask more and more of employees and when they burn out just replace them. HR's favorite phrases for the high turnover is something like: "Some people moved on to better opportunities" or "Those people were difficult to manage and it's unregrettable that they left" 
Management does not accept responsibility for high employee turnover

review_title: Large diverse company, huge variations in culture.
job_title: Senior IT Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Large global company.  Potential for global opportunities.   There are a lot of good, skilled people.  Written policies are good.
cons: Age descrimination.  Culture tends to be up and out.   Metrics focus on department performance, not overall value chain.  Short-term focus.   Most out-sourcing efforts have been overall negative to the company.  Too much yo-yo hiring.

pros: Very professional and fair. Good benefits package. Many resources available for R&D work including software, patent searching, literature searching. Many networking opportunities within the company, including international.
cons: This corporation is very large. As a result, the reasons behind decisions made at the corporate level can be very hard to understand at the local level. Agility and general ability to respond quickly to changing market conditions can be slow.

pros: The products, technology, and heritage of Honeywell make it a Mecca for engineers interested in aerospace and flight safety. Overall, there are good, smart people working on challenging problems on engineering and business issues.
cons: The industry downturn has limited the company's investment commitment compared to that of its industry peers. As a result, resources are severely constrained and friction has created poor morale amongst the survivors.

job_title: Customer & Product Support  Sr. Technical Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits, Dedicated hard working employees.
cons:
Massive lack of valuing the “workforce”. We have lost the focus of making this a family away from your family. We spend more time with our co-workers than our actual families. (Especially now that people are expected to work 50/60yhrs a week, while being compensated for 40). 10 years ago (Prior to GE’s interests and Allied Signal’s purchase) We were a family oriented business that people looked forward to serving 30-40 years and retiring from. Now we are a company that people can’t wait to find something better. It is made clear (By Sr. Leadership) that if you want to be compensated fairly, you will need to leave. We fail to invest in our people on the hopes that they will serve us loyally for their entire career. Failing to understand that hiring new employees to replace the high talent that leave for greener pastures costs a great deal of money, time, and greatly affects our ability to serve our customers (negatively)

HR is there to protect Honeywell, not the people.

Outsourcing, and reductions in force;  I am not talking about India and China here, there is a need to have diversity and coverage globally. However, years ago Honeywell manufactured the best Avionics in the industry and had an outstanding global support force. Now we are more interested in saving $10 a card or box that we can have some other business or country manufacture for us. Problem here is that we lose quality control of that product and it ends up costing us millions when they fail to perform at what we have guaranteed our customers they will.  Our world class global support has been cut to the bone forcing Avionics and Mechanical FSE’s to perform as “nose to tail” FSE’s..  Customers are not impressed. We are told to tell customers this is in an effort to be “Best in Class” (BIC) a term that most customers will tell you we “WERE” BIC prior to our re-org..

Leadership and its decisions are focused on two things and two things only; Stock performance, and Shareholder satisfaction. Customer and Employee satisfaction are distant after thoughts,.. In that order. Decissions and investments are focused on the short term vision,.. what will effect Stock performance and Shareholder satisfaction TODAY.. Until we realize that Stock performance and Shareholder satisfaction are byproducts of Customer and Employee satisfaction we will continue to be mediocre at best. 

Most of the workforce is grossly under paid, some in excess of $25,000 below the lower range of recommended salary ranges and what competitors are paying

And finally, our performance management process is broken badly. We are forced to differentiate our employees by a “numerical distribution” HR, Legal and Sr. Leadership will tell you that this is not the case. I am here to tell you it most definitely is.. We are forced in many cases to rate some of our high performers as mediocre, and even worse our “Steady Eddies” as low performers.. In order to hit our pre determined “numerical distribution” So much so that managers are being told that you will not differentiate your employees,  you will be “differentiated”

Until our executives understand that bonuses of up to 500 times the average salaries of their engineering force (Who by the way do not get ANY bonus) we will never be "Best in Class".

review_title: Place where you will learn alot but have slow advancement
pros: Lot of opportunity to learn from peers.  Will work with people from  very diverse educational, economic and culture differences. If you a person who wants to do their job and leave at the end of the day this is highly encourage.
cons: They do not put the resources into the sites for career advancement - only career skills opportunity. They outsource lots of career positions. Because of the diversity some of the less 'culture' individuals may say or do things that are 'rare'
