Honeywell follows such a policy that  unless the resource is Very very critical to the project manager and he will consider for Permanent payroll but again Management will say no why do you want new resource into Honeywell there are other employees why can't you search internally itself. It will be under hold and if the management is not able to find suitable resource for the project and if the project is for long run at-least the new resource is able to get chargeablity for more than 1 and half years continuously 

5.  Priority to the Process at any cost, management says follow the process,...

pros: Good company to grow within. Nice working environment, good tools to work with and if you look carefully you can find career models right next to you. Salaries are decent.
cons: In general the people are ready to support you but sometimes due to the workload they simply do not have the time to do it. And the rezistance to change is rather high.

review_title: Good company to work for, assuming you can get hired
pros: There are plenty of people to help out in uncertain situations, company seems to run from a financial basis which means hiring tends to be scarce. Working from home is good, Set your own schedule (some of the time)
cons: Groups are still scattered in the building, difficult to get help if the group is not in the same division, too many meetings to talk about other meetings and/or why work is not getting done

pros: Stable employer, good salary if you can negotiate it, very flexible time, good career opportunities, can change job within the company, international working environment. Friendly environment.
cons: While promotion opportunities are I'd say typical (or above typical!), the associated salary increase is capped, which means you should negotiate high starting salary, providing easier way up later on. Payraise thanks to performance evaluation is useles - makes too little difference.Office location is not very good.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Being Large there are more resources available such as expertise and money for equipment.  Pay was good.  Great stock to own because they do make money but at a cost, see cons.
cons:
Big corporate feel,..inefficient rules and procedure.  So you are pushed and measured by schedule but they put barriers all along the way like failure is by design.
Jobs are sent to China or India even if you can show that it is cheaper to do it here.  Not just production jobs but engineering too.  Merger & Acquisition is the means of growth so always looking to buy a company, cut workforce and move product line to China,

pros: Profitable company with long track record of success. Well respected executive leadership. Commitment to process excellence and cost control. Great people who care about customers.
cons: Too focused on shareholder at the expense of the employee.  Recent merit increase freeze and bonus reductions in ACS business unit are common tactics to control cost.  Shareholders win, executives win, employees lose

review_title: Corporate Greed is a disease that Honeywell has
pros: Good Money. Usually a good amount overtime (You'll need it to pay for your Health insurance)
cons: Honeywell is powered by Corporate Greed. They have a notorious reputation for offering very poor union contracts to their unionized plants. When these contracts are rejected, they kick their employees out into the street and replace them with a temporary work force that look like a group from a prison work release program. They leave their loyal workers out in the street (for years sometimes) until they have to sign the lousy contract. Don't believe me, Google it.

job_title: Mechanical Design Engineer in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
- Great peers, Good discussions to enrich yourself with tad bit of engineering knowledge.
- Managers don't really interfere with personal life and provide high 'degrees of freedom' when it comes to vacation plans or working hours.
- Impeccably organized work process makes your job and trouble shooting easier.
- Some the best minds in the industry with whom you'll be working with. And of course best to ignore the self-proclaimed industrial stalwarts. 
- If you've very little aspirations in life and are happy being complacent, then this is a place for you my friend. Special benefits if you've a detailed engineering background.
cons:
I joined right out of college, and below is just my perspective:
-You'll have a wonderful experience with what I call 'Delusion-Engineering'. You complete a number of projects, but still will have no clue as to what you've been working on and what the design actually looks  like in reality. Sad part of the story is that most around you are also sailing on the same boat as you're. No field experience makes the mechanical engineering job atrociously monotonous. It makes you lose interest and helps little in keeping yourself motivated for years to come. 
- Can find the disparity between the chemical engineers and mechanical engineers being very evident, from the simplest of things to the on the job requirements/opportunities.
- Very limited growth opportunities, there's not much you could aspire for as there is stagnation in the entire hierarchy.  You're given very few, actually none, opportunities for career growth. Don't be surprised if you do hear some opportunity coming your way, there's nothing but a disappointment yet again waiting for you.
- You'll have mediocre, slow-witted and incapable group leads ( so-called managers) you'd be reporting to. I know it's not healthy and professional to ridicule anyone, but you cant help it when you've been reporting to people who are submissive and unassertive, who'll never have your back no matter how much output you deliver but only will find opportunities to belittle you.  
-There are futile and pointless discussion on career growth that happen very year, neither are you evaluated fairly nor are you appreciated for the quality work that you deliver. This is especially in regards to the mediocre group leads that you report to in your initial years who have no idea how to keep employees motivated, absolutely ZERO managerial skills.  
-Quality of work you do either isn't any worth if you're looking to grow big in life in the field of engineering. Neither does it enrich you're engineering (reactor designing) knowledge, not does it add any significant skills that you can boast about.  Most times, you loose interest in engineering, just like I did. The market doesn't need value your experience either, so you end up narrowing down your opportunities.
- Pay is good, but you wouldn't see increments coming your way. Increments  are based neither on your diligent working nor on the quality work that you delivery consistently. They are entirely based on what the management calls "progressive evaluation", which only the management understands.
-'Bond' will the protagonist to your story as well,  but only wish if it were as elegant as James Bond. You're put on the job with very little training, no on-field experience, no travel/training opportunities that you gain during your stay for the employee agreement to make any sense. I reckon, management uses it as a leverage to retain employees which is abysmal and unprofessional. To me, bond does not seem applicable to the college graduates, and they'll stand by the company through the thick and thin only if the management provides them with opportunities that graduates from the premier institutes of the country aspire for.

job_title: Sales Engineer (Fast Track Development Program) in Kuala Lumpur
pros: The company promotes independence, as well as self-motivation. They allow us to set our own goals, in agreement with our own managers. The office space is also beautiful, and comfortable. Wonderful working environment. One thing I enjoy is the open office space, where we don't have a set workstation, but are allowed to move around everyday.
cons: Too many onboarding tasks, which may be quite confusing for someone new to the company. However, the wonderful thing is that we are given ample time to complete all these tasks.

pros: Exciting work environment, decent pay, but it's certainly way lower for aerospace standard industry pay. Opportunities for advancement are plenty.
cons: Management is slow and seems to undervalue it's employees. I've seen a lot of engineers leave in my time, and I've heard of many not being properly evaluated. Pay needs to be on par with aerospace industry, not just standard for Honeywell.

review_title: Great Experience,  a LOT of work
job_title: Senior Procurement Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great for career experience,  a lot of opportunity to expand resume.
cons: Too much flux within the organization currently, between changes in organization and changes in management, creates an unstable feeling for the employees

review_title: Love the Breadth of Knowledge Gained at Honeywell
pros: I have worked as a systems engineer on multiple avionics systems across multiple aircraft types.  I have enjoyed the daily challenges, and the feeling of a job well done at project completion.  My job is fulfilling.
cons: Honeywell adheres strongly to business based metrics that requires employees have multiple charge numbers.  This often leads to customer dissatisfaction if an issue identified is out of scope for a charge number.

review_title: It's a large company with all the problems with come with it
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Atlanta, GA
pros:
- Free Lunches! (Not always high quality, but hey, it's free)

- Many great and smart Engineers that are fun really to work with

- Wide selection of cool projects with interesting solutions.
cons:
- As an organization, time and time again it's been shown that forcing consistent tools and methodology are prioritized over delivering value to end customers.

- Barely functional network with restrictive access controls frequently block websites for senseless things. Ex: This technology blog comes from netflix, this site is a competitor of one of the tools we have a license with.

- Too many layers of management that are too far removed from our real customers.

- Bureaucracy runs rampant and unchecked. Almost every decision made is purely a political one, and all information disseminated from upper management is trickle down. It's a game of telephone before it ever hits engineering teams. It's all "he said she said".

- Strict and uncompromising security teams block release at every opportunity over the smallest and least significant of issues. Luckily, Management can overrule security on low priority items.

review_title: Declining as  an Industry Leader in the Market and with Employees
pros: Brand recognition, longevity in the marketplace.  At the ground level, Honeywell people are hardworking and very honest, and loyal customers appreciate local experience and expertise.  Lots of corporate communication to keep employees informed.  User-friendly employee website (benefits, payroll, eLearning).
cons: New employee on-boarding is nonexistent.  With globalization, there has been a dramatic decline in women as executive leaders in other than HR/MarCom with an associated sharp increase in chauvinism in the last 10 years as Honeywell hires leaders from countries not as accepting/respectful of women as in the US.  That's been very disappointing as a long term employee, as incompetent male managers are hired instead of highly competent women.  The level of respect for women at all levels has degraded noticeably in the US.  Benefits have dwindled -  among others, the high deductible medical plan and the changes to the 401K contribution match (while high, it's only paid once a year in January - golden handcuffs are a poor retention strategy) are widely unpopular.  Turnover is rampant and negatively impacts customers.  Services that customers rely on locally are outsourced overseas, and so speed and quality (once a hallmark of Honeywell and a source of higher than average margin performance) have decreased.  Customers and their needs are last in line behind over-engineered processes and profits.  Honeywell is perceived in the market as "old, cold, and behind the times," and seems unsure how to catch up technologically.  Naming oneself a "software industrial" doesn't make it so.  Wall Street appears happy, but these underlying issues will come to roost, as manifested in the employee turnover and late-to-market technology solutions for customers.   Advancement opportunities exist only due to the runaway attrition, which leaves those who step into those roles unprepared to succeed.

job_title: Cannot Say As Human Resources Might Be Checking Site.  in Waterford
pros: my fellow workers on the shop floor
cons: the attiude from management is awful and it is creating a them and us feeling in the plant, this is really evident when you are dealing with the HR dept, working for a great company like allied signal is a distant memory. what ever happened to reward and recognition and quest for exellence and the yearly ppp bonus system. the workers are being pushed further and further away from any involvement in the success of the company, and in the end this will destroy honeywell. the workers are the people that made this company great .

pros: Honeywell provides a great training ground to pick up specialized and broad skills. Many growth opportunities as a new graduate student. When it is time to move on, there are many employers who will be very glad to give you the promotions and monies to hire you.
cons: Honeywell has a lot of high performers. The lower 2/3 of the positions turn over, especially as they approach that upper 1/3. The funnel gets very small as you go up and chances to be promoted also reduce dramatically. Honeywell is not the best paying company and after 5 to 10 years, the retirement plan does not grow

review_title: great place to make a career
job_title: Demand Specialist in Monterrey, Nuevo León
pros: The salary is good and benefits are above average. Good working environment and  a lot flexibility on schedules, as some working remote possibilities. They have a good evaluation process (mid-year and yearly reviews) that allows you to receive recognition, and move fast on your career if you show results above expected, initiative and you are open to relocation.
cons: Leadership is intense, this can be translated with a lot of extra hours whenever it is needed in order to achieve results, even though they have a good evaluation system you can only move up in the ladder if you exceed expected results and are open to relocation

review_title: Focus on meeting performance goals clouds sensible decision making.
pros: Most people in corporate and on site are truly well educated dedicated professionals. You can learn something new everyday.
cons: The Honeywell Operating System requires excessive resources to complete, such as formal group meetings to discuss simple actions and too much justification for slipping on schedule A to meet an urgent schedule B, and the CA system is way over the top on time needed to close non important issues.

job_title: Center of Excellence Manager for EVMS in Columbia, MD
pros: Decent benefits for older employees and upper management.
cons: Upper management has self interests which over ride over all consideration for company.  President requested all employees not directly billable to take a 10% reduction in salary to save $30M in salaries while accepting a $32M bonus for his efforts.  Benefits are tailored for older employees and reduced for newer employees.  Management is creating an environment that is aging and not conducive to new highly desirable employees.

pros: A lot of sharp technical people.
cons: Too many "checklists" to follow stifle creativity and innovation. They are very strict on their employees doing everything their way, which leads to slow moving projects, tons of red tape, and lack of innovation. Poor insurance benefits, with only a high-deductible health plan that can cost you thousands each year. Very disappointing for such a profitable company! Major focus of future careers and investments is in "high growth" regions such as India or Mexico. If you don't live there, you won't go very far.

pros: Traveling. (But you may only get to see one country during your road career.)  Money is okay, but all the income is disposable income since there are little to no living expenses.
cons: Travel policies and lack of benefits.  Depending on your nationality, you may be taken advantage of and not allowed any return trips to home country.  People who have difficulty with getting visas get to go home more often.  In managements' eyes all advisors are dispensable.

pros: This is one of the best managed companies, the skillset one can acquire there is quite unique. Opportunities to to be part of major M&A integrations for those who are interested and work  on very sizable international projects.
cons: There is no such thing (yet?) as One Honeywell. There are multiple Honeywell's depending on geography and business. Be prepared for a culture shock from time to time.

review_title: Gone and working at a better place
pros: Was a safe stable place to work. The workers who are no longer there were top employees and very professional.
cons: Culture is terrible. Cote has created an awful corporation to work for acquiring and shutting down competitive companies. Then cutting work force to the bone along with any kind of compensation. I am a former employer because our whole company had a layoff over as short period of time because of Cote. Glad not to be a shareholder anymore of the unethical company.

pros: Flexible work schedule. I am able to work from home whenever I need to, I choose my hours. Retirement contributions are pretty good (75% for the first 8%). If you want to take the train to work and save yourself some gas, they'll pay for a ticket. The people are great to work with. Merit-based rewards/raises.
cons: Health insurance isn't so great (high deductible only, 3K deductible, 20% coinsurance after you hit the deductible). Benefits and opportunities seem to be decreasing, not increasing. Had layoffs this year plus a furlough.

review_title: One of the Best Companies for Chemical Engineers.
pros: Great place to learn and grow as a chemical engineer. Lots of opportunities to travel after training. Friendly workplace with good facilities. Great work-life balance. We used to get a year long training in the US.
cons: Salary is not very competitive. US training has been scrapped. There should be opportunities for freshers to get field experience during their 2 years training at UOP. Bond should be removed for freshers.

review_title: Difficult work environment at publicly traded companies
job_title: Customer Quality Engineer in Mississauga, ON
pros:
- Large exposure to many teams and departments
- Easy to standout if you can get your work done and on-time
cons:
- People who work there are lifers - average age of workers is 45.
- Decisions made by Executive Management are only for the benefit of moving the stock price
- Lack of motivation from workforce

pros: Large diverse company provides a lot of opportunities to get varied experience across multiple product types and industries.
cons:
Upper/executive management is clueless in regards to what's important to employees and often delivers tone deaf messages and mandates to the working staff. Employees feel unvalued due to recent losses in flexibility and benefits; we're just head count.

The atmosphere has recently become very high-pressure as expectations to increase quickly top line growth are hampered by excessive processes as well as an inherently slow industry such as Aerospace.

pros:
Best Processes and Skills.
Fully transparent system and Meritocracy.
Awards for achievements.
Fully matured management and policies.
Employee is the first priority always.
Can work on the  best and newest technologies of industry and with the best people.
cons:
Few people of the management take the advantage of the system and bend the rules and best policies.
These people are bad for the system as a whole and are detrimental.
The DNA of Honeywell is depleting year by year by the influx into the system.

pros: lots of hours, travel pay, per diem, overtime, flexible, benefits, HR and upper management communicates well with all employees.
cons: valuable employee do not receive the reconization or promotions they deserve. Not strict enough with lazy employees. Not alot of job options within this company unless you want to live in another state all year long.

job_title: ISC Supervisor in Kansas City, KS
pros: Stable company with long-term security. 9/80 work schedule is the saving grace of benefits - if that went away, I'd start looking for another position in another company.
cons: Everything starts early and typical ISC Supervisor work-day is 7am to 430pm, which grinds after a while. ISC Supervisor doesn't have a specific career path with the organization, so many employees use it as a launch pad into project management, business analysis, etc.

job_title: Senior Engineering Project Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I really enjoy the flexibility and understanding of the upper management. They don't try to micro manage you and trust you to do your own work. They are, however, always there for you if you need help. Coworkers are always willing to help where they are able especially when you are new and that was great to have when I started out.
cons: There are a lot of changes happening in a short period of time due to different processes used in different locations and because Honeywell took over Intelligrated a few years ago. I joined the company in a transition phase and almost 2 years later we are still transitioning.

pros: Generally good people in the plants.
cons:
Company is ultra cheap. Literally would do anything to save a dollar. At the expense of anything, they’ll do whatever it takes and expend countless hours to save a buck. This kills the factories and the people having to deal with the aftermath. 

Guilted into canceling a preapproved vacation, at Christmas, with my family. Lost the $1000’s spent. Sums up the work first, family second culture.

review_title: Honeywell stinks and they are losing a lot of talented people
pros: If you have allied signal retirement it's OK.  If you have Honeywell retirement don't plan on retiring.  They try and make you think the benefits are good but they are just average
cons: this company is just a revolving door for employees.  I have seen more employees quit here in the last ten years than most companies probaly hire in twenty.

review_title: Company focus is get production out
pros: Good pay for the area. The work load is steady.
cons: Rotating shift work. You never can develop a normal sleep pattern. Senior employees should be able to get steady day work. Company pits one employee against another by posting performance results. Supervisors don't listen to employees. When you have an idea how to make things better, they tell you you to just get production out the door.  Equipment is not properly maintained, they just keep running production until there is a breakdown. They use too many temporary workers. Temporary workers don't care because they don't have a permanent job with the company.

review_title: Honeywell stinks and they are losing a lot of talented people
pros: If you have allied signal retirement it's OK.  If you have Honeywell retirement don't plan on retiring.  They try and make you think the benefits are good but they are just average
cons: this company is just a revolving door for employees.  I have seen more employees quit here in the last ten years than most companies probaly hire in twenty.

cons: Rotating shift work. You never can develop a normal sleep pattern. Senior employees should be able to get steady day work. Company pits one employee against another by posting performance results. Supervisors don't listen to employees. When you have an idea how to make things better, they tell you you to just get production out the door.  Equipment is not properly maintained, they just keep running production until there is a breakdown. They use too many temporary workers. review_title: Honeywell Employees Contemporary, hard working individuals
job_title: Human Resources Director in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Highly contemporary in their functional areas (IT, Finance, HR, Sales / Marketing), excellent benefits, ability to work internationally, fast pace for role transition, wide scope, span and complexity of roles within each organization.  The organization as a whole is very process driven, thrives on process improvement, Six Sigma, Lean, and Leadership Development.  The range of roles within each function can be interesting and career enhancing.  Many roles include dual responsibilities or secondary "specialties" which is also career enhancing.
cons: Not especially nimble, heavy amount of politics, a lot of "churn and burn", expected to give 125% all the time, 24 / 7

review_title: Good work environment but customer satisfaction problems
pros: Good working conditions, great brand recognition, good training in some divisions. The products are generally great and the company has a good handle on energy efficiency and sustainability.
cons: Problems with service tarnish the brand. Hours can be long to get the work done. Some divisions have poor leadership and training. As with any big company, it can be difficult to wade through the bureaucracy. Too much attention paid to process and reporting.

job_title: Sheet Metal Worker III in Torrance, CA
pros: Many of the positions pay well, and the older/experienced employees are very knowledgeable.
cons: Toxic work culture. Management does not care for the employees, and the employees do not care for management. It is nearly impossible to get people from multiple departments to work together or to show any sense of teamwork. Standardized tier boards are not correctly standardized. Workflow specialists are in charge of Tier 1 boards, but they are consistently scrutinized by multiple administrators who request differing information and/or organization of the boards. Allocation of "planned" material is changed on a daily bases--meaning that parts that have been set aside for specific jobs will almost always go to other jobs, after a customer complains about not receiving a specified unit on schedule. This leads to planning of parts constantly not mattering. The blue collar workers know that what they will work on will not be what was planned and that management will complain about them not finishing the units they were originally scheduled to work on. Also, HOS (Honeywell Operation System) management does not allow parts to be in the department if they are not currently being used.  This leads to jobs that are set up for work the next day, missing when employees come in in the morning and the parts often being lost or allocated to other departments/jobs. Also, new employees are not properly trained on the SAP system, and specific types of jobs, GAMS, PROs, and others, require specific areas of SAP that even experienced employees have not been trained on. Furthermore, all benefits are reducing in quality on an annual bases, while the older employees are being forced out of the company in order to bring in lower paid and contract employees, whom the company does not care about either.

job_title: Sales Manager in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Though there are many, here are some top ones:

1. One who owns 90% technologies to refine the crude knows it all, inside out. There is no one else who can ever come near that claim to fame.

2. Hardcore technology company with clear focus on specific segment of the industry, now diversifying by making use of existing capabilities and strengths

3. A company where majority of people have experience of 20-30 years plus. Normally someone with a 20 year experience counts themselves "young" in the company.

4. The deep knowledge of domain, the facilities at R&D centers, the global presence, and think tanks in the domain makes it a Mecca for sure

5. Have access to all the major refiners globally, that means have seen problems and issues from all part of the world that are posed in the industries. So they know it all.

6. Very analytic approach to problems, no one shows arrogance for the knowledge they possess, rather majority of the people love to share their experience.

7. Majority of the people comes from a strong professional or educational background, you feel good here.

8. If you are bright and the best in your subject, there is no limit on what all you can learn and what all you can be trained by UOP

9. Work life balance they offer can be great if stars align for you
cons:
1. Salaries

2. Some people of course, as every place has that kind of elements

3. Owned by a company from a different industry has its own problem. Honeywell has its own DNA whereas UOP has its own, probably a personality conflict is evident some time. But there are pro's also for the same

4. UOP technology is not cheap, compared to many other players from Europe. That may be a problem while competing in the market

5. Now they are having big time compromises on quality of people being hired, that can be a suicide in knowledge driven industry in general, and for UOP being the quality gurus in

review_title: Very good place to work with better work life balance
pros: Less stress in work. Very good training. Appreciates self learning and sponsors certifications. Work and life balance is very good. Salary hike is not bad, but not good compared to other companies. There is no variable component in salary.
cons: Manager driven company. Manager decides the fate of his reportee. If manager decides that the employee is under performing, the employee life is gone. They wont listen to what employee says, they hear to only manager. HR person is very lazy. Importantly no employee benefits other than salary.

review_title: OK, pretty stable company, but penny-pinching accountants run the show
pros: The best reasons would be working with good people.  The other engineers, 1st-level managers, and other "individual contributors" at Honeywell are personable, and generally competent at their jobs.  I really like my direct supervisor, and the other engineers I work with on a day-to-day basis.  Also, at least at my location, it's very flexible on working hours and telecommuting.  They don't ask me to work OT unless they really need it - which happens rarely.  The retirement contribution is pretty good if you've been there for a while.
cons:
Since 2009, the general raise pool has been 0, 0, 2.5, 2.5, 0, and 2.5.  This when company profits, and executive compensation, have skyrocketed.  It''s tough to take - going to quarterly meetings where we hear how much money we're making, but then we can't afford raises.  
The other major con is the mass bureaucracy that I suppose may be typical at many large companies.  How many managers, project managers, asst project mangaers, project engineers, PP&C people, etc., do we need on a project.  It often seems like there's more managers than technical people working on a project.  And when you look at our org chart near the top, Honeywell has dozens of Presidents, hundreds, if not thousands, of Vice Presidents, and on and on.  Honeywell is a functional organization now, too, which means that HR only cares about HR, engineering only cares about engineering, project managers only care about that.  It results in constant top-down directives that do nothing to improve the product, customer experience, or working environment of employees.

As just a minor example of how this translates to my job, there's been a hard, hard cap on promotions above my current level since 2008.  Whereas before a decent engineer might've expected to make Principal Engineer by his mid-30s or certainly early 40s, now there is a hard cap that has no forseeable end date.  This is because one of the accountants running the show said "Hey, we've got too many people at that level!" and then just top-down dictated no more promotions.  They've gotten away with it because the economy's been so crappy that no one has wanted to leave.  But if things pick up, they'll have young people leaving.  Also, they've got a huge contingent of employees in their late 50s to early 60s who'll be retiring in the next 5-15 years.  Their solution is to hire Puerto Ricans, Czechs, and others overseas.  They are very penny-wise and pound-foolish on this and many, many other decisions.

Also, we have to pay a lot for our health insurance.  A co-worker of mine saves $5K/year by being on his wife's plan vs what he'd pay at Honeywell.

review_title: Good Place to Start a Career
job_title: Field Technical Advisor in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Good place to start a career. Interesting travel opportunities. Interesting technologies. They give you a lot of responsibility early in your career, which forces you to learn things very quickly.
cons: The job can be overwhelming at times. Treatment from management has recently become poor. This combined with a lack of benefits has led to many of the more experienced engineers leaving. Younger engineers are often put into situations that they aren't ready for. Jobs are often short staffed, which means extra hours with little to no additional compensation. Benefits have steadily reduced.

review_title: Large corporations aren't always what they are cracked up to be.
pros: Salary and benefits seem fair for office personnel.
cons: In the name of running "lean" you are expected to do the work of 3 or 4 people. Work to life balance is not good. They also change employee schedules at the drop of a hat, without any consideration for the employee. Health insurance deductibles are ridiculous for a company that size.

pros: Good Work Environment. Got Onsite Opportunities. Good Exposure to Aerospace Products and Product Knowledge. Lot of data available as knowledge Base.
cons: Stuck with Reuse for all the projects. Never something new is tried. Most of the time is spent doing HOS activities. Which are ultimately unproductive. Hard to even try a new product or equipment while designing a new product. Bound my age old technologies.

pros: 30-plus hr. part time. Large organization with all the standard management systems in place. 401k match paid in company stock. Reasonable package of benefits for regular employees.
cons: Two tiered employment system (maybe more): regular employees and non-regular employees who were relegated to an in-house "temp" system, although you could be in this "temp" system for years. Limited benefits on the non-regular system, 401k match was about it. CEO compensation package, like many CEO's compensation, is excessive. CEO's total package was worth $29 million in 2011.

job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Work flexibility (work from home), large company that does provide advancement opportunity (especially if you're willing to travel), stable organization that delivers on shareholder expectations
cons: Disconnected leadership, convoluted processes that are seldom followed, continually dwindling resources and hardcore cost-cutting culture, poor benefits (very high healthcare deductibles), extremely controversial biometric screening requirement (Honeywell is currently being sued by the Federal Government for this), slightly lower pay across the board (but especially in marketing), layoffs and offshoring at every turn, challenging business outlook (for our particular business unit)

pros: The people there are generally really nice and fun to work with. Fun and diverse projects to work on.
cons: Layoffs, furloughs, no more working from home, terrible management decisions, no pay raises for several consecutive years. It's clear that the company management only cares about profits and stock price. Employees are treated as expendable. The company is selling less and less products, and forcing the employees to make up the difference with furloughs, layoffs, and paycuts. Meanwhile, the leadership team still rewards itself with million dollar bonuses.

review_title: They really don't care about you
pros:
Company car that I pay almost $200 per month for
Good rates for life insurance
Good co-workers
Appreciative customers
cons:
You are nothing but a number. It took over a year to get to new hire orientation, and in that year I went through three managers. The first two never even had time to give me the time of day, the third acted as though I should be completely up to speed on this incredibly complex company and industry with zero training and support. The pay structure is laughable, bonuses are impossible to get because the growth number they expect from the sales rep are literally five times the number that the company projects as a whole. Constant pressure and micro management. Layer upon layer of middle and upper management. Seriously, its a nightmare...

Oh yeah, how about the benefits. They only offer high deductible health plans. So my family had to pay $400 per month for medical insurance, plus a $3000 deductible before they paid for anything but routine checkups. Meanwhile the CEO gets a huge raise and Honeywell pulls in billions in profit. And NEW FOR 2017! Honeywell makes no contribution towards dental! Oh yeah, and when they eventually match your 401k contributions after a year, they do it with Honeywell stock! So if you want to invest in something else you have to go in and sell that stock and reinvest it.

pros:
Excellent technology and exciting projects.  Cohesive and smart group of engineers and engineering managers. Low turnover.  Manufacturing under the same roof.  Relatively low stress work environment.  Good work-life balance for starting out, decreases as your area of responsibility grows.

ISC (factory) has undergone many positive changes with the Honeywell Operating Standards over the past 5 years.  Improved efficiency, quality, sense of ownership, and workplace environment.

Engineering salaries are very good, respectable annual merit increases (2-3+%), fluctuates with the market conditions as well as with individual contributions.  Performance incentives (bonuses) for Principal and Staff Engineers and Management, Band 4 & 5.  Respectable 401k match, believed to be 1%/1% to 3%, then 1/2%/1% to 6%.

On site cafeteria with food trucks.
cons:
Honeywell is going through a period of furloughs and layoffs over the last year and a half.

Honeywell Aerospace is making adjustments while trying to streamline engineering and manufacturing processes, mostly good, but the one-size-fits-all across all product lines is detrimental to some sites, this one specifically.  With a short development cycles (1-3 yrs) additional processes have increased the overall development cycle duration and cost while OEM customers expect decreasing development cycles.  Executive management has recognized this and is starting to make changes.

The local engineering organization, as great as it is, seems to be unable or unwilling to become excellent.  A lack of vigor and/or a sense of complacency seems present.

Honeywell Aerospace is a matrix organization with little on-site business presence.  The ISC manufacturing support of new programs needs more of a sense of urgency early in development with a comprehensive manufacturing plan with concise objectives.   The ISC leader and his management team changes every 1-2 years; it's hard to make sustainable improvements with a revolving door.

Grass roots growth for the site is available, but challenging to support within the Honeywell corporate umbrella.  Organizational changes on the business side are in process to improve this.

Career advancement is given little effort by management, and the measurement of developing skills is ambiguous.  Willingness to relocate improves your opportunity to accelerate your career growth.  The executive management solution to engineering attrition has primarily been more global engineers, mainly in India.  Grim outlook for new graduates in the states with this company. 

Vacation time starts at 2 weeks, even for experienced employees (5-10 yrs).   3 weeks at 5 years, and I believe 4 weeks at 15 years and caps at 5 weeks at 25 years.  Vacation time is non-negotiable for new hires.  

Aging site with insufficient reinvestment.  Dated conference rooms for customer meetings, office area carpet is grungy with lots of duct tape on lifting seams, 15-30 year old cubicles.

review_title: A beginning of a wonderful journey
pros: First of all the new office environment is absolutely amazing and it feels like home. Besides that, you are free to work at anywhere you fill like working there are no specific workspace for you. The staffs here are very friendly and helpful. Office starts at 9am and ends at 6pm, however, if you come early to work you can leave early as well.
cons: Since there are no specific workspace for you or your colleagues it is a bit hard to find your bosses or your colleague sometimes so better take their number in advance.

pros: The people who work for Honeywell want to truly meet customer demands and make great products but the demand is so high from upper mananagement and no raises, benefits, and good job is the way of Honeywell anymore.
cons: Lots of benefits taken after union talk a few years back.  Raises are terrible and new people being trained to train the older regular people.  The new people are running the show and the quality is not there.  They are being paid more or the same as people that have been there along time.  Insurance is to high to keep.   If you buddy your supervisor you will work your way up, and hanging out with leads is the way to move up too.  What will that do for your raise???

review_title: I hope you like constant reporting.
pros: Good Name recognition, and lot's of internal opportunities IF you're willing to move to another state.
cons:
Typical Public Co. B.S.  
Bureaucracy is terrible.  Every decision requires multiple meeting,  PPT presentations, and then wait for it go thru channels. Constant pressure to meet aggressive targets.

They make no bones about putting Wall Street Stockholder before it's employees.

If your division doesn't meet the lofty targets, you get 2 weeks furlough (no pay) in the last 2 Qtrs of each year.   Same with NO travel, NO Indirect spending.   So, basically your place suffers 6 months of every year.

They love outsourcing everything possible to low-rent countries, so all of your A/P people are in MX.  All of the original people were fired from Cincy.  If you "love" calling India for IT support, this is your place. 

Constant reporting of dozens of Metrics that'll make your head spin.  Death by meetings discussing these metrics until everyone is so sick of them they acquiesce and give up.  

High turnover because the pressured culture, and then it's compounded by over-loading the people who stayed behind, with double the workload, because it's a cost-savings they want to hold the position open for as long as possible.

ERP systems like Oracle, SAP, and JD Edwards are so lame compared to what small biz software is these days.  You have to use a spreadsheet for everything.

Family Health Plan costs $5k to have $6k deductible.  Also you have submit yourself to annual blood tests for Fat and Smoking fines.  If your Fat (BMI) you & your spouse will pay a $500 penalty, and if you Smoke you'll pay a $1500 penalty EACH.

401k plan stinks, because they don't match 4% until Dec, and only match in HON stock, and they don't offer many invest choices.  No 401k loans, and you can't move your money to a Self IRA unless you resign.

review_title: Have been with Honeywell for now 10 years
pros:
1) An organization  with strong and robust due diligence processes
2) A process driven organization but which is always agile and open to incorporate new learnings an thoughts without compromising on its strong fundamentals of integrity and customer first approach.
3) An organization which truly believes in the principals of providing equal opportunity for every employee and provides a very safe and promising career for diversity candidates
cons: Pace of new product innovations a bit slower

review_title: Have been with Honeywell for now 10 years
pros:
1) An organization  with strong and robust due diligence processes

pros:
They portray good values.
A lot of good people in the organization.
Lunch, snacks, and drinks provided.
Good Midtown Atlanta location.
Parking and bus fare benefits.
Great coffee shop in the lobby.
Close to many good restaurants.
cons:
- Toxic culture -
 If employees do not like you, they'll complain to HR about petty stuff you do or say (e.g., a slip of the tongue) and eventually you'll be let go.  Managers rarely address employee conflict issues: those are mostly handled by HR.  You must be careful of everything you say and do, otherwise, you'll likely be reported to HR.  Keep to yourself, hold your emotions and personal opinions, don't make jokes.

- Your Manager or Director may block your professional growth -
If you're offered a job within a different team, your manager must approve the transfer.  If your manager doesn't want to lose you, then you can't take the job offer, even if it is a promotion opportunity.

- Uncertain job stability -
Even though you may work for a team dedicated to your job function, (e.g., you're a PM in the PMO), you can be moved to a team that is not aligned with your job function, without your consent.  You'll still be doing the same job function, but your career path and job stability are now tied to a team or organization outside of where you originally desired to be.

- Benefits are expensive -
$800+ per month is not uncommon for health and life benefits.

- Honeywell hates work from home -
Even if your job function requires you to interface with teams across the USA or even the world, you can't WFH.  You'll need to commute (no matter how long that takes) just so you can find a desk for the purpose of working with people in 4 or 5 different timezones.

review_title: Think thrice before you join this company

Also opportunity to find another project in your technical domain is very limited.

job_title: Engineer/Scientist R&D II in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Honeywell's "revolving door" philosophy makes it a leader in providing the 3-5 years of experience required to obtain your dream job.  You will have the opportunity to work with some bright, talented, and personable people.
cons:
You will also find that many employees from the pre-Honeywell era are simply counting the days until their retirement.  You can obtain the experience you need for gainful employment outside of Honeywell if you can stand listening to senior employees say thing like "this used to be a fun place to work".  

Surveys conducted by the company will indicate your compensation is competitive, but I found that my own pay was ~20-30% below that of my contemporaries from school.  My first (prorated) merit increase in my new job was more generous than any merit increase I received from a full years' work for Honeywell.

Even while RIF's occurred at lower levels within the company, new roles were being created in upper management with goals which sounded arbitrary, or redundant with those of existing positions.  This gave me the impression that the cautious fiscal conservatism preached in quarterly updates was little more than a way to funnel pay out of low-level employees' pockets to support cronyism in upper management.

review_title: Employees are a cost to be cut
job_title: Product Manufacturing Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Salary is competitive, room for advancement, and great co-workers.
cons:
You are a number, and this isn't a typical scorned employee opinion, this is fact.  In the 5 years I've been with the company:
- Top pay for high level mechanics has been cut by 10k/year
- Medical costs have risen 20%
- Company contribution to HSA account was reduced, then removed altogether
- We are now "fined" up to 1.5k (to be added to medical cost) for not participating in employee health screenings and for smoking
- Pentions are now capped at current salary (will no longer increase as salary increases)
- Two (2ea) raises in 5 years totaling 2.5% (1st was 1%, 2nd was 1.5%).  Raises are suspended this year as well
- Furloughed for a week (7 days without pay one month before Christmas).  Upon return, layoff begins

There are more examples but who has the time.  It seems no opportunity to screw employees is passed.  It happens incrementally, slowly, meticulously removing another "perk" as soon as the memory if the last fades.

The stock is doing well, so it must be working for them.

job_title: Research Scientist/Engineer II in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
At the time of this review, I am very new, and I also work on a small team doing more software related stuff, so take this with a grain of salt.

Coworkers here are very friendly, making the work atmosphere great. Everyone is very communicative, and conversation is good so far. The internal web portals are very well organized, and getting settled in has been a breeze.

Honeywell so far has come across as a company that really wants to make an investment in their employees, allowing them to grow in their profession.
cons:
If you are going into software looking for a fancy skyscraper office looking out over a city, this isn't exactly it. You will probably get your standard cubicle, although the equipment provided is pretty nice. 

Honeywell is a bit more of an older company, and they are heavy in government contract work. While it seems that many of their new policies are pretty progressive, their seems to be a fair amount of cookie cutter government paperwork / red tape / corporate kind of activity that goes on (such as redundant or unnecessarily extensive training videos, or lots of digging to get access to materials / information to move forward with projects).

review_title: Don't work here unless you  are a "yes" (wo)man that is okay with the status quo
pros:
- Work with smart people

- Brand name on your resume

- Compensation at market rate when you start
cons:
- Systemic lack of accountability, ownership, and career growth across the different businesses unless you are at VP, GM, or above

- Furloughs, pay cuts, re-orgs, and title changes are infamously part of Honeywell's "MOS" year after year

- Approx 30% voluntary attrition within 2 years and 15-20% within 1 year across multiple functions (especially product management, sales, marketing, customer experience...engineers and production tend to be RIF/RIM instead of leaving voluntarily)

- Outside of a high-level onboarding at HQ, you and your team will likely not receive training, education, or tools as your budget keeps getting cut

- Annual raises above 3% for even the most stellar employee, totally unheard of. Average raise without a job promotion is 1-2%. The 8 core behaviors are subjective performance metrics and the vehicle that Honeywell uses to downgrade your annual bonus because each department does not get a decent budget for bonus or merit.

- Run down offices. Free coffee not provided.

- Many more, which layoff.com does a good job recording while also providing endless entertainment

pros: No such pros are here for employees!

pros: Great salary well above the starting average for a chemical engineer.  Benefits Package that is pretty standard.  Some locations have great people and management.
cons:
This position was advertised as a 1 year rotational program cycling through 2 or possibly 3 plants over a year to gain engineering experience in a variety of processes before being placed into a permanent role.  The actual job was to train and work as a process operator at 1-2 sites that were undergoing union labor contract negotiations.  This would enable the company to push a tougher contract on the operators without any chance of a work-stoppage.  In this case it was planned to lockout the workers if a contract was not reached, which puts them in financial difficulty and removes the likelihood that a new contract is not agreed to.

I have spent the better half of 2015 working as an operator in come capacity with night and day shift weeks ranging from 48h minimum to 88h week maximum.  The majority of this time was paid as a salaried worker (See no overtime or extra compensation of any kind.  No comp days.)  I am totally burnt out and frustrated that I signed on for something that was very different from what was promised when I had other options for employment upon the time of my college graduation.

There is plenty more to write, but I don't want to turn this review into a longwinded rant.  I have essentially lost a year of my life without anything really happening due to almost zero free time.

- My salary was much less than those who were hired directly through Honeywell; even with equal job responsibilities. Numerous promises to rectify this were never fulfilled. 
- Management made promises to clients without any concern about the impact on their employees.

It's a good place to start building your skill set but it doesn't mean there is a conserted effort to advance your career. After all, you're just a tool.
cons:
You're just a tool management wishes to exploit for as long as you're willing to bow your head.

No interest in solving the pressing engineering problems. You're expected to stick to "established methods" and agree with everything management goes with. You will be managed and led by some of the most incompetent engineers in the field, don't make the mistake of knowing too much science. That's frowned upon and you'll be targeted and your life made a living hell. 

The more effort you put in your work, the more devalued your time is. Political acumen will go a long way in this company. If you plan to be in engineering for a long time, don't work here for over a couple years. 

On the other hand, if you have aspirations for running for office or being a politician, this is a great place to work with an environment to help nurture a lot of the backstabbing sabotaging strategies and techniques needed for a successful political career. 

Many of the people in charge in the firm are not the managers but an elite group of clandestine members of a religious cult who seek to preserve people like them and rid the place of outsiders like you. If you belong to the institution, you'll do fine. If not, run..


Best of luck

pros: None that I can think of.
cons:
Understand this is based on being a contractor in one of the Arizona plants.
Security is ridiculous in some ways and yet totally lax in others (no consistency).
This company is HUGE and you are just a microbe in its enormous body. I never understood how big until I started working here. If you think you can get in to this company by getting your foot in the door as a contractor think again. Almost everything is outsourced, from the janitors to IT. Most of the offices are dreary and lifeless, Contractors do not generally get anything resembling an office, you will be luck if you get a desk. The company you contract through will have to supply you with just about everything. Office supplies are nearly non existent even for direct employees. Policies and procedures are mired in bureaucracy and red tape. Documentation of procedures are usually wrong or outdated but you are required to use them. If what they say to do does not work or is confusing the problem is with YOU. Direct employees rarely admit errors. Training of procedures often degenerates in to arguments between contractor managers and honeywell "instructors". Internal software has been customized and never works as documentation says it should (Remedy). When trying to communicate with plants in india accents can be so thick as to be unintelligible. Email is deleted from your mailbox automatically on a regular basis (oh was that important? too bad!). Propaganda monitor displays are everywhere. The company is very dilbertesqe.

review_title: It stays afloat by cutting employee benefits
pros: It is a safe company to work for. They push safety but I'm sure its more for the bottom line.
cons:
It can careless about the health of it's employees, we basically have minimal insurance with a $3000 dollar delectable that has expensive premiums and it claims it is self insured.
It is not giving raises this year on the lame excuse "they are not sure what is going to happen if we go over the fiscal cliff", my take is they are just adding to their profits, It has cut our benefits down to the point it cannot cut anymore. 
Did I mention our company made billions of dollars last year so our CEOs, with a plural there will get their bonuses. 
We also have received email notices not to talk to any law enforcement about company business and are to refer them to our legal department.
This is a review from a 25+ year employee so I have to much invested to find another job. I would not work for them because it is just a shell of what it was 25 years ago Cote has gutted it.

review_title: Highly centralized/bureaucratic and no commitment to employees
pros: The people I work with locally are intelligent and great to work with.  Work life balance is good.
cons:
The company is highly centralized - i.e. all meaningful power is concentrated at the VP level or higher.  e.g. The ability to hire people is not at the Manager, Senior Manager, or even the Director level - all hiring must be approved at the VP level or higher.  Any travel must be approved by a VP.  Individuals are NOT empowered to do their jobs at all, and, instead, are bogged down by company-dictated processes that do not add value.

Benefits are not competitive.  Cost cutting has steadily eroded benefits and pay very significantly over the past few years.  Annual raises are very low, even for top employees.  All of this is done in the name of "uncertainty of the future", but it is obvious to everyone that it is really done to cut costs and boost stock price.  Company stock price is higher than ever but it is not shared with the employees.  The company no longer approves training for personal improvement.  Promotions are extremely rare, and typically require a manager to create a "new" job posting for which an employee deserving promotion has to apply.

This company does not have a good future.

review_title: Used to be a fantastic place to work, but it's rapidly going down hill
pros: Fantastic opportunities for career development and progression. Exciting opportunities for overseas assignments for those who are willing and able to relocate.  Strong performance is recognized and rewarded. Lots of exceptionally smart and talented people working for the organisation. Twice yearly performance reviews, with meaningful input from management. Some very inspiring leaders at tier 2 and 3 in the organisation.
cons: Honeywell is no longer a fun place to work.  CEO focus on results and shareholder value at the expense of any empathy towards employees.  Widespread benefits erosion (cost saving) impacting employees at all levels.  Reductions in workforce leading to loss of tribal knowledge and de-skilling in large areas of the organisation. Remaining employees expected to absorb the work and continue delivering more, but with less resources, knowledge and experience.  Performance culture is driving 'me first' behaviours instead of collaborative team working in some parts of the organisation, making them unpleasant environments in which to work.  Home working was abolished some time ago (blanket global policy), so there is little flexibility regarding work life balance.

review_title: Good development experience/resume builder, not for the long haul
pros:
Honeywell (specifically FM&T in Kansas City, MO) has been a great development opportunity.  Due to high turnover, they generally give early career engineers more responsibilities than industry average.  After a few years as a solid performer you should have some pretty good experience for the resume.

Corporate Honeywell brings both positives and negatives to the table, with an end result of a neutral.  Functionally, it's a great company with a strong stock.  However, the employee policies are generally pretty terrible and the benefits are average.
cons: There is basically no long term option.  At best, as a top 20% performer, you can grow your career like the average employee outside.  If you are in the middle 70%, you can basically forget getting raises higher than inflation.  As a government contractor, they are constantly compressing salaries to be competitive for renewing the contract.  The bottom 10% get reviewed yearly and put on a plan with which 50% are let go.  I've been told the general breakdown is consistent across Honeywell (and other companies like GE), but our raises are significantly lower.

pros: Honeywell makes a wide range of significant components for everything that flies. The technical challenges can be very interesting and some of Honeywell's solutions are unique and successful.
cons: Recent executive changes foretell major strategic changes in many of the company's product lines. The company has 25,000 engineers, scientists, and technicians, 60% of whom don't write software. It's unlikely that a company that constantly reminds it's employees that it is a software company is going to keep those smart engineers much longer. Technical expertise is no longer valued by the top three-four layers of good old boy executives. The technical career path exists on paper. No one knows what the requirements are to climb the last two-three steps.

review_title: Stay Away unless your just desperate for a job in this economy
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Company worked hard to get you nice ergonomic desks - you pick out your chair, mouse, they set up everything ergonomically correct.  They had a nice (but small) gym & even offered training.  Picnic tables outside were nice when the weather was warm.  Close to lake - escaped to walk around the lake when I couldn't take it anymore.  Did offer 3 sigma training.
cons: Contract I worked required 42 hrs/week for 40 hrs pay.  Even if you didn't have work to do, you were required to put in your "green" time.  No pay for travel time but you could accumulate green time if you travelled.  Ridiculous work that made no sense - busy work that didn't add value.  Cube farm had street names so you could find your way around.  No real break room.  Weird safety briefings required daily - if you didn't hold the handrails on the stairs you could get fired!  Many good sub-contractors laid off and treated badly.

review_title: No longer a good company to work for
pros: Pay is good, but good luck getting a decent raise.
cons:
The company is top heavy at the corporate level.  At individual sites, they run with the minimum number of employees possible.  Everybody wears multiple hats.  Everything gets done in a mediocre way.  Nothing gets done well because you are always in a rush to get to the next fire.

Local management are yes men to the US corporate team.  All sites are not held to the same standards.  US locations can get away with more push back than Canadian sites, even when it comes to safety.

All management (local and corporate) like to read out the rules, but fail to follow these same rules themselves.

Management is not honest or ethical when it comes to reviews.  You can refute what is said, but they say that once they have entered their reviews into the system they cannot be changed.  They will not even put in addendums even when their is physical proof.

HOS is a huge burden to small locations.  There is minimal benefit to the site, but the costs are huge.  It is all about "metrics" that time is spent on compiling, but are not used to better the location.

CEO is too overpaid and not worth the cost.

review_title: Not a place to go for a career anymore
pros: Decent pay.  The executives think highly of themselves. Stock holders are King. Non US workforce is run with more employee goodwill. Good 401K match. Good place to get experience (and then leave)
cons: Very spotty career paths with US workforce being constantly reduced. Severe lack of positive re-enforcement. Poor Job stability. Support workforce teams are highly disjointed which basically eliminates mentoring and team synergy. Constantly turn 10-20% of workforce per a systematic process built into their 9 block performance system. Poor and un-timely executive downward communication on what matters to employees. Vacation time off based solely on Managers prerogative. Benefits are constantly being watered down. Focused on getting out of manufacturing and moving all operations possible off-shore to low cost regions. Many international meetings and a work from home policy that does not work for this type of modern culture.

review_title: Work in Aerospace domain is OUTDATED
pros:
No spoon feeding, that gives employees more things to learn.
Nothing as such to highlight
cons:
This is my brutal honest opinion of Honeywell, who work in Aerospace domain
Aerospace domain in Honeywell is much OUTDATED as compared to market.
1. For namesake its a product based company, most of the CORE development is done in US. The leftover work comes to INDIA.
2.  Especially the people who work in Verification & Validation jobs, they are highly pressurized by the management (Nasty Micro Management Tracking which flows down from higher management). In return the engineers in ground level aren't recognized. Basically it lacks good leaders.
3. Least opportunities, given to work on emerging technologies for the current employees.
4. No employee satisfaction & facilities are provided.
5. Lot of organizational changes happens, in the sake of positions(Designations) for higher management people.
6. People who work in Madurai (Honeywell-Aerospace), the management screws the employees "Work-Life-Balance". Here they are forced to work on every Saturday & Sunday in office premises.
7. The Local Managers are cruel for other region employees, there is lot of biasing for localities.
8. The hiring process for freshers from local colleges around Madurai is very poor standard.
9. The employees who move from BLR or HYD offices to Madurai office for the purpose of higher positions, after 1-2 years of stay they comeback.
10. Madurai (Extreme Southern part of India), it makes difficult to connect other parts of India. (No proper communication)
11. They Should better shutdown the office in Madurai.

review_title: Good place to have a career
job_title: Specialist Project II in Deer Valley, AZ
pros:
I personally am satisfied with Honeywell.  I specifically work with Process Solutions for Technology R&D, so I can only speak on my experience with that organization of Honeywell.  

There are quite a few benefits that come with being permanently employed with the company - the basics: medical, dental, vision, 401K.  Of course you can buy their products at a discounted rate.  There are wellness benefits that keep getting added and implemented.  EAP is a thing here as well.  

Information is readily available if you know where to look. Being fairly new with the company (almost 2 years) I can say that things got easier when I figured out where to find the little things that come with "tribal knowledge".
cons:
We have to use Express Scripts as part of our medical insurance and they are horrid to work with.  

In my experience, there are too many applications used for different purposes across different businesses.  It would be nice to have less of that and more streamlined and integrated information between businesses as well as functions.

review_title: Good job if a steady paycheck is all you're after
pros:
Great if you're after a 40-hr work week go home-type gig. 
Lots of interesting projects and stuff to learn about.
Coworkers are generally ok, but some are complete douchebags and have an arrogant attitude who will put you down for asking stupid questions while others are totally helpful and super nice to work with.
Salary is OK, but it's not competitive. Benefits are average as well.
cons:
Some employees are really arrogant about their knowledge and it seems like they will put you down just because you asked any question.
The title seems to drive everyone's behavior. So many new hires who are Engineer I and II are looked down upon like if they're complete idiots like myself even if they're more highly educated than they are.
Management has a constant apply downward pressure technique to force you to work overtime. Then you get told at your review, you're doing great, and get rewarded with a crappy raise that's below inflation, which if you're doing the math is a salary decrease.... 
There's too much "growth" talk going on and the need to follow the "8 behaviors".
Promotions rarely happens. You'll either have to promote yourself by leaving or moving within the company. So hard work and technical expertise/innovative solutions are not seen/rewarded.

review_title: Big, strong culture in a company that expects a lot from it's rank-and-file employees
job_title: Supply Chain Manager in Houston, TX
pros: The industry and the company doesn't feel to be as up-and-down due to the good diversification among the portfolio of products (Honeywell as a whole); however, how Honeywell does in the bad economy is yet to be seen.  Honeywell is a great company to work for to bolster your resume and gain experience (as you'll be working hard).
cons: Honeywell is a culture stuck in the "we've always done this and it's the best way" company.  I haven't seen much openness to change or improvement of the current ways.  Management doesn't seem to value employees as people as much as commodities.  Work-life balance outside of emergencies is non-existent.  Salaries are low compared to industry (for my role) as compensation is done "on the cheap".  Jobs have recently been sent overseas and budgetary spending is not done wisely.  VERY metrics based organization.  Goals seem to be constantly moving, as even meeting or exceeding goals is often met with "we need more" and very rarely a "good job".   Even people hired in the past 2 years have been on a revolving door as people come and leave the organization often.

pros:
* Flexible work-hours and work from home policy (5 days a month) is a definite plus.
* My manager does not sit at the top of my head for deliverables.
* Expectations are not unreasonable and difficulties are well understood by the management.
* Salary planning is pretty good since there are no variable bonuses etc and we can to an extent configure own salary to maximize tax benefits.
cons:
* Performance evaluation is really bad and to good extent non-professional. Loyalty for your manager pays well and nothing else.
* Job assignment practices are also very bad. Only charge-hours matter to most of the managers and nothing else as such.
* Nobody cares whether you are satisfied with your work or are making any self improvements or not.
* Senior management is often busy in their own world and hardly care to learn what on junior level employees feeling or what problems they might have. Middle level management is a real fad.
* Salary as such is poor as compared to other companies except may be management level or selected groups.
* Politics in rewards and recognition.

pros: Nice facility, opportunity to work with people locally and internationally.
cons: The company claims that it is a progressive one offering good benefits, competitive pay, training opportunities and career growth.  Over the 6 years I worked there, the company said it couldn't afford to pay our earned merit increases for 3 of those years while the CEO received his, and compensation fell well below industry standards.  Benefits only became more expensive each year, although they did contribute funds to your HSA to help.  My management would not pay for the training opportunities that were available to me because they believed their current practices were satisfactory - innovation and risk taking were discouraged and you would get a slap on the hand if you made recommendations to senior management.  Finally, unless you worked in Finance, management and HR were not interested in career planning or development.  I watched dozens of talented college graduates leave the company over my 6 years there to work for a different company that was actually invested in their employees and developing talent for long-term growth.

review_title: High Employee Attrition. Beware - Aero CBM India Team
pros: Good salary. Benefits are just right.
cons:
Honeywell Technology Solutions (HTS) has become a school; a Bad One. CBM Aero, Bangalore team is the worst. 
There is a rising concern against companies' "Hygiene" factors" and "Motivator" factors. For examples, policies and administration, supervision, interpersonal relationship, status and security issues with the Project Leaders, cases of frequent employee harassment, verbal assaults and high employee attrition rate. The conflict resolution is by forceful techniques, where the other party views and concerns are ignored and rudely put down. Besides, there are
redundancies leading to the loss of sense of accomplishment, recognition, work satisfaction, growth and advancement. Well-experienced resources joining Honeywell find it difficult to adjust in this environment and many have left in less than a year. More often than not, rude emails by PLs are circulated. PLs
promote their own fabricated negative work culture. For examples, forcing the team to be physically present in everyday status meetings from 9.00 am, monetary fine if they fail to attend meetings, not allowing to attend such meetings from home if the resource did not stay beyond 9.00 pm the previous day, threatening resource to apply for leave if their card access time in a week is less than 45 hours, random peak expectations on people despite of no trainings. There are circumstances in which the PLs literally threatened resources in appraisal meetings.

Overall, HTS is no more holding its virtues. It is lost.

review_title: Not for long term US employment for HON-Aerospace
pros:
Excellent pay, 
Ability to work from home.  
Bonuses if you're able to get Band 4 or above.
Software engineers are a focus for the future.
cons:
Expensive health insurance with $3000 deductible.
Relentless focus on removing US employees in Aerospace and placing overseas.
Layoffs and furloughs with no annual raises are happening more frequently.
Low investment in new Aerospace products, appear to be cost cutting company to death or sale to another company.  UTC was smart to stay away.
Upper management appears to never focused beyond 1 year out.  They tell Wall Street one thing and employees another.  
They've been saying they're in a slow growth environment for 8 years now.
If you're right out of college,  I wouldn't recommend Honeywell as you'll find better management. work environment, health insurance and more elsewhere without the high risk of losing your job.   
They want to be a software company,  so Aerospace hardware is in conflict with that.

pros: Very good environment and friendly
cons: nothing bad to say about the company

review_title: Big company politics - don't change from practices of 30 years ago.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Redmond, WA
pros: Some can get in a niche and it will be a reasonably secure job.
cons:
Not cutting edge. Using techniques and methods that were proven ineffective 25 years ago by the rest of the world. Those trying to change things for the better are not rewarded, only fought at every step of the way, including by upper management.

Often not given the tools needed to do the job. For example, so many websites are blocked now, that I've been unable to access websites I tried to use to find good info to do my technical job. Also been blocked from doctor's websites. Far too much "scare tactics" that you are being monitored.

Too much hero worship. Instead of setting up a positive environment to do things right in the first place, the standard procedure seems to reward the "heros" who come in and save the day so that it is ALWAYS a firefighting mode type of lifestyle.

review_title: Corporate company, but doesn't feel corporate
job_title: User Experience Designer in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Stability working for an established company (as opposed to startups)
Startup mentality within the teams I work on
Great pay, very competitive with other companies in the city
Working on worthwhile and fulfilling projects
Chances to take ownership/responsibility for projects beyond your role responsibilities, which helps expand the scope of your skillset
The importance of good design and human-centered design approaches is recognized from top-level executives
Supportive managers that are there to help you reach your career goals
Managers recognize that work-life balance is important
Unlimited vacation policy
cons:
The health insurance is just ok - this is where Honeywell is not competitive, it's better than no insurance though
Sometimes feels very corporate - you can't get away from this, but sometimes decisions take a while to be made as they go up the chain of command
Company politics - Honeywell is a company that is built from acquisitions, and some of those acquisitions have vitriol against Honeywell, which makes for some interesting (but also frustrating) office politics

job_title: Senior Project Engineer in Houston, TX
pros:
- Great people and technologies to work with.
- Always learning opportunities and challenges
- Superior flexibility and great stability even with  volatile market
- Push very hard on IT infrastructure development and digitization
cons:
- Lower than average compensation
- Benefits are worsen annually
- Unfair performance review system
- Cost saving initiative and Wall street focus
- Often overlook on current employee
- Product quality and customer satisfaction worsen annually
- Lack of truly valuable new project
- Culture shifting downward is for real
- Pretending employee focus initiative marketing such as future shaper. Truth is employees and their opinions are being overlooked more than ever

job_title: Senior Human Resources Generalist in Tijuana, Baja California
pros: Growth Opportunities , Friendly Environment, Very Professional Company
cons: I haven't found any opportunity so far

job_title: Senior Quality Analyst in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros: challenging activity, opportunities for improvement, personal development
cons: nothing bad to be shared

pros:
- Salary is high for the area (rural), especially considering the cost of living.
- Direct boss is good at defending our time and shared similar views regarding the job we were *actually* hired to do.
- Honeywell is a big brand name that impresses outsiders.
- The safety-first culture is real and permeates well throughout. People may gripe about the rules, but a safe workplace is the best industrial workplace.
-Opportunities are always available to apply to, but relocation is practically universally required.
cons:
- Health benefits are a complete joke and encourage employees to seek coverage elsewhere.
- Honeywell's corporate "lean" system is a hodgepodge of, at best, well-intentioned requirements that leave no room for making the system work on a plant-to-plant basis. All these corporate musts fall on the shoulders of engineers that should be focusing on process-related projects, not time-consuming charts and graphs and pretty pictures.
