pros: Salary is acceptable. Projects I've worked on have been multi-disciplinary, technically challenging, and overall interesting to work on.
cons: The leadership is tanking this company. I never knew this level of low morale was even possible. Most attribute it to the insatiable greed of the outgoing CEO. He is trying to ensure his retirement comfort through the furloughs, layoffs, reduction in benefits, salary freezes, etc., that have been going on for years now. The company is doing well, but he is milking every dollar for the bottom line he can with these unsustainable hardships on the employees. I can't imagine there has ever been a company that has cared less about their employees.  Also, management cares more about the number of overtime hours you put in, rather than any output of value or quality of work. This contributes to a terrible work culture and general lack of work-life balance.

pros:
Honeywell got lot of market and really very good company in terms of brand but when it comes to Pune, it is really worst and experience is un believable.
 - Collage campus like buildings
 - Co-workers and their support
 - Campus gym ( 150 rupee only per month)
 - Good parking (ohh, really ? )
 - Cafetaria 
 - Best for people who wants to settle and don't want any growth in their career
cons:
- Management and their attitude
 - Time maintaining : While company tells that it follows flexibility in time, management changes perhaps they have their own rules on timing. Ex: One of the manager(my manger) defined his own rule says that: reporting people should come before manager comes to office and should leave office after manager leaves office
 - Least priority on work people do: Managers told that, "we are paid to do the work", how rash he is ?
 - Worst perks and not at all good place
 - Not a best place for people who want to see their career development

review_title: Great Performance-based Company with plenty of opportunity
job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
-lots of opportunity to get diverse experience and move up in the company quickly
-Currently transforming into a software industrial company which is an exciting transition to be apart of.
-Lots of support in your first 30 days.
-Supporting products that really make a difference.  You can be proud everyday you walk into work.
-Management is competent and supportive. I feel valued and heard on a daily basis.
cons:
-Many facilities are outdated and in desperate need of renovations (they are investing in fixing this).
-Work-life balance is not a strong focus point within the company culture. It really falls on the employee to establish this "line in the sand". Although I have not had a problem with work/life balance in my role, it is something I hear many people discuss as the biggest weakness to Honeywell's culture.

pros: Diversity, Interesting projects, reasonable training
cons: Bad environment to work for

pros:
Honeywell provides it's employees with a great benefits package, including health, dental, and a vision plan. They also match 50% of 401(k) contributions, which changes to 100% after 5 years. Honeywell provides regularly scheduled reviews, which help you know where you are standing within your department, and how you can improve. 

While I mention it as a downside as well, due to Honeywell's size, there are many, many opportunities for advancements and career path changes. You have the opportunity to do pretty much any job role you want, if you work hard enough.
cons: Honeywell is a massive company, and it can be frustrating to accomplish seemingly simple tasks due to the trail of red tape and procedures that need to be followed. There can also disparity between treatment for different band level employees.

pros: Honeywell is a huge corporation with over 120,000 employees worldwide, so things tend to vary by division and location. They are a process oriented organization, and provide a significant amount of training, pretty good benefits, and exposure to world class technology in many cases. I believe that executive management is competent, and leading the company in the right direction.
cons: Because of its size, you sometimes feel like a cog in a giant wheel, where the quarterly earnings are all important. They will cut quickly to make projected numbers, without much regard for the long term. Much of HON is a manufacturing driven organization, and has a hard time truly understanding some of their service based businesses. There can also be competition in the marketplace between various HON divisions. Although they claim to take an objective approach, if you are in a company acquired by HON, leave quickly, as they will gut it and put their own people in place (even as they say they won't).

job_title: Project Manager in Des Plaines, IL
pros: While my time at Honeywell was limited, you can tell that employee development and career advancement was an important part of Honeywell-- from the SMART review system to the employee training/skills development programs--you could tell that it was an integral part of the company. They also offer and in some ways promote changing positions within the company through their internal job search system.
cons: Unfortunately for me, the opportunities to continue to work at a great company was cut short due to their unwillingness to allow for remote work/telecommuting--even though many of the projects that I would manage would be at remote locations (e.g. - not in the home office) and spent most of my time communicating with people on the phone of via Lync around the world.  In my humble opinion, this type of position could very well be conducted from almost anywhere, especially with current technological advancements.

review_title: Upper management doesn't care about it's employees. But stocks are at all time high so who cares /s
pros: Coworkers, managers, Sr. manager, and some directors were good, friendly.
cons:
- They keep cutting down benefits. They now have HSA, no vision, not sure if they cut dental out yet. Except for CA, you get "unlimited vacation" with approval from management. Good luck getting it. 
- Don't treat employees with respect. If someone leaves, the work on the desk gets redistributed and good luck getting a replacement. Could take a year or more. By then, they would ask "Do we really need to hire another person, we are doing okay right now" even though everyone is overworked. 
- Don't trust it's employees at all.  You need to get everything approve, there is a operating system you nee to follow. 
- Only way to go up is if you're in AZ and not other sites that support it.

review_title: Team Lead, Cutting Room, or Sewer
pros: The only pro for having this job is that you have a job.  It's an ok position if you love endless mandatory overtime and low pay with stressful times.  Yes, you can get hired on and get lost in the crowd, but you have very little chance to excel.
cons: Mandatory overtime, (50-60 hrs a week),  very low pay for the responsibilities they make you responsible for.  hourly rates are like 8.00 an hour aprox. many many people do not speak English so you are faced with the stress associated with such a divers culture you want to scream at times.  They will listen to you try to better the place but it will go undone and all the new things they implement seems to last less than 6 months.

pros: Flexible work schedule is a major plus. In my group, we are allowed to work different hours, so long as our yield is met, and advance notice is given. My direct management is generally available and willing to help when direction is needed.
cons:
I don't think that executive management is really looking out for the employee. Pay cuts were given to employees, but not to the executive management. Throughout the various townhall meetings, you get the distinct impression that you are being told one thing, but that the actions will soon be something else. 
The processes in place for almost every activity can be a real headache to get through. It can be discouraging to see simple tasks take weeks or even months, due to a "process"

pros: Great Industries they are in, Good to Fair Products, Great Opportunities if given the chance,  Desperately need great talent so if you are talented, you will shine.  If you are mediocre, very compliant, stay fit, do nothing innovative,  and tell Upper Management what they want to hear you will succeed here.
cons: Below Average Industry Benefits,  Masters at Cutting not Growing, Stock is vastly overpriced, Double Standards abound, Cut so much staff-most hardworking employees are overtaxed with little support,  Less Staff than 5 years ago,  Few Subject Matter Experts left,  No Accountability for Engineering and Upper Management,  Far too much turnover especially with the most talented and proven staff.   SPS is the worst performing Group and that's where Darius came from which should tell anyone especially stockholders.

job_title: Product Security Engineer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I really liked the people I worked with and some of the work was interesting.
cons: HR and IT is horrible. I put my resignation in February 8 and HR did not put it into the system until March 4. They paid me extra because of that. Now they want the money back. OK no problem. But when they sent me notifications via paper mail, they looked like a scam so I ignored it. I finally, after the 3rd notice, called them and asked for more details. They sent the reply via email to the wrong email address. I called them again after not hearing from them. They said they sent it via email and sent it again.  After getting it, I sent an email asking to set up payments but they already sent it over to a collection agency. IT is not much better. I had a computer problem (windows config problem) and they had to re-image the computer, but they did not backup my files, they backed up the Windows directory. Luckily I did not lose too much. I had to acquire a external hard drive to backup my files, just in case. These are only a few examples of the problems.

pros:
- Good Technical exposes
- Development is good
cons: - Firing anytime without intimation

review_title: Just a Minion with a Number - HBS/HPS
pros: As long as you're not an Admin Assistant I would say that salaries are competitive. Also if you are a senior manager then you are treated with respect.
cons: There is no work-life balance for most. Leadership is self-serving. Union employees fair better. If you have the courage to stand up for yourself you are labled a trouble maker. HR is more about protecting the company then doing what is best for employee. If you have medical needs, Honeywell does not work with you. Anything you say will be used against you. Performance bonus is a joke and is based on your popularity with your manager.

pros:
Secure job. They won't fire anybody no matter how bad they are.

Good vacation and holiday policy.

Management is very good at allowing time off when needed. (see the first thing)
cons:
Processes, processes, Processes. Processes are more important than production and keeping the cost down. You spend more time keeping up with processes than engineering and manufacturing hardware.

There are 4 stages of a company. One, creation. Two, growth. Three sustain. Four, decline. Honeywell is definitely in the 4th stage. The problem is the management structure is so large that by the time you get high enough up the chain where 2 groups have a common manager that it is such a small problem to that manager that nothing ever gets fixed. The groups are separated and work in a vacuum removed from actually being responsible for cost so much that they don’t care if a process cost more money. It’s whatever it takes to make their job easier.

There is very little chance for advancement. Promotions are very few and far between if at all. Many people have worked for over 20 years without a promotion.

Frustration from work environment and lack of growth have sucked the life out of the people. They are like zombies trying to put in their time until they can retire.

review_title: Running place to ground. Fake leaders. Layoffs. Demotions.
pros: Big brand. Large portfolio. Diversified Technologies. Innovation and process. Fortune 100. #illusion. #shareholdervalue. #stockprice. #goodfromoutside
cons: #ReductionInForce #RIF You cannot make up the stuff that goes in Honeywell. HON only cares about operating income and #shareholder value. #Layoffs are a norm. This place is a #circus. You are constantly seen as a number. If you are a #block5, be worried. You are seen as #average. They keep telling everyone an 'A' player from outside is typically a #block5. You will be on #RIF. Everyone is constantly #worried. We keep getting told that HON has to do the #rightthing. #shareholdervalue. #donotrecommend. #50hourworkweek. #7amConferenceCalls.

review_title: Absolutely awful since day 1 with Intelligrated.
pros: Absolutely none. Paychecks are always on time?
cons:
-Piss poor leadership; bad leaders in positions they should not be in. 
- Zero growth despite excellent reviews and/or feedback. Leaders seem to want yes men in higher up positions for further org control  
- raise cuts, paycuts /furloughs
- slave labor hours to support poor engineering quality/lack of a stable product.
      - weekends weekends weekends. You need to work       every single weekend. Even when off site but mostly on site. Prepare to miss out on your personal life as long as you work here. 
-Blame falls on the wrong individuals for a product that just isn’t there / engineering isn’t there. 
- Software engineering is extremely political rendering it impossible to maintain a schedule or customer satisfaction 
- no visibility on where the product is and where it’s going. Company almost seems as though they want their employees to be on an absolute need to know basis. Probably because everyone knows that folks don’t stay much longer than a year.

review_title: Honeywell Aerospace is good. Each facility is not the same though
pros: Honeywell is a great company to work for. There are plenty of opportunities to grow in a company this size. The technology that the Aerospace side of the house has is fun and exciting.
cons: Learn as much as you can about each facility. They are NOT the same. The Redmond facility is all about who you know and how close you are. If you have "grown-up" there you will do just fine. If you are an outsider coming in, you may find the "Good-Ole-Boy" club hard to deal with and a hindrance when issue resolution is in order. The management is focused on dollars more so than the employees. There needs to be a balance and the employees are not afraid to tell you their feelings of neglect.

review_title: Acclimation to toxicity is not healthy
pros:
-Decent starting salary 
-Interesting work
-Unique opportunities to develop technical skills
-Good co-workers, few good managers 
-Walled cubicles (down to preference)
-OT pay
-Commuting to work is accessible, traffic around area is not bad at all
cons:
Where to begin....

-Toxic, high stress work environment
-Abysmal, and i mean ABYSMAL workplace morale 
-Literally no work/life balance. No clubs, societies, recreational leagues. No relationships outside of work.
-Lack of accountability, culture is heavily influenced by shifting blame to someone else 
-Favoritism and nepotism are clear to see
-Very top heavy; these positions are occupied by some seriously incompetent individuals
-Extremely poor project planning 
-Not a single program success in the last little while. Profit margins are still coming from products designed years ago by people who have long left for greener pastures. Lack of success comes from terrible decisions made at the highest level
-Heavily lacking a young workforce due to their inability to retain young, fresh talent
-Many half-baked and failed endeavors to improve workplace morale
-Attrition has been high the last few years, especially under current leadership. 
-No cafeteria serving food
-Poor benefits (benefits were reduced recently)
-Layoffs are an annual occurrence
-Furloughs happen every few years 
-Site leadership legitimately do not care about you, and value the worth of the dollar more than any contributions their employees make - i.e no loyalty

pros:
The technical environment at Honeywell is great at placing employees to their strengths and allowing them to learn and excel. There was very little in the way of dead weight, everyone was good at something, and I learned a ton from working with the engineers there.

Pay was great. 401k is good. Vacation is typical. And the health care plan is a joke.
cons:
On the other end, management is rather out of touch. Company policy was that there were no promotions, you simply had to apply for another job if you wanted to move up. Talent retention is abysmal with regards to younger employees for a variety of reasons that they refuse to acknowledge. Ebeneezer Scrooge runs this company. And they still use the old Jack Welch employee ranking system which pits employees against each other. 

Mandatory overtime even if work is slow.

I recommend working here for a few years, but don't expect to make a career here.

review_title: Not A Good Place to Work
pros:
The company pays their employees very well
If you like structure, Honeywell has their HOS (Honeywell Operating System) culture that they shove down your throat at every opportunity.  It is so rigid that you have to carry a pamphlet with your daily/weekly duties with you everywhere you go and mark off what/when you performed the task so management can review it when they ask for it to make sure you're doing your job.
cons:
Benefits stink.  High deductible insurance policy with HSA, 401K after 1 year of employment, very little time off for new employees.
Company lacks the value of time management skills for their employees.
Honeywell loves meetings. If something is going wrong, there's a meeting for that.  If that's going wrong, need to have another meeting for that.  They get so caught up in meetings that there is no time to actually work on what you're supposed to be doing to make sure things get accomplished/fixed.
Management acts aggressively towards their employees and expects them to work 12 hour days and gives employees a difficult time if they don't come in "early" or stay "late".

job_title: Product Manufacturing Engineer in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
There is a lot of freedom to work on what you
Pay is pretty decent
cons:
The tier system used is archaic at this point and leads to a lot of pointless meetings.  
Work life balance was awful, if you proved you were useful you would be forced to work 50+ a week while the useless employees could skate by at 40.
Do not expect a title change, you have to apply to higher positions and compete with internal and external candidates and if you do not get the position you get locked out for up to 6 months.
Due to the large rate of people quitting the team was always understaffed  since the company will only post positions at the new year
You have to watch an insane amount of training videos and due to the metrics of leadership these can take priority over line down issues

review_title: A regressive career  option for Senior IT Technical Roles.
pros: If attending meetings and not doing any actual work is your objective then this is the best organization.
cons:
Pathetic and nasty management, HR Folks and  work culture. 

Too much dependence on vendors for technical work.

Most of the significant architectural decisions taken while evaluation 
software platforms are taken by Business leaders influenced by vendors. 

Incompetent in-house technical architects and technical leadership.
Most of the technical people  have been promoted due to their loyalty (number of years in organization) rather than capabilities or have  joined here as last resort.

HR does everything else other than the what their job  requires.including encouraging colleagues and managers to spy on their own employees and inform them about personal private life of colleagues.

God forbid you decide to resign from this organization, since you are fed up and see no future for yourself in the organization, you will be harassed to no end  for getting your relieving letter and even  try to find ways to claw back some  part of your final settlement.

pros: Engineering, Reputation and Stability. If you like working at a strong and reputed engineering corporation, Honeywell is good place to be. Honeywell is a very structured environment, and very diversified, which means if you are lucky you could end up contributing to different projects.
cons:
Too many managers. Compensation is average at best. Bureaucratic Management, who's only claim to fame is that they have stuck around long enough to get promoted. The work environment is very very officious and boring. No-one jokes around, there are meeting very early in the morning. Projects usually run past deadlines due to mismanagement. 
No strong organizational commitment to innovation, but then that's the case with a lot of companies working in the same field as Honeywell.

job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Brookfield, WI
pros: Great product. Loyal Customers. Pay is good. Full Compliment of benefits. Company car, laptop, blackberry, expense account. Tremendous breathe of technology and expertise to draw from.
cons: Management totally incompetent. No knowledge of marketplace, competitors and what really will help get product sold. Outrageous quotas in some instances as much as 5000% growth expected from one year to the next. Very bureaucratic structure of company made it difficult to get the simplest things accomplished. Tremendous turnover. Terrible Customer Service caused unbelievable anger and hostility by Customers towards Company. Management would make promises to Customer's face and break them. No tact or diplomacy from upper Management. President stated at meeting "The Reps. are over paid $80K is to much for just getting up in the morning, washing your face, visiting a Customer and giving out your card". Management felt we should not attempt to "PARTNER" with Customers. But treat them purely as Customers who are only worth our time if they are buying. Product launches are half thought out and ill conceived.

pros: Great work environment; Managers won't breath down your back every day; Lots of knowledge to be gained both from text and co-workers.
cons: Low salaries compared to the market. I have only been here a few years but have already seen a handful of people leave for a different company (sometimes competitors) solely because they offered them a lot more.

review_title: Worst company culture - Honeywell Sensing and Productivity Solutions
pros: Large company with a wealth of resources
cons:
Working for or with Honeywell is a detriment to your health.  Honeywell makes its money on acquisitions - they buy up profitable companies, consolidate and outsource jobs, steal their technologies, move to the next company and repeat...They report a profitable bottom line from the acquisitions, but internally they are cutting benefits, scrutinizing every minute expense, shutting down facilities and laying off employees.  

Honeywell absolutely does not care about its employees.  They do not promote anyone to a manager without a Bachelors degree and director level promotions require a Masters degree.  It's an unwritten rule, but they write their job descriptions to rule out people they don't want.  As a result, employees with tenure from acquired companies are often overlooked and discarded.  Employees are expected to work long hours, with unrealistic expectations/metrics, and are stressed to the max because of the workloads and demands.  These expectations are not limited to their employees, but also to vendors that work for them and want their business. If you're looking for work-life balance, this is NOT the company for you.

review_title: Have room to spread my wings for sure.
pros:
I'm part of the HCE division here at Honeywell and definitely feel like as long as what I'm working on aligns directly with the overall strategy for the business, I have all the room and support from leadership in the world to go make it happen.

They are definitely allowing me to be a # Futureshaper and I'm not just saying that...no BS. Honeywell is a great company. Externally you might not be able to see the revenue but trust me its a good place to be and I'm enjoying it so far.
cons: Something else I'm working on is better aligning the day to day operations of my particular business. There are issues with the same function for example being done differently in different parts of the world or leadership not having the visibility they need.  There are things like this that need to be corrected which will make life easier for everyone once resolved and I'm working on helping address these issues. It's not that it's so bad but once the kinks get worked out everything will flow much better.

pros: Honeywell is a stable company, thee is a lot of career and knowledge growth opportunities. Opportunity to work on leading edge Aerospace R&D programs. Rich multicultural environment.
cons: Too much red tape everywhere - some of that is caused by the regulations (FAA/EASA) but the most worrisome is the over processing - there is a process and policy and rules and paperwork for anything and sometimes people just rather give up that to waste time on bureaucracy (eg. it takes 12 signatures and 6 months of time to get approved purchase of an item worth >$2500 for your project). Matrix based organization - in the end people hide behind this and refrain from making decisions or taking actions. You have to use so called "influential power" to get anything done - but some people are just resistant against this and do not help you no matter how important it is, what is at stake.

review_title: If I was provided with more training I would have enjoyed the job.
pros: Honeywell has pretty good benefits. You will not work weekends, it's Monday through Friday. You will receive an aggressive employee discount within the branch.
cons: I've never worked for a company that provides very minimal amount of training. Vendors would rarely come in to train, if they came in it was to meet a "visit quota" and leave very shortly after dropping off flyers. If you're new to the security industry this job will be a huge challenge for you. Also, you will take numerous calls a day. There's very minimal branch traffic as ADI provides drop shipping and overnight shipping. It's also team commission, so if you're use to holding your own destiny, you now rely on your team to sell and seek out new business.  There's absolutely no way that they could structure commissions on an individual level however due to the size of their customers accounts.

pros:
-Interesting work
-Decent travel mix
-Texh forward company with good technical infrastructure (SFDC, Tabluea, customer tools, etc.)
-Some Telecommute flexibility, though you have to fight for it.
- great advancement opportunity if you are a female: upper management mandates female grooming and promotion
- great if you live in a low cost of living country
cons:
- Not much opportunity for advancement in this direct path, but there are many potential branches like sales.
- Comparatively low salary, especially given the on call and after hours expectations.
-Phone system is a nightmare that tracks every second of your day.
- Airline operators are demanding 
- much less promotion opportunity if you are a male.
- prone to layoffs, especially as employees age.
- general feel that the company is 'cheap', where anything that can be is outsourced and upper management hordes the profits

pros: Supposed to provide a secure work environment - not that I have really seen it
cons:
Very large & slow moving bureaucratic elephant. Moves one degree at a time. Everything boils down to metrics and traffic lights on Excel Spreadsheets. One can create magic with numbers and distort facts if you are smart enough. 

Management ineptitude is layered under jargon's of HOS, MOS or HSE - all the same. Onsite is absolutely out of bounds for folks in Support Functions or Non - Sales roles. Every year Q4 comes with the predictable freeze in hiring and travel, though this is conveniently worked around for senior management. Visiting India is a junket tour for them under the guise of "important business meetings". 

HR is virtually non - existent and works in cahoots with the local management. No independent or employee centric decision making. Rules and processes are bended and twisted to suit convenience.

Work ethos on the floor resembles the culture of a typical BPO/Call centre with multiple support centres being established.

review_title: Excellent company with incredible resources, expertise, and unique position in the petrochemical industry
job_title: Senior R&D Engineer/Scientist in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Great learning environment, cutting edge resources, great people to work with tremendous knowledge base. UOP really has a lot of opportunities and a nurturing environment, but you have to want it. There are a lot of incentive-based opportunities available that will get you noticed. Although owned by Honeywell, UOP has its own company culture, very tight-knit group of scientists and engineers. Having Honeywell as the parent company has its advantages however (stock options). Overall a great work experience.
cons: Honeywell has somewhat diluted the company culture, many obscure meetings and company philosophies, pay is a little on the lower side, you do have to work long hours to get recognized, and everyone is overworked. People tend to stay in their roles so advancement is somewhat limited.

review_title: Resistance is futile.  You will be assimilated.  If you company is targeted for acquisition....RUN!
pros: 401K program is good.  Vacation time is good
cons:
Process, process, process.  That good 401K plan still is not back up to full match since it was cut during the recession.  I am always so busy that I do not fully enjoy my vacation time worrying about the things I need to be doing at work.  So much for the pros.

Our CEO goes on media outlets talking about how the US needs more engineers, but the mandate is no new hires in the US.  Hypocrite.  Our site is asked to grow by rather large amounts each year.  We are doing it, but no additional help.  The production workers have been working unsustainable amounts of overtime for far too long.  Everyone you bump into (including myself) looks like the company has broken them.

review_title: Things have changed over the last 10 years but it is still a good place to work
pros:
Many terrific people who work very hard at their jobs. 
A good place to be challenged on several levels.
You are given the opportunity to grow as your experience level grows.
cons:
Some business groups within the org. are too concerned about having a body that lives local to HQ and has an MBA versus actually hiring the right person for the position. Now those groups are at a point where product management and engineering have no experience/knowledge of our business and build products they want versus what the market requires. 
Too many processes, example - to roll out NPI generally takes 2 years (and that is using the Agile engineering process).
Benefits continue to slip. Over the past 10 years we have gone from a company that took care of its employees to a culture of cut costs and increase margins so we can boost the stock price so our CEO and Co-Chairmen can make 200x the average employee salary. There is a balance point that needs to achieved.

review_title: Run away and don't look back!!!
pros: Some good people. Great engineers and maintenance people. I learned a lot about process analysis and problem solving.
cons: Benefits are horrible now, cost cutting always comes at the employees expense. Upper management has ridiculous expectations. Management in my facility had the most turn over I've ever seen at any job. No work/life balance. I hated being micro-managed from some upper management that was 2000 miles away and understood the process only on paper and none of them have a clue as to what's really going on. I met some of the dumbest people with degrees that I wouldn't trust to make me a big mac correctly. Lazy employees get rewarded, hard working employees are expected to pick up their slack with no reward. Worst "raises" I've ever seen.

review_title: A company that slowly crushes the workers’ spirit.
pros: The people but they’re all quitting or walking out. Also, the flex time.
cons: This company does not care about a person. They pile work on you meant for multiple people, offer no help nor guidance, expect you to get it all completed in a day, and they simply do not care. They only care about money and nothing more. It is open environment which means you have ZERO privacy, no desk space, and as each coworker breaks down in tears you cannot console them without bring a tremendous amount of attention. So to give them some kind of privacy, you’re forced to ignore them. 80% of workers are contractors which means ZERO benefits and because you will be a contractor that means you are not allowed to participate in ANY UOP Honeywell company activities. No matter how appealing this place looks visually, it truly is not. It WILL break your spirit and they don’t care, all they will do is drive you to quit by setting you up for failure which they can then fire you; or, they flat out fire you. Like they did with a former colleague a week before his retirement (he’d been there for almost 20 years.) If you have any self value, don’t work here.

review_title: "That's the way we've always done it so why would we change it" mentality. Even if it reduces cycle time.
pros: Constantly looking to the future. Always hesitant to take the step forward. Rarely consider new/more useful processes. "That's the way we've always done it so why would we change it" mentality.
cons: Management doesn't care about their employees. Terrible insurance. Layoffs, furlough weeks. Moral is low most of the time. Always a dark cloud of 'layoff possibilities' overhead. A lot of outsourcing to other countries brings down productivity. Not a lot of energy in the environment, it can bring you down. Sometimes feel more like a number than a valued employee. Lack of qualified leadership and too many organizational changes.

review_title: Okay company. Too large of a company. Used to be a great place to work.
job_title: Software Engineer III in Redmond, WA
pros: Honeywell gives decent benefits for a large corporation. The company is a stable place to work long term. Global company and provides opportunity to move around the company easily. Work life balance is great. Most managers are good with flexible schedules.
cons: Benefits are being reduced every year for the past 5 years. Honeywell is a technology company that prides in creating new technology. However, the technology it uses to build the new things are 20-30 years old, resulting in unnecessary burden on engineers. The company has become so large that it is now all about profit. Too many young and talented engineers have left in recent years.

review_title: A company going the wrong way
pros:
Fixed pay

Work life balance

You don't need to work, you can hide behind the process forever and socialize.
cons:
Too much of process, a process also checks how many columns of icons you have in your laptop. 

No quality of work, process. 

Work from home options has also been stopped in few departments. 

Loss of pay can happen anytime. 

Promotions and on sites are kept secret, you never know when your friend is promoted or you might discover one day that he is going onsite. 

A place for the oldies where you won't find friendly colleagues. 

If you want visibility or promotion you have to become your manager's pet. 

You were not suppose to ask questions and just blindly follow your architects advise. He will be your new God from the day you joined.

job_title: Test Engineer III in South Bend, IN
pros: Able to maintain work life balance with flexible work hours. Feel a strong sense of job security and room to grow so long as the factory remains in business.
cons:
Generally, a toxic atmosphere reigns over the south bend plant. The recent lock out grew tensions between salaried and hourly union workers. Leadership seems to hold onto incompetent workers. Deviations in the manufacturing process affect a surprisingly large amount of the product being made. 

There’s a bi-modal population distribution between entry-level and senior level employees nearing retirement age. It seems most young people come in for ~3 years and run away. 

They recently debuted “unlimited vacation” but left approval to your manager’s descretion. My manager claims to not have resources to allow anyone in the group to take more vacation than they were allotted before this policy. That leaves the newer employees with 2 weeks, and the veterans with 4-6 weeks depending on tenure, so what’s the point?

review_title: Used to be a decent company a long time ago, now total garbage
pros: They're still around.  One of the few remaining companies that still has a pension plan (but not for new hires).  Many good people got their start here.
cons:
Outsourcing up the wazoo.  Complete disregard for customers, employees, vendors, and contractors.  Management incompetence levels so high it is a miracle this company is still around.  Honeywell used to imitate and do everything like GE - they forced that stupid Six Sigma nonsense that GE invented on everyone.  They used GE as a model to run every aspect of their own business.

Well.... look where GE is these days.  It's a big pile of garbage falling apart from years of mismanagement and stupidity.  That's why I'm so surprised Honeywell, the GE monkey-see-monkey-do-mini-me, is still around.

Leaving this dump was the best career move ever.

pros: Still a leader in the industry.  A few of the best and brightest in the industry,  holdovers from the old UOP,  continue to work there and have alot of knowledge to provide if you're willing to learn.
cons: Management keeps eroding away reasons to work there,  such as benefits. There is no planning beyond 5 years and for the long term health of the company. There is little planning for the many experts who will retire very soon who have been relied upon to keep UOP at the forefront of the industry. Company focuses on management, sales, and business rather than the technical capability that UOP was built upon.  Attrition in groups just spreads out the work among the rest of the group members lowering morale while the company gets the same work out of less people while management beats up the group for not having the same output.

review_title: Company Goals not in line with plant goals
job_title: Information Systems Analyst in Tucson, AZ
pros: Honeywell is a great place to work if you completely ignore the company direction and upper management goals.  Every week it seemed a new "directive" was handed down from on high, buzzwords were granted fertile ground to breed at the never ending stream of meetings that seemed to fill out the working day.  I swear to you, we actually held meeting to plan subsequent meetings.  I watched that company hemorrhage money, often wondering how they could stay in business as long as they have been operational.  Honeywell is a company that will spend 1k to save 1$.  Frankly, when I was RIF'd, I had mixed feelings.  I miss my co-workers but I don't miss the screwy corporate atmosphere.
cons: As a middle management employee there where few downsides, the company treats you well.  As a rational human being it was like working in a sitcom about a distopian mockery of a government contracting industrial corporation.  Madness and lots of it.

review_title: Culture depends on the business unit
job_title: Commodity Buyer/Commodity Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefit package.  You are vested in 401K after 2 years.   Also vested in pension after 5 years.  Very competent and bring people, although the culture depends entirely on the business unit.  I was in Honeywell Aerospace for 2 years and the Automotive group for 3 years and there is a huge difference.  Aerospace is slow to change and very stagnant, things get done slowly with lots of old-timers reluctant to change, not for you if you are bright and ethusiatic.  Automotive division however is more fast paced, and has younger average age.
cons: Not the most creative organization.  As with any large companies, promotions come with playing politics and not necessarily to the most deserving employees.   The past focus on moving job and resources to emerging markets (Mexico, China, Eastern Europe) means long term quality in product, customer service, competency is very much sacrificed for short term agenda and a check list to report to the top.

review_title: Waiting for Economy to Swing Upwards to Get Out
pros: Participation in manufacturing high tech, state of the art equipment, privileged to work with talented professionals.
cons: Only CEO seeing the bucks. Big, big bonus for him. Since Allied Signal came, company got very cheap, they don't buy any new test equipment unless they find a way to make the customer pay for it. Implemented a plan called 5S which "cleaned up" the factory but also got rid of all engineering supplies too. Impossible-to-meet schedules, which mgt. calls "challenging". Don't replace people who leave, others have to take on the work no matter how full one's plate already is. When one takes vacation, they end up giving half or more back with unpaid overtime the following week. Very, very heavy workload of no-value-added "process" means even more unpaid overtime req'd. Impending mass exodus from HI if/when economy improves.

job_title: Senior R&D Engineer/Scientist in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: It motivates employees by allowing you to innovate new ideas. You are given given lot of responsibilities to face and guided through properly. Career growth is good. Except a very few people, management follows code of conduct and safety policy religiously.
cons: Management is indifferent in India. They say a lot of big words on safety, work culture etc, but they themselves don't think before violating them openly. Though Honeywell which acquired UOP recommends to report these, but nothing happens, rather the one who reported face the heat of music by these unethical, incompetent managers. Their numbers are few, but due to their position they affect a lot of people.

pros: A paycheck - sometimes - unless you're asked to take ANOTHER mandatory week long UNPAID furlough.
cons: Your work days are at least 10 to 12 hours every day. The company operates under a fear culture & drives workers into the ground. The environment is so stressful Honeywell workers have actually committed suicide - in the office. The health plan is an absolute joke $6,000+ annual deductible in ADDITION to your bi-weekly contribution. It's Honeywell's conniving way of driving workers off its health plan. Dave Cote is so focused on pleasing Wall Street he creates slave-like work conditions using the fear of layoffs as a bully stick. It's shameful & obscene. A pristine example of a top 1% class member crushing the 99% for their own selfish gain.

review_title: Great positions as well as bad ones
pros:
Chances to travel abroad.
Exciting projects if you work on new ones completely developed in Brno.
Some good benefits, though not the best in town.
Large company with various projects allows for internal transfers, so if you don't like where you are, you can start working in another team which may suite you better without changing companies.
cons:
The location of the campus is at the outskirts of the city, so commuting is annoyance.
This following applies to only one team out of the many there are on the Brno site. Can't speak for all of them.
Working on existing product lines with established baselines, where you only modify existing product under strict processes becomes exhausting and your motivation goes down the drain pretty quickly.
Local managers seem to have little power over US mangers who make silly decisions and plan projects poorly. This results in unnecessary overtimes and frustrations.

review_title: Not a Big Fish Corporation, more like a School of Fish
job_title: Service and Repair Technician II in Charlotte, NC
pros: The paycheck has never bounced.
cons:
Health Benefits are poor, vacation accrual time is poor, only 2 weeks at onset, takes 5 years to earn more. They promote based on who's willing to take on extra responsibility and blame with no pay raise rather than knowledge or experience. Therefore management turnover rate is high here and no one wants to move up to work as management.

They just don't take care of their employees. They cut or shutdown their supply depots, 5S their spare inventory out of the building and then question why production is down. 

Their motif is a corporate greed motif. Layoff employees. Shutdown production and supply lines right before quarterly analyses so that way cost goes down because you have LESS employees and LESS material for them to actually accomplish their job, BLAME LOCAL MANAGEMENT, SELL OFF HALF YOUR STOCK MR. CEO, ATTEMPT TO MERGE WITH YET ANOTHER COMPANY using the inflated profit you usurped from NOT INVESTING IN YOUR OWN COMPANY, and yeah this company is not going to be around for long. Honeywell is a Vampire. It just sucks the blood out of every small company it picks up and moves on.

pros:
Managers - Managers are mostly helpful, knowledgeable, supportive and will usually go to bat for you
Co-workers - There are minimal politics within a department. Most people are constructive, supportive, knowledgeable and effective. Contractors and full-timers seem to get along, and everyone treats each other pretty fairly.
Work-life balance - Culture is understanding of work-life balance. All engineers are provided with a personal laptop with remote connection capability (for working offsite).
cons:
Promotions - Promotions tend to be delayed even for very qualified, experienced engineers in team lead roles
Training - Trainings are typically done online. Training content is usually drab, non-specific fluff with no engineering-specific technical content. No other training opportunities are available.
Compensation - Salaries seem to be below market rate, but not ridiculously so. Benefits have deteriorated over the past few years and are no longer competitive (e.g. glasses are not included, paramedical services such as RMT have been reduced to a fraction of what they were).

review_title: Once a great company, now a shell of its former self
pros:
Great/friendly people who are extremely knowledgeable
Interesting projects to work on
cons:
Dwindling benefits
Questionable Job Security
Disconnected leadership
Outdated technologies/products

There are a lot of experienced engineers who have been with the company for many many years. This isn't necessarily a bad thing and if often to beneficial to people who do join as there is a knowledge to be gained. However, the issue is there tends to be a lot of "bashing" of the younger generations across the organization. This isn't a huge concern in of itself and is often misplaced.

The real issues with this organization have been a lot of the leadership's decisions to become more "efficient". A lot of cutting has happened to employee benefits and there has been non stop quarterly layoffs in recent years. A lot of this is blamed on the industry not being strong but also a ton of it has been decided by gross over-reaction to stock pricing.

review_title: Could do so much better as an Employer
pros: The people you work with make it a better place to work. Variety in job roles can be possible, but you have to push yourself forward to get anywhere.
cons:
Management haven't got what it takes to make the companies within Honeywell a true success, they're too wrapped up in their own self-importance to care about much else. It can be a very insular environment, where the importance of a 'One Honeywell' is lost due to managers and others playing Politics. 

The workers at the bottom do know about the importance of production targets and quality, but it all goes down the pan when the 'Metrics' are more important than the work you are supposed to be doing.

pros:
Working from home is usually not a problem, but it will depend on who your manager is. Work times are flexible to a certain extent. 
Ok benefits. 
Very good communication between the different levels of the organization. But again, this also depends on your management.
cons:
Low growth possibilities. You can have a lot of experience, doing a great job (according to your manager) and never get promoted. It also seems it is more difficult for women to get a promotion. 
Not much vacation time, in my opinion.

review_title: Honeywell Aerospace is a decent workplace with some nice perks and horrible benefits.
pros: Opportunities to practice and engage in different departments to learn new skill sets. Travel to remote sites can be fun and interesting. Dining cafe located within the facility. Bravo award system is nice for earning cash compensation.
cons:
Too much micro-management (daily email status reports, daily system status sheets, daily morning standups; to include safety topics not pertaining to work, enforced process improvements; minimum count yearly, enforced safety calls; minimum count yearly) requires extra time and effort to meet company standards.

Benefits are atrocious requiring a high amount of out of pocket expenses.

pros: Honeywell is a large, stable company.  The pay was very competitive for our region.  Management is rewarded well for their contributions.  Lots of opportunity to work with people around the globe and gain experience with other cultures.  The company sponsored training is very impressive and my manager invested in my career growth.
cons: Since the company is large and well established, this means that the company has processes, procedures and tools in place which have solved the business needs to date and are proven stable.  That in and of itself is not a bad thing, but it means that as an employee you cannot quickly switch to new ways of doing things, or start using the latest technology, even though all evidence in the industry would suggest that they are effective.  New procedures take time to be implemented.  (This will be a con to some, not to others.)

review_title: You are a resource here, not a person.
pros: The work is interesting with an ever changing business and focus. I definitely do not get bored working here.
cons: In the 18 months or so I've worked here, there have been 4 furloughs, 3 layoffs, a decision for no raises, increased health insurance with reduced coverage, and a new ban on working remotely. They've eliminated nearly every benefit there is to working at Honeywell. Employees and their happiness are the absolute lowest priority at Honeywell.

review_title: A great place to work if your job happens to fit the Honeywell vision of the world.
job_title: Advanced Project Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros: Honeywell is a well run company that will always make the hard choices in favor of achieving short term objectives.  Meeting financial goals is the only measure of success for this business, even when goals are fundamentally flawed. Honeywell is not alone in this approach to business - they just do it extremely well.
cons: For a global company with operations in multiple industries, Honeywell still finds it difficult to treat human resources in a humane manner.  Not all businesses can be run according to the same "operating system" concept, and likewise, employees are not software sub-routines to be deleted when approaching their end-of-life-cycle dates.

review_title: Great large company with strong leader at the top
pros: Large well-established company with solid processes and procedures that help delineate roles and responsibilities and accountability. Strong focus on six sigma and lean. Strong CEO that has helped Honeywell through the weak economy and maintain if not gain in most the industries it is in compared to the last time Honeywell went through a recession. Solid 401K program and one of the few companies that still has a pension.
cons: Performance management was brought over from GE and helped at first to eliminate most of the weak performers, but now it causes solid contributors to potentially be managed out. Benefits have been cut severely especially medical. Compensation is average and it seems like merit raises are more based on your ability to "play the game" than on results.

review_title: large company with a lot of process
pros:
- plenty of opportunity if willing to pay own relocation
- lots of six sigma and lean manufacturing related processes
- meaningful and cool work
- nice office building inherited from acquisition of EMS Technologies
- very good internal tools for employee self servicing and training
cons:
- some processes not particularly useful for software development
- compensation not as competitive
- innovation and vision lacking from upper management not well versed with software dominating industry
- lack of career development and guidance since there was no local human resource
- too much red tape for internal purchasing of tooling and utilization of open source inhibiting developer productivity
- some team leads lack appropriate leadership training

pros: Nice people to work with.  Not an issue with the people.  Its an issue with the upper management starting at Dave "take the shoes off my kids feet" Cote.  Opportunities if you like to move around the country.  I never understood this policy.  Why not keep good people within the same plant?
cons: Dave "take the shoes off my kids feet" Cote will do anything to his employees to make the bottom line and pad his own pockets.  I hear he may be leaving soon.  About 5 years ago, he set out his goal to have the stock hit $120.  It did touch there, so maybe he'll back off a little.  The stock was at like $35 when he made that pronouncement.  He achieved his goal at his employees expense.  now he's dismantling the company to make numbers in a form of desperation.  He sold off / spun off the biggest Nylon division and all its supporting companies from Hopewell VA.  This is a desperate move to make quarterly numbers.  I have friends in the plant I worked at that are involved.  They now have 2 companies working from the same location in PA.

pros: Have learned management skills and tools, like communication and accountability through daily Tier Board meetings and 5S organization for efficiency  and Rapid Problem Solving and Injury management.
cons: Instability.....mandated non-paid furloughs for management twice per year; mandatory 60 hour work weeks for factory workers; result: insecurity, financially and emotionally. changed suppliers to one that could not keep parts coming, workers standing and waiting for weeks.

review_title: Not much good organization to work
pros: good for freshers and for those who don't have any job offer
cons:
All this below are meant for Engineer(0-5 year )/Senior Engineer(5-15 year)/Tech lead(10-20 year)

1.Its a community oriented organization , they treat you by your state/language even if they say world class, but it is internally this law only works.North Indian never interested to join this organization.

2.No WFH,if they allow , need written explanation, keeping senior director in loop and Hr in loop and there is a form where you have to show 8 hour work priority to WFH approval.

3.This organization hardly participate any community service activity.

4.No training for Engineer, Senior engineer , they only approve some junk outdated domain training in Avionics domain.

5.Outdated technology working , like ADA and mostly all of the work done by In house tools, so no chance to learn, once you come here, its a trap, cant leave this place.

6.Not much hike, there is no concept of salary revision.

7. Getting next level promotion is next to impossible, so their all senior members are leaving.

8. Higher management never shares the future road maps, only share their expectation.

9.There is a frequent forced holiday in this organization, so there is a less chance of job security.

10.Very strict in office timings, there is no flexi timings.

pros: Work Life Balance, Slightly above average pay, Good products to represent
cons: High health care cost, high employee cost of company vehicle with minimal choice, raises cost of employee vehicle mid lease instead of at time of car choice - different vehicles have different employee deduction.  So you can pick a cost and then mid stream they can raise it and it just comes out of your check, upper management is a revolving door, most investments put in analytics to manage up and for stockholder data, out of touch with customers.

review_title: a short title for your review
pros:
- good for starting up a career
- one of very few employers of aerospace in Czech Republic
- some benefits are interesting as well as business trip possibility
cons:
- high fluctuancy of employees - whatever the reason is, this causes that in certain areas are mostly young inexperienced people - problem worldwide
- hiring process is not always transparent

review_title: Happy to Work for an Exciting, Reputable Company
job_title: Senior Marketing Specialist in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: Challenging, exciting work and a strong team spirit. As intense as things can get at times, I always feel appreciated and motivated to do my best. Very good compensation and benefits.
cons: The work-from-home policy is draconian. While I personally prefer coming to the office (and recognize that the nature of my position mandates it), I definitely would not mind being able to save on commuting costs (and traffic-induced stress) by telecommuting one or two days a week. Also, work-life boundaries can become  extremely blurred at times (i.e., long hours, emails sent late at night, etc.).

review_title: Good benefits, enforce policies, professional environment, and challenging yet reasonable tasks.
pros: Good benefits, professional work environment, Travel overtime compensation less 1st 8 hours, gives employee room to improve.  Tasks and challenging twists that are in line with employee's abilities, and flexible hours, and serious about safety and provides extensive safety training, implements software code standardization, employee written training manuals for internal use and open documentation.
cons: Compensation below average for controls engineering.  Although chargeable salared employees are compensated for overtime during travel system startups, they are not compensated for the first 8 hours of overtime.  Policies take time away from chargeable tasks.  Not generous with bonuses and annual salary increases.  Talks about employee individual goals yet ,rarely, supports/provides opportunity for employee to obtain goal.

review_title: Welcome to the Tipping Point; hope you enjoy the view on the way down.
pros: Aerospace software engineering is your passion. You like being pulled in 20 directions at once because that's the only way to ensure your job won't be outsourced.
cons: Difficult to get up to speed on projects. All knowledge is 'tribal' based. Documentation and cooperation is poor even though they try to cram Six Sigma down your throat. Many bottlenecks in process as critcal employees take on more responsibility than they can handle in an effort to obtain job security. C-level management comes up with directives that everyone knows are doomed; so departments scramble in an awkward corporate game of 'hot potato' to see who the blame will fall on when things blow up.

review_title: Not A Bad Place To Work But You Will Likely Stagnate There
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good benefits.  Not a lot of stress or pressure about work and you can definitely have an active life outside of work as long as you aren't looking to get promoted.
cons: Lots of old technology is used and there is very little cutting edge development.  It is easy to become comfortable and stagnate in a position.  There are very few challenging projects and finding the route to advancement is difficult.  The company is more likely to promote you if you have left them for another job then if you try to work your way up within the company.

pros:
For me, I chose this job due its department which caters customers worldwide. It gave me chance to work in various countries of the world at very young age. 
Job gave me lot of opportunities which I got in early stage of my career.
cons:
They are paying very less compared to competitors. The department I am working is project department and there are different type of projects within ACS are taken place. There is lack of skills for these different type of projects & management is not taking care to train people properly before getting these various projects. 
Employees struggle to give time to their family life.

review_title: I've been there more than 20 years, so it must be OK
pros:
Big company benefits. The company invests heavily in technology that is predicted to provide a healthy return in the necessary (rather short) time.
Dave Cote seems to think like a normal person.
Anytime I've looked elsewhere, I've always come home from the interview thinking "I thought we were messed up."
cons:
Big company bureaucracy and politics. Some times the focus is too much on short term. There are several layers of "yes" men between the top and the bottom.
Our customers used to say we were "technically arrogant" and "low maintenance suppliers." They don't say that any more.
Product lines that make huge margins fund R&D in lower revenue product lines.
Business leader clout is a function of revenue, not profit margin or return on investments.

review_title: Good To Great To Poor - AlliedSignal to Honeywell changing times
pros: Decent benefits, generally secure jobs (though I was laid off after 21 years), decent pay, exciting work (aerospace), of course good people to work with over the years.
cons: The last 3-5 years management became quite ruthless, and I'm sure that came from the top (CEO), Dave Cote. The many of the type of managers put into place at the President and VP level were un-caring, malicious, deceiving, un-trustworthy; I know because I was victim of such a situation. I should have brought a law suit, but instead tried to move into another position; three years later during the lowest of the economy I was laid off (I had just turned 49...).

job_title: Senior Strategic Marketing Specialist in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Great technology, most people very competent and professional 
Strong history, treat scientists and engineers well
cons: Manager extremely unprofessional, got fired from DOW and planted himself in UOP as an "expert." Engaged in extremely high risk management practices by allowing bullying in his group (blaming the wrong person) and sexism. He constantly took credit for others' work which is pretty pathetic for someone who they supposedly hired for his experience and bragged most of the day. A former HR employee was frequently making racist comments in public (she got fired though not clear if it was due to this behavior). HR does nothing even when people go to them with concerns. The specialists run around most of the day gossiping and engaged in drama rather than doing any actual work. I can't believe anything actually gets done there.

review_title: If you're a flirtatious woman then this is a great place to work......
pros: Great benefits and leave time.  Some training provided.  Sometimes lunch provided at All Hands meetings.
cons: Two times during my employment there I witnessed women who were very flirtatious rise up the ranks to high paying positions while the rest of us more qualified and educated persons are left in the dust.  This location (Blount Island - Jacksonville, FL) is run by many retired military men.  They don't seem to understand that these women are only flirting with them to get bonuses and raises and that the women never (repeat NEVER) will go out with them!

review_title: Financial performance masks toxic culture, terrible leaders
job_title: Senior Leader in Deer Valley, AZ
pros: Phenomenal employee base, industry leading products
cons: Really awful leadership layer. Employee and union intimidation is regular policy. If you're a suck-up and know how to please your boss, you can advance your career easily. If you act as a change agent, you will fail and you will be ejected. Everyone talks about how great it is that Honeywell has gone from $60 per share to $160 per share in 6-7 years. But if the company had a better culture, share price would be at $360, not $160. They succeed in spite of themselves, mainly due to the quality of their engineers, but many are retiring or leaving due to the abusive treatment and overwork. Simultaneously, the company is having a hard time recruiting millennial talent -- too many other great options. No one wants the pain of working for a bunch of guys whose idea of leadership is the proverbial whip and cudgel. Silicon Valley professionals, don't go here -- you will regret it.

review_title: Innovative company with old fashioned mindset
pros: Pay and my coworkers are nice enough
cons:
*Lied about the type of work I would be doing. I asked a lot of questions during my interviews and was sure of the position I applied for and was interviewed for. Then I get here and this is NOT what they said I would be doing. 

*Insurance is expensive with regular coverage, (nothing spectacular for paying so much money like lower deductible or no copay)

*No work from home policy in the entire company (well actually they don’t mind you working from home as long as you have put in your 8+ hours in the office that day! Sure go home and work another 5+ hours)

*Lunch room only takes badges, no cash, no credit card and it takes FOREVER to get that setup so just bring your lunch or go out

review_title: Get in a couple of good years.  Use available benefits (tuition reimbursement for masters degree).  Then get out.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Large company.  Plenty of opportunities to move around (if you don't like your current job or co-workers you can generally apply internally for other positions in 18-24 months.  Benefits are generally pretty good.
cons: Pay was generally below market, especially for those that had been there for a couple of years.  As a large organization they were very rigid with rules about raises/promotions.  They left no decision making ability with the local managers about pay/promotion issues.

review_title: A great place to learn as an intern
job_title: Student Engineer III in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great Exposure to technology, especially for an intern.  Also the process capabilities are very diverse, so if you do get tired with the job you are working on, there is always the opportunity to move to a drastically different job, but still work under the same roof.  A very sizable portion of the current workforce is eligible for retirement, so the future opportunity for promotions and lateral movement is great.
cons: Due to the security concern of some of the work, there are always concerns of what you can and can not talk about.  Also, as a defense contractor, working for the government, there is a considerable amount of "red tape," which at times can seem to be cumbersome.  Lastly, the pace of work is fairly slow, which can bother some individuals.

review_title: Cares nothing about employees and does little to retain talent
pros: The Honeywell name has become synonymous with innovative technologies and materials.  The have hundreds of facilities all over the world and have completed several acquisitions to further diversify.
cons:
Where should I start?  I've been with this company for 14 years.  I watched as former CEO Dave Cote completed several acquisitions, only to then watch the company "spin off" two divisions into new companies that now struggle.  

Attracting and retaining talent in an unknown concept.  If you are negotiating your salary as a prospective employee, you better aim high because you're going to make that exact salary for most of your career.  The employee evaluation system sets unrealistic goals to prevent pay raises.  

Perhaps the most damaging thing I've seen is CEO Dave Cote's "Honeywell Operating System" or HOS.  It's his personal attempt to mimic the Toyota Operating System, a very time consuming and wasteful program was put in place.  At my facility, 2-3 new manager positions were created just to oversee HOS.  Production lagged and ultimately suffered.

pros:
Make good money at Honeywell but you’ll be there everyday of your life. 
Lots of good operators out there that’ll help you. 
Great place to get experience.
cons:
Poorly Managed, Management has no experience on what to do and don’t listen to the experienced operators that know the plant. Management doesn’t speak up for operators or take care of them in anyway. Basically do your job and be quiet. 
Not really a Operator Job, more of a laborer 
Things never get fixed correctly trying Bc they are always trying to save a few dollars, making it a very unsafe place work. 
The only way you’ll get noticed or moved up is if you’re a “Good Ole Boy”. 
The worst benefits you’ll get anywhere. 
Morale is horrible throughout the plant. 
Work in acid suit all day long everyday. 
Constantly trying to get equipment to work. 
Poorly engineered. 


ALL around horrible Company to work For
THEY MAKE DOLLARS NOT SENSE.

review_title: A company headed down due to upper management ideas.
job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: If you have the right connections there are some very good engineering jobs.
cons: The increases in pay are very small, most below the inflation rate.  The amount of paper work increases and you are expected to work unpaid overtime to keep up with the work load.  The company does not replace people that leave and expects the remaining people to pickup the additional work load.  The worst problem is that comments and suggestions from people not in management are rejected no matter the value to the company.

review_title: The companys successes haven't resulted in gains for the employees
pros:
They offer major medical and dental insurance
37%  401k match
Life Insurance
O.K. wage
cons:
Insurance coverage isn't very good
Pay is stagnated
No room for advancement in HPS
Lay offs are always looming due to contracts needing to be renewed annually or bi-anually

pros: work culture, organizational structure, perks to ppl travelling out of stationed office.
cons: payouts are pretty less compared to competitors. almost zero perks. people receive either certificates / petty gifts rarely (once in 2-3 years) if situated in office job. incentive payout for non sales employees is totally dependent on the manager / management. good relations with the manager can get u good perks else only fishy words. seen this especially in India and Middle east. spent approx 5 years and was working on Honeywell products without any formal training.

review_title: A solid brick and mortar employer to work for: 11 years at 2 divisions.
pros: Cross-training and making best use of current skills while improving weaknesses. Strong, consistent performance of technicians and engineering with an old school "roots" feel. Enjoyed interactions and positive vibe. Employee empowerment.
cons: Large temporary workforce makes it a fight for permanent positions. Engineers and assemblers treated as upper and lower classes with no middle class for technicians as they are viewed as a non-value added commodity. A tech implies a problem within the process attitude. This is very subtle and my only Con. Most might not notice. Oh, you can golf your way up the ladder. As a PGA sponsor they love golf - unfair to those who don't. Minor Cons.

review_title: Great People, Great Cause, Poor Management
job_title: Engineering Support Specialist in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great People, Great Mission, Stable environment
cons: Honeywell FMT out of Kansas City used to be a great place to get started. but unfortunatly Honeywell Corporate kept sticking there nose in and requiring more aggressive cost savings. Honeywell FMT no longer has a college reimbursement, they charge you for smoking, they charge you based on your Body Mass Index, they have high management turn over, and they require you to turn in 12 continuous improvements a year. That many improvements bottles up the systems and a lot of work is overhead. The real work comes second to Honeywell corporate. Expect to have daily stand up meets as part of Honeywell Operating System AKA Toyota Lean Efficiency. There HPD or Honeywell Performance Development is basically a 9 block scale where they rate you against your peers. Every manager MUST have a person below 5 block which is where everyone is.

review_title: Orthodox working style, Lacking in innovation
pros: Fairly good salary. Great for laid back persons.
cons:
1. Working style is very orthodox, Managers may behave how a petty shop owner do with their servants.
2. Massive politicized system. People do not care to respond emails on time. It took me 2 weeks to get response on an HR issue.
3. Very poor in Innovation 
4. Very poor and un-structured processes. Small  things may take weeks to get done. Massive scope of automation and Business Process Improvement but seems like no leader cares about it.
5. If your laptop or company phone stops working, they will deduct the repair charges from your salary. it happened with me last month.
6. They introduce compulsory Leave without Pay, to improve their margin performance, even if you have joined few weeks back.
7. Highly overstaffed organisation, but all due to bad systems and processes.

pros: The brand is very strong. It's remarkable how much people appreciate it. In a sense, I'd say the financial practices are a pro. The company seems to be run as a best-in-class holdings company. I don't foresee it ever disappearing, or losing money for the matter.
cons: It's a large, old company that's transforming. Not a new story. Needs to shake off the rust and modernize. Benefits are disappointing, culture is disappointing, organizational structure is very disappointing. I think its best innovations come in the form of FP&A, not technology - that's a con.

pros: The people. Most of the people here like their job and want to do it well. Sense of family at the lower levels, we look out for each other's well being.
cons:
We have to look out for each other because of the ways Honeywell is manipulating everything about working here. Furloughs coming after an extremely profitable year, hiring freezes, "unlimited" vacation (no vacation), travel restrictions, $1500 insurance charge for smoking tobacco (goes to Honeywell, btw), stock buybacks when the tax cuts happened instead of raises and bonuses, having to be re-vested EVERY YEAR to get your 401k so they can keep their cash as long as possible (or take it back if you leave).

Greed. Brace for more furloughs or RIF as the economy weakens.

pros: The workforce is young and a very fun group and the people still left from Intelligrated are knowledgable and friendly
cons: Management is actively making this a worse place to work by the day. Honeywell corporate ran off the sales folks so we have so few customers anymore. Salaries are stagnant, furloughs every year can be expected despite high earnings, no work/life balance, corporate makes unrealistic projections then cuts money from employees to look more profitable, reduction in overtime pay for the same amount of work. The list goes on, Honeywell does not care about employees, they are a slave to the shareholders and are happy to work their people ragged.

review_title: It's great for travel but perks are quickly diminishing
job_title: FOS Field Advisor in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Great way to see the world and you get a lot of experience quickly - making you very marketable. Most fellow FOS advisors are great people both technically and socially.  You make great bonds with people you are on assignment with.
cons: You work excessive hours without adequate compensation (could be 7 days a week 12 hour shifts for extensive periods of time).  Planned vacation is non-existant, often you are forced to take vacation in between assignments without any prep time.  Policy changes from Honeywell are slowly starting to trickle into FOS and perks are starting to disappear.   FOS management does not seem to care about retaining advisors or trying to make them happy - favortism seems to play a role in which people receive which assignments.

pros: Experience and knowledge are the only things which could be considered as pros.
cons: Recruitment is happ at a faster pace and quality is not being given the priority. Quantity is the first priority of the management, all the fresh faces are being added giving them good packages but really sorry for them, their future is bleak. No proper training, guess the vision 20 20 of the design house is gonna be closing of UOP in New Delhi. Sad that the top management is concentrating on production rather than R&D. Partiality, politics and power play a big role in this company. No space fo one's personal growth. Its better to consider UOP New Delhi as a stop and go facility. They have this 5 year bonds, which is really scary. Would love to leave once my term is done. Waiting for one more year then I am off.

pros: Retirement benefits are best-in-class and PTO is excellent after a few years of service.  (Note - health benefits are just average.)   Good, capable workforce.  Depending on the area you work in and the manager to whom you report, you may have flexibility to work a 4-day (10 hr days) workweek and/or telecommute.  This is not practiced company-wide but does exist in some areas.
cons: Too much focus on cost, at the expense of quality.  There are many managers in the organization but few true leaders in this environment as most are too concerned about protecting their own position rather than taking some risks in doing what's needed to inspire and lead a team of professionals.  Due to the intense focus on cost reduction, not much value or time is invested in growth of the domestic workforce. Too many reorgs and layoffs.

pros:
Aggression in Management,
Technology Focus,
Infrastructure, Lab facilities,
cons:
Lack of career growth especially for frontline people leaders,
Unprofessional managers in some business units,
Absolute Zero focus towards people, 
Unrealistic/Impractical commitments accepted by HTS management,
Default work planned is 150% of your time, at peak time it should be 200 to 250%
You are expected to work during weekends, use personal internet, mobile phone etc, and no cost reimbursement will be provided,
Totally biased management in some teams, unfortunately non-engineers are in   in senior leadership who does not understand what engineering is all about and make false commitments on behalf of teams.
Many more to list..my advice never join this company as  frontline people leader.

pros:
Flexible hours;
Romanian colleagues are supportive
