I see recent 4 and 5 star reviews and, well, they are made up. No one that actually works right now for Honeywell would or could give a good review.

review_title: Lots of Opportunity - for the right person
pros:
- At a critical inflection point as they attempt to transform to a software industrial, great opportunity for those with sought after skills.

- Solid benefits (but not great, and getting worse)

- New CEO is coming out strong with new corporate behaviors, vision and background to support it
cons:
- Rigid hiring strategy (almost all new NA positions only posted for Atlanta, GA or Morris Plains, NJ)

- Killed off any remote work, with the exception of field and sales positions.

- Financial targets and associated demand/expectations are causing burnout.

- Seems like a higher degree of attrition than I would expect.

job_title: Senior Engineering Project Manager in Kansas City, MO
pros: Lots of work, challenging projects. Some good people here
cons:
Extremely low pay. Engineers are leaving in droves and Senior management isn't doing anything about it. They've been saying "we're working on it" for over a year now. They have a ridiculous overtime policy, you have to work an extra 5 hours per week for FREE before you even start to earn overtime, then it's just straight pay. Annual raises don't keep up with inflation or medical increases. Even with a promotion you are still slowly loosing money by working here. Last year I only got 2.6 percent. Just got a promotion and it was only 2% increase, but I'm managing nearly 30 projects! 

We are all overworked too. Many good engineers are leaving and we have to keep taking on extra work loads. Meanwhile they can't get new people in because they wont offer enough to attract anyone good.

review_title: Toss up between horrible benefits and horrible management
pros:
Honeywell does pay well
My peers have a good team
Most people are good to work with
Location is convenient, but facilities are subpar
cons:
Management is clueless 
Too many internal meetings
Horrible benefits 
Corporate causes too much red tape
Nothing efficient 
Claim to want to watch expenses, no internal travel, yet Corporate constantly requiring travel there for meetings.
Furlough forced on people just so top management can hit inflated numbers for Wall Street  and get bonuses.
Too much shifting of jobs overseas
Salespeople forced to spend too much time creating PowerPoints for whatever whim management has instead of selling.
Too many acquisitions at once and not enough tech support to integrate systems makes things very difficult
Employees are NOT valued, most are used to cut to make numbers

review_title: Too many old timers.  Hard to implement changes.
pros: Company size, location, shifts, amenities, decent pay, and overtime.
cons: Honeywell has a lot of seniors (50, 60+).  I am not saying this is necessarily a bad thing.  However, when your coworkers and managers have been doing the same for decades and feel too comfortable in their positions it  is extremely hard to propose and implement changes without finding  resistance from them.  This is not a place for young people unless  you are willing to work with DOS, old computers, obsolete test stations, and grumpy coworkers who dislike innovating ideas.

pros: You get to work at your timings.
cons:
-No proper redressal of employee's work related challenges. 
-Managers are only focused at getting (read forcing) more work out of team with looking into pain points. This results in burn out of employees. The employees who don't over work and refuse to work after office hours are fired.
-No time is given for skill development in allied domains. It is not encouraged too.
-No work from home policy whatsoever.
-We were recruited from campus recruitment, the salary was reduced by 18%, from the salary at which we were interviewed and selected, immediately before joining.
-Food in canteen is not subsidized (Rs.90 for a N.V meal which includes rice and one curry) and coffee machines on floor work only for specified time (2 hours) rest of the time tea/coffee is available in canteen for Rs.25 per cup.
-The senior management works in silos often not aware of the ground reality.

pros:
- Competitive pay
- Great professional development opportunities
- Consistent activities and fun ways to get involved - game days, ping pong table, councils, raffles, yoga, masseuse on-site, etc.
- Ability to move up as well as laterally so you can learn different roles and figure out what you want; also, Honeywell is a global company so you could work anywhere in the world
- Recruiting process was simple, albeit intimidating (but maybe that's just me because I am a new graduate, new to interviews with large corporations)
cons:
- Large company so large problems that can seem daunting and metrics, unreachable
- A lot of people do not have the same sense of urgency so things can take a while to get resolved

review_title: Respectful and friendly company to work with
pros: Honeywell has been a great place to start out at right out of college.  The staff is very friendly and helpful with questions I have both logistically as well as engineering related.  I feel Honeywell takes care of its employees and has allowed me the time I have needed for my family responsibilities.  Working for Honeywell has also provided me many experiences to learn and grow in areas that interest me.
cons: A lot of the work we do is training on the job and there is not a lot of formal training for new assignments you are given.  As you get more experience, it becomes more natural, but when you first start out, it is a big learning curve to figure out how programs work and what your responsibilities entail.

review_title: Great for balance, absurd for everything else
job_title: Shipping/Receiving Clerk in Fort Mill, SC
pros: They are great about making sure that there is a balance between work and personal time.  They were constantly arranging bowling parties, movie nights, softball games, etc to boost employee morale.  The casual enviroment was wonderful to work in.
cons: The managers are not straightforward about communicating information down the line.  Something that our receivers needed to know would be communicated days after it was put in effect.  Also, management is bad about keeping employees that were harassing to fellow coworkers.  The benefits package is absurd and I don't know how many times I was given the run around with my paycheck or 401k.

pros: Has a good reputation in the industry. Has done some great things in the past, before Allied Signal took over. Been coasting downhill at an increasing rate ever since.
cons:
Management looks for the inputs that please them and lacks the courage to listen to the negatives. Employees who disagree have been told, "If you don't like it, there's the door". In many cases they have been shown the door.
Morale is rock bottom, with employees out actively searching for other jobs, to get out of teh toxic Honeywell environment. Tired fo 14 - 16 hour days with no recognition for the effort.
No pay increases for the past three years while the sharelholder dividends have been paid and the bosses have taken their bonuses.
Can't manage to get new product to market, so they are falling further and further behind every day.
They brag about the great new products, when in reality they have bought the companies that make those products.

review_title: this might just be the definition of insanity...
pros: Established great relationships with industry leaders in the multifamily direct industry.
cons: no chance for internal advancement, unrealistic managers who will take no feedback from the field reps if it is not what they want to hear.  Managers spend money on useless resources and then cut employees once they get a pay advance in order to manage the budget.   Lots of internal politics and unfair means of holding employees accountable.  Hire you as a contractor and tell you they will advance you if you perform but then never do.  Limit how many miles a contractor can drive but then tell you that you aren't working hard enough.

review_title: Engineer in Aerospace - stuck with a glass ceiling overhead
pros: It's a stable job with some interesting work.  Pay is okay, benefits okay.  Investors love the company.
cons:
Company is controlled by "bean counters".  Promotions have been stagnant for years and an aging workforce makes the company top heavy, so young or semi-young employees have little, to no room to move up.  This doesn't appear to be improving any time soon.  Senior management is bent on using low cost regions despite knowledge gaps and letting core knowledge errod.
The rules and processes are out of control.  A rule to hold the hand-rail when using the stairs is too far.

review_title: Big Company - Decent Opportunities - Fast Pace
pros:
Honeywell has deep pockets to weather economic downturns.
Many opportunities if you are willing to move.
Good paid holiday benefit.
Last of the big companies to have a pension (it's a pretty decent one, too)
Many opportunities within different business processes (Quality, Engineering, Supply Chain, Operations, Procurement, IT, etc.)
cons:
Health care benefits are not good - big changes in the past that is hurting all employees
The company does not promote a work life balance at all
It can take forever to get changes through the many systems that we have
No incentives for the common employee-operator through supervisor (no profit sharing, bonus scheme)
Improvement programs are being watered down - green belt program is not as robust and comprehensive as it used to be

pros: There is opportunity to move around the company but it is difficult to spend the time looking given it is an extremely busy environment.
cons: The company has reduced or deferred raises over the past several years, aggressively passed on health care cost to the employees, have lay-offs and furloughs and cut employee recognition expenses.  HR treats the employees like dirt and they work for the managers and not the people.  Losing much of the Aerospace business to Rockwell Collins, GE and Garmin. These actions to increase op margins a few tenths of a percent are paying a huge toll on the employee morale and productivity.

pros: 'unlimited' vacation for exempt level employees
cons: STAY AWAY!! Honeywell doesn't give a crap about its employees, its a grind and they know it and don't care.  Work life balance is a lie they perpetuate to get people in the door.  They have a huge HR organization so they know how to 'talk the talk' but dont believe it - the 'pro' mentioned above is simply their way of avoiding payout of vacation to terminated employee.  This company is so disorganized, disjointed, and dysfunctional that its a wonder they continue to survive.  Actually, the only reason they survive is through acquisition of companies that are more successful.  It's like the aliens in the move Independence Day - they swoop in, suck all the life out of the once successful, thriving organization, and then move on to their next victim.  Sad but very true.  Don't give them the time of day.  Trust me you don't want to work here.

pros: Pay grade was matched from previous, but similar line of work. Peers were excellent to work with and very knowledgeable; a great resource for help when needed. Perks included vehicle, laptop, phone, office space. Management not on site (in this case, it was a good thing... also bad).
cons: Immediate manager was out of touch with my job scope and my happenings in the field as he never spent time in the field (straight out of college, into engineering, and management). Other higher management seemed out of touch as well. Lack of customer service and support from management. Minimal mentoring. Benefits were not the greatest, but I have heard of worse.

review_title: Honeywell SPS is a heartless soul sucking company run by an incompetent man who just wants to be part of the boys club.
pros: I got a mediocre paycheck (when we weren’t on furlough) and, well, I can’t think of anything else.  They had a decent cafeteria but that was outsourced and run by another company.
cons: Management, Waldren specifically, have no interest in the employees. They outsource everything to the lowest bidder which ends up delivering bad products.  Little to no raises. Furloughs even though the company was making money.  Health benefits get cut back more and more every year.  It’s cost over everything. They don’t want American workers. The moral when I left was terrible with people leaving it wanting to leave.

review_title: Management considers job experience to be employee's greatest benefit
pros:
Challenging tasks, opportunity to drive results
Global exposure, colleagues across the globe
cons:
Too many ERP systems and slow reaction to the corporation to fix that. Focus on cost is hampering long term growth.

Considers employees as dispensable and no consideration for people's personal life or challenges. This is a company for singles, married couples with no children, or children who are now grown adults. The new brand campaign "Future-shaper" is just a mask to give an impression that people mean something. Internally, it's a further encouragement to people who can just live and die at work.

Too political environment - need to align with 5 people just to ensure something can even be presented to senior management

Too much focus on data and granularity - management can't take decision without data

review_title: If you desire stability, respect, and never forget the customer is always right, this is the company for you.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Like minded co-workers who understand and act according to the concept that helping the customer is number one.  Stable and fair company with a great benefit package...they still pay pensions.  In our particular department the people are all really close and enjoy coming to work despite the stressfull nature of the job.
cons: Since it is such a large company it takes awhile for decisions to be made and actions to be taken and sometimes the people making these decisions are too far removed from the people these decisions will be impacting most, i.e. the customer facing employee and the customer.

review_title: Get your money on the way in and don't grow roots
pros: Large company with opportunity. Room to move around but not mecessarily upward. Decent benefits but trimming away at them every year.
cons: They do not retain talent well. Management is getting caught up in making Honeywell comparative to other similar companies rather than exceeding them in employee benefits and compensation. 13 year employee with yearly raises no more than 2% average. Get your money coming into the company and dont make Honeywell your carrier. I have been making less net money every year for the past 5 years with pay freezes and increased cost in health benefits.

pros: If you are upper management, you are in like Flynn. Everything is about you.
cons: Horrible pay and horrendous benefits which shrink continuously. Micro-managing is the name of the game and they can't make things worse, they look somewhere else. For example, my department has a ten-fold increase in rework and scrap. Management hides these results in the numbers so they can give themselves a pat on the back. The waste management creates is a laughable fiasco. Lean, Just in time, HOS, are all systems to create the illusion that management uses to justify their own miserable worthless existence. Their gain is the employee's pain. I retired early to rid myself of the depressing selfish charlatans that run this corporation. This isn't Honeywell, this is Allied Signal. They bought Honeywell and took the name because it WAS a much better name. though not anymore. No amount of money is worth putting up with the torment of working and the management team lead by David (Kotex) Cote.

job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Torrance, CA
pros: It's a paycheck. But let the reader understand, it is a continuosly shrinking one.
cons: Constant threat of layoffs and unpaid furloughs, no cost of living increases nor raises for a couple years running, poor benefits and getting worse, reduced 401K match, expensive insurance ($8000.00 annual deductible for a small family), outsourcing engineering & tech roles to India, micro management, low morale, nearly zero advancement opportunities (the best jobs are being eliminated), and yes there is much more... If there were glory days, they are long gone (unless you're a top dog, then you are laughing all the way to the bank).

pros: Decent pay if you work in defense and relaxed on the defense side. They give you some leeway for showing up on time. There are refrigerators in the break room.
cons: Assume you will go to space where the engineers blame you for everything. They are to lazy to give you a process you can build too. Everyone is spying on each other and the management there takes he said she said literally. The entire company is laying off all the time that's why I am looking to jump careers.

pros: Lean processes and Honeywell Operating System creates a standard work environment where expectations are well know and communication freely flows from one area to another.
cons: Company is very concerned about the bottom line to the detriment of employees. Large variances in salaries for same jobs.  Reliance of contract hires with reluctance to hire or convert employees to permanent. Standardization creates machine-like workforce who no longer are able to think for themselves or solve problems quickly and efficiently.

pros: Good wages, clean environment
cons: Greedy Ceo and upper management. Although wages are not bad the company takes and takes from the middle class people who make the money for them. They want to keep them down instead of rewarding them for all their hard work. Young people / new hires don't get pensions, long term emploees get their pensions froze, while the CEO make over 50 million with the stock options and bonuses. It's wrong.

pros: Interesting products with diverse offerings
cons: Honeywell was a great company, but has decided that they do not need people.  Over the last few years they have continued to outsource all areas and have such a lean organization that there is no fail safe for critical processes.  If you are offered a job, make sure you get a very high starting salary-raises are few and far between.  Great place to gain some experience and move to better company.

review_title: How is credit analyst position reviewed by me
job_title: Credit Analyst in San Luis Potosí, San Luis Potosí
pros: It´s an interesing job that can help you develop a lot of  skills just as customer service and analysing risk situations like how to handle big amounts of money. You learn a lot about the internal handling of acompany, the importance of comunication between the departements involved such as customer service, sales and finance.
cons: There´s a lot of pressure in this work. A lot of time invested and sometimes it can be a little bit ciclical. You need to handle a lot of money and you can be a risk for the company if you don´t know how to do it.

job_title: Principal Security Architect in Atlanta, GA
pros: I just started here recently.  The building in Atlanta is top of the line. Everything you could imagine was provided upon starting. The relocation package was top notch. I felt like I was instantly part of a family. The benefits are insane from unlimited vacation to 8% 401k. Also, unlimited vacation time is pretty cool. They have free lunch and drinks every day.  I could go on and on here, but I have never been so happy to start working somewhere.
cons: So far and it is not really a con but I do not know how I feel yet about it. The ability to move desk everyday. I may or may not like it just not sure yet.

pros: Most of the working level people in Temp are amazing. I've learned a lot from working with these people both technically and professionally.
cons: Higher up leadership does not care about their employees. Promotions are hard, almost impossible to receive, even when your direct manager wants to promote you. 401k contributions do not become vested until after over 3 years of employment. Execs are always quick to take away merit raises, which are always low compared to peer organizations, and to enact furloughs. The company does not value training their employees for technical excellence, all time spent in training must be made up with work on chargeable programs. I would not, under any circumstances recommend anyone to work in this office. Though the people you work with are amazing, the moral at the building is very low. It is very obvious that employees are underappreciated and it effects the day to day work and conversations of the working employees.

pros: The Support Engineering Staff is extremely good and very professional.  Direct management was often very good.  Other support Staff and Admin Staff are also very qualified.   Good compensation and 401k.
cons: Poor moral.  Regular lay offs every 3-5 years, where often the most experienced and most qualified people are let go.  Direct management over the 15 years I was at Honeywell ranged from Very good, to Unprofessional.   Fortunately the bad Managers were identified over time.   From conversing with other Engineering professionals, the Cons are typical of many American Companies over the last decade.  Maybe slightly worse at Honeywell.

review_title: A pretty good place to work
job_title: Engineering Intern in Des Plaines, IL
pros: If you want to surround yourself with smart people and competent management while working for a company with good family values, you might be interested to apply here. The company is big enough that there are plenty of opportunities to move around to different technologies, though you may have to be your own driver. Technical people can grow well here, as there are opportunities for promotions strictly within the technical ladder. If you can do your job and you perform well, people will notice you here. Depending on your group, management can be flexible to very flexible with personal issues requiring telecommuting or going into work late.
cons: Average compensation, above average benefits

review_title: Great place to work, but ultimately depends on under whom you are working
pros:
Great place to work or start career.
Good place to come and settledown in senior management position.
Opportunities to change domain/projects are good
cons:
The process of promotions is entirely dependent on "CRITICALITY OF RESOURCE" in the project. If a particular resource is very critical for the project, they give everything. At the same time another resource who is equally competent, is ignored. Hence they loose good talented resources. Again it depends on the mangers capability to balance. 
The middle level management doesn't do any work, but pretend that they are working.
The top level management doesn't know whats happenning at the ground level.

review_title: Good stability, below par compensation, manageable work, incompetent middle management
pros: HPS has been stable enough throughout the economy  with minimal lay offs and high cost cuttings.
cons: HPS doesn't seem to compensate the employees at the market rates though the company did exceedingly well in sales and share market in the past year, the management is more interested in acquiring other companies. Junior Engineers have minimal guidance and appreciation from the immediate bosses and are forced with unrealistic goals. Individual growth is hardly ever important though it is projected as its of the highest priority. As this is a product based business, the philosophy of  depending on the strength and sale of the product rather than the Engineer who works on it is evident in compensation policies. Not recommended for junior/entry-level engineers

review_title: Don't expect to have a long career with Honeywell
pros: Decent pay, but you are exposed to some nasty things.
cons: Poor retirement, costly medical plan,lots of politics. Upper management out of touch with the hourly  and first line supervision.  Company will devour the best years of your life then toss you out like rubbish.  You will be hard pressed to find a happy Honeywell employee in Hopewell VA.  Don't take my word for it. Just ask someone who works or has worked there in the past 10 years.  I would not want anybody I cared about to get caught up in that rat race.  I had over 25 years there and witnessed it all.

review_title: Great Company with No Respect for Mid Level Managers
pros: Diversified company with good positions in great markets (as driven by CEO Dave Cote). Technology and Lean Tools are used everywhere. Getting traction in very exciting fields.
cons: Honeywell is doing great thanks to the hard work and leadership of thousands of underpaid and underestimated mid level managerial teams and very smart engineers that get no raises despite record profits YOY, while the senior leaders get huge rewards regardless.

job_title: Lead Systems Integration Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great place to work, you will gain a lot of knowledge and training. There is plenty room for advancement in one choices to move up. Also, Honeywell is recognize as as solid company, those who leave are generally looked append by other companies as a person who has potential
cons: Layoff are abundant. Honeywell, on the other hand does not refer to them as layoff, but rather reorgs. Meaning, they will restructure (reduce jobs), then have you apply for your own job. So you'll have say, 100 people applying for 50 jobs. Those who do not land a job, are let go.

pros:
1.Highly reputed brand all over the world.
2.Dave cote one of the best CEO's in world.
3.Job security. 
4.Good Projects.
cons:
1.Average or below average salary. 
2.No clear cut interview process.If your luck is good, you will get hired because of an incompetent employee.
3.Honeywell has now become a school due to it's stupid HOS(Honeywel Operating System)culture.
4.Whole company starts running at 9 am daily to attend their respective morning meetings. 
5.Project leads/managers will take attendance in meeting just like school and will  send you mail if you miss daily meetings often. 
6.Good relationship wifh manager will take you forward.Doesn't matter if you work or not.
7.Worst food in cafeteria.

review_title: HON AERO is in a death spiral
pros: Flexible work arrangements, but coupled with long hours in a frenetic environment. On-site gyms at many locations (not free).  Mostly a meritocracy - if you are good, you'll rise up the ranks.
cons: Terrible culture. I'd estimate 85% of the employees in AERO wish they worked somewhere else.  Zero investment in making it a fun, enjoyable place to work.  Office are very outdated - frozen in time from the early 80s. Very siloed teams.  Political, bureaucratic.  Terrible customer support; our customers HATE us. Regular furloughs, pay freezes, layoffs, outsourcing.

review_title: Not what it used to be
job_title: Customer Service in Golden Valley, MN
pros: There are some good people to work with. You get free soda or coffee as long as you bring your own cup. Recently started to have Customer Care Appreciation days, where they will pay for lunch for a whole week out the year.
cons: They are non flexible if going to school, you cannot advance within company without BA degree or know someone. Too many secrets and not enough communication.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Challenging, innovative, technical, many experts in the industry work(ed) or started their career here. There are many divisions that people can explore their career paths on.
cons: Ever since Honeywell bought the company, benefits had gone down hill. Corporate decisions on some, if not all, company policies make little to no sense. Banned remote work completely (it was one of the few perks left). Makes absolutely no sense to force employees to work at a local Honeywell site where they don't collaborate with any of them. Many employees do not feel appreciated, experience don't seem to be valued or as much as it should. Retention issue is growing though executives and HR still feel it's low and not concerning. Working environment is horrific, old building, problematic HVAC system. Slow progression.

pros: Career opportunities. A robust organization with specialists for every possible niche skill or area of knowledge. High-profile deals and famous customers. Some top notch technology, together with run-of-the-mill low-added-value-products.
cons: Red tape. Process-based organization, which can sometimes be a disadvantage. Different corporate initiatives, some not tied to actually doing business at all. Overly politically correct - prevents messages from getting across internally on a daily basis. American culture - you are supposed to be positive at all costs, saying things you do not mean just to avoid saying "no".

review_title: Great company to start a career
pros: You will be tackling difficult challenges in almost every software engineering problem, the company culture will motivate you to show initiative to overcome them. On a daily basis, there is potential to seek out new ideas to do things better. If you are a lucky, management, for the most part, will try to energize you to become better, be dependable to match your actions with your words and to focus on results and not activity which are the things you want if you want to become an achiever and not just a "doer". Most of the time you will work across diverse global teams to meet daily job duties.
cons: Sometimes management can be nitpicking everything and trying to micro-manage every aspect of the software engineering efforts.

review_title: It's an ok place to work but the culture is horrible.
pros: challenging work,  great place to get started in engineering career.  I was give a chance to really increase my knowlege and grow. The six sigma program is also a great career advancer that was provided for free. I have always gotten very positive reviews and managers have treated me fairly. My issues are more with the company at large than my specific group or manager.
cons: contant fear of layoffs due to outsourcing, people are very beaten down because of this. The workplace culture is very negative and it makes teamwork nearly impossible. Teambuilding is a joke and they treat employees like everyone is trying to steal from them.

pros: Benefits are good and aerospace engineering work can be interesting.  Still seen are as solid company, so employment there looks good on a resume.
cons: Honeywell's business strategy  is consistent in two areas: constantly outsourcing American jobs to anywhere where labor is cheap while laying off employees in the US -- then using the profits from this to buy other companies to cannibalize.  The dwindling experienced American staff are expected to clean up the substandard work that was outsourced while their salaries stagnate to generate more cash flow to buy other companies.   New engineering development is limited as management likes to milk its technology as long as possible and then sells off business units no longer able to sell their outdated products.

review_title: Still struggling five years after a re-org.
pros: Engineering Middle  management cares about people and is trying to get the job done.
cons: Reorganization into functional silos five years ago was disastrous and further injury was done by a somewhat late move into global markets.  Expertise in the US now tries to get work done by pulling the puppet strings of emerging market workforce.  Huge amount of bureaucracy created to try and "fix" / prevent project failures stemming from communication gaps between US and emerging markets.

review_title: Great place to learn from lots of smart people.
job_title: Design Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Business is booming, lots to do but not overwhelming.  
Lots of smart people to learn from.  
Ample opportunity to move around (if you desire).  
Great place to learn the refining petrochemical business...stay for your whole career if you'd like.
cons:
Work culture is stuck in the 90's, not appealing to millennials.  
No on site work out facility.
Getting crowded, many people doubled up in offices
Older buildings - nothing pretty to look at.
Vacation schedule is bad...2 weeks for the first 5 years is tough, takes long time to earn 3+ weeks.

review_title: running behind thoughtless processes,greatly missing the talent
pros: good company to work but not anymore because of mindless and pathetic project leads who misuses the talent greatly and obsolete ur skills like a mere dumb fellow..not a innovation company anymore
cons: you have to cope with a process called "HOS" which will be highly challenging to balance your personal life and improving ur competencies... really crushes you and bog down you with bossy culture..

review_title: Not a place to work; treats employees with disdain
pros: Good work life balance.  Good systems and process in place.
cons: no perks, health insurance cost rise every year, they dropped dental for next year. furloughs,merit freezes, and reduction in force despite company growth and gangbuster stock price. eliminated telecommuting.  its a company that squeezes ever bit of earnings on the backs of their employees.

review_title: UOP has gone downhill, but it's still a good place to work
job_title: Lead Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
- The people are knowledgeable and friendly, most older people are eager and willing to help.
- UOP management still cares about employees
- Great opportunities to learn
- There is a lot of focus on job training and getting new people up to speed
- Many opportunities to get involved (engineering, research, tech service, field service, etc)
- Great way to start a career
- Good 401(k) - 75% contribution to the first 8%, low cost options available
- Challenging work, but there is still a good work-life balance for most people
- Puts time and resources in developing tools to assist engineers (although the suspicion by most is that the engineers are training tools to do their jobs for them)
- Honeywell is intent on growing offices in developing regions and more or less letting American offices shrink via attrition (massive RIFs in US but added positions elsewhere)
- Unlimited vacation (also a negative, see below)
cons:
- Benefits used to be competitive but every year they keep taking things away.  Oil companies blow UOP out of the water in terms of benefits/pay.
- As of 2017 Honeywell no longer allows working from home, even if you live more than 2 hours away and the only site within those 2 hours is not even a PMT site.
- The pension is no longer available for new hires, and existing employees were capped at their 2014 salary
- Have to pay our own dental
- Furloughs, RIFs and cost cutting even when times were good for UOP - they are tied to Honeywell performance, so there's no incentive to perform
- Moral is extremely low at all levels, even management
- No longer allow business class travel, even for flights to Asia - but we still bill the customers a business class rate for travel allowance
- Sales is now driving the company and not the technology or innovation
- Honeywell wants to focus on systems and not engineers
- Vacation is no longer guaranteed and is completely subject to the whims of who you report to.

review_title: KPI Driven - You are just a number (and a letter)
pros:
Good Pay
Great colleagues
Interesting and challenging work
cons:
Obsession over KPIs
Customers can be quite abusive (not at the employee, rather they vent their frustration and anger about the company at you as you are the one talking to them!)
No focus whatsoever on the customer - I now work for a vendor reaping the rewards of this behavior.
Staff are just a number on a spreadsheet, virtually zero care for work/life balance - Will send you overseas or interstate for long periods without any consideration of your situation.
HR Rule the roost. Have way more power over staff than anywhere I've ever worked.
Massive cronyism in HBS and ACS.

review_title: A Good Company In Need Of A Benefits Overhaul
pros: As a long-term employee, I’m still proud to work at Honeywell and genuinely believe that we have some of the best people in the industry. The opportunities the company has afforded me have been vast and my career growth continues. The fast pace can be challenging but the skill development you get in return is great if you are someone who doesn’t mind change and can be flexible. The recent increase in paid maternity leave in the U.S. was excellent to see, I hope the company keeps up the good work in taking steps to make this a more women friendly work environment. Our track record in having women in senior positions is not stellar and our diversity at senior levels in general, not just gender related, needs more focus. The recent change is meaningful and deserves to be called out positively.
cons:
From middle management and up the demands are great, this can hugely impact work/life balance.
As such, the restrictive work from home policy that was introduced a year ago just isn’t realistic. This is a truly global company and we need to work at odd hours to effectively do our jobs. This means taking calls remotely, being available after hours etc. It’s  not appropriate to demand that employees must turn up at an office everyday while still expecting this kind of flexibility in return. The policy is also making it harder for those in management and leadership positions to recruit and retain talent.

pros: Salary is higher than most, but you are expected to pull the load of five people
cons:
You are treated like a number.  the way they save cost  is to Furlough staff.  They never ask for ideas to reduce cost or a furlough will happen.  They have furloughed employees five times in the last decade.
There is no CONTINUITY, eveyone is allowed to change jobs evry 18 months, to positions they have no education in or background in.  There are Seniro Directors in C&PS who hired in as a buyer and know NOTHING about cutomer service.  There are contracts Direcotrs that have never seen a law book before.  There are VP's in areas that they never worked in before much less can understnd the jobs being performed.

job_title: Field Technical Advisor in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Good smart people
Fantastic technology base
Leader in technical expertise
Knowlegde expansion is second to none
Best first job for a chemical engineer
Excellent work experience
World travel
cons:
Poor salaries, especially compared with contemporaries
Low morale
Poor communication
Poor leadership - constantly changing organization and management
lack of promotion within
Midsize company trying to act like a gian corporation
Hiring of too many contractors

review_title: Lot's of Opportunities. Some are Great, Some are true "Widow Makers."
job_title: Engineering Manager in South Bend, IN
pros: Lot's of highly qualified, intelligent co-workers.  Some of the best leaders I've ever worked for.  Great internal training opportunities allowing you to develop your skills.  Freedom to apply for new roles internal to the organization almost anywhere in the world.
cons: Large enough and beurocratic enough that some very poor managers can hide in the system if they play the politics correctly.  Individuals can be put in positions with no chance for success and then held accountable when the rest of the organization doesn't go along.

review_title: Not a bad place to work
job_title: Systems Engineer I in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Worked with some very intelligent and bright people. There are incentives to publish patents.
cons:
As with most large companies, politics and office drama were heavy there. 

Want design work as a new guy (ie 0 - 10 years) think again. Much of the design work is given to the senior engineers, who have been there for close to 30 years while the less experienced engineers are left with paperwork.

The career advancement path heavily pushed towards people management and not technical management. Was told on many year end reviews that pursuing a technical path was a waste of time.

Raises were based off high level company objectives that didn't always align with the current position.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Some flexibility in work hours.  But that depends on who you are.  I do like the people that I work with.  I would be very happy to work with any of them somewhere else.
cons:
The culture is very unproductive and very discouraging.  We are managed by people who have no connection to the product or to the customer, and that seems to be intentional.  Management is especially detached from the people who actually do the work.  Management listens only to themselves.
I have worked in other places where we took pride in the product and our customer's satisfaction.  This is not one of those places.

pros: The people you work with on a daily basis are great to be with.  Many front line workers and supervisors give 100% and pour their hearts into the job.
cons: In a 2-year period, several key positions left Honeywell-Norcross including the Site Leader, Safety Manager, HR Director, Quality Manager, HOS Leader, and Materials Manager.  So what's wrong?  Top Leadership at this location for one and everyone coming to visit having different opinions on the same subject (HOS).  Creates chaos and eliminates company loyalty.

pros: Completive pay in the technical fields.
cons:
1.  Every employee action they have taken in the last 15years is to the benefit of stockholders at the expense of the employees.
2.  They look to outsource every job they can with the exception of management.

review_title: HONEYWELL GLOBAL FINANCE CENTRE (HGFC), Bangalore controllership will bring an end to your career
pros:
Flexible working hours
Work life balance is too good here. Good for people who are 40+ and want to have easy salary
cons:
HGFC controllership is bad to work for
1) No learning
2) Same repeated stuff
3) No opportunities to do internal movement for controllership function unless you have required skills learnt in your previous company
4) All disinterested and de motivated employees
5) zero employee benefits
6) Unfair rewards and recognition
7) No parties ever in my entire 3+ years of career in Honeywell
8) Controllership leaders in India and in US are lazy and disinterested group of people

pros: The name of the company is widely recognized.  Having the company on your resume will help a lot while job searching.  There are dozens of branches within Honeywell that offers a variety different kinds of opportunities.  If you ever look for a job with Honeywell, I'd suggest the Aerospace division that constantly gets rewarded by the government with fat contracts.
cons: No advancement opportunity if you get stuck in the manufacturing department.  The work is very mundane and boring and gets very repetitive very quickly.  If you are an operator, this is the place to be.  A union shop with the operators readily taking advantage of their own bosses and trying to even mess things up whenever possible.

review_title: Honeywell - a technology driven global in need of some strategic introspection.
job_title: Principal Systems Engineer in Olathe, KS
pros: A highly ethical, well run company that provides comprehensive and market-driven employee compensation. Great depth and breadth of talent. A serious and significant commitment to applied technology development, and good communication with professional employees. Excellent attention to the business resulting in good financial performance.
cons: Strong commitment to globalization that sometimes operates at cross purposes to corporate success. Internal educational and training programs are provided, but they are more tailored to management than professional contributors. Occasional risk averseness that seems contrary to successful leveraging of longer horizon technology development opportunites.

review_title: Connect to a value stream, navigate the matrix manager
pros: Honeywell is diverse and is growing mostly through acquisitions.  Four large divisions Aerospace (Phoenix) ACS (Automation Control - Minnepolis, Phoenix) PM- Performance Materials, and TS -Transportation systems.  If you are savvy in M&A then begin your career in the ACS division - the largest and best acquisitions have come from this diverse conglomerate.  However if you have more of an operations background, each business is maturing the lean journey with HOS (Honeywell's operating system).  Over 25 standard specifications on lean management enterprise wide.  The key is to be close to value stream, where value add is managed on multiple metrics (sometimes conflicting metrics - like inventory and delivery) here you will have to navigate which matrixed manager has more authority.  As a PRO if you can align with a business case, deliver on commitments and be politically asute, you can advance.
cons: The matrixed management approach also has some downsides.  If projects are not aligned or there is quickly changing priorities you can find yourself underperforming on Honeywell's 9-block rating scale.  This is similar to GE's bottom ten percent will be fired design.  Add to this far too many levels beyond the value stream and those matrixed managers, director and VPs begin to have ambiguous titles and continued conflicting and siloed goals.  Next add a few narrsasistic eager new directors and you have the recipe for far too much politics and favoritism.  So if you can stick close to a value stream and improve it.  More power to you, but be weary of breaking into the management ranks unless you strive for that political maneuvering.

job_title: Software Engineer III in Oro Valley, AZ
pros: Challenging work and good people as an individuals.
cons: Oro Valley location lacks leadership / proactive management, declining corporate presence, and advancement is limited unless you are willing to pay out of your pocket to relocate to the greater Phoenix area etc.  Cultural is in print not practiced in reality / not healthy equating to employee's compromising their humanity either willfully &/or unconsciously, in part.

review_title: Good work culture and brand name (so far)
pros: Work culture is good in most departments outside of India. Brand name is still a benefit (not sure for how long it will be). Career development program with field services is good and gives unmatched experience.
cons:
Moving towards being a IT company. Doesnt value commitment and longer stays with company. Employees are not treated well (most of us). Disparity in pay and benefits is increasing day by day. 
Policies are not good employees and even for company in long term.

pros: Great supportive coworkers and excellent lower managers. One's career is taken seriously and there is enough room to move around different positions in the company, though training is handicapped by the restrictions from parent company Honeywell. Safety is highly stressed.
cons: Honeywell has cut all non-customer-billable spending including training and travel. Due the oil price downturn, there have been layoffs recently and minimal promotions. Honeywell upper management cares more about their shareholders than their employees, as with many large corporations. Only offer high deductible benefits packages.

job_title: Accounting Associate, Senior in Guaynabo, PR
pros: Honeywell is a global, 100 company.  You can find jobs in a variety of countries and businesses. It has annual pay increase. You can access a lot of trainings and tools, like Six sigma. You will have clear guidance on business expected behaviors and policies. Honeywell is completely invested in employees safety, security, health and well being, and provides all kinds of tools and services towards this goal.
cons: They use a lot of outsourcing. This gives you the feeling that your job is never secure.  Processes are always changing, sometimes just for the sake of change. The majority of the time there won't be a heads up on this changes. You have to be on your toes.

review_title: If you're American they don't want you to work there.
pros: 8% 401k matching after 5 or 6 years.
cons: Terrible Leadership and lack of respect for workers. They are intent on sending all jobs overseas though there seems to be little technical or financial reason for doing so. They layoff all of the workers and then wonder why they have so much trouble getting things done and why no one wants to work there. They no longer provide a "holiday dinner" at Xmas. The mis-manage programs and under-staff projects and then expect employees to bail them out with free overtime.

review_title: If you want career stability steer clear.
pros: The Aerospace Division in Albuquerque was doing all "cutting edge" technologies. The facility had excellent lab equipment and the job assignments offered as much challenge as you were willing to take on.
cons: Known for frequent "hire and layoff" cycles especially if your are low in tenure. I was promised limitless opportunities and was promptly laid off 1 day before my six month tenure. Oddly that was when my benefits were to start. I was actually made subsequent offers for other positions but refused them all. I absolutely do not trust this company and would recommend you steer clear if you're looking for long term employment.

job_title: Systems Engineer II in Phoenix, AZ
pros: They have been very good at allowing me to be flexible with my time.  Because of this, I can attend to personal matters when they come up.
cons: I was hired with the expectation of doing one type of work, and I am doing nothing remotely close to the work & direction that I would like to take in my career.  They cut off overtime, then cut pay 10%, they changed the rules on tuition reimbursement, and they are still hinting at lay-offs.  I'd prefer to keep my 10% and take my chances with lay-offs.  They are also yanking retirement medical coverage for people who chose the old system over the "one-time-cash-out" system they adopted in the late 90s.

review_title: Bad contract situation in a tough environment
pros: Relatively stable.  They seem to do a better job than most of keeping people even if their task ended.  However, they can only do this for so long.  At some point if they don't have billable work for you, you'll be laid off.
cons: Their contract situation wasn't good.  They don't have any sole source contracts with SPAWAR, and the SPAWAR MACs aren't being used yet.  This makes it very difficult for them to win new work, or even to keep existing work when it comes up for re-compete.

review_title: Good company to work for - as long as you "know the right people"
pros: Large company.  It's practically impossible to get fired from Honeywell (this can be good AND bad).
cons: If you know the right people, there is room for growth.  Layoffs have been happening more frequently.  There is a large amount of lack of accountability.

review_title: Decent company, but they keep turning the screws on their employees.
job_title: Production Supervisor in Deer Valley, AZ
pros: Decent pay and benefits. Recognized name. Large company that retains an ok image in the public eye.
cons:
Employee portion of Health care is rather pricey, especially for managers, as the more you earn, the more you need to pay. Perks have been cut back drastically over the past several years, and thousands of jobs continue to be outsourced annually, usually to low cost regions.
Raises have been very low the last several years for U.S. based employees.
If you have any degree of responsibility, expect long hours and forget about work/life balance.

review_title: A great company abundant with opportunities–many unrealized.
job_title: Production Worker in South Bend, IN
pros: Honeywell Aerospace is a fascinating place to work with elaborate systems to facilitate its' global position. Its' products are highly valued and brought to the marketplace with a keen understanding of the political and economic climates in which they operate. Their strategies for global growth seem well balanced between conservative application of capital and leading edge innovation.
cons: A highly compartmentalized culture which struggles to maintain the momentum and responsibilities necessary to achive the growth results expected from local sites (South Bend). Local sites are often starved of resources and capital as the profits are allocated to the global expansion of Honeywell International. Too much 'change for change's sake' without measureable results other than unrealized productivity and waste.

review_title: Unfair, corrupted management more than some governments!
job_title: Sales Account Manager in Mubārak al Kabīr
pros: very strong product portfolio that stands against a wide range of competitors, and product is reliable since long time... however; new updates are very poor with many problems
cons:
Management is promoting only people aligned with their politics not for being professional or performers... discrimination was clear against some nationalities! Equal opportunities!?? Don't ever believe it is their!

HR is mostly established to threaten people, turnover is huge! as people don't feel safe, only very few people feel safe and satisfied... based on their position and Manager...

when you can point few good managers! and it is extremely hard to find many of them!
very poor compensations and not fair... they don't pay end of service properly to most of the people, some already complained in court and they won against Honeywell, and yet they are doing the same with a lot of people!

review_title: UOP Gurgaon is ONLY good for south indians
pros: Good infrastructure, good brand name
cons: Top management, middle management, key technical positions, are all held by south indian employees. Management provides growth opportunities only to south indian employees. These employees work less, come late in Ofc and leave  early. Management do not make any backup for these employees (they are typically single point failures in their respective technology or skills area like prv), they get quick progressions and way higher salaries. On the other hand, non south indian employees get unfair treatment. They have to work hard, have poor work life balance, and are made to create their own backup. They do not get growth opportunities, and are unfairly evaluated. They typically get poor annual ratings and get much less salary.

review_title: Honeywell Aerospace - mind how you go!
pros:
Salaries can be attractive.   

Worked with some good knowledgeable  people.

Made me realize just how much I missed my former employer - so I went back.
cons:
Horrible corporate culture almost anti employee.  
Benefits poor.
Very political. 
Many older people hanging around to retire.
HR totally side with management - managers seem to be able to get away with unethical behavior. 
Outdated tools and processes. 
A culture of BS forced upon its smart employees with respect keeping up an image to wall street.
Company runs on quarterly basis to look good financially, which exacerbates  poor coordination between projects. 
Lack of innovation.
Is seen as a step  down in the industry - now I see why.

pros: Good co-workers, great pay. You have the opportunity to move up quickly based on how hard YOU work and learn the unit you’re in. It’s all up to you. The longer you take to put forth effort, the longer it takes for you to go anywhere. That’s what I really like about it, you are rewarded if you show commitment.
cons: No bonus. No more pension. Benefits are mediocre at best. Expensive deductible for health insurance. It’s a good thing the hourly Pay Rates and supervision salaries are great because if they weren’t, it would be tough to keep employees because of how bad the benefits are.

job_title: Senior Communications Specialist in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Honeywell is a fast-paced environment with a definite performance-driven culture, but if you're ready to work hard and change the future - this is a great place for you! Honeywell has supported me since day 1 and is constantly providing opportunities for growth in my career.  

We work hard, but the great people you will work with here make all the difference.  I highly recommend pursuing opportunities with Honeywell!
cons:
You own your own career at Honeywell - don't be afraid to speak up about new opportunities or stretch assignments  you want to take on. 

It can also be a little bit intimidating working in such a global environment at first, but Honeywell promotes a strong team environment that certainly helps make a large global company feel manageable.

review_title: Nice place to work for good benefits
pros: Great benefits and respect from supervisors makes the employment opportunity worthwhile.  On numerous projects I have worked on, the group setting has really contributed to the open and free exchange of ideas across talent and skill sets and has resulted in superior outcomes for both ourselves and the company.  The organization encourages team cooperation as well as personal accomplishment and should be commended for doing so.  However, they are also careful to measure the contributions of each individual and are open and thoughtful in terms of talent evaluation.
cons: Long hours and occasional snotty coworkers/disrespect from upper level management.  Assignments can be tedious at times.

pros: Honeywell has really good benefits, the company is doing good in these tough economic times.  Management is really considerate when it comes to requesting time off.  After a 90 day probation period you are allotted 40 hours of paid vacation time, 40 hours of sick time and 20 hours of personal time off.
cons: Some divisions are based on contracts, so as soon as contracts are terminated or end, there goes your job.  So there is no guaranteed long term relationship with the company

review_title: Honeywell is falling into a Well
pros: Brand name,reputation earned over the years as a top paymaster & technically challenging projects(till 2007-2008)
cons:
Post 2008, 
All benifits cancelled including food n snacks, 
no new project in AERO ..all they do is supply chain work..ie getting Quotes from vendors,do some googleing n stuff, 
lots of politics,
late night meetings with pheonix guys,no onsite, 
single digit hike,hike based on relationship with boss,
Guy who sits in front of me keeps doin real estate business during office hours ( like calling customers/going out of campus to show property)
No recreation,nothing apart from EXCEL SHEET n POWER POINT

review_title: Honeywell (HON) is a solid company to work for.
pros: Honeywell is a publilcly held company that is currently experiencing a rise in stock value.    Honeywell is an International powerhouse in several different industries.
cons:
Honeywell is a large company that is slow to change.
Honeywell offers below average compensation compared to similar roles in the public sector.   Honeywell's employee's benefit plan is more expensive to the employees than similar companies in the public sector.

review_title: Focus on unnecessary processes, such as mandatory Greenbelt, SAP, and HOS instead of having a business.
pros: Large corporation gave more stability.  Culture of safety was very reassuring.  Do provide (although sometimes only because its mandatory) on the job training for statistical analysis.
cons: Culture of the company lacks innovative and creative drive.  Heavy turn over of key lead people due to shuffling or exiting the company became distracting and unhelpful.

review_title: Good work-life balance, average salary, diminishing IT skills
pros: Very good work-life balance, most managers are employee friendly. There is always an opportunity to explore yourself into new technology areas. If you are working in the area of Honeywell's core business (control systems, aerospace etc, but not IT), pay will be higher. No variable component for non-executive lever
cons:
Diminishing IT skills directly causes poor quality of deliverables. Frequent resurfacing of software issues after a few months in production.

Mid level IT managers, although people friendly, lacks leadership skills or vision. 

Too many processes (borrowed from manufacturing industry and applied to IT service business). But, in most projects, a java developer can freely add a column into a table!

review_title: Barely more than the legal minimum for now
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Relaxed work environment, flexible hours as-needed, different schedules: Summer hours enabling 1/2 day Fridays, 9/80 where ever other Friday is off, or 100% remote work. Able to work a straight 40 hours. Decent return on 401(k)
cons: Catastrophic Health Insurance for barely less than you can purchase on your own. However, company claims it pays just as much as employee. HR department limits pay for internal promotions versus outside direct hires. Officially, only 30 minute, unpaid lunch breaks. 9-block ratings with little transparency. HR hides data about position pay ranges from employees. Honeywell rebrands industry terminology into internal lingo as if they created it themselves. Standards not communicated, and many one-offs allowed to operate. Continually cutting back on company match to 401(k)

review_title: Great Performing Company - High Stress level
pros: Solid stock growth, many hard working talented people in the company, good growth opportunities within the company
cons:
Company talks about fast and right and much of the focus is only on fast.
Sr Leaders cause a lot of churn in the organization with frequent demands on data and information.
Many lower and mid level managers don't believe they have the autonomy to manage and lead anymore - waiting to be directed what to do.  Level of daily detail that Sr Leaders are wanting to see in front line operations is driving high levels of stress in the organization.

job_title: Senior Engineer/Scientist in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Management has done their best during the downturn to position UOP at the top of the oil and gas industry. Even in the past month, things are really improving: promotions/progressions are occurring, we're seeing more movement with job postings, the conservative temporary pay cut was restored. Morale is improving. 2017 should be an even better year. With new technology development programs, the future should be very bright!
cons: Work life balance, but I know they're working on improvements in this area too. UOP offers the most unique package in the industry, for young chemical engineers to travel the world gaining incredible, quick, & robust experience, so this is where the lines between work and personal become blurred. For most engineers it's actually fun & the opportunity of a lifetime

pros:
Good working culture of dignity and respect
Good focus on safety and environment
Reasonable compensation
Good job stability and security.
Strategic long term vision and plan
Clear business objectives.
Flexibility at work like at times working from home due to some genuine reasons depending on rapport and understanding with  immediate managers.
Leading initiatives in technology and innovation and also in some breakthrough technologies like Big data and IOT.
Strong culture of innovation and improvement.
cons:
At times feels too much stressed with the need to keep ourselves upto with the innovation push. 
High innovation and productivity goals to meet in order for better ratings.
Getting internal career progressions and promotions very tough as there is a tough competition for that along with lot of screenings and interviews even for internal promotions.

review_title: Outdated in IT/Software. Join if you want to ruin your career in IT/Software
pros: Nothing that can be highlighted.
cons:
1) If you are in IT/Software please do not join this company. Executive's/Leaders comes from non IT background they don't understand how IT/Software's are built and importance of IT. Its a Excel spreadsheet organization. No SDLC project processes followed. Totally outdated.
2) Expensive health care premium.
3) No dedicated desks in Charlotte office. Its a rat race in the morning to acquire desk. No proper sitting arrangement. People speak loudly around desks, hallways, on the calls.
4) No professional environment. 
5) Corporate IT/Support desk have no sense of urgency.

job_title: Customer Service Specialist in Fort Mill, SC
pros: Opportunity for growth / moving around.  The name and experience you gain from working here will help springboard you to the next career.
cons: Company has a deep seeded meeting culture and tends to work on "fires" in the moment as opposed to progressive / forward thinking.  Learning from mistakes and improving the business culture is not a focus.

pros: Still looking for pros.. Not found.
cons:
First DO NOT believe fake reviews about HON. Consider only more voted HELPFUL comments. I hope Glassdoor will add "Sorting by HELPFUL" reviews options in the future.

Poor work-life balance (they ask you some reports even if you are on vacation), unrespectful managers, mobbing, retaliation, harassment, low salaries. The worst place to work. If you are sales person, they want you to fly but without wings. Insane sales targets. They never achieve the their quarter quota. They have no idea how to managing people. From top to bottom garbage managers. Lead times starting from 3 months even for commodity products. They don't care customer satisfaction. Managers are acting like a cowboys. Lots of people circulation (turnover). Every year one division asks unpaid volunteer vacation (furlough) from their employee. Stay away!

pros: Usual pros like on time salary, good insurance package, and so on.
cons: You cannot grow in this toxic environment. I cannot emphasize how bad this place is. If you're a Saudi, especially fresh graduates, don't start your career here. They only want you for the number and that's it. Work assignment and tasks are so meaningless, and you'll never develop a profession here. Important work is always outsourced to other Honeywell offices. HR is the worst function in this place, and will never support employees. There are no career paths for Saudis and no true training programs, the TecPro is the biggest joke ever! Some people are working here for 10 years without any promotions or leadership roles! They literally just want Saudis to satisfy government requirements. STAY AWAY!

review_title: Good company but you need to be mobile to grow within this HR organization.
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Morristown, NJ
pros: Within the HR function, Honeywell is a great brand and a company that you can be proud to work for. You are guaranteed to have smart colleagues around you within a stable company that is truly global.
cons: Advancement opportunities are not always given to the best qualified. Pathways program participants are given priority, even if they are underqualified or incapable. There is a fraternity of BYU grads within the HR leadership structure so if you want to become a senior leader, get a BYU degree first.

review_title: Learned alot, great people to work with
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in South Bend, IN
pros: Learned so much, opportunity to move around a little if you play your cards right, good pay and used to be good benenfits for the area but not sure that is the case now. diverse workforce
cons: overworked, stress, FAVORITISM, company cares only about profits and short term goals, line the CEO pockets, very COLD atmosphere as far as personal "stuff", declining benefits, short staffed

review_title: Good company for a stable, work-life balance job
pros:
Great engineering MNC company with a rich history and very good reputation.
Very good work-life balance. 
Good company to settle down
Ideally suited for Middle career and above professionals
Operates in various technology verticals, so you can get good exposure to some very good work.
Good onsite travel opportunities if you are into hard core technology
cons:
Too many managers and you sometimes feel that you are reporting the same thing to 4 different managers
Many employee friendly features are being gradually withdrawn, which is causing a little resentment in the employees

review_title: Too large with plenty or red tap
job_title: Software Engineer III in Ottawa, ON
pros:
- Structure and standardization and a lot of process if that is what you like
- Possibly a lot of opportunities to move around but you have to pay for your own relocation
- One can learn alot from six sigma
cons:
- Too much red tape.  Purchase orders take forever to process.  Replacement parts for PC or laptop also take forever.
- Relatively poor compensation package compared to others in the industry.
- Huge resource pool in India means they do not hire.  If they need help, the simply ship in some help from India temporarily which means, it is hard to get new blood in the company depending on the location.  I worked in Ottawa, ON, Canada.

pros: Sorry to say that I am not able to give any good reason for anyone to work at Honeywell.
cons: The shareholders & CEO do not seem to care about their employees at all. They have squeezed as much as they can out of their employees. Their benefits package is basically you paying ridicules prices major medical with a 6,000 deductible. They are constantly having layoffs and furloughs as well as many years with no cost of living / merit increase. All of this coming from a company who's net profits for 2015 was around 41, billion dollars. The CEO and shareholders still get millions in bonuses. This company could care less about their employees and they have become the Walmart of electronics with a check the box mentality. I would not advise anyone to go to work for Honeywell. That is coming from a 6 plus year employee.

job_title: Engineering Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The people who work there are really great.  Especially those on the floor.  They are passionate about their work and truly want to do great work when given the right resources.
cons:
- The leadership is only worried about two or three metrics that corporate has identified and will adjust everything to meet those metrics (this is not how to correctly run the business)
- Too worried about just getting deliveries out the door and not about putting out quality product.  Would rather ship something out knowing it will come back
- Too slow and have to jump through too many hoops to get something done
- Culture is adverse to change
- Too reactive and not strategic

review_title: Out of Sync with Canadian Market
pros: The work is challenging and management let you bring your ideas to the table.  There is not too much micromanaging.
cons:
- Benefits are designed for the US Economy and not Canadian
- There are potential of furloughs that is a very American thing - this has an ill effect on morale. 
- They work you to the bone because there is not enough staff
- There is a revolving door, which means that work takes twice to three times longer than most places

pros: Overall - Honeywell business is doing really well.  Huge investments happening in software and analytics to shift from an industrial company to a software focused one.
cons:
Two major issues.
First, the culture and approach is hugely dependent on what business you are in.  If you aren't in one of the businesses doing well, expect to suffer constant budget cuts and austerity until conditions improve.  It's easy to get trapped in a "your business isn't growing but you still need to hit your income goals, so cut every corner to hit the short term target".

Second, restructuring is constant.  The software center in Atlanta was just announced as a new center for the connected enterprise, but its not yet clear how their software leadership integrates into the businesses.

pros:
1) Honeywell is an established company in the market. Hence, the pressure is not too much.
2) Some teams have a good understanding. They help freshers learn a lot.
3) If you understand the product well, you can grow faster. I have seen people from non-technology backgrounds excel in software solutions purely because they know the product in and out.
cons:
1) Work-life balance gets affected as you go higher up the organisational hierarchy. I have seen people work all the hours except commute and sleep time.
2) As products are established, new development from the scratch is less and maintenance of these products is more.
3) A lot of time is wasted in planning. Planning is good but the plans keep changing constantly.

job_title: Integrated Supply Chain Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Honeywell always has many positions available within the company, in dozens of locations.  You can choose what you want to do and where you'd like to do it if you are motivated and willing to put in some time for improvement projects.
cons: Recognition, both verbal and monetary, increases greatly as you work up through the chain of command.  High level management receives lots of training and bonuses for directing a workforce that doesn't see the same recognition.

review_title: Experience will highly be influenced by management
pros: I worked as a contractor in Afghanistan, and I overall enjoyed the experience with this company, their pay was fair and you get a bonus after your 6 month and another at the end of your year. I was lucky to have a competent supervisor, who treated his section with respect, so coming to work every day was pleasant.
cons: I wished they would interview people before they got hired. There were a lot people hired on that did not meet the qualifications or were just too difficult to work with.

review_title: A very large company that has forgotten how to be nimble as many of it's smaller competitors.
job_title: Logistics Manager in Sterling Heights, MI
pros: Local managers know what they are doing and are very familiar and helpful with most situations that an employee will encounter.
cons: Upper level management has forgotten what made the smaller companies they have purchased successful enough to be acquired by Honeywell. Corporate leadership wants to force Honeywell culture onto people who were very successful before they were Honeywell employees. Also upper management micromanages local offices, slowing down or stopping any innovative thinking from those offices.

pros: Honeywell HPS has some great employees. The knowledge and experience that is available to you is top notch. Unfortunately most are due to retire soon.
cons:
Honeywell is horrible about trying to attract and keep top talent in the US. Many positions that can and should be filled with properly compensated, quality domestic engineering staff are filled with 2 or 3 marginal engineers from "low cost centers" with poor to non existent command of the language. 
With continual increases in cost to employees for "benefits" and a stagnant wage scale. Many of us are taking home much less that we were 5 years ago. But of course the management bonus structure is still intact.

pros: Generous holiday entitlement , Sick pay , share builder scheme , good company car choice if you are in the right pay band .
cons: There is no career progression as people in management tend to stay in their positions long term so it leaves very little opportunity for anybody bellow to climb the ladder.They don’t award annual pay increase in line with inflation, it is all performance based and even if you score well the increase is poor. Wages are bellow industry standard in some roles and the pay bands are capped so once you reach it your pay will freeze unless you can get promoted to the next pay band which is hard when there is no career progression.

review_title: Great Company on the Decline (Honeywell Aerospace)
pros: Excellent coworkers. I have rarely had as many smart, hardworking and productive individuals to work with. Some of the technical problems are tremendously interesting and challenging.  Nice automated cafeteria. Management accommodates a good work-family balance
cons:
No capital investment.
Micromanagement raised to absurd levels. 

Poor pay. Terrible benefits. Inept upper management.

The first things cut in "hard times" are employees. Next comes benefits. Management (which includes upper level engineers) bonuses cut 50%, 401k matching cut from full to 3/4. Health insurance cost rises 10-20% per year for lowest coverage of any major company. 1 week furloughs every quarter. No pay increase in 3 of the last 8 years. No mentoring of young engineers. Older, established engineers looking forward to being offered layoffs. No chance of advancement. 

The "Culture and Values" rating is due to exceptional employees, not anything put forth by upper management.

pros:
Some great people left - There have been so many changes recently - that many of the great people are leaving.  These great people are needed to run Aerospace - whic is complex - both from a manufacturing and governmental requirements.

Great products - We supply Commercial and Defense - products that make commercial products safer and defense products that make our troops safer around the world.
cons:
Benefits, Benefit, Benefits - the company used to have great benefits.  My family is now on my wife's benefits because the Honeywell benefits are too costly.  As an employee only I still pay over $6000 a year for employee only benefits.  I also have a $1500 deductible before my insurance even pays a thing.  Company is not paying for Dental this year :(

Work from Home is going away.  Yes we used to be a progressive company that trusted employees to get the job done - but now we are regressing back to the 1980's - where if they don't see you in a site - you must not be working.  In my role - I work with employees and contract workers around the world and sometimes people in the sites.  Where we work should not really not matter.  I have assembled great teams - where they worked never mattered to me - as long as they got the job done.

pros: I'm about 2 weeks into the job, but it feels professional without feeling stuffy.  Coworkers are very hospitable and helpful in my on-boarding which as so far consisted of online training and reading of documentation.
cons: One sort of dream for a software engineer is to be working on code on the first day, but here it's been 2 weeks without seeing any code.

review_title: The Reality of working at Honeywell
job_title: Principal Hardware Engineer in Lewes, England
pros: This global corporation generally has good people and most are committed to doing the best they can to support the individual parts of the business they work in.  There is a good culture of Health and Safety throughout and most work environments are clean and safe places to work.
cons:
The whole business is in a cycle of cost cutting at present (2018) which can lead to resentment among the employees.  This goes all the way down to monitoring usage of stationary!
Some of the decision made by senior management do not always seem to make sense.

review_title: Focus is only on Stock value, No Human Values
pros: You get a chance to work on the latest tool, technologies and processes; As a product company one may find it happy to see their items go out live and being used
cons: Human values are being lost, team spirit is not recognized. If you have generated income then your a star, if you have enabled income generation through secondary process then your a 0

job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Golden Valley, MN
pros: Great way to build a lot of experience in a short period of time
