pros: If you have more domain knowledge you will be respected. Work life balance, flexible hours. Prefer to join in a higher cadre
cons:
1. No onsites will be 5-10% in life unless you are very close to your manager
2. No recognization for work what you did. You have to market it to Managers.
3. Pay is not according to standards
4. Hikes n perks very low.
5. Year reviews some times will be very hectic. You can't digest those comments.

review_title: Incompetence among senior ranks due to "good old boy network"
pros: Loyal folks working in the company's lower levels, they take a lot of pride in their work
cons: With the latest re-organization so many layers have been created at the VP, Director level within the corporate organization it has turned into a white elephant. Difficult to get things done and due to the "good old boy network" a rash of incompetent players have added a new dimension of non-value add.

review_title: A series of highs and lows.
pros: Great benefits, okay wages, lots of great and very talented people (when they can keep them).  The Mississauga location has a huge full-service cafeteria, full gym, showers and even an on-site doctor & nurse. Flexible hours.
cons: Moral is low most of the time. Always a dark cloud of 'layoff possibilities' overhead. A lot of outsourcing to other countries brings down productivity. Not a lot of energy in the environment, it can bring you down.  Sometimes feel more like a number than a valued employee.  Lack of qualified leadership and too many organizational changes.

pros: It is a successful, growing and well respected company with a drive for continuous improvement, which involves all employees. Honeywell is developing and expanding product offerings to position itself growth in current and future markets. They are investing in correcting issues within the supply chain to improve performance to their customers.
cons: The demands on time for keeping abreast of the continual flow of information, both job related and organizational, growing scope of responsibilities and maintenance of database inputs. The survey requests are endless.

job_title: Process Engineer in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Large cooperation with an emphasis on training and access to many resources. Honeywell is a stable company.
cons:
Honeywell is a large cooperation but chemicals are not its core business. The decisions that are made from the cooperate level are not consistent with operating a chemical plant safely and efficiently. This leads to unsafe working conditions and repeat failures. 

Benefits are mediocre at best, low raises, and no bonuses make the job unrewarding financially. High turnover rate does not allow for any sustained progress.

review_title: Fast paced, lean culture, hard-working environment.
pros: Growth, change management focus, you will learn an amazing amount about 6 and lean sigma in a short amount of time.  Constantly striving to be better and driving results.
cons: Fast paced, almost breakneck speed, high expectations of all employees.  Just coming to work and doing a good job isn't enough - you have to shine and be a star performer to move up.  40 hour weeks don't exist - you will work evenings and weekends.

review_title: Good learning experience provided you "get" the right opportunities
pros:
- Good work life balance
- Job stability
- Good place to work for short term and see if you "land" up with right people who are open minded !
cons:
- Bureaucracy in different levels
- Mid-level management does not promote talent and is insecure

pros: Better company to start your career in and develop internally than being acquired
cons: Benefits are terrible; company will send jobs outside of US to low cost regions at every opportunity; people leave and do not get replaced - increase productivity internally and shift jobs to india or romania or mexico all to improve shareholder performance like most large US companies.  Destroyed our businesses positive culture and work enviroment - people leaving voluntarily that have been with org for years - of course they either do not get replaced or backfilled at snails pace.

pros: Wonderful people on team.  Demanding and fast paced environment.  Good place to work if you are young and right out of school.
cons: No room for promotion unles you are one of the chosen few.  Lousy merit increases. Always rumors of reductions in force.  Management in Aerospace are always crying slow performance yet attend expensive resorts for meetings, fly internationally when not required, and take pay cuts out on the workers exempting themselves.  Then they turn around to Wall Street and say that they beat their performance forecast.

pros: Great colleagues trying to work to the best of their ability regardless of the circumstances.  Due to the implementation of lean and 6Sigma throughout the company, Honeywell has been able to build a strong reputation for quality products.
cons: Several years of reorganizations, furloughs, layoffs, and managements refusal to fill key positions have negatively impacted the company's once strong culture.  Employees all over the U.S. have been forced to do more with less, have had multiple changes in leadership, and have watched their colleagues be RIF'd all around them.  The mission and vision is no longer clear.

review_title: Dont believe HR Shill reviews, There is nothing posativer at Honeywell.
pros: The only Pro I can think of is Allied Signal will soon completely destroy another company reputation, and need to acquire another new name.
cons: Cut headcount to unsustainable levels drive employees to continuously do more and more (now driving for 35% overtime)  negative culture and moral from top down.  Employees are viewed as disposable, Seasoned subject matter experts are leaving the company but instead of acknowledging this as regrettable turnover, it is shrugged off as oh well just hire someone younger for less money.  HR is staffed by by 20 & 30 year old inexperienced pawns.   That think posting positive reviews are fooling anyone.

review_title: Joining this company was the biggest mistake I have done in my life

There are many stupid projects in aerospace where they make us work on some tools and when we want to escape from this company nobody will accept us. My heartiest advice to freshers is that, management will tell that you are working on rocket science , but the truth is if you continue there, you can work only there. This is from my own experience. From past three years i am begging for jobs in other companies and nobody even respond.

review_title: Horrible Culture and Out of Touch Leadership
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Mill, SC
pros: Good pay, some great people
cons: Chaotic, lack of strategic direction from leadership, most people work in panic mode daily, lack of collaboration, global operation but corporate mandates you cannot work from home, except when it benefits them, working at a high level is fine but not when direction and priorities shift faster than other company I have worked for causing complete lack of productivity and momentum

pros:
1. Honeywell is a big platform that is worth paying for, where you will be exposed to a variety of technology masters, so as to make yourself grow rapidly.
Honeywell offers many opportunities to travel abroad, both in Europe and developed countries such as the United States.
3. On the whole, I'm very much in favor of working for honey.
cons:
1. If you're fit for business travel, this is perfect for you! Not only increase experience, but also enhance their ability. It is true that some places have a tough environment, but it is true that people can be trained and their efforts will be rewarded.
2. If it's not suitable for business travel, then you don't agree.

pros: Honeywell is a good company to help you grow and learn. It forces you out of your comfort zone. Also, the pay makes it worth it.
cons: There’s a lack of formal training and compassion from leadership. People struggle to fit in and find their place. There’s definitely a learning curve. It’s also an extremely aggressive and stressful work environment. Employees are expected to work at least some weekends without overtime. There’s been a decrease in paid holidays in some departments.

pros: Decent pay, good PTO/Vacation benefits, good company to work for, relatively clean and safe, if you're in you've probably knew someone or you're very lucky(in the location i've worked at anyway)
cons: Job security is questionable, one month we'll be told we are strong for the next 5 years to come business is good; to now recent lay off not even 2 years later..

review_title: World class organization. Frequent leadership structure upheaval.
job_title: Senior Technical Project Manager in Richmond, RI
pros: Able to utilize existing world class new product introduction methodologies and tool sets. Honeywell velocity product introduction builds in additional rigor with the ultimate goal of being faster, better, stronger, organized and metric centric.
cons:
Leadership team and structure transitions every 1-2 years. New initiatives which require culture change are continually being rolled out. The constant upheavals are exhausting. Difficult to deploy great tools like VPD when the structure and leaders are constantly changing. 

Benefit cost increases outpace salary increases.

pros: There are some very smart people working within the ranks of Honeywell, from entry level up to the C suite.  The breadth of products is enormous and opportunities are everywhere.
cons: The leadership team does not support the employees.  Many in the rank and file at Honeywell consider the leadership team's  order of precedence to be (starting with most important): self,  shareholders, customers.

review_title: Worked for 7 years. Ok types company
pros: Good work, job security, experienced ppl, solid process orientation.
cons: No work from home, very less growth chances , manager are trained to stop your career development n just give sugar coate words, cribbing around the count in India office and crying to give benefits to employee, cost cutting in every penny, old employee don't share knowledge so new employee has to suffer by self learning, below ok work life balance.

pros: A lot of very smart people.
cons: Back stabbing, dishonest people who are cut throat.  They work in silo's and care nothing about their people, it's all a facade.  HR is horrible and upper management is demanding to the point that you have no quality of life and the pay is below scale.

pros: Stable big company, lots of talented people to meet and work with.
cons: Managers are not able to react to the market changes quickly enough. Honeywell had grown to dinosaur size.

review_title: Too focused on profit at employees expense.
pros: Work life balance. Flex schedule.
cons: Declining benefits year over year, EVERY year. No 401K match per pay period, now annual lump sum in January, if and if you are employed on Dec 15th. So RIF's will now be commonplace the beginning of December & no benefit of compounding gains throughout the year. Pay is low versus peers for technicians. Engineers are compensated fairly with lots of promotion opportunities. They typically get promoted several times in the first few years of employment and are paid very well. Technicians have no path to move up and only 2 promotion possibilities throughout career.

pros: If you are friends with the supervisors they will lie for you and cover up your mistakes.
cons:
Poor quality no one cares of quality.
Documents are forged a numbers are just made up on a daily basis.
Hard work is penalized quality work is also penalized and you are retaliated on by The Slackers for making them look bad. Bottom line is it doesn't really matter how good or bad you are at your job just be friends with your supervisor no matter how much you hate them and they will make you look good.
Can not take any issues to the HR department nothing will ever be done and they will just gossip to the shop about whatever you tell them.

review_title: Great company to work, great opportunity to learn and improve on career path.

cons: My role involved a lot of travel and acclimatizing to different time zones and weather sometimes but this is part of the job, so you have to brace up for the challenges and excel at the end.

job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Salary slightly higher than market average
Some unique and innovative projects
cons:
Chaos, Chaos, CHAOS - unrealistic project deadlines forcing 12+ days nights and weekends.  need to work a variety of hours because of the different team time zones
Pompous and arrogant leadership that borders on incompetence - leadership has no experience with software development process and it shows.
Honeywell's employee model is to ask more and more of employees and when they burn out just replace them. HR's favorite phrases for the high turnover is something like: "Some people moved on to better opportunities" or "Those people were difficult to manage and it's unregrettable that they left" 
Management does not accept responsibility for high employee turnover

review_title: Large diverse company, huge variations in culture.
job_title: Senior IT Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Large global company.  Potential for global opportunities.   There are a lot of good, skilled people.  Written policies are good.
cons: Age descrimination.  Culture tends to be up and out.   Metrics focus on department performance, not overall value chain.  Short-term focus.   Most out-sourcing efforts have been overall negative to the company.  Too much yo-yo hiring.

pros: Tuition reimbursement, pension, 8% matching, nice people to work with, Bravo award
cons: outsourcing, salary increase on promotion is minimum, no profit sharing, no bonus. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

pros: Very professional and fair. Good benefits package. Many resources available for R&D work including software, patent searching, literature searching. Many networking opportunities within the company, including international.
cons: This corporation is very large. As a result, the reasons behind decisions made at the corporate level can be very hard to understand at the local level. Agility and general ability to respond quickly to changing market conditions can be slow.

pros: The products, technology, and heritage of Honeywell make it a Mecca for engineers interested in aerospace and flight safety. Overall, there are good, smart people working on challenging problems on engineering and business issues.
cons: The industry downturn has limited the company's investment commitment compared to that of its industry peers. As a result, resources are severely constrained and friction has created poor morale amongst the survivors.

job_title: Customer & Product Support  Sr. Technical Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits, Dedicated hard working employees.
cons:
Massive lack of valuing the “workforce”. We have lost the focus of making this a family away from your family. We spend more time with our co-workers than our actual families. (Especially now that people are expected to work 50/60yhrs a week, while being compensated for 40). 10 years ago (Prior to GE’s interests and Allied Signal’s purchase) We were a family oriented business that people looked forward to serving 30-40 years and retiring from. Now we are a company that people can’t wait to find something better. It is made clear (By Sr. Leadership) that if you want to be compensated fairly, you will need to leave. We fail to invest in our people on the hopes that they will serve us loyally for their entire career. Failing to understand that hiring new employees to replace the high talent that leave for greener pastures costs a great deal of money, time, and greatly affects our ability to serve our customers (negatively)

HR is there to protect Honeywell, not the people.

Outsourcing, and reductions in force;  I am not talking about India and China here, there is a need to have diversity and coverage globally. However, years ago Honeywell manufactured the best Avionics in the industry and had an outstanding global support force. Now we are more interested in saving $10 a card or box that we can have some other business or country manufacture for us. Problem here is that we lose quality control of that product and it ends up costing us millions when they fail to perform at what we have guaranteed our customers they will.  Our world class global support has been cut to the bone forcing Avionics and Mechanical FSE’s to perform as “nose to tail” FSE’s..  Customers are not impressed. We are told to tell customers this is in an effort to be “Best in Class” (BIC) a term that most customers will tell you we “WERE” BIC prior to our re-org..

Leadership and its decisions are focused on two things and two things only; Stock performance, and Shareholder satisfaction. Customer and Employee satisfaction are distant after thoughts,.. In that order. Decissions and investments are focused on the short term vision,.. what will effect Stock performance and Shareholder satisfaction TODAY.. Until we realize that Stock performance and Shareholder satisfaction are byproducts of Customer and Employee satisfaction we will continue to be mediocre at best. 

Most of the workforce is grossly under paid, some in excess of $25,000 below the lower range of recommended salary ranges and what competitors are paying

And finally, our performance management process is broken badly. We are forced to differentiate our employees by a “numerical distribution” HR, Legal and Sr. Leadership will tell you that this is not the case. I am here to tell you it most definitely is.. We are forced in many cases to rate some of our high performers as mediocre, and even worse our “Steady Eddies” as low performers.. In order to hit our pre determined “numerical distribution” So much so that managers are being told that you will not differentiate your employees,  you will be “differentiated”

Until our executives understand that bonuses of up to 500 times the average salaries of their engineering force (Who by the way do not get ANY bonus) we will never be "Best in Class".

review_title: Place where you will learn alot but have slow advancement

cons: They do not put the resources into the sites for career advancement - only career skills opportunity. They outsource lots of career positions. Because of the diversity some of the less 'culture' individuals may say or do things that are 'rare'

pros: Plenty of opportunity if you bust your a$$. Dedicated hard working employees, Sr Leadership and middle management seem to care for their people (Not representative of Executive Leadership..) “

(Especially now that people are expected to work 50/60yhrs a week, while being compensated for 40). 10 years ago (Prior to GE’s interests and Allied Signal’s purchase) We were a family oriented business that people looked forward to serving 30-40 years and retiring from. Now we are a company that people can’t wait to find something better. It is made clear (By Sr. Leadership) that if you want to be compensated fairly, you will need to leave. We fail to invest in our people on the hopes that they will serve us loyally for their entire career. Failing to understand that hiring new employees to replace the high talent that leave for greener pastures costs a great deal of money, time, and greatly affects our ability to serve our customers (negatively)

HR is there to protect Honeywell, not the people.

Outsourcing, and reductions in force; I am not talking about India and China here, there is a need to have diversity and coverage globally. However, years ago Honeywell manufactured the best Avionics in the industry and had an outstanding global support force. Now we are more interested in saving $10 a card or box that we can have some other business or country manufacture for us. Problem here is that we lose quality control of that product and it ends up costing us millions when they fail to perform at what we have guaranteed our customers they will. Our world class global support has been cut to the bone forcing Avionics and Mechanical FSE’s to perform as “nose to tail” FSE’s.. Customers are not impressed. We are told to tell customers this is in an effort to be “Best in Class” (BIC) a term that most customers will tell you we “WERE” BIC prior to our re-org..

Leadership and its decisions are focused on two things and two things only; Stock performance, and Shareholder satisfaction. Customer and Employee satisfaction are distant after thoughts,.. In that order. Decisions and investments are focused on the short term vision,.. what will effect Stock performance and Shareholder satisfaction TODAY.. Until we realize that Stock performance and Shareholder satisfaction are byproducts of Customer and Employee satisfaction we will continue to be mediocre at best.

Most of the workforce is grossly under paid, some in excess of $25,000 below the lower range of recommended salary ranges and what competitors are paying

And finally (And most importantly!!), our performance management process is broken badly. We are forced to differentiate our employees by a “FORCED numerical distribution” HR, Legal and Sr. Leadership will tell you that this is not the case. I am here to tell you it most definitely is.. We are forced in many cases to rate some of our high performers as mediocre, and even worse our “Steady Eddies” as low performers.. In order to hit our pre determined “numerical distribution” So much so that managers are being told that you will not differentiate your employees, you will be “differentiated”

Until our executives understand that bonuses of up to 500 times the average salaries of their engineering force (Who by the way do not get ANY bonus) we will never be "Best in Class"
Our engineers are our golden egg laying goose..  NOT Executive Leadership,.. TAKE CARE OF THEM!!!

review_title: Great start but not for the long haul.
job_title: Field Installation Specialist in Cranston, RI
pros: Great product to work with. With the right management team behind you day to day tasks are easy. Fly away training to gain skill sets were good to get you up to speed on hardware and software.
cons: Merit raises are routinely cancelled due to economic conditions or partial furloughs implemented. Benefits have been reducing year over year to cut business costs but not beneficial to employees.

pros: Work was challenging and learned lots as a first engineering job out of University. Mississauga Ontario site was nice and people were friendly.
cons: Company only care about the stockholders and don't give a damn about the actual employees that do the work.  Pay is not competitive with other aerospace companies and definitely lower than other industries for engineers in Ontario. Raises and promotions are also slow and hard to come by.  Company will hold you at as low a pay as they can until you threaten to leave.  Health insurance benefit is crap, compared to other companies in Ontario.  Car parking lacked security and thefts do occur in broad daylight.

review_title: Great Place to Work, But Share the Wealth Mr. Cote
pros:
Great Place to Work.
- Interesting work
- Always improving
- Great Confidence the company will be making money for a long time.
- Very diverse work force with almost no prejudices among workers.
- Love be able to work with fellow employees in Malaysia one day, Phoenix the next and the Czech Republic the next.
- Fantastic bosses going up at least 3 levels.
- Honeywell Operating System and other core business process are well thought out and make the whole company more effective.
cons:
- NO Raises in 2013.
- Average Raises less than 3% in 2014
- CEO and top execs got HUGE Bonuses, Stock Options, Long Term Growth payouts in 2013 and even bigger increases in 2014.
- Stock value was up around 40% in 2013.
- Please share the wealth, it is not FAIR.
- If you could not give us a raise in 2013, how about an extra $1000 in our HSA or 401k plans.  
- How about a $500 holiday bonus

- Merit Pay increase nine block system is a joke!  What a waste of my manager's and my time.  The whole system is insulting.  
- Please read what Walter Deming says about these employee evaluation systems.
- A 1 is great, 2 is really good, but a 3 is bad and a four is really good and 5 is average.  Who came up with this?  And I hear NO ONE can be ranked a 1, but managers are forced to have people ranked below 5 by HR.

- HR is non-existence.  Never have I heard from them.  Any question you have is a vaguely answered by Hewitt, not a Honeywell employee.

job_title: Supply Chain & Operations Leader in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Honeywell is a great company work for. It truly cares about its employees with the integration its Honeywell Operating System(HOS), where it not only focusing on driving results but also developing its people and culture with the OD group. If you don't believe it just take a look at its stock price vs. its competitors.
cons: Some times it could be frustrating based on Annual goals set without the infrastructure of supporting them. Challenging goals are great as it enables sites & functions to come together and work with each other, but it also hurts they end of working against each other.

pros: Large corporate business, across all globe, with good brands and with opportunities for career progression. Good salaries for Bucharest, Romania. Through hard work and long hours at the office, you can develop your abilities.
cons: A lot of resources for data extraction, with no data management. Little use of Business Intelligence tools, so the data crunching takes a lot of time, remaining less time for the analyses. This also affects the traceability and the possibility of using the data for other business purposes.

pros: They have a roof to keep the rain off of you.
cons: When it comes to penny ante bs this company takes the cake.  You can't just come in and do your job, they pick at the stupidest things.    Wearing the proper straps isn't even enough, you have to wear it in a certain way even if works another way.  I've always wore my strap on the ankle, now they are saying I might trip over it.  I'M SITTING DOWN WHEN MY STRAP IS ON!!!  I refuse to wear it on my wrist because the cord caught a board once and got knocked on the floor.  They keep hiring temps, but we are slow.  I'm so bored of coming in with very little to do.  Why don't they give work to the people already here?

review_title: Company leaning towards Manager driven company
job_title: Worked As Senior Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
Good exposure on Aerospace Domain. Some of the people are really cool to work with.
Good company for Freshers to learn product/Domain.
cons:
Lots of politics after HOS it's leaning towards manager driven. HR's are dummy and higher managers not much care about employees concerns and if you want good promotion or hike you should say yes boss always.
More process than actual work, very less scope to learn or work for new technologies.
No work life balance always virtual pressure on mind. I heard employees met accidents after enforcement of TAM ( to attend office exactly 9 am)

review_title: Overworked in certain areas, underworked and overpaid in others
pros: Average medical insurance coverage at a high premium (this usually qualifies to be a bad thing) the brand name and occasional smart and dedicated coworkers
cons: it's too big and inefficient. there are useless corporate mandates that do not fit the need or reality of each site that need to be complied regardless. long tenure corporate bureaucrats take pride in being stuck with the same company for 40 years and not seen anything else outside of honeywell. to make it worse, they prey on employees that do not fit their stereotype and improve process/procedure not know to honeywell

job_title: Process Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Skilled and knowledgeable Fellows, interesting work, lots of travel, many technologies to engage in
cons: Policy changes are negatively impacting the employees, lack of compensation for hours worked, non-responsive management, trickle-down Honeywell policies that do not work in this industry are being force-implemented, no reward for hard work well done, non ethical monetary practices

review_title: High political company driven by personal management interest
pros: I don't have any pros. Actually yes, it opened my mind and I know for what type f company I don't want to work.
cons: Lack of trust among employees and very poor management. Leadership is a title but no substance. You have to kneel in front of management and do all they say even if it makes absolutely no sense and you need to restart over because the proposal was completely wrong. Yes men culture, management is untouchable even if they are psychopats. I learnt the meaning of CYA in this company.

pros: Honeywell gives you flexibility with respect to work-life balance, surprisingly managers (or my former manager in particular) are not the stereotypical managers to work with and certainly the brand name Honeywell counts.
cons: There has been a major setback in work over the past few years and Honeywell has been slow in adapting itself to the recent trends relying on legacy alone. Salaries for employees who are recruited laterally are so much lesser than college recruits, exceptions do exist. You will receive atleast one email each week about the organization restructuring which is hell confusing.

job_title: Chemical Process Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: UOP is a world class petroleum refining technology company providing an opportunity to work with the latest technology and collaborate with exceptionally strong engineers and researchers.  Legacy manager are strong and develop staff from when UOP was a "graduation to retirement" company.  The employees organize themselves into social groups (bowling, golfing, tennis, etc.) independently.
cons:
Petroleum is a cyclical business dependent on stability or steadily rising price of oil.  During the troughs in the business cycle, UOP focuses on cutting costs (headcount, expenses) instead of infrastructure to prepare for the next turn around.  Since becoming fully owned by Honeywell, many key decisions are made in the context of a business subsidiary instead of a stand alone business.  Money is re-invested in the company in a way to reduce labor costs through either automation or delegating work to low cost offices overseas.  Compensation is average to low with "merit" raises below inflation unless accompanied with a promotion.  The company mitigates risk by standardized work procedures and processes so extensively that 9 - 18 months is required to familiarize oneself before becoming productive.  Because promotions and sub inflation pay increases are normal, morale suffers.  In addition, several items which the company previously provided (subsidized dental, subsidized medical for spouse and family, furlough instead of layoffs, business class travel) are no longer available, morale suffers.  In addition, UOP, once viewed as the world class petroleum technology leader has been valued as a sales path for other Honeywell products and less for its own technology.
Since becoming part of Honeywell, most support services (HR, accounting, IT, etc) are remotely located and unfamiliar with UOP business.
Facilties have not kept up:  walking track half removed to make room for flood water retention, basketball court in parking lot eliminated, building is vintage 1950s-60s and is updated only with networking and computerized workstations.

review_title: Was once a Great Company and department (PPC) to work for
job_title: Program Planning and Control Analyst in Clearwater, FL
pros:
-Lots of training and industry experience to be gained. 
-Pay decent for industry standard
-Unlimited Vacation at level 3 and higher (if manager approves)
-Paid OT for Level 1 and 2
-Standard processes
-Experienced gained can be easily applied anywhere
-Work life balance is good but it depends on who your manager is
cons:
-There is no clarity among managers as to how to apply vacation.  Unlimited should be unlimited not up for discretion if all of your work duties are met

-REMOTE work is highly frowned upon (discouraged) and highly audited.. If you have to work remote for a day you have to get manager and HR approval and you can expect your time card to be audited on a weekly/monthly basis to see if you are in the building for the amount of hours you charged so you have to make your comments clear (the company has zero trust in employees

-less gray areas on what PP&C is responsible for; seems like everything falls on PP&C when it's not clear who the task should go to.  This increases to already massive work load as while there are many standard processes they are all managed by the analyst who also has full Cost and Schedule requirements (unlike most DOD companies one analyst is usually responsible for cost and schedule on multiple large projects).

-Streamlining of data to various upper management functions. Seems like each director/sr. manager is looking at different numbers.  PPC should push back on the multiple request from multiple departments which results in an extreme amount of duplicated work.

-Many non value added tasks as mentioned above.  Many tasks performed by PPC are only important to PPC Management while engineering does not use or need.  Honeywell is the standard for Earned Value Management but EVM at the minute level is not necessary on all projects.  FFP and projects under a certain value that do not have a customer requirement are not necessary to have EVM yet all projects are required to perform EV my PPC management to keep up company metrics.

-Too Many Metrics.  PPC is expected to manage all metrics and keep accuracy for areas that PPC has no control over (head count, manpower, engineering and production hours etc) essentially doing the CAM jobs for them.

Morale is very low in the department and the company as a whole, they reduced company match and you have to work until December to get it., 5 block used for performance appraisal... very hard to get outside of the median (unless you kiss enough butt in the right places).  Once you reach the SR level there is no upward mobility for most.

Benefits are EXTREMELY  expensive and they do not cover anything until you hit your deductible usually 3k for family.  Expect to get LARGE bills whenever you have to do anything medical except for your normal checkups.

review_title: Honeywell was a good company, but now it's not
pros: Honeywell was a very good company till  2014.
cons:
I worked around 8 years in this company. I resigned last year.
 There is no job security in Honeywell now. The mangers are trying their level best to keep their job safe.they are very busy in this worst politics dramas, but they have no time to take care of the project/engineers.most of the eligible engineers left the company.

review_title: First views on working as a manager at Honeywell
job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Bracknell, England
pros: Very thorough induction programme.  Complete support package of people, software, systems and established processes to help you get up and running straight away.  These are clearly well established practises as individuals take ownership for making sure that your first 90 days runs to plan.
cons: Hit with a very large amount of learning material outside of job role in a short space of time.  Most IT/Web portals are 'teach yourself' which is not always appropriate.

pros:
-Honeywell has a long, innovative history which is super interesting and employees should feel very proud to be a part of it -- I know I certainly do.

-The stability and growth opportunities of such a well established, Fortune 100 company is valuable. 

-The company is fast-paced, global, and employs some of the most intelligent people from around the world, which keeps things interesting and keeps me learning from the best of the best every day.
cons: -As expected of a Fortune 100 company,  there is always a lot going on at once and workload can be significant. One must be a talented multi-tasker to keep up and be able to balance competing priorities with agility to thrive.

review_title: Company passionate about making an impact and leaving a legacy
pros: Your mission will truly impact the future. The work you do here, will in no way leave you wondering if it is worth it. If you want to be a part of something bigger than yourself, look here.  The people are great and offices are nice and in the heart of Atlanta with easy access to interstate and PeachPass and Marta line. Opportunity to grow and stretch what you thought you could do and create your own path.
