Very fast learning, good knowledge transfer about the technology. the experience can not be compared with any other leaning specially for the beginners. Lot of options are available to change the profile once the change is asked by engineer. People are very open to share their experience of various technologies.
cons: Changes are Slow, changes in technology are not used. The work becomes boring once you stay at same profile for a long time. change is required.

review_title: Lots of big company opportunity, but with some frustrating drawbacks
pros: Exposure to what makes a big company work (big thinking, slow moving, careful, metrics, politics, etc); great brand on the resume; diverse company with exposure to lots of market/mfg areas;
cons: big company environment is full of politics and can be too slow/careful at times - definitely not for everyone;  way too metrics driven and often the wrong metrics;  management needs to allow more control from lower levels

job_title: Manager, Business Process Architect in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Talented people, strong executive leadership, financially stable, well positioned products and services, key global supplier to commercial and military
Outplacement service (Right Management) does a good job supporting post severance needs.
cons:
Don't expect to retire from Honeywell.  
If you are in a "terminal" location like I was the downsizing is pretty relentless.  If you are in a growth location there is plenty of opportunity.
Exit process is cold and isolating.

pros: Access to capital is often easy when justified.  There is a lot of cross division transfers.  Work/life balance is good and they are flexible.
cons:
Perpetual highering freeze limits growth.  We know we need to improve in certain aspects of our business and can justify the hire economically but are still allowed to hire due to conservative management.  Everything is very slow to happen, everything.

Benefits are not competitive at all.  Expensive insurance, high deductible.  No discount stock purchase plans (that would be nice since we have performed great).

review_title: Challenging and wide array of opportunities to work on.
pros:
Good support for development infrastructure - hardware equipment, labs, legal teams for IP support, multiple consulting teams for specialised product development support. Global development centres allows one to learn by working in different markets. Opportunities to work across a diverse set of technologies from thermostats, to avionics systems to application development.
If you take initiatives, then you are given more responsibilities - share the success and the failures.
Can learn from global experts with niche skills
cons: Senior technical roles involve coordinating between multiple teams - hardware, mechanical, marketing, manufacturing, certification, etc. and can push the work life balance. Can become stressful.

job_title: Project Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Well established processes and procedures
Updated hardware
cons: Frugal in spending, heavy work load, inconsistent messages from upper level management, poor benefit offerings

review_title: Rapidly becoming a thankless place to work
pros: Working with state of the art aerospace technology. The work is very challenging and is a great springboard for new engineers who want to gain knowledge for moving to different companies that respect employees experiences
cons: Management demands more productivity with less resources, funding, and schedule. 60 hour weeks are the norm and expected. Product quality is poor and requirements appear to be optional for mission critical systems.

pros: For the most part very good sales team
cons: Disconnect from Senior leadership.  Massive micromanagement.  Constantly told what to sell and how to sell rather than let you sell what your customers want.  Too much day to day unnecessary meaningless tasks that are unproductive.  Terrible commission pay cycle.  Poor data to track sales.  Major lack of confidence that you are getting paid for what you have sold.

review_title: Honeywell - Hiring, Growing, Leading, & Shaping the Future
job_title: Procurement Specialist in South Bend, IN
pros: Honeywell is a great company with a solid reputation and passion for their people.  They are customer focused and growing as a result of their awesome products and cutting edge technologies.  If you want a rewarding career with an amazing company Honeywell is the place for you.
cons: Due to the rapid growth and promoting within new team members may join frequently which repeats the learning curve, but this is inevitable in a growing organization.

review_title: Great Place with lots to grow and learn
job_title: Marketing Director in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: Teams are highly motivated, get the support they need, with independence and a thought process for business reviews, and others.
cons: Very demanding environment,  lack of support or data to drive business discussions, too much bureaucracy in some processes, and no Home office with strict no discussion about it.

review_title: Thought this gig was forever... Ecstatic my eyes were open
job_title: Systems Engineer in Deer Valley, AZ
pros: Was trying to push it to the end, i started when they were offering a pension.  This was a big reason i did not want to leave.
cons: I really don't have enough time to explain everything, from management, fellow employees, down to the cafeteria.  Management creates an environment where employees become cutthroat to one another.  Many individuals are being under paid by really high margins.  There was nothing satisfying, rewarding, or challenging in this company.  Get your experience and get the flock out!

job_title: Project Manager in San Luis Potosí, San Luis Potosí
pros: Office location in San Luis Potosi
cons: They treat you like labor. Not allowed to question management decisions no matter how stupid. No opportunities to grow. They assess your behaviors and not only your results. It is a sect. Stressful environment. Only americans get promoted. So many changes in management it is hard to get recognized for past achievements. They skip you over for promotions. Ungrateful company. Drop of a hat and you are history. Salaries below market value. Not a single raise in 8 years. Their offices smell like real bad. Very few bathrooms for so many people. Constant shortage of running water. Management usually knows less than you do.

review_title: Solid company with some room for organizational improvement
pros: Great products in a growing industry.  It is a relatively large organization with siginificant opportunities to join new groups and some cross-functional experience.  The benefits are a bit average but better than other similar companies.
cons: Given its large size, you may at times feel like you are just a number.  In addition, with their recent organizational structure, there are not as many opportunities to grow into a Leadership position as there was when the company had 10 different business units with their own profit and loss.

review_title: Its been fun working at Honeywell, realised apart from technical skills having strong communication skills are must.
pros: Honeywell has adopted Six Sigma and other quality initiatives becoz of which we see a well structured policies and standards across the orgnization.
cons: Due its very nature of business and constant M&A activities Honeywell has multiple folks performing similar jobs in IT, which is a hindrance to form consensus and thus leads to slow down project / change execution.

review_title: Great engineering teams that excels in product development
pros: Excellence in engineering core competency makes it a pleasure to work along side such great engineers each day.  Technology and products are very complex, challenging even the best each day.
cons: Honeywell needs to end the Performance Improvement Plan nine block assessment, unless it is really justified.  Too many great engineers are rated in ouside L that is unwarrented.  The GE model of 10 percent in bottom L just does not fit this organization.

pros: Great front line managers. Good work/family balance.
cons: Too many bureaucratic "initiatives" which don't add value and detract from productivity, running way too lean on resources, high stress level, massive global outsourcing adds huge inefficiencies which saves the corporation money but ends up losing customers and extracting capital and knowledge base from the US. Revolving door upper management who are only driven by their 8 quarters of bonuses before they move on.

review_title: Cheap cheap cheap and CEO hates it's employees while being over paid
pros: I have a job and really good co-workers. Finally have a manager that knows what she is doing.
cons:
The company is still digging out of almost loosing it's AS9001 certification. Many many many documents need fixing. Honeywell loves to shoot it' s self in the foot. It worries more about cody's H.O.S. then making a quality product. 
You might as well self insured when you buy it's health insuracne, employees pick up 90% of the cost. The only thing they do to help is give you back $1.500-1.000 towards your bills, after that your pretty much on your own.
It made over $9 billion last quarter alone, but could not give it's employees a raise this year.
It's CEO is gready.

review_title: Fast paced environment for those who love constant change
pros: Not a slow old school company with lots of layers of management, Honeywell is a progressive company that is constantly changing to drive improvements, growth and the bottom line.  There are no shortage for opportunities to get involved in some cutting edge initiatives.
cons: Can be overly cost conscious which sometimes drives the wrong decisions for the long run, years of no external hiring has created an aging workforce with a lack of outside thinking, ideas and innovation.

review_title: Used to be a good place now we are worried daily for our jobs
pros:
Great people and great products and amazing place to learn;
Great team working environments
Relaxed work place
Flexible boss
Good pension 
Good 401k
Diverse people
cons:
No job security , non merit increase 
Benefits in decline, no future, no direction from top managements 
No over time for the extra hours
Hard to meet dealines

job_title: Chemical Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Excellent resources and exposure. Likely never to get bored. One of a kind company where you can exposure to multiple refining technologies in different parts of the world.
cons: Compensation wise not at standard with competitors. You can have a long career in this company as long as primary motive for you is technical excellence and exposure to multiple technologies

review_title: Won’t recommend it anymore went from a 5 star 3 years ago to a 1 star company
pros: Flexible, good atmosphere, nice co workers
cons: Hardly but mostly no salary increases after working 3 years in company, lots of cost cutting going on and lots of people unhappy, leaving or looking to leave. Having different versions to different people why no salary increase so, in other words just lies as to why. Management doesn’t care about it, just another big stakeholder company where employees are just replaceable objects. And even low paid countries as Romania turns to become to expensive for upper management just waiting for them to say we stop and move to vietnam or India where it’s cheaper.

pros: Provides to opportunity to think out of box and come up with new ideas. Encourages patent filing and implementation of the idea based on feasibility.
cons: Since Honeywell is product based company and more into giving reliable solution to existing customers, there is very less chances of changing the platforms of existing projects . This will for the employee to work on the same technology for longtime where the technology is growing at light speed in the current situation. I understand changing the stable code by moving to latest technology is a big risk for company. They need to plan for employee growth.

review_title: New Joiner on a great journey!
pros: Well structured On-boarding process; close relationships with the colleagues who are very friendly and extremely helpful; the organization for my 1st day was top! During my 1st week, I got the chance to visit another site of the company for a training and I met in person a lot of international colleagues with whom I will be interacting on a daily basis. Great opportunity!
cons: Like in all huge corporations, you need to get yourself acquainted with loads of information, policies and procedures but this is how it works - once you know how the "machine" is working, it only helps you to connect the dots and become efficient on your role.

review_title: Great company! Really serious about 6sigma lean.
pros: Quality first. Really understand the tier escalation process...
cons: To much promotion from within has cause management to suffer! Certainly you want to encourage upward mobility but that needs to be tempered with new talent who can bring in benchmarking and best practice from other companies.

review_title: Site needs to be looked at by Corporate
pros:
Great 401k match benefits 
Competitive Salary
cons:
Salaried work experience:
Poor work life balance.
Leads by fear. 
Taking computer home every evening and weekends is required.
Unpaid weekend shifts are required. 
Lack of respect from upper management.
Micro-management from the highest levels of site leadership. 
Old ineffective software - no integrated software systems

review_title: Honeywell provides a safe/relaxed work environment and  helpful resources to train, educate and empower employees.
pros: Great place to receive training. 401K and pension benefits are industry standard and above average.
cons: Healthcare packages are too expensive and restrictive opting for high premiums as well as high deductibles.  Dental and vision coverages by comparison more affordable and above par.

pros: Stable company. Competitive salaries. Above average 401k company match. Pricey but comprehensive health plan. HQs campus is a nice environment.
cons: There is no career path for growth for administrative personnel. In recent years, salary increases have either been frozen or kept low at this level but there is above average compensation increases for higher level employees. Bonus were eliminated at this level as well. This company no longer invests in its administrative staff through training and professional growth opportunities as it did years ago. This has been a very disappointing and de-motivating change in leadership culture for administrators.

pros: Honeywell pays good for my section which is PMT. The wages are competitive for this market. The size of the company allows for movement if you are salary or company hire. Other divisions of the company are innovative.
cons: The company is so large that some divisions are left in the 1950's. Not a lot of empowerment or change for employees. The company has an aging workforce with very old school beliefs. The average worker on the hourly level has a GED or High School diploma.

pros: Great products and great coworkers, for the most part.
cons: Compensation is low. Because HR is in an entirely different state, any promotions or employment status changes are long drawn out battles through the mail, often resulting in nothing. Benefits are laughable. High out of pocket costs. "Voluntary" health screening tests - you are given the choice to either volunteer to take invasive blood tests OR volunteer to pay up to $4000. So if you opt not to pay the fines, you take the blood tests. If those blood tests show you do not have perfect health, you need to correct whatever is wrong or be penalized.

pros: Freedom to express new ideas and also get funding for implementing these innovative ideas. Work life balance is good and one gets to learn the details of multiple industries. Company also helps its employees to pursue higher education, drive organizational initiatives and all these help to get noticed by leadership.
cons: The work is so core that sometimes employees find it exhaustive. Also the work sometimes becomes routine and its important for employees to start engaging themselves in as many initiatives as possible to have fresh perspectives

job_title: Design Engineer II in Chicago, IL
pros: You really work with some extremely smart people at a company which practically invented the industry.
cons: Very outdated facilities, corporate culture, and management.  Lots of middle management which is unnecessary and working there kind of feels like its the 90s.  Many departments are full of dead end careers.  Management pays absolutely no attention to the needs of their employees.  In certain departments employee satisfaction with management is extremely low however nothing will ever change.

review_title: Regret to join the company.  Sweat shop with no appreciation.
job_title: Senior Director, Product Marketing in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Nothing is good with this company. I did not believe when my uncle told me Honeywell treat their people badly.  Now I do.
cons:
Benefit cut every year.  Vision and dental insurance not subsidized.  Medical benefit is high deductible to the nth degree.  Honeywell is a self insured company = benefit as a profit center for the company.

Work from home policy is gone.  Yet people are asked to attend mtgs before and after normal hours.  No work life balance at all.

Switch to unlimited vacation plan.  You only have 7 days of sick leave now.  

Management only cares about making numbers to meet wall street target.  No one cares about the employee.  Many good people left .

pros:
Diversified portfolio
Clear vision moving towards software
Aggressive top leadership
Decent pay
cons:
Poor work-life balance; no work from home but expects employees to work from home beyond office hours
Inept, arrogant middle level management trying to keep their posts in the transformation
No benefits for employees except for salary in India. Time to be a shareholder than an employee
Process heavy, even have process for how to think (innovation) and more conflicting process as it is a amalgamation of numerous small companies

review_title: Stay away, worst company I have ever worked for.
job_title: ISC Supervisor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Flex time, 9/80 work schedule, Vision and Dental plans, some of the best people i have ever met work at the Kansas City Plant.
cons:
Senior management has no clue what is going on down on the factory floor.  Discrimination in a common occurrence in this company.  There is a transgendered employee in the plant that gets targeted on a daily basis.  If you are not a white man, then you are treated like you don’t know anything.  The bad thing is that HR doesn’t even care.  
The union protects poor performing employees, even employees that break the law.

pros: The work is very interesting and low level management is very supportive of their teams.  Egos are often left at the door and people really work as a team than just for themselves.
cons: Mandatory 48 hour overtime is “required” for all salaried employees.  Individual employee performance targets are built for failure to limit compensation and career growth.  Customers and venders are mistreated based on my experience.  There is no honest initiatives to foster internal technology growth.

review_title: Was good up to the last two years.  Poorly managed business, employees are last.
pros: Had some great experiences and working relationships.  Was a great family-oriented company once upon a time.  Great former managers cared about teams.  SPS, HBT,  Aero are different divisions, so not all may be same.
cons: Employees are no longer important.   Benefits cut, long hours, no reward or acknowledgement.  No mentoring from senior staff. No knowledge management. Revolving HR means no long-term people development.  Reduction of long-term employees with much knowledge and value, only to reduce costs.

review_title: Not For Everyone - Can Be A Good Experience
job_title: Field Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
UOP is not for everyone.  They made that clear when they hired me.  They asked me multiple times throughout the hiring process if I was aware that I was hiring for a full time travel position as if I had somehow forgotten.  I worked as a field engineer for a few years as one of their new university hires.  If you think that you would enjoy traveling the world and not having a home, I would recommend it, but do think carefully about it - I had studied abroad and traveled some before this, but it's not something to take lightly.  It can get quite lonely, and it also gets tiresome having so many trans-continental flights after awhile, but for the first year or two, it was quite a bit of fun.  I was fortunate to be able to travel with my wife after I got married, which was a nice benefit.

I enjoyed being able to work with experts in different parts of the oil and gas sector at a very young age in my career, and though the learning curve is quite steep, it is manageable.  Just keep all your resources in hand, be willing to talk to your fellow field engineers and office staff, and you'll be all right.  As a young engineer, you'll be exposed to different ways of thinking, from the refiners that you work with to other areas of the oil and gas sector that you may be introduced to as well as within UOP.  It was a great introduction to being an engineer.  I was also pleased that I was able to work in many different parts of the oil and gas sector, from upstream to downstream, despite UOP having a reputation of predominantly being only a refining company.  I actually thoroughly enjoyed working in the upstream sector, which has a very different feel from refining.

Once you start traveling, the pay is quite good.  Prior to that, the salary is somewhat competitive, but nothing compared to say an entry engineer at a supermajor.  If you start working overseas, additional foreign bonus is applied on top of your salary, and if you are leading UOP's work overseas as a chief engineer, you also receive an additional bonus for that, as well as per diem.  Lump all this together and UOP's total compensation package is competitive with supermajor engineers.

Both a positive and negative was that I was able to see about a dozen countries on UOP's dime, which was a great experience, but it eventually became overwhelming having to take so many flights so frequently.  My last year, my longest job was only three weeks.  I really wanted to immerse myself in the local culture and learn the local languages, but it's hard to do that when you're only in a country for a few weeks.

One final point is that most of the old time engineers are very knowledgeable and personable, as well as a lot of the local engineers at the regional offices.  Everyone is very friendly and willing to help.  I really appreciated this, particularly while being so early in my career.   Every overseas office I went to was extremely friendly and tried to make me feel comfortable and well prepared for whatever job I came to do, which was great.
cons:
Honeywell continues to clamp down on every aspect of the business, trying to suck UOP dry.  Cost cutting measures keep being aggressively put in place to limit spending with little regard for how this affects the quality of life of the field engineers.  Penny pinching over a few dollars a night spent at an extra hotel.  I was relatively fortunate with regards to this, but I know many who were not.

UOP lies to its customers and bills them for business class travel and then gets only economy class travel.  I was only able to upgrade my travel to economy plus, and even then, only on long haul, 8+ hour flights, and not to continental Europe.  Doing these long haul flights two or three times a month like I was doing is not healthy or sustainable and was a serious factor in me leaving the company.  Business class would have made this much easier to deal with.  Beyond that, UOP makes you choose amongst the cheapest economy class flights, so frequently you are left with sub-optimal flight plans with nonsensical, excessive layovers and total flight time.

Per diem is pitifully, hysterically low in the US at $35 per day.  This is completely absurd and should be updated to a reasonable amount.  The only way I was able to stay below per diem while working in the US was to stay at hotels where my wife and I could cook.

Some engineers had the opposite problem that I did - they would wind up stuck in Southeast Asia for 14 months straight, while I was traveling from one site to another every two weeks.  Both are difficult and are possibilities that are outside of your control as a young field engineer.

A lot of the engineers in the above situation also had issues getting time off.  I was fortunate with regards to this and never had much of an issue getting time off.  UOP and Honeywell have "unlimited vacation" policies, which were all right for me - I probably averaged about four or five weeks off each year after they implemented the policy.  Some of the more experienced engineers were less fortunate and would only get one or two.  It's really a roll of the dice, but by removing a specific number, it can really hurt you.

I was also in a two year training program before traveling where the pay was reduced.  Some of the rotations were not valuable and the training that was given was not extremely helpful at the time.  This program should be shortened - it already was reduced from two years to a year and a half, but I would recommend shortening it even more - beyond the fact that obtaining a six month lease is a logistical nightmare that.  A year for cultural indoctrination and training should be more than adequate.  The pay while in training is relatively low compared to what you could be makin elsewhere, but the workload is also quite low, so it's all fair.

review_title: Honeywell - Strong at the top and bottom, but weak in the middle
pros: 100% employee match up to 8% of salary after one year of service for the 401.  Generous benifit package.  Excellent products.
cons: Promotions tend to be on the "good ole boy" buddy system.  Medical Insurance Premiums are astronomical.  Too much time is wasted on the flavor of the month program such as 6 sigma, just in time inventory, greenbelt training, group meetings and writing our own performance reviews instead of doing our actual job and innovating.

pros: Corporate culture is friendly, depending on who works within your group.  Benefits are pretty good, but getting worse rapidly.  If you chase new internal certifications and external credentials (degrees from universities) you will be promoted to new work.  When the economy is good, extra overtime can sometimes be rewarded.  Work obligations seem based on what you get done, so if you work expediently/efficiently, you are making more money for less work.  The dress code is relaxed if you work for the right people and aren't afraid to test the waters.  Working from home is possible with years of time under the same boss, or with certain jobs.
cons: Overtime is mandatory for many employees at many locations.  If you make X dollars for 40 hours a week and they make you work 60 hours a week, you are really only making x(2/3)+x(14/40) which means you make less than they would lead you to believe.  Politics can be brutal in some groups.  Some groups are friendly, but the majority of them have a backstabbing factor, where you have to be very careful what you say in front of people.

review_title: Would not recommend anyone take a job at Honeywell in Kansas City
pros: The work life balance is pretty good compared to many large companies.  No one is working 60 hour weeks.
cons: Poor teamwork.  Lack of trust.  Company will not admit that they force approximately 10% of the workforce into "the elbow"  The elbow means that you go on a Performance Improvement Plan with the goal that many will either quit or be fired.  This is taking a toll on morale throughout the business.

review_title: better than most, a few caveats.
job_title: Project Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: If you ever wanted to work in the oil industry, especially in the refining world, UOP should be your number one objective. Start here and all the doors will open to you. If you're experienced and plan on joining, then it's another story. You will find more opportunities and money in the EPC world (Bechtel, KBR etc..) or in the producers world (BP, Shell, ..)
cons: Salaries are lower by 20 to 30% compared to Houston area or big oil companies. UOP still relies on their name to attract people, and they don't care about the high turn over they get, specially among young engineers, since there's constant re-supply. What they believe in is that when these guys go and work for a refiner, they'll bring them new business since they'll know UOP. Since the purchase by Honeywell, compensations, benefits, etc.. collapsed even further. Moreover, Honeywell  wants to apply thermostat-manufacturing by the thousands-type of mentality, to a customised EPC industry. It just doesn't make sense. From the inside, everything that was said in this site is quite spot on. The most disturbing would be to be dominated by the "I've been here for 40 years so I know everything and everything I say is right compared to the stupid ideas you must have since you've been here for the past 10 years only". This goes along with the erosion from the young generation. what used to be the commitment of a generation or a family (many relatives work here), has disappeared. People leave as soon as they get their "uop stamp", leaving a big gap between the graduates and the soon to retire. To complete the picture, a lot of the design is now done in India or Korea or China, just like fabrication, and it's obviously encouraged by management. Not nice.

pros: Money is OK but benefits slowly being removed. Looks good on CV and the industry is somewhat stable, although highly supported thru Government (military) contracts.
cons:
1) Remote leadership makes the calls and therefore is out of touch with local requirements (resources/ equipment/etc).

2) Local leadership merely puppets and jump when US talks.

3) HOS operating system not geared for low volume/high end unit production, hence waste is created in the massive administration required to upkeep graphs, charts and various sub-programs (kaizens/RPS/5S) which do nothing more than appease the remote leaders during the dog and pony shows during their visits.

4) Too many management layers which has created "silos" in the organization. Cross departmental help is nearly non existent as charge numbers are required for everything. Managers too concerned on containing costs for their empires and create more barriers than they remove.

5) Internal promotions non-existent as local management prefers to hire "fresh" minds (i.e. no experience to challenge them). 

6) Local  finger pointing (from leadership) now a common culture since their power/control is very limited and any criticism of remote leadership decisions  would be a career ending move. The result becomes a very toxic atmosphere where front line workers are under a microscope at all times. Tier meetings (at all levels) fail  to address main barriers and become nothing more that nit picking sessions resulting in a public flogging. Very demoralizing start to the day.

pros:
Get to work remotely.
Good IT support.
Cool Product line.  Airplane Engines to almost everything else on an airplane.
Flexible hours.
Pretty good benefits.
Very Good starting pay.
Lots of weekly and online training.
Very nice, easy going boss and co-workers.
A lot of very long term employees.
Did not lay off people in 2008-2010 time frame.  Just reduced pay and hours worked.
Interesting work and able to get stuff done.  
Lots and lots of new programs and software.  Constant improvement.
Can get help with a project when I need it without being made to feel bad.
Lots of  communication from executives.  Good town hall meetings and website and emails.
Nice Hometown Charity fund.
cons:
Only two weeks vacation for very senior engineers coming in new.   Can not negotiate.
No Bonus at all available for senior engineers.
401k Match not until after one year.   And not a good match at that.
Health Insurance is a high deductible plan with a Health Savings Account (HSA) option.  
$3000 Deductible for families.
Honeywell gives you the 1st $1000 in HSA.
Health Insurance is VERY expensive for a High Deductible Plan.   5X more than other employers I have had for the same coverage.
With 130,000 employees, you would think they could get a better price on Health Insurance.
Terrible additional Life Insurance program.  Never an open enrollment if you don't sign up on hire.  I have never seen that at any other company.
Small Raises in 2012
NO RAISES IN 2013.   While executives are expected to get HUGE bonuses.  And company did fantastic in 2012.  This is killing morale.

pros: The mentality of "it's somebody else's fault" and "CYA" is in full effect here.
cons: Leadership has no common sense. They're MRR process is silly and is only beneficial for about 0%. They litterally don't care about their employees. Compensation policy is underbid the market and don't give raises or promotions. You have to LEAVE and come back to be promoted. Succession is a joke, and there's so much finger pointing it's comical. Finally  (and there's plenty more) Leadership (Sr Dir and above) only worry about their salaries and who to blame.

review_title: Started well but did not end well
pros: Peers knowledgeable, friendly, and helpful
cons: Medical benefits deteriorated (worked there seven years), no work-life balance, compensation below market, professional development lacking, focused on profit at employees' expense

review_title: Bad Company, Worse at Plant Level
pros:
- As a process engineer, you get responsibility quickly - because the turnover is so high.
- Some decent people to work with
cons:
- The leadership team refuses to listen to anything and prefers to stay in their echo chamber.
- Technical manager will throw you under the bus the first chance he gets, and consistently test you with oblique operational questions instead of collaborating with and empowering you in your work.
- Policies are changed at the whim of your supervisor, so your group can be treated completely differently than the entire rest of the plant.
- Relocation payback is two years and not prorated. Think carefully before you accept it.

pros: Strong brand name. Perfect work ethics by code of conduct. Enough sales tools but not enough local marketing. Low base salary, satisfavtory bonus plan if you sucseed.
cons: Internal barriers, not good relations btw sales-sales support-operation team. Too much internal politics. No support from management to sales team. If you will work in sales, be ready to be all alone, this is a one man show. You will be able to sell only if you can manage internal resistance and barriers. Also be aware that your target will be quite high and unrealistic.

review_title: Internally the company is young and energetic and transforming towards Cloud, IoT & Analytics
pros:
This is regarding the Honeywell Home & Building Technologies Group:
1) Pleasantly surprised to see a young and energetic employee eco system.
2) A thorough product development focused group.
3) The group is going through a transformation around Cloud, IoT, BigData, Analytics, Edge Computing. Certainly a great time to be a part of the journey at this moment.
4) A culture that strongly encourages collaboration & team work
cons: The external image of Honeywell is an area of improvement. Certainly the experience within is a lot more positive and that of a forward looking innovation driven organization.

pros: I recently started with Honeywell, which is the fifth company for which I have worked. From the moment I walked in the door on day one, the employees, management, and company have been communicative and supportive in ensuring I have the best onboarding experience possible. All to-do's, scheduling, materials, and introductions were laid out clearly in front of the new hires and we were made to feel welcome from the beginning until now. I have not heard or seen any other company who does onboarding as well as Honeywell.
cons: I will add feedback here if I find a con but, for now, it's been a fantastic experience in every way.

review_title: Plenty of opportunities, but not enough support,
job_title: Project Software Engineer in Mason, OH
pros: If you're into controls engineering and automation there are plenty of opportunities.
cons: Rapid growth plus high turnover for controls engineers means those that do stay don't always have the support they need, manage multiple projects,  and are tasked with training new hires while commissioning.  Not a fan of the high deductible health insurance plan, too costly.

pros: A company so big and so positioned that you feel proud and safe for being there. There are lot of very senior people at higher management, which I consider both a good and a so-so thing because ...they are there for proven experience, but they are not so tech savvy at the same time.
cons:
After hiring it was like I didn’t exist for the company... of course I had the weirdest experience being hired just a day before a major catastrophe in my city. After the alarm period ended, the company announced the spin-off of the Home business which created a lot of tension and stress among colleagues...
The company is heavily bureaucratic.

job_title: Staff Chemical Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Interesting work, good co-workers. UOP is a company with a proud technical legacy.
cons: It would be difficult to find a more unethical employer than Honeywell, the parent company. The past 10 years have been all about reducing costs and propping up the stock price at the expense of the employee (and customers). There has been intense downward pressure on compensation (both salary and benefits) driven by excessive offshoring, coupled with hostility for the U.S. workforce, communities, and cultural institutions. If you want an example of sociopathic capitalism run amuck, look no further. Only vestiges of the original UOP corporate culture remain, and the institutional knowledge is rapidly being lost.

review_title: Unsteady work even in steady times
pros: Easy to move positions, fast paced work environment
cons: Expect to work unpaid overtime, raises are maybe 2% in good times, budget control is by population control, Everything is rushed/hectic - no planning, people move so much you won't get any training for your role, Everything is run from quarter to quarter with no thought of long term impact to the company

pros: Diversity of products and platforms.  Majority of employees are knowledgeable and good at what they do.  Quality of people is excellent even though the teamwork can be improved at times.  Compensation is above the industry average.
cons: Bureaucracy and lack of collaboration.  Can be territorial at times among managers and factions within the organization.  Not much focus on professional development.  The major reorganization by Rob Gillette was needed but has led to poor morale and a loss of A players across the company.  Overall- the company is slow to respond to the market which led to essentially no work on the 787.

review_title: Overall, Honeywell is an ok place to work. But there are a lot of waste. Too many layers and too many iniatives.
pros: Can have good work life balance. Work time is flexible. You do your thing and go, nobody would care because there is so much work to do.
cons: Very political. Too many layers at and too many changes from the management level. Depending on who's in charge, different initiatives can come out any time any day.

review_title: Great at the start, now declining.
pros: Exciting products.  Dedicated employees willing to go the extra mile.  Respected standing in the aerospace community.  Good selection of markets in which to participate.
cons: U.S. based employees are no longer a valued asset.  The goal seems to be to eliminate all U.S. positions.  Shareholders have the largest share of the pie in terms of stakeholders and employees are constantly asked to sacrifice in order to propel share holders profits.

pros:
1). Helpful colleagues
2). Descent pay just above average.
3). Good Career growths,
4). Onsite opportunities to Arizona if in Aerospace
cons:
1). life is good if Primary manager is good;other\wise welcome to hell where everything will be about behaviors and no one is perfectionist, isn't it?
2). Once you stumble, you can't stand up; leave better.
3). Lots of people are there to take credit of your work....everybody else wants to be recognized because of good payment and promotions attached to it, but no body will recognize you...go get yourself nominated kind of culture.

review_title: In Transition: Buyout Could Still Go Either Way
pros: Great work, good coworkers, keeping busy, good work life balance, good pay.  Still has a small office atmosphere.
cons: Integration with UOP (Honeywell) is ongoing. Honeywell owns 70%.  Will own 100% by end of 2015.  HON is a decidedly large company and is bringing change to this small office.  Some good, some bad.

review_title: Backstabbing and too political in upper management
pros: None. Don't. Shouldn't. They look for scape goats to hide their inadequacy.
cons: You are a scape goat to senior management. They make stupid decisions and then when you tell them how to fix it they take YOUR SOLUTIONS AND ACT LIKE THEY THOUGHT IT UP. So sick of senior leadership not seeing their peers as who they are. This includes top leaders in this company. Grow up guys. See that you are covering the wrong backs!!!!

pros: Typical American fortune 500. The process, the staffs, the tech, the training, the facilities are all great. Oh, the salary is competitive.
cons:
Typical big company. There's border of your capability, so if you're someone seeking maximising your value, this might not be the best place to implement, but an ideal place to learn.

Another problem would be the culture. The culture there is no culture. Employees have no ownership to the company, they're all very professional, sometimes too professional.

pros: Pay, people,hours and no uniforms.
cons: Management is horrible, benefits used to be good really high deductible now. Reviews really bad supervisors put no effort into knowing employees  even less effort into reviews. Only thing they care about are shareholders. They spend no money on updating equipment but they love wasting money on furniture and trying to impress auditors by stopping production to move things and clean. Mandatory overtime due to rifs and alot of lost talent due to furloughs.

job_title: Senior Meteorology Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Strong company name. Good benefit package for employees.
cons: Management too hung up on "meeting roll down goals" to actually lead. "Walk the Talk gentlemen"!! Employees need actual motivation other than artificial goals created at review time to pat ones-self on the back.  Actual raises would  of gone a long way and the message "Well folks, we just didn't meet our BS goals so no raises for below management level raise. Then why doesn't UPPER management take the hit also??

job_title: IT Architect in Morris Plains, NJ
pros:
Tons of great brands, great products, and great engineers
Great subject matter experts in their fields
Some of the individual businesses seem to be run well
cons:
Benefits are sub-par
This  conglomerate's corporate team cannot get their act together
They will hire you and then let you go months later for no reason
They will try to move you and your family every time a different state offers a tax credit
Company allows hostile work environment and HR is asleep at the wheel

pros:
As a Software Engineer you will be able to deliver innovative solutions for challenging problems.
As a part of a big company, there are a lot of resources at your disposal and lot of opportunities.
Personal development is highly valued and fostered.
cons:
In such a big company sometimes there can be challenges in moving quickly.
With such a diverse portfolio, it can seems the company lacks focus at times, however, within each business unit it is much clearer.
Being a US based company, the focus at the corporate level can be on US operations and employees and not other regions.

review_title: A great place for talented people who want to grow their career year and learn
pros:
Working for Honeywell allow me to stay in permanent contact with talented people from almost any cultural background from anywhere in the world, work with them and learn from them.
Been part of one of the biggest corporations in the world has also allowed me to work with the latest technology.
The COVID-19 is also demonstrating Honeywell cares about their people, allowing us to work remotely and providing us continuous information and support.
cons: Nothing major I can think off, probably the pension plan in Uk is not that great as it used to be but, in some other countries is fine.

review_title: A moderately well structured company with above average benefits.
job_title: Electrical Engineer I  in Teterboro, NJ
pros: The new re-org allows employees to engage in different work across multiple sites in the US. Also, all the software or hardware tools needed were usually available or could be obtained without issue. I didn't realize how much I took that for granted until I left and worked at a place that doesn't want to spend money on tools.
cons: The new re-org also requires working with other employees who are in different time zones. This requires more time spent in meetings to stay in sync and sometimes having meetings during your lunch hour to accommodate others.

pros: Tremendous opportunities for learning and growth.  Good work environment in which people are respected and paid fairly.  Very supportive of family obligations and desire for self improvement.  Good pay and benefits package, very professional work environment.
cons: Moving lots of work overseas, company not as aggressive as it could be in managing poor managers out of the system.   Still lots of opportunity though.

pros: The company matches 401K contributions at 100% and also has a defined pension plan - that's pretty good in comparison to other companies today
cons: The cyclical nature of the business makes working at Honeywell challenging at times.  The senior management will keep their salaries and perks at the expense of the rank and file workers.

review_title: A good place to work, if you can handle the dysfunction.
pros: My co-workers are (mostly) great. The work is interesting and always a challenge. There are opportunities to learn new technologies and new applications for existing technologies. The learning curve can be steep and the pace very fast.
cons: The reviewer who stated that the 'old timers have been doing the same things the same way for 30 years' is spot-on. These are the people that are difficult to work with; the upside is that a select few (very, very few) of them are founts of knowledge - if they feel like sharing and think you are worthy.

review_title: A good place to work, but it needs to revamp itself for the current technology marketplace.
pros:
Good team working environment
Innovative engineering colleagues
Flexible work schedule
Good benefits package
Great opportunities for learning outside of your job scope
Great place to learn due to the large number of senior level engineers
Produces high quality components employees can be proud of
cons:
Lack of communication structure between business and engineering
Too much reliance on legacy systems, unwillingness to adapt new methodologies
Management forced to focus on metrics and not personnel

review_title: Great experience with lot of oportunities
pros:
I worked in a great team of Software developers who design supporting tools for other Honeywells devel.teams.
The positin offers a travel possibility to USA-Phoenix, where the mother company is located.
On-site work combined with home office is also a great benefit.
Besides homeoffice there are other benefits like meal vouchers, pension insurance contribution, special cell phone contracts with big discount, 5weeks of vacation,bonuses for extra work results, ...
cons: I didn't like the "Personal Goals" approach where employee has to define his/her targets for the current year as it seems not very flexible to me. But I agree it's good to have this practice from long term view of planning.

review_title: Aggressive company focusing on short term success
pros:
Very result driven. Well established organization and a lot of resource you can leverage in your daily work
Focusing on new product development and VOC. New product launch is a critical task for all business people.
Quite stable company and you can just stay if you want to say
cons:
Too short term focus without long term development vision and strategy except for some business unit;
Take too long time to update STRAP which is a 5 year development strategy every year.
Too afraid of making mistakes, especially for senior leadership
Lack of direct and straight communication to senior leadership. Everybody is guess big boss's thought

3. Honeywell Follows one good policy after 8 months either u hire him under direct payroll or throw the contract employee out and these guys .

4.
